original: Namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa
analyzed: namaḥ tassa bhagavataḥ arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa
translated: Homage to that Blessed One, the Worthy One, the Rightly Self-awakened One

original: Saṃyuttanikāye🔽Khandhavagga-aṭṭhakathā
analyzed: saṃyutta nikāye  khandha vagga aṭṭhakathā
translated: In the Connected Discourses🔽The exposition of the Khandha Vagga

original: 1. Khandhasaṃyuttaṃ🔽1. Nakulapituvaggo
analyzed: khandha saṃyuttam  nakula pitu vaggo
translated: The Connected Discourses with Khandha🔽The Group of the Father of Nakula

original: 1. Nakulapitusuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: nakula pitu sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The First Discourse in the Khandha Vagga

original: 1. Khandhiyavaggassa paṭhame bhaggesūti evaṃnāmake janapade. Susumāragireti susumāragiranagare.
analyzed: khandhiya vaggassa paṭhame bhaggesu iti evaṃnāmake janapade susumāragirā iti susumāragira nagare
translated: In the first discourse in the Khandha Vagga, “in the Bhagga country” means in a country by that name. “On the Susumara mountain” means in the city on the Susumara mountain.

original: Tasmiṃ kira māpiyamāne susumāro saddamakāsi, tenassa “susumāragira”ntveva nāmaṃ akaṃsu.
analyzed: tasmin kira māpiyamāne susumāraḥ saddam akāsi tena assa nāmam akaṃsu
translated: It seems that when it was being built, a Susumara (a kind of bird) made a sound, and therefore it was named “Susumara mountain.”

original: Bhesakaḷāvaneti bhesakaḷāya nāma yakkhiniyā adhivutthattā evaṃladdhanāme vane. Tadeva
analyzed: bhesakaḷā vana iti bhesakaḷāya nāma yakkhiniyā adhivutthattā evaṃladdha nāme vane tat eva
translated: “In the Bhesakala forest” means in a forest that got that name because it was inhabited by a female spirit named Bhesakala. That forest

original: migagaṇassa abhayatthāya dinnattā migadāyoti vuccati. Bhagavā tasmiṃ janapade taṃ
analyzed: miga gaṇassa abhaya tthāya dinna ttā migadāyā iti vuccati bhagavā tasmin janapade tam
translated: is called “the Deer Park” because it was given for the safety of a herd of deer. The Blessed One was dwelling in that country,

original: nagaraṃ nissāya tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe viharati. Nakulapitāti nakulassa nāma dārakassa pitā.
analyzed: nagaram nissāya tasmin vana saṇḍe viharati nakula pitā ati nakulassa nāma dārakassa pitā
translated: near that city, in that forest grove. “The father of Nakula” means the father of a boy named Nakula.

original: Jiṇṇoti jarājiṇṇo. Vuḍḍhoti vayovuḍḍho. Mahallakoti jātimahallako. Addhagatoti tiyaddhagato.
analyzed: jiṇṇo ti jarā jiṇṇaḥ vuḍḍho ti vayas vuḍḍhaḥ mahallako iti jāti mahallakaḥ addha gato ti tiyaddha gataḥ
translated: “Old” means worn out by old age. “Elder” means aged by age. “Advanced in years” means great by birth. “Past his prime” means past his prime.

original: Vayoanuppattoti tesu tīsu addhesu pacchimavayaṃ anuppatto. Āturakāyoti gilānakāyo.
analyzed: vayaḥ anuppatto ti tesu tīsu addhesu pacchima vayam anuppatto ātura kāyaḥ ti gilāna kāyo
translated: Reached the age: reached the last of the three ages. Afflicted with disease: his body was sick.

original: Idañhi sarīraṃ suvaṇṇavaṇṇampi niccapaggharaṇaṭṭhena āturaṃyeva nāma. Visesena panassa
analyzed: idam hi sarīram suvaṇṇa vaṇṇam pi nicca paggharaṇa aṭṭhena āturam yeva nāma visesena pana assa
translated: For this body, though it be the colour of gold, is called “afflicted” in the sense of its constant discharge. But in particular

original: jarāturatā byādhāturatā maraṇāturatāti tisso āturatā honti. Tāsu kiñcāpi eso mahallakattā
analyzed: jarā ātura tā byādha ātura tā maraṇa ātura tā ati tissaḥ ātura tāḥ honti tāsu kiñcā api esaḥ mahallakattā
translated: there are three kinds of affliction: affliction by ageing, affliction by disease, and affliction by death. Of these, though he was afflicted by ageing

original: jarāturova, abhiṇharogatāya panassa byādhāturatā idha adhippetā. Abhikkhaṇātaṅkoti🔽abhiṇharogo nirantararogo. Aniccadassāvīti tāya āturatāya icchiticchitakkhaṇe āgantuṃ
analyzed: jarā āturaḥ uva abhiṇha roga tāya panassa byādhā ātura tā idha adhippetā abhikkhaṇa ātaṅko ti  abhiṇha rogaḥ nirantara rogaḥ anicca dassāvī iti tāya ātura tāya icchiticchita kkhaṇe āgantum
translated: because of his great age, his affliction by disease, because of his frequent illnesses, is what is intended here. A chronic disease:🔽a frequent disease, a continuous disease. A witness of impermanence: the meaning is, “I get to see him only sometimes, not all the time, because of his affliction,

original: asakkonto kadācideva daṭṭhuṃ labhāmi, na sabbakālanti attho. Manobhāvanīyānanti manavaḍḍhakānaṃ.
analyzed: a sakkontaḥ kadācid eva daṭṭhum labhāmi na sabba kālam ti atthaḥ manaḥ bhāvanīyānam ti mana vaḍḍhakānam
translated: unable to come whenever I want to.” Worthy of confidence: worthy of respect.

original: Yesu hi diṭṭhesu kusalavasena cittaṃ vaḍḍhati, te sāriputtamoggallānādayo mahātherā
analyzed: yesu hi diṭṭhesu kusala vasena cittam vaḍḍhati te sāriputta moggallāna ādayaḥ mahā therā
translated: Those who, when seen, the mind gains confidence through the wholesome, are the great elders such as Sāriputta, Moggallāna, etc.,

original: manobhāvanīyā nāma. Anusāsatūti punappunaṃ sāsatu. Purimañhi vacanaṃ ovādo nāma,
analyzed: manobhāvanīyāḥ nāma anusāsatu uti punappunam sāsatu ovādaḥ nāma
translated: and they are called “worthy of confidence.” Instruct: advise again and again. For the first statement is called “advice,”🔽and the second “instruction.”

original: aparāparaṃ anusāsanī nāma. Otiṇṇe vā vatthusmiṃ vacanaṃ ovādo nāma, anotiṇṇe tantivasena
analyzed: aparāparam anusāsanī nāma otiṇṇe vā vatthusmim vacanam ovādaḥ nāma an otiṇṇe tanti vasena
translated: The other is called advice. Advice is a statement about a matter that has arisen;

original: vā paveṇivasena vā vuttaṃ anusāsanī nāma. Apica ovādoti vā anusāsanīti vā atthato
analyzed: vā paveṇi vasena vā vuttam anusāsanī nāma apica ovādo ti vā anusāsanī iti vā atthato
translated: instruction is a statement about a matter that has not arisen, either in the form of a question or in the form of a pronouncement. Moreover, advice and instruction

original: ekameva, byañjanamattameva nānaṃ.🔽Āturo hāyanti āturo hi ayaṃ, suvaṇṇavaṇṇo piyaṅgusāmopi samāno niccapaggharaṇaṭṭhena
analyzed: ekam eva byañjana mattam eva nānam  āturaḥ hāyanti āturaḥ hi ayam suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ samānaḥ nicca paggharaṇa ṭṭhena
translated: are the same in meaning; there is only a difference in the phrasing.🔽“He is sick”: he is sick because of the constant dripping of urine and excrement.🔽Though he may be fair as gold or as jasmine, he is sick in the sense of dripping.

original: āturoyeva. Aṇḍabhūtoti aṇḍaṃ viya bhūto dubbalo. Yathā kukkuṭaṇḍaṃ vā mayūraṇḍaṃ
analyzed: aṇḍa bhūtaḥ iti aṇḍam viya bhūtaḥ dubbalaḥ yathā kukkuṭaṇḍam vā mayūraṇḍam
translated: “He is as if in an egg”: he is as weak as if he were in an egg. Just as an egg of a fowl or a peacock,

original: vā geṇḍukaṃ viya gahetvā khipantena vā paharantena vā na sakkā kīḷituṃ, tāvadeva🔽bhijjati, evamayampi kāyo kaṇṭakepi khāṇukepi pakkhalitassa bhijjatīti aṇḍaṃ viya
analyzed: vā geṇḍukam gahetvā khipantena vā paharantena vā na sakkā kīḍitum tāvat eva  bhijjati evam ayam pi kāyaḥ kaṇṭake pi khāṇuke pi pakkhalitassa bhijjati iti aṇḍam viya
translated: or a ball of dough, cannot be played with by being thrown about or hit, but breaks🔽immediately if one tries to do so, so too this body breaks when one stumbles over a thornbush or a stump or when one slips on a muddy bank. Thus he is as if in an egg.

original: bhūtoti aṇḍabhūto. Pariyonaddhoti sukhumena chavimattena pariyonaddho. Aṇḍañhi sāratacena
analyzed: bhūto ti aṇḍa bhūto pariyonaddhaḥ iti sukhumena chavimattena pariyonaddhaḥ aṇḍam hi sāratacena
translated: “He is enclosed”: he is enclosed by a thin skin.

original: pariyonaddhaṃ, tena ḍaṃsamakasādayo nilīyitvāpi chaviṃ chinditvā yūsaṃ paggharāpetuṃ
analyzed: pariyonaddham tena ḍaṃsa makasa ādayaḥ nilīyitvā api chavim chinditvā yūsam
translated: and the mosquitoes and gadflies, though they may bite through the skin, are unable to get any nourishment from it.

original: na sakkonti. Imasmiṃ pana chaviṃ chinditvā yaṃ icchanti, taṃ karonti. Evaṃ sukhumāya
analyzed: na sakkonti imasmin pana chavim chinditvā yam icchanti tam karonti evam sukhumāya
translated: and so the gadflies and flies, though they alight on it, are unable to pierce the skin and suck out the serum. But they can do as they like with this skin, which is so thin.

original: chaviyā pariyonaddho. Kimaññatra bālyāti bālabhāvato aññaṃ kimatthi? Bāloyeva ayanti
analyzed: chaviyā pariyonaddhaḥ kim aññatra bālyā ati bāla bhāvataḥ aññam kim atthi ayanti
translated: What else is there but the skin? What else is there but the state of being a fool? The meaning is that it is just a fool.🔽Therefore:

original: attho. Tasmāti yasmā ayaṃ kāyo evarūpo, tasmā.🔽Tenupasaṅkamīti rañño cakkavattissa upaṭṭhānaṃ gantvā anantaraṃ pariṇāyakaratanassa🔽upaṭṭhānaṃ gacchanto rājapuriso viya, saddhammacakkavattissa bhagavato upaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: attha u tasmā ati yasmai ayam kāyaḥ evarūpaḥ tasmā  tena upasaṅkami iti raññaḥ cakkavattissa upaṭṭhānam gantvā anantaram pariṇāyaka ratanassa  upaṭṭhānam gacchantaḥ rāja puriso viya saddhammacakkavattissa bhagavataḥ upaṭṭhānam
translated: Because this body is of such a nature, therefore.

original: gantvā, anantaraṃ dhammasenāpatissa apacitiṃ kātukāmo yenāyasmā sāriputto, tenupasaṅkami.
analyzed: gantvā anantaram dhamma senāpatissa apacitim kātu kāmo yena āyasmā sāriputto tena upasaṅkami
translated: Approached: just as a man who has gone to attend on a universal monarch goes next to attend on the jewel of a counsellor, so too, having gone to attend on the Blessed One, the Buddha, the universal monarch of the True Idea, and wishing to pay respect to the Dhamma-sena­pati, the jewel of a counsellor of the Blessed One, the Buddha, the universal monarch of the True Idea, he approached the venerable Sariputta.

original: Vippasannānīti suṭṭhu pasannāni. Indriyānīti manacchaṭṭhāni indriyāni. Parisuddhoti
analyzed: vippasannāni iti suṭṭhu pasannāni indriyāni iti manacchaṭṭhāni indriyāni parisuddhaḥ uti
translated: Clear: quite clear. Faculties: the six internal bases beginning with the eye. Pure:

original: niddoso. Pariyodātoti tasseva vevacanaṃ. Nirupakkilesatāyeva hi esa pariyodātoti
analyzed: niddoso pariyodāto ti tassa iva vevacanam nirupakkilesa tāya iva hi esa pariyodāto ti
translated: and free from stain. Pure is a synonym for that. For it is just this freedom from stain that is its purity.

original: vutto, na setabhāvena. Etassa ca pariyodātataṃ disvāva indriyānaṃ vippasannataṃ aññāsi.
analyzed: vuttaḥ na seta bhāvena etassa ca pariyodāta tam disvāva indriyānam vippasanna tam aññāsi
translated: “Stainless” is a synonym for “pure.” For it is said that it is “pure” because it is free from defilements, not because of the color white. And it was by seeing its purity that he knew the clarity of the faculties.

original: Nayaggāhapaññā kiresā therassa.
analyzed: naya ggāha paññā therassa
translated: This is the kind of understanding the Elder possessed, the understanding of one who has grasped the main point.

original: Kathañhi no siyāti kena kāraṇena na laddhā bhavissati? Laddhāyevāti attho. Iminā
analyzed: katham hi no siyā ati kena kāraṇena na laddhā bhavissati laddhāya iva ati atthaḥ iminā
translated: “How could it not be?” means “For what reason could it not be obtained? It must be obtained.”

original: kiṃ dīpeti? Satthuvissāsikabhāvaṃ. Ayaṃ kira satthu diṭṭhakālato paṭṭhāya pitipemaṃ,
analyzed: kim dīpeti satthu vissāsika bhāvam ayam kira satthu diṭṭha kālato paṭṭhāya pitipemam
translated: What does this show? It shows the Elder’s confidence in the Teacher. It seems that from the time he saw the Teacher, he obtained the love and affection of a son for his father,

original: upāsikā cassa mātipemaṃ paṭilabhati. Ubhopi “mama putto”ti satthāraṃ vadanti. Bhavantaragato🔽hi nesaṃ sineho. Sā kira upāsikā pañca jātisatāni tathāgatassa mātāva, so ca, gahapati,
analyzed: upāsikā ca ssa māti pemam paṭilabhati ubho pi mama putto ti satthāram vadanti bhavantara gataḥ  hi sinehaḥ sā kira upāsikā pañca jāti satāni tathāgatassa mātā ava so ca gahapati
translated: and the lay devotee obtained the love and affection of a mother for her son. Both of them called the Teacher “our son.”

original: pitāva ahosi. Puna pañca jātisatāni upāsikā mahāmātā, upāsako mahāpitā, tathā cūḷāmātā
analyzed: puna pañca jāti satāni upāsikā mahāmātā upāsakaḥ mahā pitā tathā cūḷāmātā
translated: For their affection for him was not confined to this present existence. It seems that for five hundred existences the lay devotee was the Tathāgata’s mother, and he was her son. Again for five hundred existences the lay devotee was the Great Mother, the Elder was the Great Father, and the lay devotee’s mother was the Little Mother.

original: cūḷapitāti. Evaṃ satthā diyaḍḍhaattabhāvasahassaṃ tesaṃyeva hatthe vaḍḍhito. Teneva
analyzed: cūḷa pitā ati evam satthā diyaḍḍha atta bhāva sahassam tesam yeva hatthe vaḍḍhito tena iva
translated: and Nakula’s mother as the foremost of the lay devotees who are confident. In this way the Teacher increased the number of those who had attained the first stage of arahantship to one thousand two hundred and fifty.

original: te yaṃ neva puttassa, na pitu santike kathetuṃ sakkā, taṃ satthu santike nisinnā🔽kathenti. Imināyeva ca kāraṇena bhagavā “etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, mama sāvakānaṃ upāsakānaṃ
analyzed: te yam na iva puttassa na pitu santike kathetum sakkā tam satthu santike nisinnā  kathenti iminā iva ca kāraṇena bhagavā etat aggam bhikkhave mama sāvakānam upāsakānam
translated: And so they told the Master, sitting in his presence, what they had been unable to tell either their son or their father.

original: vissāsikānaṃ yadidaṃ nakulapitā gahapati, yadidaṃ nakulamātā gahapatānī”ti te etadagge
analyzed: vissāsikānam yat idam nakula pitā gahapati yat idam nakula mātā gahapatānī iti te etat agge
translated: And for this very reason the Exalted One placed them at the head of those lay devotees who are confident, saying: “The foremost of my lay devotees who are confident are the layman Nakula’s father and the laywoman Nakula’s mother.”

original: ṭhapesi. Iti so imaṃ vissāsikabhāvaṃ pakāsento kathañhi no siyāti āha. Amatena abhisittoti
analyzed: ṭhapesi iti saḥ imam vissāsika bhāvam pakāsento katham hi no siyā ti āha amatena abhisitto ti
translated: Thus, in proclaiming his own confidence, the layman Nakula’s father said: “How could it be otherwise?”

original: nassidha aññaṃ kiñci jhānaṃ vā vipassanā vā maggo vā phalaṃ vā “amatābhiseko”ti daṭṭhabbo,
analyzed: aññam kiñci jhānam vā vipassanā vā maggaḥ vā phalam vā amata abhisekaḥ ti daṭṭhabbo
translated: Anointed with the deathless: here no other jhāna, insight, path, or fruit should be regarded as the “anointing with the deathless.”🔽The sweet deathless Dhamma-talk alone should be understood as the “anointing with the deathless.”

original: madhuradhammadesanāyeva pana “amatābhiseko”ti veditabbo. Dūratopīti tiroraṭṭhāpi tirojanapadāpi.
analyzed: madhura dhamma desanāya iva pana amata abhisekaḥ ti veditabbaḥ dūratas api iti tiroraṭṭhā api tirojanapadā api
translated: From afar: from far-off countries and far-off districts.

original: Assutavā puthujjanoti idaṃ vuttatthameva. Ariyānaṃ adassāvītiādīsu ariyāti ārakattā
analyzed: assutavā puthujjanaḥ ti idam vutta ttham eva ariyānam adassāvī itiādīsu ariyāti āraka ttā
translated: The rest is as stated in the commentary. 10. The meaning of the words “unacquainted with the Ariyans” , etc., is this. Ariyan : far-removed ,

original: kilesehi, anaye na iriyanato, aye iriyanato, sadevakena ca lokena araṇīyato buddhā
analyzed: kilesehi anaye na aye sa devakena ca lokena araṇīyataḥ buddhāḥ
translated: not wandering in the jungle of the defilements, wandering in the path of the jungle, worthy of being worshipped by the world with its gods, Brahmas, and men.

original: ca paccekabuddhā ca buddhasāvakā ca vuccanti. Buddhā eva vā idha ariyā. Yathāha –
analyzed: ca paccekabuddhā ca buddha sāvakā ca vuccanti buddhāḥ eva vā idha ariyāḥ yathā āha
translated: Buddhas, Paccekabuddhas, and Buddhas’ disciples are called Ariyans. Or only Buddhas are Ariyans here,

original: “sadevake, bhikkhave, loke…pe… tathāgato ariyo”ti vuccatīti. Sappurisānanti ettha
analyzed: sa devake bhikkhave lokepe tathāgato ariyo ti vuccati iti sappurisānam ti ettha
translated: as it is said: “In the world with its gods, bhikkhus, with its Maras and Brahmas, with its ascetics and Brahmins, with its princes and men, the Tathagata is called an Ariyan” .🔽As for the words “unacquainted with good men” ,

original: pana paccekabuddhā tathāgatasāvakā ca sappurisāti veditabbā. Te hi lokuttaraguṇayogena
analyzed: pana paccekabuddhā tathāgata sāvakā ca sappurisā ati veditabbā te hi lokuttara guṇa yogena
translated: Paccekabuddhas and the Tathagata’s disciples should be understood as “good men” . They are good men because they are adorned with supramundane special qualities.

original: sobhanā purisāti sappurisā. Sabbeva vā ete dvedhāpi vuttā. Buddhāpi hi ariyā ca sappurisā
analyzed: sobhanā purisā ti sappurisā sabbā iva vā ete dvedhā api vuttā buddhā api hi ariyā ca sappurisā
translated: Or all these are called both Ariyans and good men. For Buddhas are Ariyans and good men,

original: ca, paccekabuddhā buddhasāvakāpi. Yathāha –
analyzed: ca paccekabuddhāḥ buddha sāvakāḥ api yathā āha
translated: and Paccekabuddhas and the Buddhas’ disciples are Ariyans and good men. As it is said:

original: “Yo ve kataññū katavedi dhīro,
analyzed: yaḥ ve kataññū kata vedi dhīraḥ
translated: “The wise man who is grateful and thankful,

original: Kalyāṇamitto daḷhabhatti ca hoti;
analyzed: kalyāṇa mittaḥ daḷha bhatti ca hoti
translated: Who has good friends and a strong will,

original: Dukhitassa sakkacca karoti kiccaṃ,
analyzed: dukhitassa karoti kiccam
translated: Who does his job well when in pain—

original: Tathāvidhaṃ sappurisaṃ vadantī”ti. ;
analyzed: tathāvidham sappurisam vadanti iti
translated: Such a man is called a good man” .

original: “Kalyāṇamitto daḷhabhatti ca hotī”ti ettāvatā hi buddhasāvako vutto, kataññutādīhi
analyzed: kalyāṇa mittaḥ daḷha bhatti ca hoti iti ettāvatā hi buddha sāvakaḥ vuttaḥ kataññu tā ādīhi
translated: The one who is not of such a nature is called a worldling.

original: paccekabuddhabuddhāti. Idāni yo tesaṃ ariyānaṃ adassanasīlo, na ca dassane sādhukārī,
analyzed: paccekabuddha buddha ati idāni yaḥ tesam ariyānam a dassana sīlaḥ na ca dassane sādhu kārī
translated: Now, he who is of such a nature but who is not of the habit of seeing ariyans and of doing what is beneficial in the presence of ariyans,

original: so “ariyānaṃ adassāvī”ti veditabbo. So ca cakkhunā adassāvī, ñāṇena adassāvīti duvidho.
analyzed: so ariyānam adassāvī iti veditabbo so ca cakkhunā adassāvī ñāṇena adassāvī iti duvidhaḥ
translated: should be understood as “one who is not of the habit of seeing ariyans.” And he is of two kinds: one who does not see with the eye and one who does not see with knowledge.

original: Tesu ñāṇena adassāvī idha adhippeto. Maṃsacakkhunā hi dibbacakkhunā vā ariyā diṭṭhāpi
analyzed: tesu ñāṇena a dassāvī idha adhippetaḥ maṃsa cakkhunā hi dibba cakkhunā vā ariyā diṭṭhā api
translated: Of these, the one who does not see with knowledge is intended here. For, although ariyans are seen with the fleshly eye or with the divine eye,

original: adiṭṭhāva honti tesaṃ cakkhūnaṃ vaṇṇamattaggahaṇato na ariyabhāvagocarato. Soṇasiṅgālādayopi
analyzed: a diṭṭhā va honti tesam cakkhūnam vaṇṇa matta ggahaṇato na ariya bhāva gocarato soṇa siṅgāla ādayaḥ api
translated: they are as if not seen by those eyes, because those eyes grasp only colour and shape, not the domain of ariyan states. Even dogs, jackals, etc.,

original: cakkhunā ariye passanti, na cete ariyānaṃ dassāvino nāma.
analyzed: cakkhunā ariye passanti na ca ite ariyānam dassāvinaḥ nāma
translated: see ariyans with their eyes, but they are not called “seers of ariyans.”

original: Tatridaṃ vatthu – cittalapabbatavāsino kira khīṇāsavattherassa upaṭṭhāko vuḍḍhapabbajito
analyzed: tatra idam vatthu cittala pabbata vāsinaḥ kira khīṇāsava therassa upaṭṭhākaḥ vuḍḍha pabbajitaḥ
translated: Here is an illustration: a certain elderly monk, it seems, who was an attendant of an arahat elder who lived at Cittalapabbata,

original: ekadivasaṃ therena saddhiṃ piṇḍāya caritvā, therassa pattacīvaraṃ gahetvā, piṭṭhito
analyzed: eka divasam therena saddhim piṇḍāya caritvā therassa patta cīvaram gahetvā piṭṭhitaḥ
translated: one day went about for alms with the elder, took his bowl and robe, and followed him.

original: āgacchanto theraṃ pucchi – “ariyā nāma, bhante, kīdisā”ti? Thero āha – “idhekacco
analyzed: āgacchantaḥ theram pucchi ariyāḥ nāma bhante kīdisā iti theraḥ āha idha ekacco
translated: As he was coming he asked the elder, “What are Noble Ones like, venerable sir?” The elder said, “Here, a certain person

original: mahallako ariyānaṃ pattacīvaraṃ gahetvā vattapaṭivattaṃ katvā sahacarantopi neva
analyzed: mahallakaḥ ariyānam patta cīvaram gahetvā vatta paṭivattam katvā sahacarantaḥ pi na iva
translated: goes about with the Noble Ones’ bowl and robe, and he does and arranges for them to do all kinds of services,

original: ariye jānāti, evaṃ dujjānāvuso, ariyā”ti. Evaṃ vuttepi so neva aññāsi. Tasmā na cakkhunā🔽dassanaṃ dassanaṃ, ñāṇena dassanameva dassanaṃ. Yathāha – “kiṃ te, vakkali, iminā
analyzed: ariye jānāti evam dujjānā āvuso ariyā ti evam vutte pi so na iva aññāsi tasmai na cakkhunā  dassanam dassanam ñāṇena dassanam eva dassanam yathā āha kim te vakkali iminā
translated: and still he does not know the Noble Ones. So hard to know are Noble Ones, friend.” Though he was told thus, he still did not know. Therefore it is not by seeing with the eye

original: pūtikāyena diṭṭhena? Yo kho, vakkali, dhammaṃ passati, so maṃ passati. Yo maṃ passati,
analyzed: pūti kāyena diṭṭhena yaḥ kho vakkali dhammam passati saḥ mam passati yaḥ mam passati
translated: that there is seeing. It is by seeing with knowledge that there is seeing. As it is said: “What is the use to you of seeing this foul body, Vakkali? He who sees the Dhamma, Vakkali, he sees me;

original: so dhammaṃ passatī”ti. Tasmā cakkhunā passantopi ñāṇena ariyehi diṭṭhaṃ aniccādilakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: so dhammam passati iti tasmā cakkhunā passantaḥ api ñāṇena ariyehi diṭṭham anicca ādi lakkhaṇam
translated: he who sees me, he sees the Dhamma” . Therefore, although he sees with the eye, if he does not see with knowledge the characteristic of impermanence, etc., which is seen by Noble Ones,

original: apassanto, ariyādhigatañca dhammaṃ anadhigacchanto ariyakaradhammānaṃ ariyabhāvassa
analyzed: a passantaḥ ariya adhigatañca dhammam an adhigacchantaḥ ariya kara dhammānam ariya bhāvassa
translated: and if he does not reach the Dhamma that has been reached by Noble Ones, then because he does not see the states that make one a Noble One and the state of being a Noble One,

original: ca adiṭṭhattā “ariyānaṃ adassāvī”ti veditabbo.
analyzed: ca a diṭṭha ttā ariyānam a dassāvi iti veditabbaḥ
translated: he should be understood as “one who has not seen the Noble Ones.”

original: Ariyadhammassa akovidoti, satipaṭṭhānādibhede ariyadhamme akusalo. Ariyadhamme avinītoti ettha pana –
analyzed: ariya dhammassa akovidaḥ ti sati paṭṭhāna ādi bhede ariya dhamme akusalaḥ ariya dhamme avinīto ti ettha pana
translated: He is unskilled in the Noble One’s state: he is unskilled in the Noble One’s state consisting in the foundations of mindfulness, etc. He is untrained in the Noble One’s state: here,

original: “Duvidho vinayo nāma, ekamekettha pañcadhā;
analyzed: duvidhaḥ vinayaḥ nāma ekam ekā itthā pañcadhā
translated: “Discipline is of two kinds, each with five divisions;

original: Abhāvato tassa ayaṃ, avinītoti vuccati”.🔽Ayañhi saṃvaravinayo pahānavinayoti duvidho vinayo. Ettha ca duvidhepi vinaye ekameko🔽vinayo pañcadhā bhijjati. Saṃvaravinayopi hi sīlasaṃvaro satisaṃvaro ñāṇasaṃvaro🔽khantisaṃvaro vīriyasaṃvaroti pañcavidho. Pahānavinayopi tadaṅgappahānaṃ, vikkhambhanappahānaṃ
analyzed: abhāvato tassa ayam avinītaḥ ti vuccati  ayan hi saṃvara vinayaḥ pahāna vinayaḥ iti duvidhaḥ vinayaḥ ettha ca duvidhe api vinaye  vinayaḥ pañcadhā bhijjati saṃvara vinayaḥ api hi sīla saṃvaraḥ sati saṃvaraḥ ñāṇa saṃvaraḥ  khanti saṃvaraḥ vīriya saṃvaro ti pañcavidhaḥ pahāna vinayaḥ api tad aṅga pahānam vikkhambhana ppahānam
translated: Because he lacks it, he is called untrained.”

original: samucchedappahānaṃ paṭippassaddhippahānaṃ nissaraṇappahānanti pañcavidho.
analyzed: samuccheda pahānam paṭippassaddhi ppahānam nissaraṇa ppahānam ti pañcavidhaḥ
translated: For discipline is of two kinds, namely, discipline as restraint and discipline as non-transgression. And in each of these two kinds of discipline there are five divisions. Discipline as restraint is of five kinds as restraint by virtue, restraint by mindfulness, restraint by knowledge, restraint by patience, and restraint by energy. Discipline as non-transgression is of five kinds as the non-transgression that is abandonment of the particular defilement, the non-transgression that is suppression of the particular defilement, the non-transgression that is cutting off of the particular defilement, the non-transgression that is tranquillization of the particular defilement, and the non-transgression that is escape from the particular defilement.

original: Tattha “iminā pātimokkhasaṃvarena upeto hoti samupeto”ti ayaṃ sīlasaṃvaro. “Rakkhati cakkhundriyaṃ, cakkhundriye saṃvaraṃ āpajjatī”ti ayaṃ satisaṃvaro.
analyzed: tattha iminā pātimokkha saṃvarena upetaḥ hoti samupetaḥ iti ayam sīla saṃvaraḥ rakkhati cakkhu indriyam cakkhu indriye saṃvaram āpajjati iti ayam sati saṃvaraḥ
translated: Herein, “he is endowed with and possesses the restraint by virtue” is restraint by virtue. “He guards the eye faculty, enters upon restraint of the eye faculty” is restraint by mindfulness.

original: “Yāni sotāni lokasmiṃ, (ajitāti bhagavā)
analyzed: yāni sotāni lokasmin bhagavā
translated: “Whatever are the sense-doors in the world,

original: Sati tesaṃ nivāraṇaṃ;
analyzed: sati
translated: The guarding of them is mindfulness;

original: Sotānaṃ saṃvaraṃ brūmi,
analyzed: sotānam saṃvaram brūmi
translated: I call the restraint of the sense-doors

original: Paññāyete pidhīyare”ti. –🔽Ayaṃ ñāṇasaṃvaro. “Khamo hoti sītassa uṇhassā”ti ayaṃ khantisaṃvaro. “Uppannaṃ kāmavitakkaṃ🔽nādhivāsetī”ti ayaṃ vīriyasaṃvaro. Sabbopi cāyaṃ saṃvaro yathāsakaṃ saṃvaritabbānaṃ
analyzed: paññāyete  ayam ñāṇa saṃvaraḥ khamaḥ hoti sītassa uṇhassa ati ayam khanti saṃvaraḥ uppannam kāma vitakkam  na adhivāseti iti ayam vīriya saṃvaro sabbaḥ api ca ayam saṃvaro yathāsakam saṃvaritabbānam
translated: The stopping of the mind on seeing. ”

original: vinetabbānañca kāyaduccaritādīnaṃ saṃvaraṇato “saṃvaro” vinayanato “vinayo”ti vuccati.
analyzed: vinetabbānam ca kāya duccarita ādīnam saṃvaraṇato saṃvaraḥ vinayanataḥ vinayo ti vuccati
translated: This is the restraint of knowledge. “He is able to endure cold and heat” is the restraint of patience. “He does not tolerate a thought of sensual desire that has arisen” is the restraint of energy. And all this restraint is called “restraint” and “discipline” because it restrains and disciplines what should be restrained and disciplined, respectively, that is, bodily misconduct, etc.

original: Evaṃ tāva saṃvaravinayo pañcadhā bhijjatīti veditabbo.🔽Tathā yaṃ nāmarūpaparicchedādīsu vipassanāñāṇesu paṭipakkhabhāvato dīpālokeneva tamassa,
analyzed: evam tāva saṃvara vinayaḥ pañcadhā bhijjati iti veditabbo  tathā yam nāma rūpa pariccheda ādīsu vipassanā ñāṇesu paṭipakkha bhāvataḥ dīpa ālokena iva tamassa
translated: Thus, to begin with, it should be understood that the discipline of restraint is fivefold.🔽Likewise, the discipline of abandoning is the abandoning of the various kinds of harm, such as wrong views, etc., by means of the various kinds of knowledge, such as the knowledge of the analysis of meaning, etc., which are opposed to them, as darkness is by light.

original: tena tena vipassanāñāṇena tassa tassa anatthassa pahānaṃ. Seyyathidaṃ – nāmarūpavavatthānena
analyzed: tena tena vipassanā ñāṇena tassa tassa anatthassa pahānam seyyathidam nāma rūpa vavatthānena
translated: That is to say, by the knowledge of the analysis of meaning there is the abandoning of the wrong view of individuality;🔽by the knowledge of the analysis of the truths, the wrong view of holding to a doctrine of self;

original: sakkāyadiṭṭhiyā, paccayapariggahena ahetuvisamahetudiṭṭhīnaṃ, tasseva aparabhāgena
analyzed: sakkāya diṭṭhiyā paccaya pariggahena ahetu visama hetu diṭṭhīnam tassa iva apara bhāgena
translated: by the knowledge of the analysis of the elements, the wrong view of holding to extremes;🔽by the knowledge of the analysis of the faculties, the wrong view of deprecation;🔽by the knowledge of the analysis of dependent origination, the wrong view of misapprehending causality;🔽by the knowledge of the analysis of what is possible and impossible, the wrong view of misapprehending what ought to be done;🔽by the knowledge of the analysis of the path, the wrong view of misapprehending the means of purification;🔽by the knowledge of the analysis of the way, the wrong view of misapprehending the means of arriving at the goal.

original: kaṅkhāvitaraṇena kathaṃkathībhāvassa, kalāpasammasanena “ahaṃ mamā”ti gāhassa, maggāmaggavavatthānena🔽amagge maggasaññāya, udayadassanena ucchedadiṭṭhiyā, vayadassanena sassatadiṭṭhiyā,🔽bhayadassanena sabhaye abhayasaññāya, ādīnavadassanena assādasaññāya, nibbidānupassanāya🔽abhiratisaññāya, muccitukamyatāñāṇena amuccitukāmatāya. Upekkhāñāṇena anupekkhāya,
analyzed: kaṅkhā vitaraṇena kathaṃkathībhāvassa kalāpa sammasanena aham mama ati gāhassa magga amagga vavatthānena  amagge magga saññāya udaya dassanena uccheda diṭṭhiyā vaya dassanena sassata diṭṭhiyā  bhaya dassanena sa bhaye abhaya saññāya ādīnava dassanena assāda saññāya nibbida anupassanāya  abhirati saññāya muccitu kamya tā ñāṇena a muccitu kāma tāya upekkhā ñāṇena an upekkhāya
translated: by the surmounting of doubt, of being a questioner;🔽by the defining of ideas in the clumps, of the misinterpreting of “I” and “mine” ;🔽by the defining of the path and not-path, of the perception of a path where there is not one;🔽by seeing rise, of the view of annihilation; by seeing fall, of the view of eternalism;🔽by seeing fear, of the perception of safety where there is fear; by seeing danger, of the perception of comfort;🔽by the contemplation of dispassion, of delight;🔽by the knowledge of the desire for deliverance, of the desire not to be delivered; by the knowledge of equanimity, of nonequanimity;🔽

original: anulomena dhammaṭṭhitiyaṃ nibbāne ca paṭilomabhāvassa, gotrabhunā saṅkhāranimittagāhassa🔽pahānaṃ, etaṃ tadaṅgappahānaṃ nāma.🔽Yaṃ pana upacārappanābhedena samādhinā pavattibhāvanivāraṇato ghaṭappahāreneva udakapiṭṭhe🔽sevālassa, tesaṃ tesaṃ nīvaraṇādidhammānaṃ pahānaṃ, etaṃ vikkhambhanappahānaṃ nāma.
analyzed: anulomena dhamma ṭṭhitiyam nibbāne ca paṭiloma bhāvassa gotrabhunā saṅkhāra nimitta gāhassa 🔽pahānam etam tadaṅgappahānam nāma 🔽yam pana upacāra ppanā bhedena samādhinā pavatti bhāva nivāraṇataḥ ghaṭa ppahārena iva udaka piṭṭhe 🔽sevālassa tesam tesam nīvaraṇa ādi dhammānam pahānam etam vikkhambhana pahānam nāma
translated: By the surmounting of doubt, by the state of having nothing to be done, by the state of not questioning, by the state of being unconfused, by the state of being without uncertainty, by the state of having no more learning to do, by the state of having reached the consummation, by the state of being a disciple, by the state of being a paccekabuddha, by the state of being a perfectly state of being a master of the twelve baskets, by the state of being a master of the five hundred baskets, by the state of being a master of the whole canon, by the state of being a master of the Teacher’s Dispensation, by the state of being a master of the

original: Yaṃ catunnaṃ ariyamaggānaṃ bhāvitattā taṃtaṃmaggavato attano santāne “diṭṭhigatānaṃ
analyzed: yam catunnam ariya maggānam bhāvita ttā taṃ taṃ maggavataḥ attano santāne diṭṭhi gatānam
translated: The “view” is the view of the four noble paths, which is the view of the one who has developed the paths.

original: pahānāyā”tiādinā nayena vuttassa samudayapakkhikassa kilesagaṇassa accantaṃ appavattibhāvena
analyzed: pahānāya ati ādinā nayena vuttassa samudaya pakkhikassa kilesa gaṇassa accantam appavatti bhāvena
translated: The abandoning of the entire set of defilements on the side of origin that is stated in the way beginning, “For the purpose of abandoning the views” by the development of the four noble paths in the individual’s own mental continuity is called “abandoning by cutting off.”

original: pahānaṃ, idaṃ samucchedappahānaṃ nāma. Yaṃ pana phalakkhaṇe paṭippassaddhattaṃ kilesānaṃ,🔽etaṃ paṭippassaddhippahānaṃ nāma.🔽Yaṃ sabbasaṅkhatanissaṭattā pahīnasabbasaṅkhataṃ nibbānaṃ, etaṃ nissaraṇappahānaṃ
analyzed: pahānam idam samuccheda pahānam nāma yam pana phala kkhaṇe paṭippassaddhattam kilesānam  etam paṭippassaddhi ppahānam nāma  yam sabba saṅkhata nissaṭa ttā pahīna sabba saṅkhatam nibbānam etam nissaraṇa ppahānam
translated: The state of being completely stilled of the defilements at the moment of fruition is called “abandoning by allaying.”🔽The Nibbāna that is the abandoning of all formations because of being free from all formations is called “abandoning by escape.”

original: nāma. Sabbampi cetaṃ pahānaṃ yasmā cāgaṭṭhena pahānaṃ, vinayaṭṭhena vinayo, tasmā
analyzed: nāma sabbam pi cetam pahānam yasmā cāga ṭṭhena pahānam vinaya ṭṭhena vinayaḥ tasmā
translated: And all this abandoning is called “abandoning as relinquishment” and “discipline as restraint” because it is abandoning in the sense of relinquishing and because it is discipline in the sense of restraining.

original: “pahānavinayo”ti vuccati. Taṃtaṃpahānavato vā tassa tassa vinayassa sambhavatopetaṃ
analyzed: pahāna vinayaḥ ti vuccati taṃ taṃ pahānavataḥ vā tassa tassa vinayassa sambhava tā upetam
translated: Or alternatively, it is called “abandoning as relinquishment” and “discipline as restraint” because of the occurrence of that and that discipline in one who has the abandoning of this and that.

original: “pahānavinayo”ti vuccati. Evaṃ pahānavinayopi pañcadhā bhijjatīti veditabbo.
analyzed: pahāna vinayo ti vuccati evam pahāna vinayaḥ api pañcadhā bhijjati iti veditabbo
translated: Thus the abandoning as discipline should be understood as fivefold.

original: Evamayaṃ saṅkhepato duvidho, bhedato ca dasavidho vinayo bhinnasaṃvarattā pahātabbassa
analyzed: evam ayam saṅkhepataḥ duvidhaḥ bhedataḥ ca dasavidhaḥ vinayaḥ bhinna saṃvara ttā pahātabbassa
translated: So it is in brief twofold, and in detail it is tenfold. It is called “unskilled” because it is not the virtue of one skilled in the abandoning of what should be abandoned,

original: ca appahīnattā yasmā etassa assutavato puthujjanassa natthi, tasmā abhāvato tassa🔽ayaṃ “avinīto”ti vuccatīti. Esa nayo sappurisānaṃ adassāvī sappurisadhammassa akovido
analyzed: ca appahīna ttā yasmai etassa a ssutavataḥ puthujjanassa na atthi tasmai abhāvato tassa  ayam avinītaḥ ti vuccati iti esa nayo sappurisānam a dassāvī sappurisa dhammassa a kovidaḥ
translated: and because it is not the virtue of one skilled in the attainment of what should be attained.🔽And so too in the case of “unseeing of noble ones” and “unskilled in the noble one’s Dhamma” and “untrained in the noble one’s Discipline.”

original: sappurisadhamme avinītoti etthāpi. Ninnānākaraṇañhi etaṃ atthato. Yathāha –🔽“Yeva te ariyā, teva te sappurisā. Yeva te sappurisā, teva te ariyā. Yo eva so ariyānaṃ🔽dhammo, so eva so sappurisānaṃ dhammo. Yo eva so sappurisānaṃ dhammo, so eva so ariyānaṃ🔽dhammo. Yeva te ariyavinayā, teva te sappurisavinayā. Yeva te sappurisavinayā, teva
analyzed: sappurisa dhamme avinītaḥ ti ettha api ninnānākaraṇam hi etam atthataḥ yathā āha  yeva te ariyā teva te sappurisāḥ yeva te sappurisāḥ teva te ariyāḥ yaḥ eva saḥ ariyānaṃ  dhammo saḥ eva saḥ sappurisānam dhammo yaḥ eva saḥ sappurisānam dhammo saḥ eva so ariyānam  dhammo yeva te ariya vinayā teva te sappurisa vinayā yeva te sappurisa vinayā teva
translated: For this is a mere difference in the phrasing. As it is said:🔽“Those who are noble are the same as those who are true men. Those who are true men are the same as those who are noble. That which is the Dhamma of the noble ones

original: te ariyavinayā. Ariyeti vā sappuriseti vā, ariyadhammeti vā sappurisadhammeti vā,
analyzed: te ariya vinayāḥ ariya iti vā sappurisa iti vā ariya dhamma iti vā sappurisa dhamma iti vā
translated: is the same as that which is the Dhamma of true men. That which is the Dhamma of true men is the same as that which is the Dhamma of noble ones. Those who are the noble ones’ training are the same as those who are the true men’s training. Those who are the true men’s training are the same as those who are the noble ones’ training. Whether it is called ‘noble’ or ‘true man,’ whether it is called ‘noble Dhamma’ or ‘true men’s Dhamma,’

original: ariyavinayeti vā sappurisavinayeti vā esese eke ekaṭṭhe same samabhāge tajjāte taññevā”ti.🔽Rūpaṃ attato samanupassatīti idhekacco rūpaṃ attato samanupassati, “yaṃ rūpaṃ, so
analyzed: ariya vinaye ti vā sappurisa vinaye ti vā esese eke ekaṭṭhe same sama bhāge tad jāte tañca eva ati  rūpam attataḥ samanupassati iti idha ekaccaḥ rūpam attataḥ samanupassati yam rūpam so
translated: or in the discipline of the Noble Ones, or in the discipline of the True Person, these are just different ways of referring to this same thing.”🔽He regards material form as self: here someone regards material form as self, thinking: “Material form is my self.”

original: ahaṃ, yo ahaṃ, taṃ rūpa”nti rūpañca attañca advayaṃ samanupassati. Seyyathāpi nāma
analyzed: aham yaḥ aham tam rūpanti rūpan ca attañca advayam samanupassati sā iyyathā api nāma
translated: He regards self and material form as non-dual,

original: telappadīpassa jhāyato yā acci, so vaṇṇo. Yo vaṇṇo, sā accīti acciñca vaṇṇañca advayaṃ
analyzed: telappadīpassa jhāyataḥ yā acci saḥ vaṇṇaḥ yaḥ vaṇṇaḥ sā accī iti accin ca vaṇṇam ca advayam
translated: just as the flame of a lamp burning in sesame oil is inseparable from the light.

original: samanupassati, evameva idhekacco rūpaṃ attato samanupassati…pe… advayaṃ samanupassatīti🔽evaṃ rūpaṃ “attā”ti diṭṭhipassanāya passati. Rūpavantaṃ vā attānanti arūpaṃ “attā”ti🔽gahetvā chāyāvantaṃ rukkhaṃ viya taṃ rūpavantaṃ samanupassati. Attani vā rūpanti
analyzed: samanupassati evam eva idha ekaccaḥ rūpam attataḥ samanupassati pe advayam samanupassati iti  evam rūpam attā ati diṭṭhi passanāya passati rūpavantam vā attā ananti arūpam attā ati  gahetvā chāyāvantam rukkham viya tam rūpavantam samanupassati attani vā
translated: So too, someone regards material form as self. …🔽He regards self as possessing material form: having apprehended the immaterial self in material form, he regards it as possessing material form, like a tree possessing shade.

original: arūpameva “attā”ti gahetvā pupphasmiṃ gandhaṃ viya attani rūpaṃ samanupassati. Rūpasmiṃ
analyzed: arūpam eva attā ati gahetvā pupphasmim gandham viya attani rūpam samanupassati rūpasmim
translated: Or he regards material form as in self: having apprehended the immaterial self, he regards material form as in the self, like a fragrance in a flower.🔽Or he regards self as in material form:

original: vā attānanti arūpameva “attā”ti gahetvā karaṇḍake maṇiṃ viya taṃ attānaṃ rūpasmiṃ🔽samanupassati. Pariyuṭṭhaṭṭhāyīti pariyuṭṭhānākārena abhibhavanākārena ṭhito, “ahaṃ
analyzed: vai attā ananti arūpam eva attā ati gahetvā karaṇḍake maṇim tam attānam rūpasmin  samanupassati pariyuṭṭha ṭhāyī iti pariyuṭṭhāna ākārena abhibhavana ākārena ṭhitaḥ aham
translated: Or else, having apprehended the formless only as self, he regards that self as in the material form, like a gem in a casket.

original: rūpaṃ, mama rūpa”nti evaṃ taṇhādiṭṭhīhi gilitvā pariniṭṭhapetvā gaṇhanako nāma hotīti
analyzed: rūpam mama rūpan ti evam taṇhā diṭṭhīhi gilitvā pariniṭṭhapetvā gaṇhanakaḥ nāma hoti iti
translated: The meaning is that he is one who, by way of craving and views, swallows up and digests the material form, thinking, “I am the material form,” “The material form is mine.”

original: attho. Tassa taṃ rūpanti tassa taṃ evaṃ gahitaṃ rūpaṃ. Vedanādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: tassa tam ti tassa tam evam gahitam rūpam vedanā ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ
translated: His material form: his material form thus apprehended. The same method applies to feeling, etc.

original: Tattha “rūpaṃ attato samanupassatī”ti suddharūpameva attāti kathitaṃ. “Rūpavantaṃ🔽vā attānaṃ, attani vā rūpaṃ, rūpasmiṃ vā attānaṃ, vedanaṃ attato…pe… saññaṃ… saṅkhāre…
analyzed: tattha rūpam attataḥ samanupassati iti suddha rūpam eva attā iti kathitam rūpavantam  vā attānam attani vā rūpam rūpasmim vā attānam vedanam saññam saṅkhāre
translated: Herein, “He regards material form as self” is said with reference to the mere material form. “He regards self as possessed of material form,” “He regards material form as in self,” and “He regards self as in material form” are said with reference to the formless.

original: viññāṇaṃ attato samanupassatī”ti imesu sattasu ṭhānesu arūpaṃ attāti kathitaṃ. “Vedanāvantaṃ
analyzed: viññāṇam attataḥ samanupassati iti imesu sattasu ṭhānesu arūpam attā ati kathitam vedanāvantam
translated: “He regards feeling as self” … “He regards perception as self” … “He regards formations as self” … “He regards consciousness as self” are said with reference to the formless.

original: vā attānaṃ, attani vā vedanaṃ, vedanāya vā attāna”nti evaṃ catūsu khandhesu tiṇṇaṃ
analyzed: vā attānam attani vā vedanam vedanāya vā attānam ti evam catūsu khandhesu tiṇṇam
translated: “He regards self as possessed of feeling,” “He regards feeling as in self,” and “He regards self as in feeling” are said with reference to the four aggregates.

original: tiṇṇaṃ vasena dvādasasu ṭhānesu rūpārūpamissako attā kathito. Tattha “rūpaṃ attato🔽samanupassati, vedanaṃ… saññaṃ… saṅkhāre… viññāṇaṃ attato samanupassatī”ti imesu
analyzed: tiṇṇam vasena dvādasasu ṭhānesu rūpa arūpa missakaḥ attā kathitaḥ tattha rūpam attataḥ  samanupassati vedanam saññam saṅkhāre viññāṇam attataḥ samanupassati iti imesu
translated: The self is spoken of as consisting of matter and the immaterial in twelve ways by means of the three. Herein, in the five ways beginning with “He regards materiality as the self” ,

original: pañcasu ṭhānesu ucchedadiṭṭhi kathitā, avasesesu sassatadiṭṭhīti evamettha pannarasa
analyzed: pañcasu ṭhānesu uccheda diṭṭhi kathitā avasesesu sassata diṭṭhi iti evam ettha pannarasa
translated: annihilationism is taught, and in the remaining seven ways eternalism is taught. Thus here there are fifteen

original: bhavadiṭṭhiyo pañca vibhavadiṭṭhiyo honti, tā sabbāpi maggāvaraṇā, na saggāvaraṇā,
analyzed: bhava diṭṭhiyaḥ pañca vibhava diṭṭhiyaḥ honti tā sabbā api magga āvaraṇā na sagga āvaraṇā
translated: views of becoming and five views of non-becoming. All of them are hindrances to the path, not hindrances to heaven,

original: paṭhamamaggavajjhāti veditabbā.
analyzed: paṭhama magga vat jhā ati veditabbā
translated: and they should be understood as abandoned by the first path.

original: Evaṃ kho, gahapati, āturakāyo ceva hoti āturacitto cāti kāyo nāma buddhānampi āturoyeva.
analyzed: evam kho gahapati ātura kāyaḥ ca iva hoti ātura cittaḥ ca ati kāyaḥ nāma buddhānam pi
translated: “Thus, householder, one is afflicted in body and afflicted in mind”: the body of the Buddhas is afflicted.

original: Cittaṃ pana rāgadosamohānugataṃ āturaṃ nāma, taṃ idha dassitaṃ. No ca āturacittoti
analyzed: cittam pana rāga dosa moha anugatam āturam nāma tat idha dassitam no ca ātura citta ti
translated: But the mind is called afflicted when it is accompanied by lust, hatred, and delusion. That is what is shown here. “But he is not afflicted in mind”:

original: idha nikkilesatāya cittassa anāturabhāvo dassito. Iti imasmiṃ sutte lokiyamahājano
analyzed: idha nikkilesa tāya cittassa anātura bhāvaḥ dassito iti imasmim sutte lokiya mahājano
translated: here the non-affliction of the mind through the absence of defilements is shown. Thus in this sutta the worldling is shown as

original: āturakāyo ceva āturacitto cāti dassito, khīṇāsavā āturakāyā anāturacittā, satta sekhā🔽neva āturacittā, na anāturacittāti veditabbā. Bhajamānā pana anāturacittataṃyeva
analyzed: ātura kāyo ca iva ātura citto ca ati dassitaḥ khīṇa āsavāḥ ātura kāyāḥ anātura cittā satta sekhā  na iva ātura cittā na anātura cittā ati veditabbā bhajamānā pana
translated: and the cankers destroyed are shown as having a sick body but not a sick mind, and the seven kinds of trainers

original: bhajantīti. Paṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: bhajanti iti paṭhamam
translated: should be understood as having neither a sick mind nor a sick body. But those who are devoted to the state of having a sick body are devoted to the state of having a sick mind. First.

original: 2. Devadahasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: . Commentary on the Devadaha Sutta

original: 2. Dutiye devadahanti devā vuccanti rājāno, tesaṃ maṅgaladaho, sayaṃjāto vā so dahoti,
analyzed: dutiye deva dahanti devāḥ vuccanti rājānaḥ tesam maṅgala daho sayaṃjātaḥ vā saḥ dahoti
translated: . In the second sutta, “Devadaha” means the fire festival of the gods. The gods are kings. Their fire festival is called “Devadaha.” Or the fire festival is self-arisen.

original: tasmā “devadaho”ti vutto. Tassa avidūre nigamo devadahantveva napuṃsakaliṅgavasena
analyzed: tasmā deva daho ti vutto tassa avidūre nigamaḥ deva dahan tu eva napuṃsaka liṅga vasena
translated: Therefore it is called “Devadaha.” Not far from there is a town called Devadaha in the neuter gender.

original: saṅkhaṃ gato. Pacchābhūmagamikāti pacchābhūmaṃ aparadisāyaṃ niviṭṭhaṃ janapadaṃ gantukāmā.
analyzed: saṅkham gatā u pacchābhūma gamikā ati pacchābhūmam apara disā ayam niviṭṭham janapadam gantu kāmā
translated: “Going to the country of the Magadhans” means wishing to go to the country of the Magadhans, which is situated in the south.

original: Nivāsanti temāsaṃ vassāvāsaṃ. Apalokitoti āpucchito. Apalokethāti āpucchatha. Kasmā
analyzed: nivāsanti temāsam vassāvāsam apalokito ti āpucchitaḥ apaloketha ati āpucchatha kasmā
translated: “They stayed” means they stayed for the three months of the rains. “They asked” means they asked the Elder. “They asked him” means they asked him. Why

original: theraṃ āpucchāpeti? Te sabhāre kātukāmatāya. Yo hi ekavihāre vasantopi santikaṃ na
analyzed: theram te sabhāre kātu kāma tāya yaḥ hi eka vihāre vasantaḥ api santikam na
translated: did they ask the Elder? Because they wanted to do the robe-making ceremony. For one who lives in a single dwelling, even if he is nearby,

original: gacchati pakkamanto anāpucchā pakkamati, ayaṃ nibbhāro nāma. Yo ekavihāre vasantopi🔽āgantvā passati, pakkamanto āpucchati, ayaṃ sabhāro nāma. Imepi bhikkhū bhagavā “evamime
analyzed: gacchati pakkamantaḥ anāpucchā pakkamati ayam nibbhāraḥ nāma yaḥ eka vihāre  āgantvā passati pakkamantaḥ āpucchati ayam sabhāraḥ nāma ime pi bhikkhū bhagavā evam ime
translated: When he goes away without taking leave, this is called not being helpful. When one who is staying in the same dwelling-place🔽sees him on his return and takes leave of him when he is going away, this is being helpful. The Blessed One, thinking, “In this way these bhikkhus will grow in virtue, etc.,”

original: sīlādīhi vaḍḍhissantī”ti sabhāre kātukāmo āpucchāpeti.
analyzed: sīla ādīhi vaḍḍhissanti iti sabhāre kātu kāmaḥ āpuccha apeti
translated: wants to make them helpful.

original: Paṇḍitoti dhātukosallādinā catubbidhena paṇḍiccena samannāgato. Anuggāhakoti āmisānuggahena
analyzed: paṇḍito ti dhātu kosalla ādinā catubbidhena paṇḍiccena samannāgataḥ anuggāhako ti āmisa anuggahena
translated: Wise: possessed of the four kinds of “wisdom” , namely, skill in the aggregates, skill in the sense bases, skill in the faculties, and skill in dependent origination.

original: ca dhammānuggahena cāti dvīhipi anuggahehi anuggāhako. Thero kira aññe bhikkhū viya🔽pātova piṇḍāya agantvā sabbabhikkhūsu gatesu sakalaṃ saṅghārāmaṃ anuvicaranto asammaṭṭhaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: ca dhamma anuggahena ca ati dvīhi pi anuggahehi anuggāhakaḥ theraḥ kira aññe bhikkhū viya  pātova piṇḍāya a gantvā sabba bhikkhūsu gatesu sakalam saṅgha ārāmam anuvicarantaḥ a sammaṭṭha ṭṭhānam
translated: Helpful: helpful in two ways, by material help and by the help of the Dhamma.

original: sammajjati, achaḍḍitaṃ kacavaraṃ chaḍḍeti, saṅghārāme dunnikkhittāni mañcapīṭhadārubhaṇḍamattikābhaṇḍāni
analyzed: sammajjati a chaḍḍitam kaca varam chaḍḍeti saṅgha ārāme dunnikkhittāni mañca pīṭha dāru bhaṇḍa mattikā bhaṇḍāni
translated: The elder, it seems, did not go into the village for alms like the other bhikkhus, but when they had all gone he would wander all over the monastery and sweep out the places they had missed, throw away the rubbish they had missed, and put in order the beds, chairs, wooden goods, and earthen goods that were lying about higgledy-piggledy.

original: paṭisāmeti. Kiṃ kāraṇā? “Mā aññatitthiyā vihāraṃ paviṭṭhā disvā paribhavaṃ akaṃsū”ti.
analyzed: paṭisāma iti kim kāraṇā mā añña titthiyāḥ vihāram paviṭṭhāḥ disvā paribhavam akaṃsu iti
translated: Why did he do this? “Lest the sectarians who came in should make fun of the monastery.”

original: Tato gilānasālaṃ gantvā gilāne assāsetvā “kenattho”ti pucchitvā yena attho hoti,
analyzed: tatas gilāna sālam gantvā gilāne assāsetvā kena attho ti pucchitvā yena attho hoti
translated: Then he goes to the sick ward, cheers up the sick, and asks what they need.

original: tadatthaṃ tesaṃ daharasāmaṇere ādāya bhikkhācāravattena vā sabhāgaṭṭhāne vā bhesajjaṃ
analyzed: tad attham tesam dahara sāmaṇere ādāya bhikkhā cāra vattena vā sabhāga ṭṭhāne vā bhesajjam
translated: If they need medicine, he gets it for them by going on alms round with young bhikkhus or by seeking it from suitable people.

original: pariyesitvā tesaṃ datvā, “gilānupaṭṭhānaṃ nāma buddhapaccekabuddhehi vaṇṇitaṃ, gacchatha🔽sappurisā appamattā hothā”ti te pesetvā sayaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā upaṭṭhākakule vā bhattakiccaṃ
analyzed: pariyesitvā tesam da tvā gilānupaṭṭhānam nāma buddha paccekabuddhehi vaṇṇitam gacchatha  sappurisāḥ appamattāḥ hotha ati te pesetvā sayam piṇḍāya caritvā upaṭṭhāka kule vā bhatta kiccam
translated: After giving it to them, he sends them away, saying, “Nursing the sick is praised by the Buddha, the Enlightened One.🔽Go, good people, and be diligent.”

original: katvā vihāraṃ gacchati. Idaṃ tāvassa nibaddhavāsaṭṭhāne āciṇṇaṃ.
analyzed: katvā vihāram gacchati idam tāva assa nibaddha vāsaṭṭhāne āciṇṇam
translated: After going on alms round himself and taking his meal in the house of a supporter, he goes to the monastery. This is his usual practice while living in a fixed abode.

original: Bhagavati pana cārikaṃ caramāne “ahaṃ aggasāvako”ti upāhanaṃ āruyha chattaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: bhagavati pana cārikam caramāne aham aggasāvakaḥ iti upāhanam āruyha chattam gahetvā
translated: But when the Exalted One goes on tour, he does not go in front of the Exalted One, mounting his sandals and taking his sunshade, thinking “I am the chief disciple.”🔽But he goes behind the Exalted One, taking the sandals and sunshade, and he makes a place for the Exalted One to sit down in whatever place the Exalted One stops for the day’s lodging.

original: purato purato na gacchati. Ye pana tattha mahallakā vā ābādhikā vā atidaharā vā,
analyzed: puratas puratas na gacchati ye pana tattha mahallakāḥ vā ābādhikāḥ vā atidaharāḥ vā
translated: And if there are senior bhikkhus or sick bhikkhus or very young bhikkhus there,

original: tesaṃ rujjanaṭṭhānāni telena makkhāpetvā pattacīvaraṃ attano daharasāmaṇerehi gāhāpetvā
analyzed: tesam rujjana ṭṭhānāni telena makkhāpetvā patta cīvaram attanaḥ dahara sāmaṇerehi gāhāpetvā
translated: he has their resting places anointed with oil, and he has them take their bowls and outer robes, and he has them go ahead.

original: taṃdivasaṃ vā dutiyadivasaṃ vā te gaṇhitvāva gacchati. Ekadivasañhi taññeva āyasmantaṃ
analyzed: tad divasam vā dutiya divasam vā te gaṇhitvā ava gacchati eka divasam hi tam na eva āyasmantam
translated: He took them on that day or the following day and went away.

original: ativikāle sampattattā senāsanaṃ alabhitvā, cīvarakuṭiyaṃ nisinnaṃ disvā, satthā punadivase
analyzed: ati vikāle sampattattā senāsanam a labhitvā cīvarakuṭiyam nisinnam disvā satthā puna divase
translated: For on one day the venerable one did not get a lodging because it was too late, and the Teacher, seeing him sitting in the robe-room,

original: bhikkhusaṅghaṃ sannipātāpetvā, hatthivānaratittiravatthuṃ kathetvā, “yathāvuḍḍhaṃ
analyzed: bhikkhu saṅgham sannipātāpetvā hatthi vānara tittira vatthum kathetvā yathāvuḍḍham
translated: on the following day had the Order of monks convened and related the story of the elephant, the monkey, and the mynah bird.

original: senāsanaṃ dātabba”nti sikkhāpadaṃ paññāpesi. Evaṃ tāvesa āmisānuggahena anuggaṇhāti.
analyzed: senāsanam dātabbanti sikkhāpadam paññāpesi evam tāva esa āmisa anuggahena anuggaṇhāti
translated: Then he laid down the training precept that “The lodging is to be given according to seniority.” That is how he favours with material things.

original: Ovadanto panesa satavārampi sahassavārampi tāva ovadati, yāva so puggalo sotāpattiphale
analyzed: ovadantaḥ pana esa sata vāram sahassa vāram pi tāva ovadati yāva so puggalo sotāpatti phale
translated: But as for instructing, he instructs so often, whether a hundred times or a thousand times, until that person is established in the fruit of stream-entry,

original: patiṭṭhāti, atha naṃ vissajjetvā aññaṃ ovadati. Iminā nayena ovadato cassa ovāde
analyzed: patiṭṭhāti atha nam vissajjetvā aññam ovadati iminā nayena ovadataḥ ca ssa ovāde
translated: and then he dismisses him and instructs another. In this way, as he instructs,

original: ṭhatvā arahattaṃ pattā gaṇanapathaṃ atikkantā. Evaṃ dhammānuggahena anuggaṇhāti.
analyzed: ṭhatvā arahattam pattā gaṇana patham atikkantā evam dhamma anuggahena anuggaṇhāti
translated: those who have reached Arahantship by keeping to his instructions are beyond number. That is how he favours with the True Idea.

original: Paccassosunti te bhikkhū “amhākaṃ neva upajjhāyo, na ācariyo na sandiṭṭhasambhatto.
analyzed: paccassosunti te bhikkhū amhākam na iva upajjhāyaḥ na ācariyo na sandiṭṭha sambhatto
translated: “He is not our preceptor, nor our teacher, nor one who is known to us,” said those monks.

original: Kiṃ tassa santike karissāmā”ti? Tuṇhībhāvaṃ anāpajjitvā “evaṃ, bhante”ti satthu vacanaṃ
analyzed: kim tassa santike karissāma ati tuṇhībhāvam an āpajjitvā evam bhante iti satthu vacanam
translated: What can we do for him there? ” Without falling into silence, they accepted the Teacher’s word, saying, “So be it, Reverend Sir.”

original: sampaṭicchiṃsu. Eḷagalāgumbeti gacchamaṇḍapake. So kira eḷagalāgumbo dhuvasalilaṭṭhāne
analyzed: eḷagalāgumbā iti gaccha maṇḍapake saḥ kira eḷagalāgumbaḥ dhuva salilaṭṭhāne
translated: The Eḷagalā tree is in the Gaccha pavilion. That tree, it seems, grew in a place where water always stood.

original: jāto. Athettha catūhi pādehi maṇḍapaṃ katvā tassa upari taṃ gumbaṃ āropesuṃ, so taṃ
analyzed: jātaḥ atha ittha catūhi pādehi maṇḍapam katvā tassa upari tam gumbam āropesuṃ saḥ tam
translated: Then they made a pavilion with four pillars there, and they raised that tree above it. It shaded that pavilion.

original: maṇḍapaṃ chādesi. Athassa heṭṭhā iṭṭhakāhi paricinitvā vālikaṃ okiritvā āsanaṃ paññāpayiṃsu.
analyzed: maṇḍapam chādesi athassa heṭṭhā iṭṭhakāhi paricinitvā vālikam okiritvā āsanam paññāpayiṃsu
translated: Then they had bricks laid down below it, and sand spread over them, and a seat prepared.

original: Sītalaṃ divāṭṭhānaṃ udakavāto vāyati. Thero tasmiṃ nisīdi. Taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “eḷagalāgumbe”ti.
analyzed: sītalam divāṭṭhānam udaka vātaḥ vāyati thero tasmin tam sandhāya vuttam eḷagalāgumbā iti
translated: A cool breeze from the water blew on the pavilion during the day. The Elder sat there. In reference to that it was said, “In the Eḷagalā tree.”

original: Nānāverajjagatanti ekassa rañño rajjato nānāvidhaṃ rajjagataṃ. Virajjanti aññaṃ rajjaṃ.
analyzed: nānā verajja gatanti ekassa raññaḥ rajjataḥ nānāvidham rajja gatam virajjanti aññam rajjam
translated: The various realms of kings: the various realms of kings in the realm of one king. The various realms of kings are different from one another.

original: Yathā hi sadesato añño videso, evaṃ nivuttharajjato aññaṃ rajjaṃ virajjaṃ nāma, taṃ
analyzed: yathā hi sa desataḥ aññaḥ videsaḥ evam nivuttha rajjataḥ aññam rajjam virajjam nāma tam
translated: Just as a foreign country is different from one’s own country, so a realm is different from a realm that is not one’s own.

original: verajjanti vuttaṃ. Khattiyapaṇḍitāti bimbisārakosalarājādayo paṇḍitarājāno. Brāhmaṇapaṇḍitāti
analyzed: verajjanti vuttam khattiya paṇḍita ati bimbisāra kosala rāja ādayaḥ paṇḍita rājānaḥ brāhmaṇa paṇḍitā ati
translated: ‘To the enemy’ is said.🔽‘The wise nobles’: the wise kings such as Bimbisāra and the King of Kosala. ‘The wise brahmins’:

original: caṅkītārukkhādayo paṇḍitabrāhmaṇā. Gahapatipaṇḍitāti cittasudattādayo paṇḍitagahapatayo.
analyzed: caṅkī tārukkha ādayaḥ paṇḍita brāhmaṇāḥ gahapati paṇḍita ati cittasudatta ādayo paṇḍita gahapatayo
translated: the wise brahmins such as Caṅkī and Ārāḍa. ‘The wise householders’: the wise householders such as Citta and Sudatta.

original: Samaṇapaṇḍitāti sabhiyapilotikādayo paṇḍitaparibbājakā. Vīmaṃsakāti atthagavesino.
analyzed: samaṇa paṇḍita ati sabhiya pilotika ādayo paṇḍita paribbājakāḥ vīmaṃsakāḥ ati attha gavesino
translated: ‘The wise ascetics’: the wise wanderers such as Sabhiya and Pilōtika. ‘The inquirers’: those who seek the meaning.🔽‘What does he say?’ means: what is his own view? What does he hold? ‘What does he declare?’ means:

original: Kiṃvādīti kiṃ attano dassanaṃ vadati, kiṃ laddhikoti attho. Kimakkhāyīti kiṃ sāvakānaṃ🔽ovādānusāsaniṃ ācikkhati? Dhammassa cānudhammanti bhagavatā vuttabyākaraṇassa anubyākaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: kiṃvādī iti kim attanaḥ dassanam vadati kim laddhiko ti attho kim akkhāyī iti kim sāvakānam  ovāda anusāsanim ācikkhati dhammassa ca anudhammanti bhagavatā vutta byākaraṇassa anubyākaraṇam
translated: what does he teach to his disciples?🔽‘The doctrine in conformity with the doctrine’: the explanation in conformity with the explanation given by the Blessed One.

original: Sahadhammikoti sakāraṇo. Vādānuvādoti bhagavatā vuttavādassa anuvādo. “Vādānupāto”tipi
analyzed: sahadhammikaḥ ti sa kāraṇaḥ vādānuvādo ti bhagavatā vutta vādassa anuvādaḥ vāda anupāto ti pi
translated: ‘In conformity with the doctrine’: with a reason. ‘The doctrine in conformity with the doctrine’: the doctrine in conformity with the doctrine spoken by the Blessed One. The reading ‘vādanupāto’

original: pāṭho, satthu vādassa anupāto anupatanaṃ, anugamananti attho. Imināpi vādaṃ anugato🔽vādoyeva dīpito hoti.
analyzed: pāṭhaḥ satthu vādassa anupātaḥ anupatanam anugamananti atthaḥ iminā api vādam anugataḥ 🔽dīpitaḥ
translated: is also found. The meaning is: the doctrine in conformity with the doctrine spoken by the Master, the doctrine that follows it, the doctrine that goes along with it. By this, too, the doctrine that follows the doctrine is shown.

original: Avigatarāgassātiādīsu taṇhāvaseneva attho veditabbo. Taṇhā hi rajjanato rāgo, chandiyanato
analyzed: avigata rāgassa ati ādīsu taṇhā vasena iva atthaḥ veditabbaḥ taṇhā hi rajjanataḥ rāgaḥ chandiyanataḥ
translated: In the case of the words “not yet freed from lust, etc.,” the meaning should be understood according to the method stated in the case of the words “not yet freed from lust, etc.” for lust is called “lust” because of its lusting , and because of its being a channel for defilements it is called “channel” .

original: chando, piyāyanaṭṭhena pemaṃ, pivitukāmaṭṭhena pipāsā, anudahanaṭṭhena pariḷāhoti🔽vuccati. Akusale cāvuso, dhammetiādi kasmā āraddhaṃ? Pañcasu khandhesu avītarāgassa🔽ādīnavaṃ, vītarāgassa ca ānisaṃsaṃ dassetuṃ. Tatra avighātoti niddukkho. Anupāyāsoti
analyzed: chandaḥ piyāyana ṭṭhena pemam pivitu kāma ṭṭhena pipāsā anudahana ṭṭhena pariḷāhaḥ ti  vuccati akusale ca āvuso dhamma itiādi kasmai āraddham pañcasu khandhesu avīta rāgassa  ādīnavam vīta rāgassa ca ānisaṃsam dassetum tatra avighāto ti niddukkhaḥ anupāyāsaḥ ti
translated: In the case of the terms beginning with “not yet freed from passion,” the meaning should be understood according to the method of explanation given above. For craving is called passion because it is the state of being passionate. It is called desire because it is the state of desiring. It is called affection because it is the state of being affectionate. It is called thirst because it is the state of being thirsty. It is called fever because it is the state of being feverish.

original: nirupatāpo. Apariḷāhoti niddāho. Evaṃ sabbattha attho veditabbo. Dutiyaṃ.
analyzed: nirupatāpaḥ apariḷāhaḥ ti niddāhaḥ evam sabbattha atthaḥ veditabbaḥ dutiyam
translated: Why is the unprofitable beginning with “unprofitable ideas” mentioned? In order to show the danger in the five aggregates for one who is not yet freed from passion and the benefit in them for one who is freed from passion. Herein, unharassed is without pain. Unvexed is without fever. Unfeverish is without heat. The meaning should be understood in this way in all cases. The second tetrad is finished.

original: 3. Hāliddikānisuttavaṇṇanā🔽3. Tatiye avantīsūti avantidakkhiṇāpathasaṅkhāte avantiraṭṭhe. Kuraraghareti evaṃnāmake🔽nagare. Papāteti ekato papāte. Tassa kira pabbatassa ekaṃ passaṃ chinditvā pātitaṃ
analyzed: hāliddikāni sutta vaṇṇanā  tatiye avantīsu iti avanti dakkhiṇāpatha saṅkhāte avanti raṭṭhe kuraraghara iti evaṃnāmake  nagare papāteti ekatas papāte tassa kira pabbatassa ekam passam chinditvā pātitam
translated: The exposition of the Hāliddikāni Sutta

original: viya ahosi. “Pavatte”tipi pāṭho, nānātitthiyānaṃ laddhipavattaṭṭhāneti attho. Iti
analyzed: viya ahosi pavattā iti pi pāṭhaḥ nānā titthiyānam laddhi pavatta ṭṭhāne iti attho iti
translated: In the third, in Avanti: in the country called Avanti, which is the southern part of the Dakkhiṇāgiri country. In the Kuraraghara: in the town of that name. On the slope: on the one slope. It was as though it had been cut off and dropped from one side of that mountain, it seems. The reading “in the practice” is also allowable; the meaning is: in the place of practice of the various sects. Thus

original: thero tasmiṃ raṭṭhe taṃ nagaraṃ nissāya tasmiṃ pabbate viharati. Hāliddikānīti evaṃnāmako.
analyzed: theraḥ tasmim raṭṭhe tam nagaram nissāya tasmin pabbate viharati hāliddikāni iti evaṃnāmakaḥ
translated: The Elder lived in that country on that mountain near that town. He was called Hāliddikāni.

original: Aṭṭhakavaggiye māgaṇḍiyapañheti aṭṭhakavaggikamhi māgaṇḍiyapañho nāma atthi, tasmiṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhaka vaggiye māgaṇḍiya pañha iti aṭṭhaka vaggikamhi māgaṇḍiya pañhaḥ nāma atthi tasmin
translated: In the Book of Eights, in the Discussion of Māgaṇḍiya,

original: pañhe. Rūpadhātūti rūpakkhandho adhippeto. Rūpadhāturāgavinibaddhanti rūpadhātumhi
analyzed: pañhe rūpa dhātū ti rūpa kkhandho adhippeto rūpadhātu rāga vinibaddhanti rūpadhātumhi
translated: in that discussion. The form element is intended by the form aggregate. Bound by lust for the form element: bound by lust for the form element.

original: rāgena vinibaddhaṃ. Viññāṇanti kammaviññāṇaṃ. Okasārīti gehasārī ālayasārī.
analyzed: rāgena vinibaddham viññāṇan ti kamma viññāṇam oka sārī iti geha sārī ālaya sārī
translated: Consciousness: kamma-consciousness. Goes to a new becoming: goes to a new house, goes to a new abode.

original: Kasmā panettha “viññāṇadhātu kho, gahapatī”ti na vuttanti? Sammohavighātatthaṃ. “Oko”ti
analyzed: kasmā pana ittha viññāṇa dhātu kho gahapati iti na vuttan ti sammoha vighāta attham
translated: But why is it not said here, “The consciousness element, householder”? For the purpose of dispelling confusion.

original: hi atthato paccayo vuccati, purejātañca kammaviññāṇaṃ pacchājātassa kammaviññāṇassapi
analyzed: hi atthato paccayaḥ vuccati purejātam ca kamma viññāṇam pacchājātassa kamma viññāṇassa api
translated: For “house” is said to be a cause in the sense of a condition. And the kamma-consciousness that has arisen before is a condition for the kamma-consciousness that arises later,

original: vipākaviññāṇassapi vipākaviññāṇañca vipākaviññāṇassapi kammaviññāṇassapi paccayo
analyzed: vipāka viññāṇassa api vipāka viññāṇañca vipāka viññāṇassa api kamma viññāṇassa api paccayaḥ
translated: and for the resultant consciousness, and the resultant consciousness is a condition for the kamma-consciousness.

original: hoti, tasmā “kataraṃ nu kho idha viññāṇa”nti? Sammoho bhaveyya, tassa vighātatthaṃ
analyzed: hoti tasmā kataram nu kho idha viññāṇanti sammohaḥ bhaveyya tassa vighāta attham
translated: Therefore there would be confusion as to which consciousness is meant here, and for the purpose of dispelling that confusion,

original: taṃ agahetvā asambhinnāva desanā katā. Apica ārammaṇavasena catasso abhisaṅkhāraviññāṇaṭṭhitiyo
analyzed: tam a gahetvā asambhinnā ava desanā katā api ca ārammaṇa vasena catasso abhisaṅkhāra viññāṇa ṭhitiyo
translated: Moreover, the four stations for consciousness accompanied by applied thought are stated in terms of object,

original: vuttāti tā dassetumpi idha viññāṇaṃ na gahitaṃ.
analyzed: vuttā iti tā dassetum pi idha viññāṇam na gahitam
translated: so consciousness is not taken here in order to show them.

original: Upayupādānāti taṇhūpayadiṭṭhūpayavasena dve upayā, kāmupādānādīni cattāri upādānāni
analyzed: upayupādānā ti taṇhu upaya diṭṭhu upaya vasena dve upayā kāma upādāna ādīni cattāri upādānāni
translated: Approaches and clingings: there are two approaches, that of craving and that of views, and there are four clingings, that to sense desires and the rest.

original: ca. Cetaso adhiṭṭhānābhinivesānusayāti akusalacittassa adhiṭṭhānabhūtā ceva abhinivesabhūtā
analyzed: ca cetasaḥ adhiṭṭhāna abhinivesa anusayā ati akusala cittassa adhiṭṭhāna bhūtā ca iva abhinivesa bhūtā
translated: Mental standpoints, adherences, and propensities: these are the mental standpoint, the adherence, and the proclivity of an unwholesome consciousness.🔽The Tathāgata: the Fully Enlightened One.

original: ca anusayabhūtā ca. Tathāgatassāti sammāsambuddhassa. Sabbesampi hi khīṇāsavānaṃ
analyzed: ca anusaya bhūtā ca tathāgatassa ati sammāsambuddhassa sabbesam pi hi khīṇāsavānam
translated: For these are abandoned in all cankers-destroyed noble persons,

original: ete pahīnāva, satthu pana khīṇāsavabhāvo loke atipākaṭoti uparimakoṭiyā evaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ete pahīnā ava satthu pana khīṇāsava bhāvo loke ati pākaṭaḥ ti uparima koṭiyā evam vuttam
translated: but the Tathāgata’s canker-destroyed state is very evident in the world, so it is said in the highest degree.

original: Viññāṇadhātuyāti idha viññāṇaṃ kasmā gahitaṃ? Kilesappahānadassanatthaṃ. Kilesā hi
analyzed: viññāṇa dhātuyā ti idha viññāṇam kasmā gahitam kilesa ppahāna dassana ttham kilesāḥ hi
translated: In the consciousness element: why is consciousness taken here? For the purpose of showing the abandoning of defilements.🔽For defilements are not abandoned only in the four aggregates, they are abandoned in the five as well.

original: na kevalaṃ catūsuyeva khandhesu pahīnā pahīyanti, pañcasupi pahīyantiyevāti kilesappahānadassanatthaṃ
analyzed: na kevalam catūsu yeva khandhesu pahīnā pahīyanti pañcasu pi pahīyanti yeva ati kilesa ppahāna dassana ttham
translated: For the purpose of showing the abandoning of defilements,

original: gahitaṃ. Evaṃ kho, gahapati, anokasārī hotīti evaṃ kammaviññāṇena okaṃ asarantena
analyzed: gahitam evam kho gahapati anokasārī hoti iti evam kamma viññāṇena okam a sarantena
translated: So too, when one does not go by the track of kamma-process consciousness,

original: anokasārī nāma hoti.
analyzed: anokasārī nāma hoti
translated: he is called one who does not go by tracks.🔽The sign of materiality, the abode, the spreading, the tie-up: materiality is the sign in the sense of being a condition for defilements;

original: Rūpanimittaniketavisāravinibandhāti rūpameva kilesānaṃ paccayaṭṭhena nimittaṃ, ārammaṇakiriyasaṅkhātanivāsanaṭṭhānaṭṭhena🔽niketanti rūpanimittaniketaṃ. Visāro ca vinibandho ca visāravinibandhā. Ubhayenapi🔽hi kilesānaṃ patthaṭabhāvo ca vinibandhanabhāvo ca vutto, rūpanimittanikete visāravinibandhāti
analyzed: rūpa nimitta niketa visāra vinibandhā ati rūpam eva kilesānam paccaya ṭṭhena nimittam ārammaṇa kiriya saṅkhāta nivāsana ṭṭhena  niketanti rūpa nimitta niketam visāraḥ ca vinibandhaḥ ca visāra vinibandhāḥ ubhayena api  hi kilesānam patthaṭa bhāvaḥ ca vinibandhana bhāvaḥ ca vuttaḥ rūpa nimitta nikete
translated: it is the abode in the sense of being the place of resort for the act of adverting;🔽the spreading and the tie-up are the spreading and the tie-up of defilements.🔽For by both of these the defilements are spread and tied up.

original: rūpanimittaniketavisāravinibandhā, tasmā rūpanimittaniketamhi uppannena kilesavisārena
analyzed: rūpa nimitta niketa visāra vinibandhā tasmā rūpa nimitta niketamhi uppannena kilesa visārena
translated: The meaning is: he is called one who goes by an abode because of the spreading of defilements and the tie-up of defilements that have arisen in the sign of materiality, the abode of materiality.

original: ceva kilesabandhanena cāti attho. Niketasārīti vuccatīti ārammaṇakaraṇavasena nivāsanaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: ca iva kilesa bandhanena ca ati attho niketasārī iti vuccati iti ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena nivāsana ṭṭhānam
translated: He is called one who goes by an abode because of the act of adverting by making materiality his object.

original: sārīti vuccati. Pahīnāti te rūpanimittaniketakilesavisāravinibandhā pahīnā.
analyzed: sārī iti vuccati pahīnā ati te rūpa nimitta niketa kilesa visāra vinibandhā pahīnā
translated: The abandoning: the spreading of defilements and the tie-up of defilements in the sign of materiality, the abode of materiality, are abandoned.

original: Kasmā panettha pañcakkhandhā “okā”ti vuttā, cha ārammaṇāni “niketa”nti? Chandarāgassa
analyzed: kasmā pana ittha pañca kkhandhā okā ati vuttā cha ārammaṇāni niketanti chandarāgassa
translated: But why are the five aggregates called “home” and the six bases “town”?

original: balavadubbalatāya. Samānepi hi etesaṃ ālayaṭṭhena visayabhāve okoti niccanivāsanaṭṭhānagehameva
analyzed: balavat ubbala tāya samāne api hi etesam ālaya ṭṭhena visaya bhāve nicca nivāsana ṭṭhāna geham eva
translated: Because of the strength and weakness of the lust and passion. For although they are alike in being the abode and the objective field, the home is called the place where one always lives, the house,

original: vuccati, niketanti “ajja asukaṭṭhāne kīḷissāmā”ti katasaṅketaṭṭhānaṃ nivāsaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: vuccati niketanti ajja asuka ṭṭhāne kīḷissāma ati kata saṅketa ṭṭhānam nivāsa ṭṭhānam
translated: and the town is the place where one has made an appointment to meet, the place where one lives, the garden, etc.,

original: uyyānādi. Tattha yathā puttadāradhanadhaññapuṇṇagehe chandarāgo balavā hoti, evaṃ
analyzed: uyyāna ādi tattha yathā putta dāra dhana dhañña puṇṇa gehe chanda rāgaḥ balavā hoti evam
translated: thinking, “Today I shall play there.” Therein, just as the lust and passion are strong in the house full of children, wife, wealth, and corn,

original: ajjhattikesu khandhesu. Yathā pana uyyānaṭṭhānādīsu tato dubbalataro hoti, evaṃ bāhiresu
analyzed: ajjhattikesu khandhesu yathā pana uyyāna ṭṭhāna ādīsu tatas dubbalataraḥ hoti evam bāhiresu
translated: so too, in regard to the internal aggregates. But just as they are weaker in the garden, etc., so too, in regard to the external bases.

original: chasu ārammaṇesūti chandarāgassa balavadubbalatāya evaṃ desanā katāti veditabbo.🔽Sukhitesu sukhitoti upaṭṭhākesu dhanadhaññalābhādivasena sukhitesu “idānāhaṃ manāpaṃ
analyzed: chasu ārammaṇesu iti chanda rāgassa balavat ubbala tāya evam desanā katā ati veditabbaḥ  sukhitesu sukhitaḥ ti upaṭṭhākesu dhana dhañña lābha ādi vasena sukhitesu idānāham manāpam
translated: Thus the teaching should be understood to have been given in this way because of the strength and weakness of lust and passion.

original: bhojanaṃ labhissāmī”ti gehasitasukhena sukhito hoti, tehi pattasampattiṃ anubhavamāno
analyzed: bhojanam labhissāmi iti geha sita sukhena sukhitaḥ hoti tehi patta sampattim anubhavamāno
translated: “Happy with those who are happy” : when the attendants are happy through the acquisition of wealth, corn, etc., he is happy with the happiness of the home, thinking, “Now I shall get to eat delicious food.” Experiencing the excellence of the alms bowl through them,

original: viya carati. Dukkhitesu dukkhitoti tesaṃ kenacideva kāraṇena dukkhe uppanne sayaṃ
analyzed: viya carati dukkhitesu dukkhitaḥ ti tesam kenacid eva kāraṇena dukkhe uppanne sayam
translated: He is one who shares the sorrow of those who are sorrowful. When they are sorrowful for some reason or other, he is himself sorrowful🔽with twice their sorrow. He is one who takes up the burden of those who are burdened. He takes up the burden of their duties, which are called “burdens,”

original: dviguṇena dukkhena dukkhito hoti. Kiccakaraṇīyesūti kiccasaṅkhātesu karaṇīyesu. Tesu🔽yogaṃ āpajjatīti upayogaṃ sayaṃ tesaṃ kiccānaṃ kattabbataṃ āpajjati. Kāmesūti vatthukāmesu.
analyzed: dviguṇena dukkhena dukkhitaḥ hoti kicca karaṇīyesu iti kicca saṅkhātesu karaṇīyesu tesu  yogam āpajjati iti upayogam sayam tesam kiccānam kattabba tam āpajjati kāmesu iti vatthu kāmesu
translated: himself, by undertaking to do them. He is one who is not greedy for sensual desires. He is not greedy for sensual desires as objects.

original: Evaṃ kho, gahapati, kāmehi aritto hotīti evaṃ kilesakāmehi aritto hoti anto kāmānaṃ
analyzed: evam kho gahapati kāmehi arittaḥ hoti iti evam kilesa kāmehi arittaḥ hoti antar kāmānam
translated: Thus, householders, he is not greedy for sensual desires. Thus he is not greedy for defilement-sensual desires. He is not empty inside with the

original: bhāvena atuccho. Sukkapakkho tesaṃ abhāvena ritto tucchoti veditabbo.
analyzed: bhāvena atucchaḥ sukkapakkho tesam abhāvena rittaḥ tucchaḥ ti veditabbo
translated: presence of sensual desires. He is empty, void, because of the absence of that side of virtue.

original: Purakkharānoti vaṭṭaṃ purato kurumāno. Evaṃrūpo siyantiādīsu dīgharassakāḷodātādīsu🔽rūpesu “evaṃrūpo nāma bhaveyya”nti pattheti. Sukhādīsu vedanāsu evaṃvedano nāma;
analyzed: vaṭṭam puratas kurumānaḥ evaṃrūpaḥ siyanti ādīsu dīgha rassa kāḷodāta ādīsu  rūpesu evaṃrūpaḥ nāma bhaveyyanti sukha ādīsu vedanāsu evaṃvedanaḥ nāma
translated: He is one who has put away the burden. He is one who has put away the round of rebirths. He is one who has put down the burden. He is one who has put down the round of rebirths. He is one who has folded the hands. He is one who has folded the round of rebirths. He is one who has crossed over. He is one who has crossed over the round of rebirths. He is one who has reached the further shore. He is one who has reached the further shore of the round of rebirths. He is one who has detached himself. He is one who has detached himself from the round of rebirths. He is one who has unyoked. He is one who has unyoked from the round of rebirths. He is one who has attained Nibbana. He is one who has attained Nibbana by not taking up any further becoming.

original: nīlasaññādīsu saññāsu evaṃ sañño nāma; puññābhisaṅkhārādīsu saṅkhāresu evaṃsaṅkhāro
analyzed: nīla saññā ādīsu saññāsu evam saññaḥ nāma puñña abhisaṅkhāra ādīsu saṅkhāresu evaṃsaṅkhāraḥ
translated: He is one who is not desirous of any kind of form, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near. He is one who is not desirous of any kind of feeling … of any kind of perception … of any kind of formations … of any kind of consciousness, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near.

original: nāma; cakkhuviññāṇādīsu viññāṇesu “evaṃ viññāṇo nāma bhaveyya”nti pattheti.🔽Apurakkharānoti vaṭṭaṃ purato akurumāno. Sahitaṃ me, asahitaṃ teti tuyhaṃ vacanaṃ
analyzed: nāma cakkhu viññāṇa ādīsu viññāṇesu evam viññāṇaḥ nāma bhaveyyanti pattheti  vaṭṭam puratas a kurumānaḥ sahitam me a sahitam te iti tuyham vacanam
translated: He hopes that the consciousnesses such as eye-consciousness will be “such consciousness.”

original: asahitaṃ asiliṭṭhaṃ, mayhaṃ sahitaṃ siliṭṭhaṃ madhurapānasadisaṃ. Adhiciṇṇaṃ te viparāvattanti
analyzed: asahitam a siliṭṭham sahitam siliṭṭham madhura pāna sadisam adhiciṇṇam te viparāvattanti
translated: Not having made the round in front: not having made the round in front of him. My view is consistent, yours is inconsistent: your view is inconsistent, unpolished, like drinking molasses. Your view has been turned back:

original: yaṃ tuyhaṃ dīghena kālena paricitaṃ suppaguṇaṃ, taṃ mama vādaṃ āgamma sabbaṃ khaṇena
analyzed: yam tuyham dīghena kālena paricitam su paguṇam tam mama vādam āgamma sabbam khaṇena
translated: what has been well-practiced by you for a long time, all that has been turned back, turned away,

original: viparāvattaṃ nivattaṃ. Āropito te vādoti tuyhaṃ doso mayā āropito. Cara vādappamokkhāyāti
analyzed: viparāvattam nivattam āropito te vādaḥ ti tuyham doso mayā āropito cara vāda ppamokkhāya ati
translated: by my view in an instant. Your view has been overthrown: your fault has been overthrown by me. Go, seek release for your view:

original: taṃ taṃ ācariyaṃ upasaṅkamitvā uttari pariyesanto imassa vādassa mokkhāya cara āhiṇḍāhi.
analyzed: tam tam ācariyam upasaṅkamitvā uttari pariyesantaḥ imassa vādassa mokkhāya cara āhiṇḍāhi
translated: going to this and that teacher, seeking further, go, wander about, seeking release for this view.

original: Nibbeṭhehi vā sace pahosīti atha sayameva pahosi, idheva nibbeṭhehīti. Tatiyaṃ.
analyzed: nibbeṭhehi vā sace pahosi iti atha sayam eva pahosi idha iva nibbeṭhehi iti tatiyam
translated: Or disentangle it if you can: but if you can do it by yourself, disentangle it right here. The third sutta.

original: 4. Dutiyahāliddikānisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya hāliddikāni sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The commentary on the second sutta on Hāliddikāni.

original: 4. Catutthe sakkapañheti cūḷasakkapañhe, mahāsakkapañhepetaṃ vuttameva. Taṇhāsaṅkhayavimuttāti
analyzed: catutthe sakka pañhā iti cūḷa sakka pañhe mahā sakka pañhe petam vuttam eva taṇhā saṅkhaya vimuttā iti
translated: In the fourth, in the Sakka questions : in the Shorter and the Longer Collections of Questions of Sakka, this has already been told. Liberated by destruction of craving :

original: taṇhāsaṅkhaye nibbāne tadārammaṇāya phalavimuttiyā vimuttā. Accantaniṭṭhāti antaṃ
analyzed: taṇhā saṅkhaye nibbāne tad ārammaṇāya phala vimuttiyā vimuttā accanta niṭṭhā ati antam
translated: they are liberated by the destruction of craving, that is, by the Nibbāna which is the object of the fruit of liberation. They have reached the ultimate :

original: atikkantaniṭṭhā satataniṭṭhā. Sesapadesupi eseva nayo. Catutthaṃ.
analyzed: atikkanta niṭṭhā satata niṭṭhā sesa padesu pi esa iva nayaḥ catuttham
translated: they have reached the ultimate by going beyond the end. They have reached the ultimate permanently. The same method of explanation applies to the other terms. The fourth.
