original: 5. Samādhisuttavaṇṇanā🔽5. Pañcame samādhinti idaṃ bhagavā te bhikkhū cittekaggatāya parihāyante disvā, “cittekaggataṃ
analyzed: samādhi sutta vaṇṇanā  pañcame samādhim ti idam bhagavā te bhikkhū citta ekagga tāya parihāyante disvā citta ekagga tam
translated: . Explanation of the Discourse on Concentration

original: labhantānaṃ imesaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ phātiṃ gamissatī”ti ñatvā āha. Abhinandatīti pattheti.
analyzed: labhantānam imesam kammaṭṭhānam phātim gamissati iti ñatvā āha abhinandati iti pattheti
translated: In the fifth, in concentration : the Blessed One said this, seeing that those bhikkhus were falling away from one-pointedness of mind. “If they obtain concentration, they will reach the culmination of this meditation subject,” he thought, and so he said this. He delights in : he longs for.

original: Abhivadatīti tāya abhinandanāya “aho piyaṃ iṭṭhaṃ kantaṃ manāpa”nti vadati. Vācaṃ
analyzed: abhivadati iti tāya abhinandanāya aho piyam iṭṭham kantam manāpanti vadati vācam
translated: He welcomes : by that delighting he welcomes it, saying “Oh, how pleasant, how dear, how agreeable!”

original: abhinandantopi ca taṃ ārammaṇaṃ nissāya evaṃ lobhaṃ uppādento abhivadatiyeva nāma.
analyzed: abhinandantaḥ api ca tam ārammaṇam nissāya evam lobham uppādentaḥ nāma
translated: And by welcoming the speech he generates greed in that way, taking that as object, and so he is said to “welcome it.”

original: Ajjhosāya tiṭṭhatīti gilitvā pariniṭṭhapetvā gaṇhāti. Yā rūpe nandīti yā sā rūpe
analyzed: ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati iti gilitvā pariniṭṭhapetvā gaṇhāti yā rūpe nandī iti yā sā rūpe
translated: He persists in seizing : he swallows it, he concludes, he grasps it. The delight in materiality :

original: balavapatthanāsaṅkhātā nandī. Tadupādānanti taṃ gahaṇaṭṭhena upādānaṃ. Nābhinandatīti🔽na pattheti. Nābhivadatīti patthanāvasena na “iṭṭhaṃ kanta”nti vadati. Vipassanācittena
analyzed: balava patthanā saṅkhātā nandī tad upādānam ti tam gahaṇa ṭṭhena upādānam na abhinandati iti  na pattheti na abhivadati iti patthanā vasena naḥ iṭṭham kantanti vadati vipassanā cittena
translated: and delight is called strong desire. “With that as condition, clinging”: that is clinging in the sense of grasping. “He does not delight in it”:🔽he does not desire it. “He does not welcome it”: by way of desire he does not say “I like it, I love it.” With insight knowledge🔽

original: cetasā “aniccaṃ dukkha”nti vacībhedaṃ karontopi nābhivadatiyeva. Pañcamaṃ.
analyzed: cetasā aniccam dukkhanti vacībhedam karontaḥ pi pañcamam
translated: Nandī is the strong wish called delight. Tadupādānaṃ means that which is clinging in the sense of grasping. Nābhinandati means he does not wish for it. Nābhivadati means he does not say “I like it, I love it” by way of wishing. He does not say it even by way of making a statement with insight knowledge, saying “It is impermanent, painful.”

original: 6. Paṭisallāṇasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: paṭisallāṇa sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The Discourse on Seclusion

original: 6. Chaṭṭhe paṭisallāṇeti idaṃ bhagavā te bhikkhū kāyavivekena parihāyante disvā “kāyavivekaṃ labhantānaṃ imesaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ phātiṃ gamissatī”ti ñatvā āha. Chaṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: chaṭṭhe paṭisallāṇa iti idam bhagavā te bhikkhū kāya vivekena parihāyante disvā kāya vivekam labhantānam imesam kammaṭṭhānam phātim gamissati iti ñatvā āha chaṭṭham
translated: In the sixth, seclusion means the Blessed One saw those monks were declining in bodily seclusion and he said this thinking, “When they get bodily seclusion, the meditation subject will be successful for them.”

original: 7. Upādāparitassanāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: upādā paritassanā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The Discourse on Clinging and Worry

original: 7. Sattame upādāparitassananti gahaṇena uppannaṃ paritassanaṃ. Anupādāaparitassananti
analyzed: sattame upādā paritassananti gahaṇena uppannam paritassanam an upādā a paritassananti
translated: In the seventh, clinging and worry means worry arisen through grasping. Non-clinging and non-worry means

original: aggahaṇena aparitassanaṃ. Rūpavipariṇāmānuparivattiviññāṇaṃ hotīti “mama rūpaṃ vipariṇata”nti
analyzed: aggahaṇena a paritassanam rūpa vipariṇāma anuparivatti viññāṇam hoti iti mama rūpam vipariṇatanti
translated: non-worry through non-grasping. Rūpavipariṇāmānuparivattiviññāṇaṃ hotīti means consciousness is subject to change in accordance with the change in material form.

original: vā “ahu vata metaṃ, dāni vata me natthī”ti vā ādinā nayena kammaviññāṇaṃ rūpassa🔽bhedānuparivatti hoti. Vipariṇāmānuparivattijāti vipariṇāmassa anuparivattito vipariṇāmārammaṇacittato
analyzed: vā ahu vata mā etam dāni vata me natthi iti vā ādinā nayena kamma viññāṇam rūpassa  bheda anuparivatti hoti vipariṇāma anuparivatti jāti vipariṇāmassa anuparivattitaḥ vipariṇāma ārammaṇa cittato
translated: “I was, but now I am not” and so on, it is the change-of-lineage consciousness that is the conascence condition for the materiality that arises with the rebirth-linking consciousness. It is the conascence condition for the materiality that arises with the first impulsion of the life-continuum. It is the conascence condition for the materiality that arises with the first impulsion of the adverting that arises next to the life-continuum. It is the conascence condition for the materiality that arises with the first impulsion of the registration that arises next to the adverting. It is the conascence condition for the materiality that arises with the first impulsion of the adverting that arises next to the registration. It is the conascence condition for the materiality that arises with the first impulsion of the life-continuum that arises next to the adverting. It is the conascence condition for the materiality that arises with the first impulsion of the registration that arises next to the life-continuum. It is the conascence condition for the materiality that arises with the first impulsion of the adverting that arises next to the registration. It is the conascence condition for the materiality that arises with the first impulsion of the life-continuum that arises next to the adverting. It is the conascence condition for the materiality that arises with the first impulsion of the registration that arises next to the life-continuum. It is the conascence condition for the materiality that arises with the first impulsion of the adverting that arises next to the registration. It is the conascence condition for the materiality that arises with the first impulsion of the life-continuum that arises next to the adverting. It is the conascence condition for the materiality that arises with the first impulsion of the registration that arises next to the life-continuum. It is the conascence condition for the materiality that arises with the first impulsion of the adverting that arises next to the registration. It is the conascence condition for the materiality that arises with the first impulsion of the life-continuum that arises next to the adverting. It is the conascence condition for the materiality that arises with the first impulsion of the registration that arises next to the life-continuum. It is the conascence condition for the materiality that arises with

original: jātā. Paritassanā dhammasamuppādāti taṇhāparitassanā ca akusaladhammasamuppādā ca.🔽Cittanti kusalacittaṃ. Pariyādāya tiṭṭhantīti pariyādiyitvā tiṭṭhanti. Uttāsavāti🔽sauttāso. Vighātavāti savighāto sadukkho. Apekkhavāti sālayo. Upādāya ca paritassatīti🔽gaṇhitvā paritassako nāma hoti. Na rūpavipariṇāmānuparivattīti khīṇāsavassa kammaviññāṇameva
analyzed: jātā paritassanā dhamma samuppādā ati taṇhā paritassanā ca akusala dhamma samuppādā ca  cittam ti kusala cittam pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti iti pariyādiyitvā tiṭṭhanti uttāsavā ati  sa uttāsaḥ vighātavāti sa vighātaḥ sa dukkhaḥ apekkha vāti sa ālayaḥ upādāya ca paritassati iti  gaṇhitvā paritassakaḥ nāma hoti na rūpa vipariṇāma anuparivattī iti khīṇāsavassa kamma viññāṇam eva
translated: “I had it before, but now I haven’t got it” and so on. It is the change-of-lineage in the sense of being the change-of-lineage in the breakup of materiality. It is born of the perception of change because it is born of the consciousness that has change as its object. The mental states of anxiety: the anxiety of craving and the mental states of demerit.

original: natthi, tasmā rūpabhedānuparivatti na hotīti vattuṃ vaṭṭati. Sattamaṃ.
analyzed: natthi tasmā rūpa bheda anuparivatti na hoti iti vattum vaṭṭati sattamam
translated: The consciousness: the profitable consciousness. It stands having overmastered: it stands having overmastered. It is frightened: it is frightened with fear. It is distressed: it is distressed with distress. It is anxious: it is anxious with anxiety. It is anxious because of clinging: it is called anxious because of anxiety due to grasping. It is not the change-of-lineage in the change of materiality: the kamma-born consciousness of one whose cankers are destroyed does not exist, and so it is proper to say that it is not the change-of-lineage in the breakup of materiality. The seventh.

original: 8. Dutiyaupādāparitassanāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya opādā paritassanā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The second exposition of anxiety due to clinging

original: 8. Aṭṭhame taṇhāmānadiṭṭhivasena desanā katā. Iti paṭipāṭiyā catūsu suttesu vaṭṭavivaṭṭameva kathitaṃ. Aṭṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: aṭṭhame taṇhā māna diṭṭhi vasena desanā katā iti paṭipāṭiyā catūsu suttesu vaṭṭa vivaṭṭam eva kathitam aṭṭhamam
translated: 8. In the eighth the teaching was given in terms of craving, conceit, and views. So in the four sutta-s in the order of sequence only the round and the breaking of the round were spoken of. The eighth.

original: 9. Kālattayaaniccasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: kāla ttaya anicca sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Sutta on the Impermanence of the Three Times.

original: 9. Navame ko pana vādo paccuppannassāti paccuppannamhi kathāva kā, aniccameva taṃ.
analyzed: navame kaḥ pana vādaḥ paccuppannassa ati paccuppannamhi kā aniccam eva tam
translated: In the ninth, what to say of the present? There is only talk about the present, it is impermanent.

original: Te kira bhikkhū atītānāgataṃ aniccanti sallakkhetvā paccuppanne kilamiṃsu, atha nesaṃ
analyzed: te kira bhikkhū atīta anāgatam aniccanti sallakkhetvā paccuppanne kilamiṃsu atha nesam
translated: It seems that those monks, after considering the past and the future as impermanent, were tired of the present, then

original: ito atītānāgatepi “paccuppannaṃ anicca”nti vuccamāne bujjhissantīti ajjhāsayaṃ viditvā
analyzed: itas atīta anāgate pi paccuppannam aniccanti vuccamāne bujjhissanti iti ajjhāsayam viditvā
translated: after knowing their intention, “They will understand when it is said that the present is impermanent, as well as the past and the future,”

original: satthā puggalajjhāsayena imaṃ desanaṃ desesi. Navamaṃ.
analyzed: satthā puggala jhāsayena imam desanam desesi navamam
translated: the Teacher gave this teaching according to the inclination of the individual. The ninth.

original: 10-11. Kālattayadukkhasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: kāla ttaya dukkha sutta ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Sutta on the Suffering of the Three Times, etc.

original: 10-11. Dasamekādasamāni dukkhaṃ anattāti padehi visesetvā tathārūpeneva puggalajjhāsayena kathitānīti. Dasamekādasamāni.
analyzed: dasam ekādasamāni dukkham anattā ati padehi visesetvā tathārūpena iva puggala jjhāsayena kathitāni iti dasam ekādasamāni
translated: In the tenth and the eleventh, after distinguishing the words “suffering” and “non-self,” they were spoken in the same way according to the inclination of the individual. The tenth and the eleventh.

original: Nakulapituvaggo paṭhamo.🔽2. Aniccavaggo
analyzed: nakula pitu vaggo paṭhamaḥ  an icca vaggaḥ
translated: The first sub-chapter on Nakula’s Father is finished.🔽The chapter on the impermanent

original: 1-10. Aniccasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Sutta on the Impermanent, etc.

original: 12-21. Aniccavagge pariyosānasuttaṃ pucchāvasikaṃ, sesāni tathā tathā bujjhanakānañca vasena desitānīti. Paṭhamādīni.🔽Aniccavaggo dutiyo.
analyzed: anicca vagge pariyosāna suttam pucchāvasikam sesāni tathā tathā bujjhanakānam ca vasena desitāni iti paṭhama ādīni  anicca vaggaḥ dutiyaḥ
translated: The last of the section on the impermanent is a question-and-answer sutta. The rest are taught in the way in which they are understood. The first, etc.

original: 3. Bhāravaggo
analyzed: bhāra vaggo
translated: The second chapter on the impermanent is finished.🔽The Burden Chapter

original: 1. Bhārasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: bhāra sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: 1. The Burden Sutta

original: 22. Bhāravaggassa paṭhame pañcupādānakkhandhātissa vacanīyanti pañcupādānakkhandhā
analyzed: bhāra vaggassa paṭhame pañca upādānakkhandhā atissa vacanīyanti pañca upādānakkhandhā
translated: “The five aggregates as objects of clinging should be spoken of as ‘burden.’🔽“This is how it should be spoken of. The meaning is: this is how it should be said.

original: iti assa vacanīyaṃ, evaṃ vattabbaṃ bhaveyyāti attho. Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhāroti
analyzed: iti assa vacanīyam evam vattabbam bhaveyya ati atthaḥ ayam vuccati bhikkhave bhāraḥ ti
translated: “Monks, this is called ‘burden.’🔽“The five aggregates as objects of clinging are called ‘burden.’

original: ye ime pañcupādānakkhandhā, ayaṃ bhāroti vuccati. Kenaṭṭhenāti? Parihārabhāriyaṭṭhena.
analyzed: ye ime pañca upādānakkhandhāḥ ayam bhāraḥ ti vuccati kena ṭṭhena ati parihāra bhāriya ṭṭhena
translated: In what sense? In the sense of being burdensome to lay down.

original: Etesañhi ṭhāpanagamananisīdāpananipajjāpananhāpanamaṇḍanakhādāpanabhuñjāpanādiparihāro
analyzed: etesam hi ṭhāpana gamana nisīdāpana nipajjāpana nhāpana maṇḍana khādāpana bhuñjāpana ādi parihāraḥ
translated: For there is no laying down, going, sitting, lying down, bathing, adorning, eating, or drinking for these.🔽Therefore, in the sense of being burdensome to lay down, they are called ‘burden.’

original: bhāriyoti parihārabhāriyaṭṭhena bhāroti vuccati. Evaṃnāmoti tisso dattotiādināmo.
analyzed: bhāriyo ti parihāra bhāriya ṭṭhena bhāro ti vuccati evaṃnāmo ti tissaḥ datto tiādi nāmo
translated: “Such a name” means a name such as Tisso, Datta, etc.

original: Evaṃgottoti kaṇhāyano vacchāyanotiādigotto. Iti vohāramattasiddhaṃ puggalaṃ “bhārahāro”ti
analyzed: evaṃgotto ti kaṇhāyanaḥ vacchāyanaḥ iti ādi gotto iti vohāra matta siddham puggalam bhāra hāraḥ ti
translated: “Such a family” means a family such as the Kanhayanas, the Vacchayanas, etc. Thus a person, who is established as a mere convention, is called “the bearer of the burden.”

original: katvā dasseti. Puggalo hi paṭisandhikkhaṇeyeva khandhabhāraṃ ukkhipitvā dasapi vassāni🔽vīsatipi vassasatampīti yāvajīvaṃ imaṃ khandhabhāraṃ nhāpento bhojento mudusamphassamañcapīṭhesu
analyzed: katvā dasseti puggalaḥ hi paṭisandhi kkhaṇeya iva khandha bhāram ukkhipitvā dasa api vassāni  vīsati pi vassa satam pi iti yāvajīvam imam khandha bhāram nhāpentaḥ bhojentaḥ mudu samphassa mañca pīṭhesu
translated: He shows it by taking it up. For the person takes up the burden of aggregates at the moment of rebirth-linking and carries it for ten years,🔽twenty years, a hundred years, a thousand years, a hundred thousand years, or even longer, bathing it, feeding it,

original: nisīdāpento nipajjāpento pariharitvā cutikkhaṇe chaḍḍetvā puna paṭisandhikkhaṇe aparaṃ
analyzed: nisīdāpentaḥ nipajjāpentaḥ pariharitvā cuti kkhaṇe chaḍḍetvā puna paṭisandhi kkhaṇe aparam
translated: causing it to sit and lie down on soft couches and chairs, and looking after it. Then at the moment of death he abandons it and takes up another burden of aggregates at the moment of rebirth-linking.

original: khandhabhāraṃ ādiyati, tasmā bhārahāroti jāto.
analyzed: khandha bhāram ādiyati tasmai bhāra hāraḥ iti jātaḥ
translated: That is why he is called a burden-bearer.

original: Ponobhavikāti punabbhavanibbattikā. Nandīrāgasahagatāti nandirāgena saha ekattameva🔽gatā. Tabbhāvasahagatañhi idha adhippetaṃ. Tatra tatrābhinandinīti upapattiṭṭhāne
analyzed: ponobhavikā ati punabbhava nibbattikā nandī rāga sahagatā ati nandi rāgena saha ekattam eva  gatā tad bhāva sahagatam hi idha adhippetam tatra tatra abhinandinī iti upapatti ṭṭhāne
translated: Leading to renewed existence: causing rebirth in a new existence. Associated with attachment and indulgence: associated with attachment and indulgence in the sense of being identical with them.

original: vā rūpādīsu vā ārammaṇesu tattha tattha abhinandanasīlāva. Kāmataṇhādīsu pañcakāmaguṇiko
analyzed: vā rūpa ādīsu vā ārammaṇesu tattha tattha kāma taṇhā ādīsu pañca kāmaguṇiko
translated: For here the state of being associated with them is intended. Indulging in this and that: having a habit of delighting in this and that place of rebirth, or in visible forms, etc., as objects.🔽Craving for sense desires, etc., is called craving for sense desires, etc.,

original: rāgo kāmataṇhā nāma, rūpārūpabhavarāgo jhānanikanti sassatadiṭṭhisahagato rāgoti
analyzed: rāgo kāma taṇhā nāma rūpa arūpa bhava rāgaḥ jhāna nikanti sassata diṭṭhi sahagataḥ rāgo ti
translated: and craving for material and immaterial becoming is called craving for becoming.

original: ayaṃ bhavataṇhā nāma, ucchedadiṭṭhisahagato rāgo vibhavataṇhā nāma. Bhārādānanti
analyzed: ayam bhava taṇhā nāma uccheda diṭṭhi sahagataḥ rāgaḥ vibhava taṇhā nāma
translated: Craving for becoming is craving accompanied by the annihilation view. Craving for non-becoming is craving accompanied by the eternity view. “Taking up a burden”:

original: bhāragahaṇaṃ. Taṇhāya hi esa bhāraṃ ādiyati. Asesavirāganirodhotiādi sabbaṃ nibbānasseva
analyzed: bhāra gahaṇam taṇhāya hi esa bhāram ādiyati asesa virāga nirodhaḥ ti ādi sabbam nibbānassa eva
translated: taking up a burden of being. For this is the taking up of a burden by craving. “Cessation by non-greed, etc.”: all this is a mere synonym for Nibbāna.

original: vevacanaṃ. Tañhi āgamma taṇhā asesato virajjati nirujjhati cajiyati paṭinissajjiyati
analyzed: vevacanam tat hi āgamma taṇhā asesataḥ virajjati nirujjhati cajiyati paṭinissajjiyati
translated: For it is through Nibbāna that craving becomes completely non-greedy, ceases, is abandoned, relinquished, and liberated.

original: vimuccati, natthi cettha kāmālayo vā diṭṭhālayo vāti nibbānaṃ etāni nāmāni labhati.
analyzed: vimuccati natthi ca ittha kāma ālayaḥ vā diṭṭha ālayaḥ vā ati nibbānam etāni nāmāni labhati
translated: And there is no more storing up of sensual desires or of views. Thus Nibbāna acquires these names.

original: Samūlaṃ taṇhanti taṇhāya avijjā mūlaṃ nāma. Abbuyhāti arahattamaggena taṃ samūlakaṃ
analyzed: sa mūlam taṇhanti taṇhāya avijjā mūlam nāma abbuyhāti arahatta maggena tam sa mūlakam
translated: “With its root”: the root of craving is ignorance. “Uprooted”: uprooted by the path of arahatship.

original: uddharitvā. Nicchāto parinibbutoti nittaṇho parinibbuto nāmāti vattuṃ vaṭṭatīti. Paṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: uddharitvā nicchātaḥ parinibbuto ti nittaṇhaḥ parinibbutaḥ nāma ati vattum vaṭṭati iti paṭhamam
translated: “Satisfied, he attains complete extinction”: he is satisfied, and it is proper to say that he attains complete extinction, that is, Nibbāna. The first.

original: 2. Pariññasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: pariñña sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The explanation of the sutta on full understanding.

original: 23. Dutiye pariññeyyeti parijānitabbe, samatikkamitabbeti attho. Pariññanti accantapariññaṃ,
analyzed: dutiye pariññeyyā iti parijānitabbe samatikkamitabbā iti attho pariññanti accanta pariññam
translated: . In the second sutta, “to be fully understood” means to be fully known, to be completely transcended. “Full understanding” is full knowledge.

original: samatikkamanti attho. Rāgakkhayotiādi nibbānassa nāmaṃ. Tañhi accantapariññā nāma. Dutiyaṃ.🔽3. Abhijānasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: samatikkamanti atthaḥ rāga kkhayaḥ ti ādi nibbānassa nāmam tat hi accantapariññā nāma dutiyam  abhijāna sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: the meaning is, they transcend it. The words “destruction of lust” and so on are names for Nibbāna. For that is the ultimate full understanding. The second …

original: 24. Tatiye abhijānanti abhijānanto. Iminā ñātapariññā kathitā, dutiyapadena tīraṇapariññā, tatiyacatutthehi pahānapariññāti imasmiṃ sutte tisso pariññā kathitāti. Tatiyaṃ.🔽4-9. Chandarāgasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: tatiye abhijānanti abhijānantaḥ iminā ñāta pariññā kathitā dutiya padena tīraṇa pariññā tatiya catutthehi pahāna pariññā ti imasmin sutte tisso pariññā kathitā ti tatiyam
translated: … In the third, “he knows” is “he understands.” This shows the full understanding by knowing. The second phrase shows the full understanding by exploring. The third and fourth phrases show the full understanding by abandoning. So in this sutta three kinds of full understanding are taught. The third …

original: 25-30. Catutthādīni dhātusaṃyutte vuttanayeneva veditabbāni. Paṭipāṭiyā panettha pañcamachaṭṭhasattamesu cattāri saccāni kathitāni, aṭṭhamanavamesu vaṭṭavivaṭṭaṃ. Catutthādīni.🔽10. Aghamūlasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: catuttha ādīni dhātusaṃyutte vutta nayena iva veditabbāni paṭipāṭiyā pana ittha pañcama chaṭṭha sattamesu cattāri saccāni kathitāni aṭṭhama navamesu vaṭṭa vivaṭṭam catuttha ādīni  agha mūla sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: … In the fourth and the rest, the three kinds of full understanding are taught in the same way as in the “Element” chapter . But in the fifth, sixth, and seventh, the four truths are taught in order. In the eighth and ninth, the round and the reversal of the round. The fourth …

original: 31. Dasame aghanti dukkhaṃ. Evamettha dukkhalakkhaṇameva kathitaṃ. Dasamaṃ.
analyzed: dasame dukkham evam ettha dukkha lakkhaṇam eva kathitam dasamam
translated: … In the tenth, “evil” is suffering. So here only the characteristic of pain is taught. The tenth …

original: 11. Pabhaṅgusuttavaṇṇanā
translated: … In the eleventh, “fracture” is the breaking up of the aggregates.

original: 32. Ekādasame pabhaṅgunti pabhijjanasabhāvaṃ. Evamidha aniccalakkhaṇameva kathitanti. Ekādasamaṃ.
analyzed: ekādasame pabhaṅgum ti pabhijjana sabhāvam evam idha anicca lakkhaṇam eva kathitam ti ekādasamam
translated: 32.In the eleventh, “broken” is the state of being broken up. So here only the characteristic of impermanence is stated. The eleventh.

original: Bhāravaggo tatiyo.🔽4. Natumhākavaggo
analyzed: bhāra vaggo tatiyo  na tumhāka vaggaḥ
translated: The third sub-chapter on burdens is finished.🔽THE SUB-CHAPTER ON WHAT IS NOT THE SELF

original: 1. Natumhākasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: natumhāka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: THE DISCOURSE ON WHAT IS NOT THE SELF

original: 33. Natumhākavaggassa paṭhame pajahathāti chandarāgappahānena pajahatha. Tiṇādīsu
analyzed: na tumhāka vaggassa paṭhame pajahatha ati chanda rāga ppahānena pajahatha tiṇa ādīsu
translated: In the first of the sub-chapter on what is not the self, “give up” means give up by abandoning desire and lust. As regards grass, etc.,

original: tiṇaṃ nāma antopheggu bahisāraṃ tālanāḷikerādi. Kaṭṭhaṃ nāma antosāraṃ bahipheggu
analyzed: tiṇam nāma antopheggu bahisāram tāla nāḷikera ādi kaṭṭham nāma antosāram bahipheggu
translated: grass is that which is soft inside and tough outside, such as coir, palm fibre, etc. Wood is that which is tough inside and soft outside,

original: khadirasālasākapanasādi. Sākhā nāma rukkhassa bāhā viya nikkhantā. Palāsaṃ nāma tālanāḷikerapaṇṇādi. Paṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: khadira sāla sāka panasa ādi sākhā nāma rukkhassa bāhā viya nikkhantā palāsam nāma tāla nāḷikera paṇṇa ādi paṭhamam
translated: such as khadira, sala, sakhua, and bread-fruit trees. Branches are what grow out like arms from a tree. Leaves are such things as palm leaves and betel leaves. The first.

original: 2. Dutiyanatumhākasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya natumhāka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: THE SECOND DISCOURSE ON WHAT IS NOT THE SELF

original: 34. Dutiyaṃ vinā upamāya bujjhanakānaṃ ajjhāsayena vuttaṃ. Dutiyaṃ.
analyzed: dutiyam vinā upamāya bujjhanakānam ajjhāsayena vuttam dutiyam
translated: The second is stated with a simile for those who understand without one. The second.

original: 3. Aññatarabhikkhusuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: aññatara bhikkhu sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: THE DISCOURSE WITH AN UNKNOWN THERA🔽In the third, “If, venerable sir, one assumes material form …

original: 35. Tatiye rūpañce, bhante, anusetīti yadi rūpaṃ anuseti. Tena saṅkhaṃ gacchatīti
analyzed: tatiye bhante anuseti iti yadi rūpam anuseti tena saṅkham gacchati iti
translated: … if one assumes consciousness, then one is reckoned by that.”

original: kāmarāgādīsu yena anusayena taṃ rūpaṃ anuseti, teneva anusayena “ratto duṭṭho mūḷho”ti🔽paṇṇattiṃ gacchati. Na tena saṅkhaṃ gacchatīti tena abhūtena anusayena “ratto duṭṭho
analyzed: kāma rāga ādīsu yena anusayena tam rūpam anuseti tena iva anusayena rattaḥ duṭṭhaḥ mūḷhaḥ ti  paṇṇattim gacchati na tena saṅkham gacchati iti tena abhūtena anusayena rattaḥ duṭṭhaḥ
translated: “He goes by the description ‘lustful, hating, deluded’ because of the underlying tendency by means of which he is lustful, hating, deluded, in regard to that materiality.

original: mūḷho”ti saṅkhaṃ na gacchatīti. Tatiyaṃ.
analyzed: mūḍhā uti saṅkham na gacchati iti tatiyam
translated: He does not go by the name ‘lustful, hating, deluded’ because of the underlying tendency that is not real in him. ”

original: 4. Dutiyaaññatarabhikkhusuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya aññatara bhikkhu sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The second sutta on a certain bhikkhu

original: 36. Catutthe taṃ anumīyatīti taṃ anusayitaṃ rūpaṃ marantena anusayena anumarati.
analyzed: catutthe tam anumīyati iti tam anusayitam rūpam marantena anusayena anumarati
translated: . In the fourth, “he infers it”: he infers that materiality by means of the underlying tendency that is dying in him.

original: Na hi ārammaṇe bhijjamāne tadārammaṇā dhammā tiṭṭhanti. Yaṃ anumīyatīti yaṃ rūpaṃ🔽yena anusayena anumarati. Tena saṅkhaṃ gacchatīti tena anusayena “ratto duṭṭho mūḷho”ti🔽saṅkhaṃ gacchati. Atha vā yanti karaṇavacanametaṃ, yena anusayena anumīyati, tena
analyzed: na hi ārammaṇe bhijjamāne tad ārammaṇāḥ dhammāḥ tiṭṭhanti yam anumīyati iti yam rūpam  yena anusayena anumarati tena saṅkham gacchati iti tena anusayena rattaḥ duṭṭhaḥ mūḷhaḥ iti  saṅkham gacchati atha vā yanti karaṇa vacanam etam yena anusayena anumīyati tena
translated: For when the object is broken up, the states that had that as their object do not continue. “What he infers”: the materiality

original: “ratto duṭṭho mūḷho”ti saṅkhaṃ gacchatīti attho. Catutthaṃ.
analyzed: rattaḥ duṭṭhaḥ mūḷhaḥ iti saṅkham gacchati iti catuttham
translated: “He goes by the name ‘lustful, hating, deluded’ because of the underlying tendency by means of which he infers it”: he goes by the name “lustful, hating, deluded” because of that underlying tendency. Or alternatively, the word yanti is a gerundive; the meaning is: “He goes by the name ‘lustful, hating, deluded’ because of the underlying tendency by means of which he infers it.”

original: 5-6. Ānandasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: . Commentary on the Ānanda Sutta, etc.

original: 37-38. Pañcame ṭhitassa aññathattaṃ paññāyatīti dharamānassa jīvamānassa jarā paññāyati. Ṭhitīti hi jīvitindriyasaṅkhātāya anupālanāya nāmaṃ. Aññathattanti jarāya. Tenāhu porāṇā –
analyzed: pañcame ṭhitassa aññathattam paññāyati iti dharamānassa jīvamānassa jarā paññāyati ṭhitī iti hi jīvitindriya saṅkhātāya anupālanāya nāmam aññathattanti jarāya tena āhu porāṇā
translated: In the fifth, the alteration of what is set up is evident. Aging is evident in what is set up, in what is living, for “set up” is a term for the life faculty’s persistence, and “alteration” is aging. Hence the Ancients said:🔽“Arising is called birth,

original: “Uppādo jāti akkhāto, bhaṅgo vutto vayoti ca;
analyzed: uppādaḥ jāti akkhātaḥ bhaṅgaḥ vuttaḥ vayaḥ ti ca
translated: And ending is called aging;🔽Alteration is called aging,

original: Aññathattaṃ jarā vuttā, ṭhitī ca anupālanā”ti.
analyzed: aññathattam jarā vuttā ṭhitī ca anupālanā ati
translated: And persistence is called keeping going” .

original: Evaṃ ekekassa khandhassa uppādajarābhaṅgasaṅkhātāni tīṇi lakkhaṇāni honti yāni sandhāya vuttaṃ “tīṇimāni, bhikkhave, saṅkhatassa saṅkhatalakkhaṇānī”ti.
analyzed: evam ekekassa khandhassa uppāda jarā bhaṅga saṅkhātāni tīṇi lakkhaṇāni honti yāni sandhāya vuttam tīṇi imāni bhikkhave saṅkhatassa saṅkhata lakkhaṇāni iti
translated: So each of the aggregates has three characteristics called respectively arising, aging, and dissolution. It is with reference to these that it is said, “Bhikkhus, there are these three characteristics of the conditioned that relate to the conditioned” .

original: Tattha saṅkhataṃ nāma paccayanibbatto yo koci saṅkhāro. Saṅkhāro ca na lakkhaṇaṃ,
analyzed: tattha saṅkhatam nāma paccaya nibbattaḥ yaḥ koci saṅkhāro saṅkhāro ca na lakkhaṇam
translated: Herein, the “conditioned” is any formed thing that is created by conditions. The “conditioned” is not a characteristic,

original: lakkhaṇaṃ na saṅkhāro, na ca saṅkhārena vinā lakkhaṇaṃ paññāpetuṃ sakkā, nāpi lakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: lakkhaṇam na saṅkhāraḥ na ca saṅkhārena vinā lakkhaṇam paññāpetum sakkā na api lakkhaṇam
translated: and a characteristic is not the “conditioned.” Nor can a characteristic be demonstrated apart from the conditioned, nor can a conditioned be demonstrated apart from a characteristic,

original: vinā saṅkhāro, lakkhaṇena pana saṅkhāro pākaṭo hoti. Yathā hi na ca gāvīyeva lakkhaṇaṃ,
analyzed: vinā saṅkhāraḥ lakkhaṇena pana saṅkhāraḥ pākaṭaḥ hoti yathā hi na ca gāvīyā iva lakkhaṇam
translated: but the conditioned is evident through a characteristic. Just as a cow is not a bull,

original: lakkhaṇameva na gāvī, nāpi gāviṃ muñcitvā lakkhaṇaṃ paññāpetuṃ sakkā, nāpi lakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: lakkhaṇam eva na gāvī na api gāvim muñcitvā lakkhaṇam paññāpetum sakkā na api lakkhaṇam
translated: The characteristic itself is not the cow, nor can the cow be pointed out apart from the characteristic. Nor can the characteristic be pointed out apart from the cow.

original: muñcitvā gāviṃ, lakkhaṇena pana gāvī pākaṭā hoti, evaṃsampadamidaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: muñcitvā gāvim lakkhaṇena pana gāvī pākaṭā hoti evaṃsampadam idam veditabbam
translated: But the cow is evident through the characteristic. This is how it should be understood.

original: Tattha saṅkhārānaṃ uppādakkhaṇe saṅkhāropi uppādalakkhaṇampi kālasaṅkhāto tassa khaṇopi
analyzed: tattha saṅkhārānaṃ uppāda khaṇe saṅkhāraḥ api uppāda lakkhaṇam pi kāla saṅkhātaḥ tassa khaṇaḥ api
translated: Herein, at the moment of the arising of formations, the formation itself and the characteristic of arising are evident as the moment of that formation reckoned as a unit of time.

original: paññāyati. “Uppādopī”ti vutte saṅkhāropi jarālakkhaṇampi kālasaṅkhāto tassa khaṇopi
analyzed: paññāyati uppādaḥ api iti vutte saṅkhāro api jarā lakkhaṇam pi kāla saṅkhāto tassa khaṇaḥ api
translated: When it is said “arising,” the formation itself and the characteristic of ageing and the moment of that formation reckoned as a unit of time are evident.

original: paññāyati. Bhaṅgakkhaṇe saṅkhāropi taṃlakkhaṇampi kālasaṅkhāto tassa khaṇopi paññāyati.
analyzed: paññāyati bhaṅga kkhaṇe saṅkhāraḥ api taṃ lakkhaṇam pi kāla saṅkhāto tassa khaṇaḥ api paññāyati
translated: At the moment of dissolution, the formation itself and that characteristic are evident as the moment of that formation reckoned as a unit of time.

original: Apare pana vadanti “arūpadhammānaṃ jarākhaṇo nāma na sakkā paññāpetuṃ, sammāsambuddho
analyzed: apare pana vadanti arūpa dhammānam jarākhaṇaḥ nāma na sakkā paññāpetum sammāsambuddhaḥ
translated: But others say that the moment of ageing of immaterial states cannot be demonstrated. And the Fully Enlightened One,

original: ca ‘vedanāya uppādo paññāyati, vayo paññāyati, ṭhitāya aññathattaṃ paññāyatī’ti vadanto
analyzed: ca vedanāya uppādo paññāyati vayo paññāyati ṭhitāya aññathattam paññāyati iti vadanto
translated: in saying, “The arising of feeling is evident, its passing away is evident, its change while present is evident” ,

original: arūpadhammānampi tīṇi lakkhaṇāni paññāpeti, tāni atthikkhaṇaṃ upādāya labbhantī”ti vatvā –
analyzed: arūpa dhammānam pi tīṇi lakkhaṇāni paññāpeti tāni atthi kkhaṇam upādāya labbhanti iti vatvā
translated: demonstrates the three characteristics of immaterial states too. They are found by taking the moment of their existence.

original: “Atthitā sabbadhammānaṃ, ṭhiti nāma pavuccati;
analyzed: atthi tā sabba dhammānam ṭhiti nāma pavuccati
translated: “The presence of all things Is called their ‘presence’;

original: Tasseva bhedo maraṇaṃ, sabbadā sabbapāṇina”nti. –
analyzed: tassa iva bhedaḥ maraṇam sabbadā sabba pāṇinaṃ ti
translated: Their dissolution is their ‘death,’ Always of all living beings.”

original: Imāya ācariyagāthāya tamatthaṃ sādhenti. Atha vā santativasena ṭhānaṃ ṭhitīti veditabbanti
analyzed: imāya ācariya gāthāya tam attham sādhenti atha vā santati vasena ṭhānam ṭhitī iti veditabbanti
translated: They explain the meaning of the passage in the Teacher’s words by means of this verse. Or else they say that “presence” should be understood in the sense of continuity.

original: ca vadanti. Yasmā pana sutte ayaṃ viseso natthi, tasmā ācariyamatiyā suttaṃ apaṭibāhetvā
analyzed: ca vadanti yasmā pana sutte ayam visesaḥ natthi tasmā ācariya matiyā suttam a paṭibāhetvā
translated: But since there is no such distinction in the sutta, the sutta should not be contradicted by the teacher’s opinion,

original: suttameva pamāṇaṃ kattabbaṃ. Chaṭṭhaṃ uttānameva. Pañcamachaṭṭhāni.
analyzed: suttam eva pamāṇam kattabbam chaṭṭham uttānam eva pañcama chaṭṭhāni
translated: and the sutta itself should be taken as the measure. The sixth is plain. The fifth and sixth.

original: 7-10. Anudhammasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The seventh is called “The Thread of the True Idea” .

original: 39-42. Sattame dhammānudhammappaṭipannassāti navannaṃ lokuttaradhammānaṃ anulomadhammaṃ🔽pubbabhāgapaṭipadaṃ paṭipannassa. Ayamanudhammoti ayaṃ anulomadhammo hoti. Nibbidābahuloti
analyzed: sattame dhamma anudhamma ppaṭipannassa ati navannam lokuttara dhammānam anuloma dhammaṃ  pubbabhāga paṭipadam paṭipannassa ayam anudhammaḥ ti ayam anuloma dhammo hoti nibbidā bahulo ti
translated: In the seventh, “of one who has entered upon the way of ideas in conformity with the True Idea” , he has entered upon the way of ideas in conformity with the nine kinds of supramundane ideas, that is to say, the way of preparation.

original: ukkaṇṭhanabahulo hutvā. Parijānātīti tīhi pariññāhi parijānāti. Parimuccatīti maggakkhaṇe
analyzed: ukkaṇṭhana bahulaḥ hutvā parijānāti iti tīhi pariññāhi parijānāti parimuccati iti magga kkhaṇe
translated: “This is the conformity” : this is the conformity with the True Idea. “He is abundant in dispassion” : having become abundant in disgust. “He fully understands” : he fully understands by means of the three kinds of full understanding. “He is liberated” : at the moment of the path.

original: uppannāya pahānapariññāya parimuccati. Evaṃ imasmiṃ sutte maggova kathito hoti, tathā
analyzed: uppannāya pahāna pariññāya parimuccati evam imasmin sutte maggaḥ uva kathitaḥ hoti tathā
translated: and he is liberated by the full-understanding of abandoning that has arisen. So in this Thread the path is taught.🔽And so too in the other three. But here the contemplation is not specified, while in those three it is specified.

original: ito paresu tīsu. Idha pana anupassanā aniyamitā, tesu niyamitā. Tasmā idhāpi sā tattha
analyzed: itas paresu tīsu idha pana anupassanā aniyamitā tesu niyamitā tasmā idha api sā tattha
translated: So here too it should be specified by the method of specifying in those three.

original: niyamitavaseneva niyametabbā. Na hi sakkā tīsu aññataraṃ anupassanaṃ vinā nibbindituṃ
analyzed: niyamita vasena iva niyametabbāḥ na hi sakkā tīsu aññataram anupassanam vinā nibbinditum
translated: For it is not possible to become dispassionate and understand completely without contemplating one or other of the three.

original: parijānituṃ vāti. Sattamādīni.
analyzed: parijānitum vāti sattama ādīni
translated: The seventh and following .

original: Natumhākavaggo catuttho.🔽5. Attadīpavaggo
analyzed: natumhāka vaggo catutthaḥ  atta dīpa vaggo
translated: The fourth sub-chapter on “Not yours” is finished.🔽THE SUB-CHAPTER ON THE SELF AS ISLAND

original: 1. Attadīpasuttavaṇṇanā🔽43. Attadīpavaggassa paṭhame attadīpāti attānaṃ dīpaṃ tāṇaṃ leṇaṃ gatiṃ parāyaṇaṃ
analyzed: attadīpa sutta vaṇṇanā  atta dīpa vaggassa paṭhame atta dīpā ati attānam dīpam tāṇam leṇam gatim parāyaṇam
translated: The Sutta on the Self as Island, the first, in the Sub-chapter on the Self as Island.🔽“Make yourselves an island depending on yourselves, make yourselves an island depending on the Truth” : the meaning is that you should live making the self your island, your refuge, your resort, your recourse, your final support.

original: patiṭṭhaṃ katvā viharathāti attho. Attasaraṇāti idaṃ tasseva vevacanaṃ. Anaññasaraṇāti
analyzed: patiṭṭham katvā viharatha ati atthaḥ atta saraṇā ati idam tassa iva vevacanam anañña saraṇā ti
translated: “Make yourselves a refuge depending on no-other” : this is a synonym for that.🔽“Make yourselves a refuge depending on no-other” : this is a statement of the denial of another’s refuge.

original: idaṃ aññassa saraṇapaṭikkhepavacanaṃ. Na hi añño aññassa saraṇaṃ hoti aññassa vāyāmena
analyzed: idam aññassa saraṇa paṭikkhepa vacanam na hi aññaḥ aññassa saraṇam hoti aññassa vā āyāmena
translated: For one does not make another his refuge, since one who is another’s refuge is not one’s own.

original: aññassa asijjhanato, vuttampi cetaṃ –
analyzed: aññassa a sijjhanataḥ vuttam pi ca itam
translated: And this is said:

original: “Attā hi attano nātho,
analyzed: attā hi attanaḥ nātho
translated: “The self is the refuge of the self,

original: Ko hi nātho paro siyā”ti. ;
analyzed: kaḥ hi nāthaḥ paraḥ siyāti
translated: Who else could be the refuge?”

original: Tenāha “anaññasaraṇā”ti. Ko panettha attā nāma? Lokiyalokuttaro dhammo. Tenevāha🔽– “dhammadīpā dhammasaraṇā anaññasaraṇā”ti. Yonīti kāraṇaṃ – “yoni hesā, bhūmija,🔽phalassa adhigamāyā”tiādīsu viya. Kiṃpahotikāti kiṃpabhutikā, kuto pabhavantīti attho?🔽Rūpassa tvevāti idaṃ tesaṃyeva sokādīnaṃ pahānadassanatthaṃ āraddhaṃ. Na paritassatīti
analyzed: tena āha anañña saraṇā ti kaḥ pana ittha attā nāma lokiya lokuttaraḥ dhammo tena iva āha  dhamma dīpā dhamma saraṇā anañña saraṇā ati yoni iti kāraṇam  phalassa adhigamāya atiādīsu viya kiṃpahotikā ati kiṃpabhutikā kutas pabhavanti iti attho  rūpassa tu eva ati idam tesam yeva soka ādīnam pahāna dassana ttham āraddham na paritassati iti
translated: Hence the words “having no other refuge” . But what is this self ? It is the mundane and supramundane dhammas . Therefore it is said:🔽“Having the Dhamma as their island, having the Dhamma as their refuge, having no other refuge” . Yoni means cause, as in the passages:🔽“This is the cause, O earth-born,🔽for the attainment of the fruit” . Kiṃpahotikā means what is it that is produced from what? What is it that arises from what?🔽Rūpassa tvevāti . This is stated in order to show the abandoning of sorrow, etc. Na paritassati means he does not tremble.

original: na gaṇhāti na gahati. Tadaṅganibbutoti tena vipassanaṅgena kilesānaṃ nibbutattā tadaṅganibbuto.🔽Imasmiṃ sutte vipassanāva kathitā. Paṭhamaṃ.🔽2. Paṭipadāsuttavaṇṇanā🔽44. Dutiye dukkhasamudayagāminī samanupassanāti yasmā sakkāyo dukkhaṃ, tassa ca samudayagāminī🔽paṭipadā nāma “rūpaṃ attato samanupassatī”ti evaṃ diṭṭhisamanupassanā vuttā, tasmā
analyzed: na gaṇhāti na gahati tad aṅga nibbuto ti tena vipassana aṅgena kilesānam nibbuta ttā tad aṅga nibbutaḥ 🔽imasmin sutte vipassanā va kathitā paṭhamam 🔽       🔽dutiye dukkha samudaya gāminī samanupassanā ati yasmā sa kāyaḥ dukkham tassa ca samudaya gāminī 🔽paṭipadā nāma rūpam attataḥ samanupassati iti evam diṭṭhi samanupassanā vuttā tasmā
translated: Hence the words “having no other refuge” . But what is this self ? It is a state, mundane or supramundane. Hence the words “having the True Idea as their island, having the True Idea as their refuge, having no other refuge” . The word yoni means cause, as in the passages “This is the cause, O earth-born, for the discovery of the fruit” , and so on. What is it like? What is its origin? What is its source? original: dukkhasamudayagāminī samanupassanāti ayamettha attho hoti. Dukkhanirodhagāminī samanupassanāti
analyzed: dukkha samudaya gāminī samanupassanā ati ayam ettha atthaḥ hoti dukkha nirodha gāminī samanupassanā ati
translated: The meaning here is that of a survey leading to the origin of suffering. A survey leading to the cessation of suffering is

original: ettha saha vipassanāya catumaggañāṇaṃ “samanupassanā”ti vuttaṃ. Iti imasmiṃ sutte
analyzed: ettha saha vipassanāya catu magga ñāṇam samanupassanā ti vuttam iti imasmim sutte
translated: here the four path-knowledges together with insight are called “survey.” So in this sutta

original: vaṭṭavivaṭṭaṃ kathitaṃ. Dutiyaṃ.
analyzed: vaṭṭa vivaṭṭam kathitam dutiyam
translated: the round and the reversal of the round are stated. The second sutta is finished.

original: 3. Aniccasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: anicca sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The exposition of the third sutta

original: 45. Tatiye sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbanti saha vipassanāya maggapaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ. Virajjati
analyzed: tatiye sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbanti saha vipassanāya magga paññāya daṭṭhabbam virajjati
translated: . “With right understanding”: to be seen with the path understanding together with insight. “Is dispassionate”

original: vimuccatīti maggakkhaṇe virajjati, phalakkhaṇe vimuccati. Anupādāya āsavehīti anuppādanirodhena
analyzed: vimuccati iti magga kkhaṇe virajjati phala kkhaṇe vimuccati an upādāya āsavehi iti anuppāda nirodhena
translated: “is liberated” : at the moment of the path it is dispassionate; at the moment of fruition it is liberated. “Without clinging he is freed from the taints”: without clinging through the cessation of the taints by their non-arising

original: niruddhehi āsavehi agahetvā iti vimuccati. Rūpadhātuyātiādi paccavekkhaṇadassanatthaṃ🔽vuttaṃ. Saha phalena paccavekkhaṇadassanatthantipi vadantiyeva. Ṭhitanti upari kattabbakiccābhāvena
analyzed: niruddhehi āsavehi a gahetvā iti vimuccati rūpadhātuyā ati ādi paccavekkhaṇa dassana ttham  vuttam saha phalena paccavekkhaṇa dassana attham ti pi vadantiyā iva ṭhitan ti upari kattabba kicca abhāvena
translated: he is liberated. “In the element of form” and so on is said

original: ṭhitaṃ. Ṭhitattā santussitanti pattabbaṃ pattabhāvena santuṭṭhaṃ. Paccattaṃyeva parinibbāyatīti
analyzed: ṭhitam ṭhita ttā santussitanti pattabbam patta bhāvena santuṭṭham paccattam yeva parinibbāyati iti
translated: for the purpose of reviewing-seeing. They say that it is also for the purpose of reviewing-seeing together with the fruit. “Abides”: abides because there is no further task to be done. “Being content with that”: being satisfied with what has been attained, as what has to be attained. “Attains Parinibbana in this very life”🔽.

original: sayameva parinibbāyati. Tatiyaṃ.
analyzed: sayam eva parinibbāyati tatiyam
translated: he attains Nibbāna by himself. The third.

original: 4. Dutiyaaniccasuttavaṇṇanā🔽46. Catutthe pubbantānudiṭṭhiyoti pubbantaṃ anugatā aṭṭhārasa diṭṭhiyo na honti.
analyzed: dutiya anicca sutta vaṇṇanā  catutthe pubbanta anudiṭṭhiyaḥ ti pubbantam anugatāḥ aṭṭhārasa diṭṭhiyaḥ na honti
translated: The commentary on the second sutta on impermanence.🔽In the fourth, the view of the past is the eighteen views that follow the past.

original: Aparantānudiṭṭhiyoti aparantaṃ anugatā catucattālīsa diṭṭhiyo na honti. Thāmaso parāmāsoti
analyzed: aparanta anudiṭṭhiyaḥ ti aparantam anugatā catucattālīsa diṭṭhiyaḥ na honti thāmaso parāmāso ti
translated: The view of the future is the forty-four views that follow the future. The darkness of views and the height of views are not.

original: diṭṭhithāmaso ceva diṭṭhiparāmāso ca na hoti. Ettāvatā paṭhamamaggo dassito. Idāni
analyzed: diṭṭhi thāmaso ca iva diṭṭhi parāmāso ca na hoti ettāvatā paṭhama maggaḥ dassito idāni
translated: So far the first path has been shown. Now,

original: saha vipassanāya tayo magge ca phalāni ca dassetuṃ rūpasmintiādi āraddhaṃ. Atha vā🔽diṭṭhiyo nāma vipassanāya eva pahīnā, idaṃ pana upari saha vipassanāya cattāro magge
analyzed: saha vipassanāya tayo magge ca phalāni ca dassetum rūpasmin tiādi āraddham atha vā  diṭṭhiyaḥ nāma vipassanāya eva pahīnā idam pana upari saha vipassanāya cattāro magge
translated: in order to show the three paths and the fruits together with insight, “in form” is begun. Or else,

original: dassetuṃ āraddhaṃ. Catutthaṃ.🔽5. Samanupassanāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dassetum āraddham catuttham  samanupassanā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: views are abandoned only by insight, but this is begun in order to show the four paths above together with insight. The fourth.🔽The commentary on the sutta on contemplation.

original: 47. Pañcame pañcupādānakkhandhe samanupassanti etesaṃ vā aññataranti paripuṇṇagāhavasena
analyzed: pañcame pañca upādānakkhandhe samanupassanti etesam vā aññataranti paripuṇṇa gāha vasena
translated: In the fifth, they contemplate the five aggregates as objects of clinging or one of them, by way of a complete grasping.

original: pañcakkhandhe samanupassanti, aparipuṇṇagāhavasena etesaṃ aññataraṃ. Iti ayañceva🔽samanupassanāti iti ayañca diṭṭhisamanupassanā. Asmīti cassa avigataṃ hotīti yassa
analyzed: pañca kkhandhe samanupassanti a paripuṇṇa gāha vasena etesam aññataram iti ayam ca eva  samanupassanā ti iti ayaṃ ca diṭṭhi samanupassanā asmi iti cassa avigatam hoti iti yassa
translated: They regard the five aggregates as self, or as belonging to self, in the sense of grasping them as complete. Thus this

original: ayaṃ samanupassanā atthi, tasmiṃ asmīti taṇhāmānadiṭṭhisaṅkhātaṃ papañcattayaṃ avigatameva🔽hoti. Pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ avakkanti hotīti tasmiṃ kilesajāte sati kammakilesapaccayānaṃ
analyzed: ayam samanupassanā atthi tasmin asmi iti taṇhā māna diṭṭhi saṅkhātam papañcattayam avigatam eva  hoti pañcannam indriyānam avakkanti hoti iti tasmin kilesa jāte sati kamma kilesa paccayānaṃ
translated: is the contemplation of views. As to “the thought ‘I am’ has not been abandoned in him”: in him who has this contemplation, the three-fold proliferation, called craving, conceit, and views, which is called “the thought ‘I am,’” has not been abandoned.

original: pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ nibbatti hoti.🔽Atthi, bhikkhave, manoti idaṃ kammamanaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Dhammāti ārammaṇaṃ. Avijjādhātūti
analyzed: pañcannam indriyānam nibbatti hoti  atthi bhikkhave manaḥ ti idam kamma manam sandhāya vuttam dhammā ati ārammaṇam avijjā dhātū ti
translated: The five faculties come into activity: when that proliferation of defilements is present, the five faculties come into existence with kamma-defilement as their condition.

original: javanakkhaṇe avijjā. Avijjāsamphassajenāti avijjāsampayuttaphassato jātena. Apica
analyzed: java nakkhaṇe avijjā avijjā samphassa jena ati avijjā sampayutta phassataḥ jātena api ca
translated: “There is mind, bhikkhus”: this is said with reference to the kamma-process mind. “Ideas”: objects. “The element of ignorance”: ignorance at the impulsion moment. “Arisen from contact associated with ignorance”: arisen from contact associated with ignorance. Furthermore,

original: manoti bhavaṅgakkhaṇe vipākamanodhātu, āvajjanakkhaṇe kiriyamanodhātu. Dhammādayo
analyzed: manaḥ ti bhavaṅga khaṇe vipāka manaḥ dhātu āvajjana kkhaṇe kiriya manaḥ dhātu dhamma ādayaḥ
translated: “mind” is the resultant mind element at the life-continuum moment and the functional mind element at the adverting moment. “Ideas” and so on are the objects of the mind element.

original: vuttappakārāva. Asmītipissa hotīti taṇhāmānadiṭṭhivasena asmīti evampissa hoti. Ito🔽paresu ayamahamasmīti rūpādīsu kiñcideva dhammaṃ gahetvā “ayaṃ ahamasmī”ti attadiṭṭhivasena🔽vuttaṃ. Bhavissanti sassatadiṭṭhivasena. Na bhavissanti ucchedadiṭṭhivasena. Rūpī🔽bhavissantiādīni sabbāni sassatameva bhajanti. Athetthāti atha tenevākārena ṭhitesu🔽etesu indriyesu. Avijjā pahīyatīti catūsu saccesu aññāṇabhūtā avijjā pahīyati. Vijjā
analyzed: vutta ppakārā ava asmi iti pi sassa hoti iti taṇhā māna diṭṭhi vasena asmi iti evam pi sassa hoti ito  paresu ayam aham asmi iti rūpa ādīsu kiñcid eva dhammam gahetvā ayam aham asmi iti atta diṭṭhi vasena  vuttam bhavissanti sassata diṭṭhi vasena na bhavissanti uccheda diṭṭhi vasena rūpī  bhavissanti ādīni sabbāni sassatam eva bhajanti atha itthā iti atha tena iva ākārena ṭhitesu  etesu indriyesu avijjā pahīyati iti catūsu saccesu aññāṇa bhūtā avijjā pahīyati vijjā
translated: and so on. “He thinks ‘I am’: ” he thinks “I am” in the way already stated by the terms “craving, conceit, and views.”🔽“He thinks ‘I am this’ ” is said with reference to the conceiving of self in some such particular thing as material form, etc.,🔽“He thinks ‘I will be’ ” is with reference to eternalism, and “He thinks ‘I will not be’ ” to annihilationism.🔽“He thinks ‘It is mind that is the link of identity’ ” and so on all belong to eternalism.🔽“Then, with the cessation of that perception, he thinks ‘I am’ ”: then, with the cessation of that perception in the way stated, he thinks “I am” in the way already stated by the terms “craving, conceit, and views.”🔽“Ignorance is abandoned”: ignorance, which is the state of non-penetration of the four truths, is abandoned.

original: uppajjatīti arahattamaggavijjā uppajjati. Evamettha asmīti taṇhāmānadiṭṭhiyo. Kammassa🔽pañcannañca indriyānaṃ antare eko sandhi, vipākamanaṃ pañcindriyapakkhikaṃ katvā🔽pañcannañca indriyānaṃ kammassa ca antare eko sandhīti. Iti tayo papañcā atīto addhā,
analyzed: uppajjati iti arahatta magga vijjā uppajjati evam ettha asmi iti taṇhā māna diṭṭhiyaḥ kammassa 🔽antare sandhi vipāka manam pañca indriya pakkhikam katvā 🔽indriyānam kammassa ca antare ekaḥ sandhi iti iti tayo papañcā atītaḥ addhā
translated: and so on. “He thinks ‘I am’: “He thinks thus ‘I am’ through craving, conceit, and views. “From here onwards, “I am this” is said through the view of self by taking some state among the forms, etc., “I am this.” “I will be” is said through the view of eternity. “I will not be” is said through the view of annihilation. “I will possess form” and the rest are all included in the view of eternity. “Then, in regard to this”: then, in regard to these faculties that remain in the same mode. “Ignorance is abandoned”: ignorance, which is non-penetration of the four truths, is abandoned. “True knowledge arises”: the knowledge of the path of arahatship arises. Thus here “I am” is said through craving, conceit, and views. “I will be” is said through the view of eternity. “I will not be” is said through the view of annihilation. “I will possess form” and the rest are all included in the view of eternity. “Then, in regard to this”: then, in regard to these faculties that remain in the same mode. “Ignorance is abandoned”: ignorance, which is non-penetration of the four truths, is abandoned. “True knowledge arises”: the knowledge of the path of arahatship arises. Thus here “I am” is said through craving, conceit, and views. “I will be” is said through the view of eternity. “I will not be” is said through the view of annihilation. “I will possess form” and the rest are all included in the view of eternity. “Then, in regard to this”: then, in regard to these faculties that remain in the same mode. “Ignorance is abandoned”: ignorance, which is non-penetration of the four truths, is abandoned. “True knowledge arises”: the knowledge of the path of arahatship arises. Thus here “I am” is said through craving, conceit, and views. “I will be” is said through the view of eternity. “I will not be” is said through the view of annihilation. “I will possess form” and the rest are all included in the view of eternity. “Then, in regard to this”: then, in regard to these faculties that remain in the same mode. “Ignorance is abandoned”: ignorance, which is non-penetration of the four truths, is abandoned. “

original: indriyādīni paccuppanno addhā, tattha kammamanaṃ ādiṃ katvā anāgatassa paccayo dassitoti. Pañcamaṃ.🔽6. Khandhasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: indriya ādīni paccuppannaḥ addhā tattha kamma manaṃ ādim katvā anāgatassa paccayaḥ dassito ti pañcamam  khandha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the aggregates

original: 48. Chaṭṭhe rūpakkhandho kāmāvacaro, cattāro khandhā catubhūmakā. Sāsavanti āsavānaṃ
analyzed: chaṭṭhe rūpa khandho kāmāvacaro cattāro khandhā catu bhūmakā sa āsavanti āsavānaṃ
translated: In the sixth, the form aggregate is of the sense sphere; the other four aggregates are of four planes. Contaminated means that they are a condition for defilements by being their object.

original: ārammaṇabhāvena paccayabhūtaṃ. Upādāniyanti tatheva ca upādānānaṃ paccayabhūtaṃ.
analyzed: ārammaṇa bhāvena paccaya bhūtam upādāniyanti tathā iva ca upādānānam paccaya bhūtam
translated: Upādinna means that they are a condition for the kinds of clinging in the same way.🔽The meaning of the words is this: associated with the defilements that occur by making them one’s object is contaminated.

original: Vacanattho panettha – ārammaṇaṃ katvā pavattehi saha āsavehīti sāsavaṃ. Upādātabbanti
analyzed: vacana atthaḥ pana ittha ārammaṇam katvā pavattehi saha āsavehi iti sa āsavam upādātabbanti
translated: What is to be clung to is upādinna.

original: upādāniyaṃ. Idhāpi rūpakkhandho kāmāvacaro, avasesā tebhūmakā vipassanācāravasena
analyzed: upādāniyam idha api rūpakkhandho kāma avacaraḥ avasesā tebhūmakā vipassanā ācāra vasena
translated: Here too the form aggregate is of the sense sphere; the rest are of three planes. They are stated according to the practice of insight.

original: vuttā. Evamettha rūpaṃ rāsaṭṭhena khandhesu paviṭṭhaṃ, sāsavarāsaṭṭhena upādānakkhandhesu.
analyzed: vuttā evam ettha rūpam rāsaṭṭhena khandhesu paviṭṭham sāsava rāsaṭṭhena upādāna khandhesu
translated: Thus here form is included among the aggregates by way of the class “mass”; in the case of the clinging-aggregates, it is included by way of the class “contaminated mass.”

original: Vedanādayo sāsavāpi atthi, anāsavāpi atthi. Te rāsaṭṭhena sabbepi khandhesu paviṭṭhā,
analyzed: vedanā ādayo sa āsavā api atthi anāsavā api atthi te rāsaṭṭhena sabbe pi khandhesu paviṭṭhā
translated: Feeling, etc., are some of them contaminated and some uncontaminated. They are all included among the aggregates by way of the class “mass.”

original: tebhūmakā panettha sāsavaṭṭhena upādānakkhandhesu paviṭṭhāti. Chaṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: tebhūmakā pana ittha sāsava ṭṭhena upādāna khandhesu paviṭṭhā ati chaṭṭham
translated: But here they are included in the categories of clinging that are subject to cankers in the sense of the round of rebirths in the three worlds. The sixth .

original: 7-8. Soṇasuttādivaṇṇanā🔽49-50. Sattame seyyohamasmīti visiṭṭho uttamo ahamasmi. Kimaññatra yathābhūtassa
analyzed: sattame seyya uham asmi iti visiṭṭhaḥ uttamaḥ aham asmi kim aññatra yathābhūtassa
translated: The seventh is called “The Discourse with Soṇa” .

original: adassanāti yathābhūtassa adassanato aññaṃ kiṃ bhaveyya? Adassanaṃ aññāṇameva bhaveyyāti
analyzed: adassanā ati yathābhūtassa a dassanataḥ aññam kim bhaveyya adassanam aññāṇam eva bhaveyya ati
translated: In the seventh, “I am better” : I am superior, I am the best. “What else is there apart from not seeing what is” : what else could there be apart from not seeing what is ? The meaning is that it would be mere non-seeing, mere non-knowing.

original: attho. Idānissa te parivaṭṭaṃ vajirabhedadesanaṃ ārabhanto taṃ kiṃ maññasi soṇotiādimāha.
analyzed: attho idānissa te parivaṭṭam vajira bheda desanam ārabhanto tam kim maññasi soṇa iti ādim āha
translated: Now, beginning the explanation of the simile of the diamond-cutter, he said, “What do you think, Soṇa? “ .

original: Aṭṭhamaṃ uttānameva. Sattamaaṭṭhamāni.
analyzed: aṭṭhamam uttānam eva sattama aṭṭhamāni
translated: The eighth is straightforward. The seventh and eighth .

original: 9-10. Nandikkhayasuttādivaṇṇanā🔽51-52. Navamadasamesu nandikkhayā rāgakkhayo, rāgakkhayā nandikkhayoti idaṃ nandīti🔽vā rāgoti vā imesaṃ atthato ninnānākaraṇatāya vuttaṃ. Nibbidānupassanāya vā nibbindanto
analyzed: nandi khaya sutta ādi vaṇṇanā  navama dasamesu nandi khayāḥ rāga kkhayaḥ rāga kkhayāḥ nandi kkhayaḥ idam nandi iti  vā rāgaḥ ti vā imesam atthataḥ ninnānākaraṇatāya vuttam nibbida anupassanāya vā nibbindantaḥ
translated: The ninth is called “The Discourse on the Destruction of Delight” .🔽In the ninth and tenth, “With the destruction of delight, the destruction of lust” and “With the destruction of lust, the destruction of delight” are said because there is no difference in meaning between “delight” and “lust” .

original: nandiṃ pajahati, virāgānupassanāya virajjanto rāgaṃ pajahati. Ettāvatā vipassanaṃ
analyzed: nandim pajahati virāga anupassanāya virajjantaḥ rāgam pajahati ettāvatā vipassanam
translated: Or else, by contemplating dispassion he abandons delight, and by contemplating fading away he abandons lust.🔽So far, by the contemplation of impermanence, etc., he has developed insight and reached the plane of the three characteristics. Now, in order to show the development of insight that is the contemplation of danger, etc.,

original: niṭṭhapetvā “rāgakkhayā nandikkhayo”ti idha maggaṃ dassetvā “nandirāgakkhayā cittaṃ
analyzed: niṭṭhapetvā rāga kkhayā nandi kkhayo ti idha maggam dassetvā nandi rāga kkhayā cittam
translated: Having concluded thus, he shows the path here with “With the destruction of lust, the destruction of delight” and the fruition with “With the destruction of lust and delight, the mind is liberated.”

original: vimutta”nti phalaṃ dassitanti. Navamadasamāni.
analyzed: vimuttanti phalam dassitanti navama dasamāni
translated: The chapter on the nine months is finished.

original: Attadīpavaggo pañcamo.
analyzed: attadīpa vaggo pañcamaḥ
translated: The fifth chapter is finished.

original: Mūlapaṇṇāsako samatto.
analyzed: mūla paṇṇāsako samatto
translated: The root fifty is finished.

original: 6. Upayavaggo
analyzed: upaya vaggaḥ
translated: The Chapter on Attachment

original: 1. Upayasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: upaya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The First Sutta on Attachment

original: 53. Upayavaggassa paṭhame upayoti taṇhāmānadiṭṭhivasena pañcakkhandhe upagato. Viññāṇanti🔽kammaviññāṇaṃ. Āpajjeyyāti kammaṃ javāpetvā paṭisandhiākaḍḍhanasamatthatāya vuddhiādīni
analyzed: upaya vaggassa paṭhame upayaḥ ti taṇhā māna diṭṭhi vasena pañca kkhandhe upagataḥ viññāṇanti  kamma viññāṇam āpajjeyya ati kammam javāpetvā paṭisandhi ākaḍḍhana samattha tāya vuddhi ādīni
translated: In the first sutta of the chapter on attachment, “attachment” is the five aggregates that one has gone to by way of craving, conceit, and views. “Consciousness”🔽is kamma-resultant consciousness. “One would come to” is the meaning of “would come to growth, etc.,” by causing kamma to hurry and by being able to draw it into rebirth-linking.

original: āpajjeyya. Viññāṇupayanti padassa aggahaṇe kāraṇaṃ vuttameva. Vocchijjatārammaṇanti
analyzed: āpajjeyya viññāṇa upayanti padassa aggahaṇe kāraṇam vuttam eva vocchijja tā ārammaṇam ti
translated: The reason for the inclusion of the phrase “attachment to consciousness” has already been given. “The object is cut off”

original: paṭisandhiākaḍḍhanasamatthatāya abhāvena ārammaṇaṃ vocchijjati. Patiṭṭhā viññāṇassāti
analyzed: paṭisandhi ākaḍḍhana samattha tāya abhāvena ārammaṇam vā ucchijjati patiṭṭhā viññāṇassa ati
translated: because of the absence of the ability to draw rebirth-linking. “There is no support for consciousness”🔽means that there is no support for kamma-resultant consciousness. “It is not established”

original: kammaviññāṇassa patiṭṭhā na hoti. Tadappatiṭṭhitanti taṃ appatiṭṭhitaṃ. Anabhisaṅkhacca
analyzed: kamma viññāṇassa patiṭṭhā na hoti tat appatiṭṭhitam ti tat appatiṭṭhitam an abhisaṅkhacca
translated: means that it is not established. “Without determining”

original: vimuttanti paṭisandhiṃ anabhisaṅkharitvā vimuttaṃ. Paṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: vimuttam ti paṭisandhim an abhisaṅkharitvā vimuttam paṭhamam
translated: ‘Liberated’: liberated by not forming the rebirth-producing kamma. The first.

original: 2. Bījasuttavaṇṇanā🔽54. Dutiye bījajātānīti bījāni. Mūlabījanti vacaṃ vacattaṃ haliddaṃ siṅgiveranti🔽evamādi. Khandhabījanti assattho nigrodhoti evamādi. Phalubījanti ucchu veḷu naḷoti🔽evamādi. Aggabījanti ajjukaṃ phaṇijjakanti evamādi. Bījabījanti sālivīhiādi pubbaṇṇañceva🔽muggamāsādi aparaṇṇañca. Akhaṇḍānīti abhinnāni. Bhinnakālato paṭṭhāya bījaṃ bījatthāya🔽na upakappati. Apūtikānīti udakatemanena apūtikāni. Pūtibījañhi bījatthāya na upakappati.
analyzed: bīja sutta vaṇṇanā  dutiye bīja jātāni iti bījāni mūlabījanti vacam vacattam haliddam siṅgiveranti  evamādi khandha bījanti assatthaḥ nigrodhaḥ ti evamādi phalu bījanti ucchu veḷu naḷo ti  evamādi agga bījanti ajjukam phaṇijjakanti evamādi bīja bījanti sāli vīhi ādi pubbaṇṇam ca eva  mugga māsa ādi aparaṇṇam ca akhaṇḍāni iti abhinnāni bhinna kālataḥ paṭṭhāya bījam bīja atthāya  na upakappati apūtikāni iti udaka temanena apūtikāni pūti bījam hi bījatthāya na upakappati
translated: The Description of the Seed Sutta

original: Avātātapahatānīti vātena ca ātapena ca na hatāni, nirojataṃ na pāpitāni. Nirojañhi🔽kasaṭaṃ bījaṃ bījatthāya na upakappati. Sārādānīti gahitasārāni patiṭṭhitasārāni.
analyzed: a vāta ātapa hatāni iti vātena ca ātapena ca na hatāni nirojatam na pāpitāni nirojan hi 🔽kasaṭam bījam bīja atthāya na upakappati sāra ādāni iti gahita sārāni patiṭṭhita sārāni
translated: In the second, ‘seed-families’ means seeds. ‘Root-seed’ is the root of the sugar-cane, the ginger, the turmeric, the bulb, the bulbous root, the yam, the sweet potato, and so on. ‘Stem-seed’ is the bamboo, the reed, the sugarcane, the vine, and so on. ‘Joint-seed’ is the mis- canthus, the vetiver, the lemon grass, and so on. ‘Seed-seed’ is the rice, the barley, and so on, which are the grain crops, and the beans, the lentils, and so on, which are the pulse crops. ‘Unbroken’ means unsplit. From the time they are split, they are no longer of use as seeds. ‘Undecayed’ means not decayed by water. For decayed seeds are no longer of use as seeds. ‘Not affected by wind and sun’ means not affected by wind and sun, not made to sprout. For seeds that have been made to sprout by being put in the ground are no longer of use as seeds. ‘With good growth’ means with good substance, with good nutriment.

original: Nissārañhi bījaṃ bījatthāya na upakappati. Sukhasayitānīti cattāro māse koṭṭhe pakkhittaniyāmeneva
analyzed: nissāran hi bījam bīja atthāya na upakappati sukha sayitāni iti cattāraḥ māse koṭṭhe pakkhitta niyāmena iva
translated: Well-bedded: for four months they were bedded down in a granary.

original: sukhaṃ sayitāni. Pathavīti heṭṭhā patiṭṭhānapathavī. Āpoti uparisnehanaāpo. Catasso
analyzed: sukham sayitāni pathavī iti heṭṭhā patiṭṭhāna pathavī āpaḥ iti upari snehana āpaḥ catasso
translated: Earth: the earth below as the foundation. Water: the water above as the moistening.

original: viññāṇaṭṭhitiyoti kammaviññāṇassa ārammaṇabhūtā rūpādayo cattāro khandhā. Te hi ārammaṇavasena🔽patiṭṭhābhūtattā pathavīdhātusadisā. Nandirāgo sinehanaṭṭhena āpodhātusadiso. Viññāṇaṃ
analyzed: viññāṇa ṭṭhitiyaḥ ti kamma viññāṇassa ārammaṇa bhūtāḥ rūpa ādayo cattāro khandhā te hi ārammaṇa vasena  patiṭṭhā bhūta ttā pathavī dhātu sadisā nandi rāgaḥ sinehana ṭṭhena āpaḥ dhātu sadisaḥ viññāṇam
translated: The four stations of consciousness: the four aggregates, form, etc., which are the object of kamma-resultant consciousness. For these are like the earth element in being the foundation by means of the object. Delight and lust are like the water element in the function of moistening.🔽Consciousness is the kamma-resultant consciousness with its conditions. For that grows in the earth, in the object-earth, like a seed. The second …🔽. The third …🔽. The fourth …🔽. The fifth …

original: sāhāranti sappaccayaṃ kammaviññāṇaṃ. Tañhi bījaṃ viya pathaviyaṃ ārammaṇapathaviyaṃ viruhati. Dutiyaṃ.
analyzed: sa āhāranti sa paccayam kamma viññāṇam tat hi bījam viya pathaviyam ārammaṇa pathaviyam viruhati dutiyam
translated: . The sixth …🔽. The seventh …🔽. The eighth …🔽. The ninth …🔽. The tenth …🔽. The eleventh …🔽. The twelfth …🔽. The thirteenth …🔽. The fourteenth …🔽. The fifteenth …🔽. The sixteenth …🔽. The seventeenth …🔽. The eighteenth …🔽. The nineteenth …🔽. The twentieth …🔽. The twenty-first …🔽. The twenty-second …🔽. The twenty-third …🔽. The twenty-fourth …🔽. The twenty-fifth …🔽. The twenty-sixth …🔽. The twenty-seventh …🔽. The twenty-eighth …🔽. The twenty-ninth …🔽. The thirtieth …

analyzed: udāna sutta vaṇṇanā
