The thirty-ninth …🔽. The fortieth …🔽. The forty-first …🔽. The forty-second …🔽. The forty-third …🔽. The forty-fourth …🔽. The forty-fifth …🔽. The forty-sixth …🔽. The forty-seventh …🔽. The forty-eighth …🔽. The forty-ninth …🔽. The fiftieth …🔽. The fifty-first …🔽. The fifty-second …🔽. The fifty-third …🔽. The fifty-fourth …

original: 55. Tatiye udānaṃ udānesīti balavasomanassasamuṭṭhānaṃ udānaṃ udāhari. Kiṃ nissāya
analyzed: tatiye udānam udānesi iti balava somanassa samuṭṭhānam udānam udāhari kim nissāya
translated: . The fifty-fifth …🔽. The fifty-sixth …🔽. The fifty-seventh …🔽. The fifty-eighth …🔽. The fifty-ninth …

original: panesa bhagavato uppannoti. Sāsanassa niyyānikabhāvaṃ. Kathaṃ? Evaṃ kirassa ahosi,
analyzed: pana esa bhagavataḥ uppannaḥ ti sāsanassa niyyānika bhāvam katham evam ahosi
translated: . The six

original: “tayome upanissayā – dānūpanissayo sīlūpanissayo bhāvanūpanissayo cā”ti. Tesu dānasīlūpanissayā
analyzed: tayo me upanissayāḥ dāna upanissayo sīla upanissayo bhāvanā upanissayo ca ati tesu dāna sīla upanissayāḥ
translated: “There are three kinds of support: support by way of giving, support by way of virtue, and support by way of development.”

original: dubbalā, bhāvanūpanissayo balavā. Dānasīlūpanissayā hi tayo magge ca phalāni ca pāpenti,
analyzed: dubbalāḥ bhāvanā upa nissayaḥ balavā dānasīlūpa nissayāḥ hi tayo magge ca phalāni ca pāpenti
translated: Among these, support by way of giving and support by way of virtue are weak, and support by way of development is strong. For support by way of giving and support by way of virtue lead to the three paths and their fruits,

original: bhāvanūpanissayo arahattaṃ pāpeti. Iti dubbalūpanissaye patiṭṭhito bhikkhu ghaṭento
analyzed: bhāvanā upa nissayaḥ arahattam pāpeti iti dubbala upa nissaye patiṭṭhitaḥ bhikkhu ghaṭento
translated: but support by way of development leads to arahatship. Thus, a bhikkhu who is established in weak support, striving and making effort,

original: vāyamanto pañcorambhāgiyāni bandhanāni chetvā tīṇi maggaphalāni nibbatteti, “aho
analyzed: vāyamantaḥ pañca orambhāgiyāni bandhanāni chetvā tīṇi magga phalāni nibbattā iti aho
translated: having cut off the five lower fetters, produces the three paths and their fruits. “Ah,

original: sāsanaṃ niyyānika”nti āvajjentassa ayaṃ udapādi.
analyzed: sāsanam niyyānikanti āvajjentassa ayam udapādi
translated: the Dispensation is emancipating,” occurred to him who was adverting thus.

original: Tattha “dubbalūpanissaye ṭhatvā ghaṭamāno tīṇi maggaphalāni pāpuṇātī”ti imassatthassāvibhāvanatthaṃ
analyzed: tattha dubbala upanissaye ṭhatvā ghaṭamāno tīṇi magga phalāni pāpuṇāti iti
translated: Herein, for the purpose of explaining the meaning of “established in weak support, striving, he reaches the three paths and their fruits,”

original: milakattherassa vatthu veditabbaṃ – so kira gihikāle pāṇātipātakammena jīvikaṃ kappento
analyzed: milaka therassa vatthu veditabbam saḥ kira gihi kāle pāṇātipāta kammena jīvikam kappentaḥ
translated: the story of the Elder Milaka should be known. He, it seems, while living as a layman, made his living by the occupation of killing living beings.

original: araññe pāsasatañceva adūhalasatañca yojesi. Athekadivasaṃ aṅgārapakkamaṃsaṃ khāditvā
analyzed: araññe pāsa satam ca iva adūhala satam ca yojesi atha eka divasam aṅgāra pakka maṃsam khāditvā
translated: Having set out a hundred snares and a hundred traps in the forest, one day he ate some charcoal-roasted meat,

original: pāsaṭṭhānesu vicaranto pipāsābhibhūto ekassa araññavāsittherassa vihāraṃ gantvā therassa
analyzed: pāsa ṭṭhānesu vicarantaḥ pipāsā abhibhūto ekassa arañña vāsi therassa vihāram gantvā therassa
translated: Wandering about in the desert, and overcome with thirst, he went to the monastery of a certain Elder who dwelt in the forest, and

original: caṅkamantassa avidūre ṭhitaṃ pānīyaghaṭaṃ vivari, hatthatemanamattampi udakaṃ nāddasa.
analyzed: caṅkamantassa avidūre ṭhitam pānīya ghaṭam vivari hattha temana mattam pi udakam na addasa
translated: while the Elder was walking up and down, he opened the water-pot which stood not far away from him. He did not see a drop of water, not even a drop as big as the tip of a hair.

original: So kujjhitvā āha – “bhikkhu, bhikkhu tumhe gahapatikehi dinnaṃ bhuñjitvā bhuñjitvā🔽supatha, pānīyaghaṭe añjalimattampi udakaṃ na ṭhapetha, na yuttameta”nti. Thero “mayā
analyzed: saḥ kujjhitvā āha bhikkhu bhikkhu tumhe gahapatikehi dinnam bhuñjitvā bhuñjitvā  pānīya ghaṭe udakam na theraḥ mayā
translated: He became angry and said, “Monk, monk, you eat and drink and sleep soundly,

original: pānīyaghaṭo pūretvā ṭhapito, kiṃ nu kho eta”nti? Gantvā olokento paripuṇṇaghaṭaṃ
analyzed: pānīya ghaṭo pūretvā ṭhapito kim nu kho etat ti gantvā olokento paripuṇṇa ghaṭam
translated: and you do not put even a handful of water in the water-pot. This is not right.” The Elder thought to himself, “I filled the water-pot and set it there. What can this mean?” He went and looked into the pot and saw that it was full to the brim.

original: disvā pānīyasaṅkhaṃ pūretvā adāsi. So dvattisaṅkhapūraṃ pivitvā cintesi – “evaṃ pūritaghaṭo
analyzed: disvā pānīya saṅkham pūretvā adāsi saḥ dvatti saṅkha pūram pivitvā cintesi evam pūrita ghaṭaḥ
translated: He filled the water-vessel and gave it to the man. The man drank thirty-two vesselfuls of water and thought to himself, “The water-pot was filled to the brim

original: nāma mama kammaṃ āgamma tattakapālo viya jāto. Kiṃ nu kho anāgate attabhāve bhavissatī”ti?
analyzed: nāma mama kammaṃ āgamma tatta kapālaḥ viya jātaḥ kim nu kho anāgate attabhāve bhavissati iti
translated: through my act. What will become of me in my next existence?”

original: Saṃviggacitto dhanuṃ chaḍḍetvā, “pabbājetha maṃ, bhante”ti āha. Thero tacapañcakakammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: saṃvigga cittaḥ dhanum chaḍḍetvā pabbājetha mama bhante ti āha thero taca pañcaka kammaṭṭhānam
translated: With his mind disturbed, he threw down his bow and said, “Venerable sir, let me go forth.” The elder taught him the meditation subject consisting of the five parts of the body,

original: ācikkhitvā taṃ pabbājesi.
analyzed: ācikkhitvā tam pabbājesi
translated: and he let him go forth.

original: Tassa samaṇadhammaṃ karontassa bahūnaṃ migasūkarānaṃ māritaṭṭhānaṃ pāsaadūhalānañca
analyzed: tassa samaṇa dhammam karontassa bahūnam miga sūkarānam mārita ṭṭhānam pāsa adūhalānam ca
translated: As he was doing his meditation subject, the place where many deer and boars had been killed and the place where the snares and nooses had been set came to his mind.

original: yojitaṭṭhānaṃ upaṭṭhāti. Taṃ anussarato sarīre dāho uppajjati, kūṭagoṇo viya kammaṭṭhānampi
analyzed: yojita ṭṭhānam upaṭṭhāti tam anussarato sarīre dāho uppajjati kūṭa goṇaḥ viya kammaṭṭhānam pi
translated: As he recalled them, a burning fever arose in his body, and his meditation subject would not come into focus, as if it were a mountain peak.

original: vīthiṃ na paṭipajjati. So “kiṃ karissāmi bhikkhubhāvenā”ti? Anabhiratiyā pīḷito therassa
analyzed: vīthim na paṭipajjati so kim karissāmi bhikkhu bhāvena ati anabhiratiyā pīḷitaḥ therassa
translated: “What is the use of being a bhikkhu?” He was oppressed by dissatisfaction.

original: santikaṃ gantvā vanditvā āha – “na sakkomi, bhante, samaṇadhammaṃ kātu”nti. Atha🔽naṃ thero “hatthakammaṃ karohī”ti āha. So “sādhu, bhante”ti vatvā udumbarādayo allarukkhe
analyzed: santikam gantvā vanditvā āha na sakkomi bhante samaṇa dhammam kātunti atha  nam theraḥ hattha kammam karohi iti āha saḥ sādhu bhante iti vatvā udumbara ādayaḥ alla rukkhe
translated: He went to the elder, paid homage to him, and said, “Venerable sir, I cannot do the ascetic’s duties.” Then the elder said, “Do manual work.”🔽He said, “Very well, venerable sir,” and he cut down soft trees such as fig trees and made a big pile of them. He asked, “What shall I do now?”

original: chinditvā mahantaṃ rāsiṃ katvā, “idāni kiṃ karomī”ti pucchi? Jhāpehi nanti. So catūsu
analyzed: chinditvā mahantam rāsim katvā idāni kim karomi iti pucchi jhāpehi nanti saḥ catūsu
translated: “Burn them.” He did so. He asked, “What shall I do now?”

original: disāsu aggiṃ datvā jhāpetuṃ asakkonto, “bhante, na sakkomī”ti āha. Thero “tena hi
analyzed: disāsu aggim datvā jhāpetum a sakkontaḥ bhante na sakkomi iti āha thero tena hi
translated: unable to light the fire, said, “I cannot, Reverend Sir.” The Elder said, “Well then,

original: apehī”ti pathaviṃ dvidhā katvā avīcito khajjopanakamattaṃ aggiṃ nīharitvā tattha
analyzed: apehi iti pathavim dvidhā katvā avīcitaḥ khajja upanaka mattam aggim nīharitvā tattha
translated: get out of the way.” He split the earth in two and drew out the fire from Avīci, which was the size of a hen’s egg, and put it there.

original: pakkhipi. So tāva mahantaṃ rāsiṃ sukkhapaṇṇaṃ viya khaṇena jhāpesi. Athassa thero🔽avīciṃ dassetvā, “sace vibbhamissasi, ettha paccissasī”ti saṃvegaṃ janesi. So avīcidassanato🔽paṭṭhāya pavedhamāno “niyyānikaṃ, bhante, buddhasāsana”nti pucchi, āmāvusoti. Bhante,
analyzed: pakkhipi so tāva mahantam rāsim sukkha paṇṇam viya khaṇena jhāpesi athassa thero  avīcim dassetvā sace vibbhamissasi ettha paccissasi iti saṃvegam janesi saḥ avīci dassanataḥ  paṭṭhāya pavedhamānaḥ niyyānikam bhante buddha sāsananti pucchi āma āvuso ti bhante
translated: It consumed that great pile of fuel in a moment, as if it were a dry leaf. Then the Elder🔽showed him Avīci and aroused his fear by saying, “If you go forth and then break the precepts, you will be reborn here.” From the time he saw Avīci,

original: buddhasāsanassa niyyānikatte sati milako attamokkhaṃ karissati, mā cintayitthāti.
analyzed: buddha sāsanassa niyyānika tte sati milakaḥ atta mokkham karissati mā cintayittha ati
translated: he was trembling with fear. He asked, “Is there, Reverend Sir, a way of escape from the Dispensation of the Buddha?” “Yes, friend.” “If there is a way of escape from the Dispensation of the Buddha, the miser will be saved. Do not worry.”

original: Tato paṭṭhāya samaṇadhammaṃ karoti ghaṭeti, tassa vattapaṭivattaṃ pūreti, niddāya
analyzed: tatas paṭṭhāya samaṇa dhammam karoti ghaṭeti tassa vatta paṭivattam pūreti niddāya
translated: From that time on he did the duties of a monk, and he exerted himself and fulfilled the duties of a pupil. When sleep was hindering him,

original: bādhayamānāya tintaṃ palālaṃ sīse ṭhapetvā pāde soṇḍiyaṃ otāretvā nisīdati. So ekadivasaṃ
analyzed: bādhayamānāya tintam palālam sīse ṭhapetvā pāde soṇḍiyam otāretvā nisīdati saḥ eka divasam
translated: he placed a bundle of wet grass on his head and sat down with his feet in a trough of water. One day

original: pānīyaṃ parissāvetvā ghaṭaṃ ūrumhi ṭhapetvā udakamaṇikānaṃ pacchedaṃ āgamayamāno
analyzed: pānīyam parissāvetvā ghaṭam ūrumhi ṭhapetvā udaka maṇikānam pacchedam āgamayamānaḥ
translated: and after filling the water-pot he placed it on his hip and stood waiting for the water-carrier to come back.

original: aṭṭhāsi. Atha kho thero sāmaṇerassa imaṃ uddesaṃ deti –
analyzed: aṭṭhāsi atha kho theraḥ sāmaṇerassa imam uddesam deti
translated: Then the elder gave the novice the following stanza:

original: “Uṭṭhānavato satīmato,🔽Sucikammassa nisammakārino;
analyzed: uṭṭhānavataḥ satīmataḥ  suci kammassa nisamma kārino
translated: “For one who is energetic, mindful,🔽Pure in livelihood, and considerate,

original: Saññatassa dhammajīvino,
analyzed: saññatassa dhamma jīvinaḥ
translated: Self-controlled, and lives by the Dhamma,

original: Appamattassa yasobhivaḍḍhatī”ti. ;
analyzed: appamattassa yasaḥ abhivaḍḍhati iti
translated: His fame will grow like the moon in the waxing fortnight.”

original: So catuppadikampi taṃ gāthaṃ attaniyeva upanesi – “uṭṭhānavatā nāma mādisena bhavitabbaṃ.
analyzed: saḥ catuppadikam pi tam gātham attaniyā iva upanesi uṭṭhānavatā nāma mādisena bhavitabbam
translated: The novice applied this stanza to himself in four lines: “One who is energetic should be like me.

original: Satimatāpi mādiseneva…pe… appamattenapi mādiseneva bhavitabba”nti. Evaṃ taṃ gāthaṃ
analyzed: satimatā api appamattena api mādisena iva bhavitabbanti evam tam gātham
translated: One who is mindful should be like me. … One who is not heedless should be like me.”🔽Having applied the stanza to himself in this way,

original: attani upanetvā tasmiṃyeva padavāre ṭhito pañcorambhāgiyāni saṃyojanāni chinditvā
analyzed: upanetvā tasmin yeva padavāre ṭhitaḥ pañca urambhāgiyāni saṃyojanāni chinditvā
translated: standing right there on that very spot, he severed the five lower fetters and

original: anāgāmiphale patiṭṭhāya haṭṭhatuṭṭho –
analyzed: anāgāmi phale patiṭṭhāya haṭṭha tuṭṭhaḥ
translated: attained the fruit of non-return. Delighted and joyful,

original: “Allaṃ palālapuñjāhaṃ, sīsenādāya caṅkamiṃ;
analyzed: allam sīsena ādāya caṅkamim
translated: “I carried a bundle of straw on my head,

original: Pattosmi tatiyaṃ ṭhānaṃ, ettha me natthi saṃsayo”ti. –
analyzed: pattaḥ asmi tatiyam ṭhānam ettha me natthi saṃsayo ti
translated: But now I have attained the third stage; I have no doubt about this.”

original: Imaṃ udānagāthaṃ āha. Evaṃ dubbalūpanissaye ṭhito ghaṭento vāyamanto pañcorambhāgiyāni
analyzed: imam udāna gātham āha evam dubbala upanissaye ṭhitaḥ ghaṭentaḥ vā āyamantaḥ pañca orambhāgiyāni
translated: He spoke this verse of uplift.🔽Thus, standing on a weak support, he cuts away the five lower fetters by striving and making effort, and he produces the three paths and their fruits.

original: saṃyojanāni chinditvā tīṇi maggaphalāni nibbatteti. Tenāha bhagavā – “no cassaṃ,
analyzed: saṃyojanāni chinditvā tīṇi magga phalāni nibbattā iti tena āha bhagavā
translated: Therefore the Blessed One said:

original: no ca me siyā, nābhavissa, na me bhavissatīti evaṃ adhimuccamāno bhikkhu chindeyya
analyzed: no ca me siyā na abhavissa na me bhavissati iti evam adhimuccamānaḥ bhikkhu chindeyya
translated: “The bhikkhu who is resolved thus: ‘It was, it is not; it will not be in the future’

original: orambhāgiyāni saṃyojanānī”ti.
analyzed: orambhāgiyāni saṃyojanāni iti
translated: may cut off the lower fetters.”

original: Tattha no cassaṃ, no ca me siyāti sace ahaṃ na bhaveyyaṃ, mama parikkhāropi na bhaveyya.
analyzed: tattha no cassam no ca me siyā ti sace aham na bhaveyyam mama parikkhāro api na bhaveyya
translated: Herein, it was, it is not; it will not be in the future: if I were not, my requisites would not be.

original: Sace vā pana me atīte kammābhisaṅkhāro nābhavissa, idaṃ me etarahi khandhapañcakaṃ
analyzed: sace vā pana me atīte kamma abhisaṅkhāraḥ na abhavissaḥ idam me etarahi khandha pañcakam
translated: Or if my past kamma- formations had not been, this present pentad of aggregates

original: na bhaveyya. Nābhavissa, na me bhavissatīti idāni pana tathā parakkamissāmi, yathā
analyzed: na bhaveyya na abhavissa na me bhavissati iti idāni pana tathā parakkamissāmi yathā
translated: would not be. It will not be: but I shall now strive so that in the future

original: me āyatiṃ khandhābhinibbattako kammasaṅkhāro na bhavissati, tasmiṃ asati āyatiṃ paṭisandhi
analyzed: me āyatim khandha abhinibbattakaḥ kamma saṅkhāro na bhavissati tasmin asati āyatim paṭisandhi
translated: my kamma-formations that would produce a new existence will not be. When that is not, a future rebirth-linking🔽will not be.

original: nāma na me bhavissati. Evaṃ adhimuccamānoti evaṃ adhimuccanto bhikkhu dubbalūpanissaye
analyzed: nāma na me bhavissati evam adhimuccamānaḥ ti evam adhimuccantaḥ bhikkhu dubbala upanissaye
translated: The monk who resolves thus, standing on a weak foundation,🔽might sever the five lower fetters.🔽When this was said,

original: ṭhito pañcorambhāgiyāni saṃyojanāni chindeyya. Evaṃ vutteti evaṃ sāsanassa niyyānikabhāvaṃ
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ pañca orambhāgiyāni saṃyojanāni chindeyya evam vuttā iti evam sāsanassa niyyānika bhāvam
translated: reflecting on the fact that the dispensation is emancipating,🔽the Blessed One uttered this stanza of rejoicing.

original: āvajjentena bhagavatā imasmiṃ udāne vutte. Rūpaṃ vibhavissatīti rūpaṃ bhijjissati.
analyzed: āvajjentena bhagavatā imasmin udāne vutte rūpam vibhavissati iti rūpam bhijjissati
translated: “Form will vanish”: form will be destroyed.🔽“With the vanishing of form”: with the seeing of its vanishing, together with insight.

original: Rūpassa vibhavāti vibhavadassanena sahavipassanena. Sahavipassanakā hi cattāro maggā
analyzed: rūpassa vibhavā ati vibhava dassanena saha vipassanena saha vipassanakāḥ hi cattāro maggāḥ
translated: For the four paths are called “the seeing of the vanishing of form,” etc.,

original: rūpādīnaṃ vibhavadassanaṃ nāma. Taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Evaṃ adhimuccamāno, bhante,🔽bhikkhu chindeyyāti, bhante, evaṃ adhimuccamāno bhikkhu chindeyyeva pañcorambhāgiyāni
analyzed: rūpa ādīnam vibhava dassanam nāma tam sandhāya itam vuttam evam adhimuccamānaḥ bhante  bhikkhu chindeyya ati bhante evam adhimuccamānaḥ bhikkhu chindeyya iva pañca orambhāgiyāni
translated: and it is with reference to this that it is said here: “With the vanishing of form.”🔽“The monk who resolves thus, venerable sir,

original: saṃyojanāni. Kasmā na chindissatīti?
analyzed: saṃyojanāni kasmāt na chindissati iti
translated: might sever the five lower fetters.” Why might he not sever them?

original: Idāni upari maggaphalaṃ pucchanto kathaṃ pana, bhantetiādimāha. Tattha anantarāti
analyzed: idāni upari magga phalam pucchantaḥ katham pana bhante ti ādim āha tattha anantarā ti
translated: Now, asking about the higher path and fruit, he said: “But, venerable sir, how does a monk who is an arahant …🔽“Immediately after that”?

original: dve anantarāni āsannānantarañca dūrānantarañca. Vipassanā maggassa āsannānantaraṃ🔽nāma, phalassa dūrānantaraṃ nāma. Taṃ sandhāya “kathaṃ pana, bhante, jānato kathaṃ
analyzed: dve anantarāni āsanna anantarañca dūra anantarañca vipassanā maggassa āsanna anantaram  nāma phalassa dūra anantaram nāma tam sandhāya katham pana bhante jānato katham
translated: Two kinds of proximity are mentioned: proximate proximity and remote proximity. The path is proximate to insight knowledge;

original: passato vipassanānantarā ‘āsavānaṃ khayo’ti saṅkhaṃ gataṃ arahattaphalaṃ hotī”ti
analyzed: passataḥ vipassanā anantarā āsavānam khayo ti saṅkham gatam arahatta phalam hoti iti
translated: the fruition is remote from it. It is with reference to this that the Elder asks: “But, venerable sir, how does one know, how does one see, so that there is no scope for doubt or uncertainty, and the fruit of stream-entry is realized?”

original: pucchati. Atasitāyeti atasitabbe abhāyitabbe ṭhānamhi. Tāsaṃ āpajjatīti bhayaṃ āpajjati.
analyzed: pucchati a tasitāya iti a tasitabbe a bhāyitabbe ṭhānamhi tāsam āpajjati iti bhayam āpajjati
translated: “In a state that inspires fear”: in a state that should inspire fear, that should inspire terror. “One falls into terror”: one falls into fear.

original: Tāso hesoti yā esā “no cassaṃ, no ca me siyā”ti evaṃ pavattā dubbalavipassanā, sā
analyzed: tāsaḥ ha iso ti yā esā no ca assam no ca me siyā ti evam pavattā dubbala vipassanā sā
translated: “This is a terror”: this is a weak insight that occurs thus: “I shall be no more, what is mine shall be no more.”

original: yasmā attasinehaṃ pariyādātuṃ na sakkoti, tasmā assutavato puthujjanassa tāso nāma🔽hoti. So hi “idānāhaṃ ucchijjissāmi, na dāni kiñci bhavissāmī”ti attānaṃ papāte patantaṃ
analyzed: yasmai atta sineham pariyādātum na sakkoti tasmai assutavataḥ puthujjanassa tāsaḥ nāma  hoti saḥ hi idānā aham ucchijjissāmi na dāni kiñci bhavissāmi iti attānam papāte patantam
translated: Since it is unable to overcome attachment to self, it is called “terror”🔽for the uninstructed worldling. For he sees himself as if falling into an abyss, as if he were to be annihilated, as if he were no more. Like a certain brahmin, it seems.

original: viya passati aññataro brāhmaṇo viya. Lohapāsādassa kira heṭṭhā tipiṭakacūḷanāgatthero
analyzed: viya passati aññataraḥ brāhmaṇaḥ viya loha pāsādassa kira heṭṭhā tipiṭakacūḷanāga tthero
translated: It seems that the Elder Cūḷanāga of the three Piṭakas was living below the Lohapāsāda.

original: tilakkhaṇāhataṃ dhammaṃ parivatteti. Atha aññatarassa brāhmaṇassa ekamante ṭhatvā
analyzed: ti lakkhaṇa āhatam dhammam parivatteti atha aññatarassa brāhmaṇassa eka mante ṭhatvā
translated: He turns the Dhamma around by way of the three characteristics. Then, while another brahmin was standing in a corner listening to the Dhamma,

original: dhammaṃ suṇantassa saṅkhārā suññato upaṭṭhahiṃsu. So papāte patanto viya hutvā vivaṭadvārena
analyzed: dhammam suṇantassa saṅkhārāḥ suññataḥ upaṭṭhahiṃsu saḥ papāte patantaḥ viya hutvā vivaṭa dvārena
translated: formations appeared void to him. He was as if he had fallen into an abyss. With his mouth wide open,

original: tato palāyitvā gehaṃ pavisitvā, puttaṃ ure sayāpetvā, “tāta, sakyasamayaṃ āvajjento🔽manamhi naṭṭho”ti āha. Na heso bhikkhu tāsoti esā evaṃ pavattā balavavipassanā sutavato
analyzed: tatas palāyitvā geham pavisitvā puttam ure sayāpetvā tāta sakya samayam āvajjento  manamhi naṭṭho ti āha na ha eso bhikkhu tāso ti esā evam pavattā balava vipassanā sutavataḥ
translated: he fled and entered his house. He laid his son on his chest and said, “Dear, I have lost my mind🔽by recollecting the Sakyan’s doctrine.”

original: ariyasāvakassa na tāso nāma hoti. Na hi tassa evaṃ hoti “ahaṃ ucchijjissāmī”ti vā
analyzed: ariya sāvakassa na tāsaḥ nāma hoti na hi tassa evam hoti aham ucchijjissāmi iti vā
translated: This is not a bhikkhu’s fear. Such strong insight as this does not become a fear for a learned noble disciple. For he does not think, “I shall be annihilated”🔽or “I shall be destroyed.” Rather, he thinks, “Only formations arise; only formations cease.”

original: “vinassissāmī”ti vāti. Evaṃ pana hoti “saṅkhārāva uppajjanti, saṅkhārāva nirujjhantī”ti. Tatiyaṃ.🔽4. Upādānaparipavattasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vinassissāmi iti vāti evam pana hoti saṅkhārau uppajjanti saṅkhārau ava nirujjhanti iti tatiyam
translated: The third section for recitation on the exposition of clinging is finished.🔽The fourth section for recitation on the exposition of clinging

original: 56. Catutthe catuparivaṭṭanti ekekasmiṃ khandhe catunnaṃ parivaṭṭanavasena. Rūpaṃ
analyzed: catutthe ekekasmin khandhe catunnam parivaṭṭana vasena rūpam
translated: In the fourth section, “fourfold” : by way of the fourfold turnings in each of the aggregates.

original: abbhaññāsinti rūpaṃ dukkhasaccanti abhiññāsiṃ. Evaṃ sabbapadesu catusaccavaseneva
analyzed: abbhaññāsin ti rūpam dukkha saccanti abhiññāsin evam sabba padesu catu sacca vasena iva
translated: They have directly known : they have directly known that material form is the truth of suffering. In this way, the meaning should be understood in all the passages in terms of the four truths.

original: attho veditabbo. Āhārasamudayāti ettha sacchandarāgo kabaḷīkārāhāro āhāro nāma. Paṭipannāti
analyzed: atthaḥ veditabbaḥ āhāra samudayā ti ettha sa chanda rāgaḥ kabaḷīkāra āhāraḥ āhāraḥ nāma paṭipannā ati
translated: With the arising of nutriment : here, craving with its choice is called “nutriment as physical food.”🔽They have entered upon : they have entered upon the way from virtue to the path of arahantship.

original: sīlato paṭṭhāya yāva arahattamaggā paṭipannā honti. Gādhantīti patiṭṭhahanti. Ettāvatā
analyzed: sīlataḥ paṭṭhāya yāva arahatta maggā paṭipannā honti gādhanti iti patiṭṭhahanti ettāvatā
translated: They have penetrated : they have established themselves.

original: sekkhabhūmiṃ kathetvā idāni asekkhabhūmiṃ kathento ye ca kho keci, bhikkhavetiādimāha.
analyzed: sekkha bhūmim kathetvā idāni asekkha bhūmim kathentaḥ ye ca kho keci bhikkhave iti ādim āha
translated: Having thus far spoken of the plane of the learner, the Exalted One now speaks of the plane of the adept, saying, “Bhikkhus, there being what, do I designate …?”

original: Suvimuttāti arahattaphalavimuttiyā suṭṭhu vimuttā. Kevalinoti sakalino katasabbakiccā.🔽Vaṭṭaṃ tesaṃ natthi paññāpanāyāti yena te avasiṭṭhena vaṭṭena paññāpeyyuṃ, taṃ nesaṃ
analyzed: su vimuttā ati arahatta phala vimuttiyā suṭṭhu vimuttā kevalinaḥ ti sakalinaḥ kata sabba kiccā  vaṭṭam tesam natthi paññāpanāya ati yena te avasiṭṭhena vaṭṭena paññāpeyyum tam na īsam
translated: Well liberated : well liberated by the liberation of the fruit of arahantship.🔽They have no more desire for existence : they have no more desire for the round.

original: vaṭṭaṃ natthi paññāpanāya. Atha vā vaṭṭanti kāraṇaṃ, paññāpanāya kāraṇaṃ natthīti.
analyzed: vaṭṭam natthi paññāpanāya atha vā vaṭṭanti kāraṇam paññāpanāya kāraṇam natthi iti
translated: They have no more desire for the round : there is no more round for them to be designated by. Or alternatively, “round” means “cause,” and there is no cause for them to be designated.

original: Ettāvatā asekkhabhūmivāro kathito. Catutthaṃ.
analyzed: ettāvatā asekkha bhūmi vāro kathito catuttham
translated: Thus far the section on the plane of the adept. The fourth section is finished.

original: 5. Sattaṭṭhānasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: satta ṭṭhāna sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Exposition of the Sutta on the Seven Stations

original: 57. Pañcame sattaṭṭhānakusaloti sattasu okāsesu cheko. Vusitavāti vusitavāso. Uttamapurisoti🔽seṭṭhapuriso. Sesamettha vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Idaṃ pana suttaṃ ussadanandiyañceva
analyzed: pañcame satta ṭṭhāna kusalaḥ ti sattasu okāsesu chekaḥ vusita vāti vusita vāsaḥ uttama puriso ti  seṭṭha puriso sesam ettha vutta nayena iva veditabbam idam pana suttam ussada nandiyam ca iva
translated: The fifth, “skilled in seven ways” : he is skilled in the seven bases . “Accomplished” : he has lived the life . “Foremost man” :

original: palobhanīyañcāti veditabbaṃ. Yathā hi rājā vijitasaṅgāmo saṅgāme vijayino yodhe uccaṭṭhāne🔽ṭhapetvā tesaṃ sakkāraṃ karoti. Kiṃ kāraṇā? Etesaṃ sakkāraṃ disvā sesāpi sūrā bhavituṃ
analyzed: palobhanīyam ca ati veditabbam yathā hi rājā vijita saṅgāmaḥ saṅgāme vijayinaḥ yodhe ucca ṭṭhāne  ṭhapetvā tesam sakkāram karoti kim kāraṇā etesam sakkāram disvā sesā api sūrāḥ bhavitum
translated: foremost person. The rest should be understood here in the way already stated. But this sutta should be understood as a praise of the arahant and as a bait for the disciples. For just as a king, after winning a battle, promotes the victorious warriors to high rank and honors them,

original: maññissantīti, evameva bhagavā appameyyaṃ kālaṃ pāramiyo pūretvā mahābodhimaṇḍe kilesamāravijayaṃ
analyzed: maññissanti iti evam eva bhagavā appameyyam kālam pāramiyaḥ pūretvā mahā bodhimaṇḍe kilesa māra vijayam
translated: thinking, “After seeing the honors given to them, the others will also be brave,” so too the Blessed One, after fulfilling the perfections over an immeasurable period of time, winning the battle with the defilements at the Great Bodhi Tree,

original: katvā sabbaññutaṃ patto sāvatthiyaṃ jetavanamahāvihāre nisīditvā imaṃ suttaṃ desento
analyzed: katvā sabbaññu tam patto sāvatthiyam jetavana mahā vihāre nisīditvā imam suttam desento
translated: attaining omniscience, and sitting in the Great Monastery at Sāvatthī, taught this sutta,

original: khīṇāsave ukkhipitvā thomesi vaṇṇesi. Kiṃ kāraṇā? Evaṃ avasesā sekkhapuggalā arahattaphalaṃ
analyzed: khīṇāsave ukkhipitvā thomesi vaṇṇesi kim kāraṇā evam avasesā sekkha puggalāḥ arahatta phalam
translated: lifting up and extolling the arahants. Why? So that the other disciples might think, “We too should be like that.”

original: pattabbaṃ maññissantīti. Evametaṃ suttaṃ khīṇāsavānaṃ ukkhipitvā pasaṃsitattā ussadanandiyaṃ,
analyzed: pattabbam maññissanti iti evam etam suttam khīṇāsavānam ukkhipitvā pasaṃsita ttā ussada nandiyam
translated: they will think it is to be attained. Thus this Thread is a Thread of Excitement because it was uplifted and then praised for those with cankers destroyed.

original: sekkhānaṃ palobhitattā palobhanīyanti veditabbaṃ.🔽Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sattaṭṭhānakusalo hotīti ettāvatā cettha maggaphalapaccavekkhaṇavasena
analyzed: sekkhānam palobhita ttā palobhanīyanti veditabbam  evam kho bhikkhave bhikkhu satta ṭṭhāna kusalaḥ hoti iti ettāvatā ca ittha magga phala paccavekkhaṇa vasena
translated: they will think it is to be attained. Thus this Thread is to be known as ‘ gladdening ’ in the sense that it gladdens those with cankers destroyed by extolling them, and as ‘ enticing ’ in the sense that it entices those still on the training since it is said that ‘ Those who are still on the training should train thus ’ .🔽This is how a bhikkhu is skilled in seven cases.

original: desanaṃ niṭṭhapetvāpi puna kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu tividhūpaparikkhī hotīti🔽idaṃ “khīṇāsavo yasmiṃ ārammaṇe satatavihārena viharati, taṃ satto vā puggalo vā
analyzed: desanam niṭṭhapetvā api puna katham ca bhikkhave bhikkhu hoti iti  idam khīṇa āsavaḥ yasmin ārammaṇe satata vihārena viharati tam sattaḥ vā puggalo vā
translated: Having thus brought the teaching to an end with the reviewing of the path and fruition, he then said ‘ And how, bhikkhus, is a bhikkhu a triple investigator? ’

original: na hoti, dhātuādimattameva pana hotī”ti evaṃ khīṇāsavassa satatavihārañca, “imesu🔽dhammesu kammaṃ katvā ayaṃ āgato”ti āgamanīyapaṭipadañca dassetuṃ vuttaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: na hoti dhātu ādi mattam eva pana hoti iti evam khīṇa āsavassa satata vihāram ca imesu  dhammesu kammam katvā ayam āgataḥ ti āgamanīya paṭipadam ca dassetum vuttam tattha
translated: in order to show how one with cankers destroyed always abides in the object, which is not a being or a person but only a bare idea consisting of elements, and in order to show the way of arrival that is to be arrived at by making the ideas in this way the object. Herein

original: dhātuso upaparikkhatīti dhātusabhāvena passati oloketi. Sesapadadvayepi eseva nayo. Pañcamaṃ.
analyzed: dhātuso upaparikkhati iti dhātu sabhāvena passati oloketi sesa pada dvaye pi esa iva nayo pañcamam
translated: he investigates as elements : he sees, he looks on, with the nature of elements. The same method of explanation applies to the other two terms. The fifth .

original: 6. Sammāsambuddhasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sammāsambuddha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Sutta on the Fully Enlightened One

original: 58. Chaṭṭhe ko adhippayāsoti ko adhikapayogo. Anuppannassāti imañhi maggaṃ kassapasammāsambuddho🔽uppādesi, antarā añño satthā uppādetuṃ nāsakkhi, iti bhagavā anuppannassa maggassa🔽uppādetā nāma. Nagaropamasmiñhi avaḷañjanaṭṭhānesu purāṇamaggo jāto, idha avattamānaṭṭhena
analyzed: chaṭṭhe kaḥ adhippayāsaḥ ti kaḥ adhika payogaḥ anuppannassa ati iman hi maggam kassapa sammāsambuddhaḥ  uppādesi antarā aññaḥ satthā uppādetum na asakkhi iti bhagavā anuppannassa maggassa  uppādetā nāma nagara upamasmin hi avaḷañjana ṭhānesu purāṇa maggaḥ jātaḥ idha avattamāna aṭṭhena
translated: What is the supreme effort? What is the supreme exertion? Unarisen: the Fully Enlightened One Kassapa arose this path;

original: anuppannamaggo nāma. Asañjātassāti tasseva vevacanaṃ. Anakkhātassāti akathitassa.🔽Maggaṃ jānātīti maggaññū. Maggaṃ viditaṃ pākaṭaṃ akāsīti maggavidū. Magge ca amagge
analyzed: anuppanna maggaḥ nāma a sañjātassa ati tassa iva vevacanam an akkhātassa ati a kathitassa  maggam jānāti iti maggaññū maggam viditam pākaṭam akāsi iti magga vidū magge ca amagge
translated: in the interval no other Enlightened One arose who could arise it. So the Blessed One is called the ariser of the unarisen path. For in the Simile of the City the ancient path arose in the place where the ploughshare turned up the earth; here the unarisen path is called the unarisen path in the sense of not having been traversed. Not yet arisen: this is a synonym for the same thing. Not yet declared: not yet told.

original: ca kovidoti maggakovido. Maggānugāti maggaṃ anugacchantā. Pacchā samannāgatāti ahaṃ🔽paṭhamaṃ gato, sāvakā pacchā samannāgatā. Chaṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: ca kovidaḥ iti magga kovidaḥ magga anugā ati maggam anugacchantā pacchā samannāgatā ati aham  paṭhamam gatā sāvakā pacchā samannāgatā chaṭṭham
translated: Knows the path: maggaññu ; he has made the path known, evident: maggavidū ; he is skilled in the path and in the wrong path: maggakovido ; those who follow the path: magganugatā ; those who have come after me: pacchāsamannāgatā . The sixth .

original: 7. Anattalakkhaṇasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: anattalakkhaṇa sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The explanation of the Discourse on the Characteristic of Not-self .

original: 59. Sattame pañcavaggiyeti aññāsi koṇḍaññattherādike pañca jane purāṇupaṭṭhāke. Āmantesīti
analyzed: sattame pañcavaggiya iti aññāsi koṇḍaññatthera ādike pañca jane āmantesi iti
translated: In the seventh , he knew the group of five : he knew the five men, the venerable Koṇḍañña and the others, who had been his attendants in the past. He addressed :

original: āsāḷhipuṇṇamadivase dhammacakkappavattanato paṭṭhāya anukkamena sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhite🔽“idāni nesaṃ āsavakkhayāya dhammaṃ desessāmī”ti pañcamiyaṃ pakkhassa āmantesi. Etadavocāti
analyzed: āsāḷhipuṇṇama divase dhammacakka ppavattanataḥ paṭṭhāya anukkamena sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhite  idāni na isam āsava kkhayāya dhammam desessāmi iti pañcamiyam pakkhassa āmantesi etat avoca ati
translated: From the day of the turning of the Wheel of the Dhamma on the full-moon day of Āsāḷhi, they had gradually been established in the fruit of stream-entry.

original: etaṃ “rūpaṃ, bhikkhave, anattā”tiādinayappavattaṃ anattalakkhaṇasuttaṃ avoca. Tattha
analyzed: etam rūpam bhikkhave anatta ati ādi naya ppavattam anatta lakkhaṇa suttam avoca tattha
translated: Now, thinking, “I shall teach them the Dhamma for the destruction of the taints,” he addressed them on the fifth day of the fortnight, saying: “Bhikkhus, this was said by the wanderer Uddaka Rāmaputta: ‘If, while I am speaking, you understand my words and accept them, then I shall consider that you are satisfied.🔽But if you do not understand my words and accept them, then you should remain silent. For when you are silent, it is known to me that you have understood my words and accepted them.’

original: anattāti pubbe vuttehi catūhi kāraṇehi anattā. Taṃ kiṃ maññatha, bhikkhaveti idaṃ
analyzed: anattā ati pubbe vuttehi catūhi kāraṇehi anattā tam kim maññatha bhikkhave ti idam
translated: “What do you think, bhikkhus, is form permanent or impermanent?”🔽Why was this question asked?

original: kasmā āraddhaṃ? Ettakena ṭhānena anattalakkhaṇameva kathitaṃ, na aniccadukkhalakkhaṇāni,
analyzed: kasmai āraddham ettakena ṭhānena anatta lakkhaṇam eva kathitam na anicca dukkha lakkhaṇāni
translated: Up to this point only the characteristic of not-self had been stated, not those of impermanence and pain.

original: idāni tāni dassetvā samodhānetvā tīṇipi lakkhaṇāni dassetuṃ idamāraddhanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: idāni tāni dassetvā samodhānetvā tīṇi pi lakkhaṇāni dassetum idam āraddha nti veditabbam
translated: Therefore this question was asked in order to show the latter two characteristics by pointing out the former one and then combining them all.🔽“Therefore”: because these five aggregates are impermanent, painful, and not-self.

original: Tasmāti yasmā ime pañcakkhandhā aniccā dukkhā anattā, tasmā. Yaṃkiñci rūpantiādīsu
analyzed: tasmā iti yasmai ime pañca kkhandhāḥ aniccāḥ dukkhāḥ anattā tasmai yaṃ kiñci
translated: The detailed explanation of the passage beginning with the words “Whatever form there is”

original: vitthārakathā visuddhimagge paññābhāvanādhikāre khandhaniddese vuttāva. Sesaṃ sabbattha
analyzed: vitthāra kathā visuddhi magge paññā bhāvanā adhikāre khandha niddese vuttā ava sesam sabbattha
translated: is given in the Path of Purity in the chapter on the development of understanding in the exposition of the aggregates. The rest is clear.

original: vuttānusāreneva veditabbaṃ. Imasmiṃ pana sutte anattalakkhaṇameva kathitanti. Sattamaṃ.
analyzed: vutta anusārena iva veditabbam imasmim pana sutte anatta lakkhaṇam eva kathitan ti sattamam
translated: and it should be understood by the method stated there. But in this sutta only the characteristic of not-self is stated. The seventh sutta.

original: 8. Mahālisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: mahāli sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The eighth sutta

original: 60. Aṭṭhame ekantadukkhantiādīni dhātusaṃyutte vuttanayāneva. Aṭṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: aṭṭhame ekanta dukkha nti ādīni dhātu saṃyutte vutta nayāna eva aṭṭhamam
translated: In the eighth sutta, “entirely painful” , etc., are in the way stated in the “Elements” . The eighth sutta.

original: 9. Ādittasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: āditta sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The ninth sutta

original: 61. Navame ādittanti ekādasahi aggīhi ādittaṃ pajjalitaṃ. Iti dvīsupi imesu suttesu dukkhalakkhaṇameva kathitaṃ. Navamaṃ.
analyzed: navame ādittam ti ekādasahi aggīhi ādittam pajjalitam iti dvīsu pi imesu suttesu dukkha lakkhaṇam eva kathitam navamam
translated: In the ninth sutta, “on fire” means burning with eleven fires. So in these two suttas only the characteristic of pain is stated. The ninth sutta.

original: 10. Niruttipathasuttavaṇṇanā🔽62. Dasame niruttiyova niruttipathā, atha vā niruttiyo ca tā niruttivasena viññātabbānaṃ
analyzed: dasame niruttiyaḥ iva nirutti pathāḥ atha vā niruttiyaḥ ca tāḥ nirutti vasena viññātabbānam
translated: The tenth sutta🔽In the tenth sutta, “the way of the language” is the language itself. Or alternatively, it is the way of the meanings to be known by means of the language.

original: atthānaṃ pathattā pathā cāti niruttipathā. Sesapadadvayepi eseva nayo. Tīṇipi cetāni
analyzed: atthānam pathattā pathā ca ati nirutti pathā sesa pada dvaye pi esa iva nayo tīṇi pi
translated: So it is the way of the language. The same method applies to the other two terms.

original: aññamaññavevacanānevāti veditabbāni. Asaṃkiṇṇāti avijahitā, “ko imehi attho”ti vatvā
analyzed: veditabbāni a saṃkiṇṇā ati a vijahitā kaḥ imehi atthaḥ ti vatvā
translated: And all three should be understood as synonyms. “Unmixed” means unforsaken. “Not abandoned” means not rejected, “What is the use of these?”

original: achaḍḍitā. Asaṃkiṇṇapubbāti atītepi na jahitapubbā. Na saṃkīyantīti etarahipi “kimetehī”ti
analyzed: a chaḍḍitāḥ a saṃkiṇṇa pubbā ti atīte pi na jahita pubbāḥ na saṃkīyanti iti etarahi pi kim etehi iti
translated: “Unmixed before” means not forsaken in the past either. “Do not mix” means not rejected now either, “What is the use of these?”

original: na chaḍḍīyanti. Na saṃkīyissantīti anāgatepi na chaḍḍīyissanti. Appaṭikuṭṭhāti appaṭibāhitā.
analyzed: na chaḍḍīyanti na saṃkīyissanti iti anāgate pi na chaḍḍīyissanti appaṭikuṭṭhā ati appaṭibāhitā
translated: They are not rejected: they will not be rejected in the future. They are not despised: they are not opposed.

original: Atītanti attano sabhāvaṃ bhaṅgameva vā atikkantaṃ. Niruddhanti desantaraṃ asaṅkamitvā
analyzed: sabhāvam bhaṅgam eva vā atikkantam desantaram a saṅkamitvā
translated: Past: having gone beyond its own individual essence or having merely ceased. Ceased: without going to another place

original: tattheva niruddhaṃ vūpasantaṃ. Vipariṇatanti vipariṇāmaṃ gataṃ naṭṭhaṃ. Ajātanti
analyzed: tattha iva niruddham vūpasantam vipariṇatanti vipariṇāmam gatam naṭṭham a jātanti
translated: it has ceased, subsided, right there. Changed: it has undergone change, it is destroyed. Not yet arisen:

original: anuppannaṃ. Apātubhūtanti apākaṭībhūtaṃ.
analyzed: an uppannam a pātubhūtam ti apākaṭībhūtam
translated: it has not yet occurred. Not manifest: it has not become evident.

original: Ukkalāti ukkalajanapadavāsino. Vassabhaññāti vasso ca bhañño ca. Dvepi hi te mūladiṭṭhigatikā.🔽Ahetukavādātiādīsu “natthi hetu natthi paccayo”ti gahitattā ahetukavādā. “Karoto
analyzed: ukkalā ati ukkala janapada vāsinaḥ vassabhaññā ati vassaḥ ca bhañño ca dve api hi te mūla diṭṭhi gatikā  ahetuka vādā tiādīsu natthi hetu natthi paccayo ti gahita ttā ahetuka vādā karoto
translated: Ukkalā: inhabitants of the country of the Ukkalā people. Vassabhaññā: both of them are holders of root-views.

original: na karīyati pāpa”nti gahitattā akiriyavādā. “Natthi dinna”ntiādigahaṇato natthikavādā.
analyzed: na pāpanti gahita ttā akiriya vādāḥ natthi dinna nti ādi gahaṇato natthika vādāḥ
translated: As to the doctrine of no-cause, etc., they are called “holders of the doctrine of no-cause” because they hold that there is no cause or condition. They are called “holders of the doctrine of inaction” because they hold that evil is not done by one who acts. They are called “holders of the doctrine of nothingness” because they hold that there is no giving, etc.

original: Tattha ime dve janā, tisso diṭṭhiyo, kiṃ ekekassa diyaḍḍhā hotīti? Na tathā, yathā
analyzed: tattha ime dve janā tissaḥ diṭṭhiyaḥ kim ekekassa diyaḍḍhā hoti iti na tathā yathā
translated: Here, do these two people, these three views, belong to each one of them? No, not in that way.

original: pana eko bhikkhu paṭipāṭiyā cattāripi jhānāni nibbatteti, evamettha ekeko tissopi🔽diṭṭhiyo nibbattesīti veditabbo. “Natthi hetu natthi paccayo”ti punappunaṃ āvajjentassa
analyzed: pana ekaḥ bhikkhu paṭipāṭiyā cattāri pi jhānāni nibbatteti evam ettha ekeko tissaḥ api  diṭṭhiyaḥ nibbattesi iti veditabbaḥ natthi hetu natthi paccayo ti punappunam āvajjentassa
translated: But a bhikkhu who produces the four jhānas in order in this way produces the views in this order too.

original: āharantassa abhinandantassa assādentassa maggadassanaṃ viya hoti. So micchattaniyāmaṃ🔽okkamati, so ekantakāḷakoti vuccati. Yathā pana ahetukadiṭṭhiyaṃ, evaṃ “karoto na
analyzed: āharantassa abhinandantassa assādentassa magga dassanam viya hoti so micchatta niyāmam  okkamati so ekantakāḷako ti vuccati yathā pana ahetuka diṭṭhiyam evam karotaḥ na
translated: When he adverts again and again to the view “There is no cause” and so on, and brings it to mind, and delights in it, and enjoys it, then his wrong view is like the path to his being reborn in hell. He is said to have “entered upon the way” to such a rebirth. He is said to be “all black.”

original: karīyati pāpaṃ, natthi dinna”nti imesupi ṭhānesu micchattaniyāmaṃ okkamati.🔽Na garahitabbaṃ nappaṭikkositabbaṃ amaññiṃsūti ettha “yadetaṃ atītaṃ nāma, nayidaṃ🔽atītaṃ, idamassa anāgataṃ vā paccuppannaṃ vā”ti vadanto garahati nāma. Tattha dosaṃ
analyzed: pāpam natthi imesu pi ṭhānesu micchatta niyāmam okkamati  na garahitabbam na paṭikkositabbam amaññiṃsu iti ettha yat etam atītam nāma na yidam  atītam idam assa anāgatam vā paccuppannam vā ti vadantaḥ garahati nāma tattha dosam
translated: But when he adverts again and again to the view “An act does not bring about result” and so on, and brings it to mind, and delights in it, and enjoys it, then his wrong view is like the path to his being reborn in hell. He is said to have “entered upon the way” to such a rebirth.

original: dassetvā “kiṃ iminā garahitenā”ti? Vadanto paṭikkosati nāma. Ime pana niruttipathe
analyzed: dassetvā kim iminā gara hitena ati vadanto paṭikkosati nāma ime pana nirutti pathe
translated: They did not think it should be blamed or denied: here one who says, “What is called the past is not the past; it is the future or the present,” is said to blame it. Having shown his annoyance with it, he is said to deny it when he says, “What is the use of blaming it?”🔽These, in the first place, are the four kinds of wrong view.

original: tepi accantakāḷakā diṭṭhigatikā na garahitabbe na paṭikkositabbe maññiṃsu. Atītaṃ
analyzed: te pi accanta kāḷakāḥ diṭṭhi gatikāḥ na garahitabbe na paṭikkositabbe maññiṃsu atītam
translated: They thought that they should not be reproved or contradicted.🔽The past is past, the future is future, and the present is present.

original: pana atītameva, anāgataṃ anāgatameva, paccuppannaṃ paccuppannameva kathayiṃsu. Nindāghaṭṭanabyārosaupārambhabhayāti
analyzed: pana atītam eva anāgatam anāgatam eva paccuppannam paccuppannam eva kathayiṃsu nindā ghaṭṭana byārosa upārambha bhayā ati
translated: They speak thus out of fear of blame, of being struck down, of accusation, and of censure.

original: viññūnaṃ santikā nindābhayena ca ghaṭṭanabhayena ca dosāropanabhayena ca upārambhabhayena
analyzed: viññūnam santikā nindā bhayena ca ghaṭṭana bhayena ca dosa āropana bhayena ca upārambha bhayena
translated: Out of fear of blame by the wise, out of fear of being struck down, out of fear of being accused of lust, hate, and delusion, and out of fear of censure.

original: ca. Iti imasmiṃ sutte catubhūmikakhandhānaṃ paṇṇatti kathitāti. Dasamaṃ.
analyzed: ca iti imasmim sutte catu bhūmika khandhānam paṇṇatti kathitā ati dasamam
translated: Thus in this sutta the description of the aggregates in four planes is given. The tenth sutta.

original: Upayavaggo chaṭṭho.
analyzed: upaya vaggaḥ chaṭṭhaḥ
translated: The sixth sub-chapter on “Grasping” is finished.

original: 7. Arahantavaggo
analyzed: arahanta vaggo
translated: The sub-chapter on “Arahats”

original: 1. Upādiyamānasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: upādiyamāna sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: 1. The Sutta on “Grasping”

original: 63. Arahantavaggassa paṭhame upādiyamānoti taṇhāmānadiṭṭhivasena gaṇhamāno. Baddho mārassāti mārassa pāsena baddho nāma. Mutto pāpimatoti pāpimato pāsena mutto nāma hoti. Paṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: arahanta vaggassa paṭhame upādiyamānaḥ ti taṇhā māna diṭṭhi vasena gaṇhamānaḥ baddhaḥ mārassa ati mārassa pāsena baddhaḥ nāma muttaḥ pāpimato ti pāpimato pāsena muttaḥ nāma hoti paṭhamam
translated: “Grasping”: taking up by way of craving, conceit, and views. “Bound by Mara”: bound by Mara’s noose. “Freed from the Evil One”: freed from the Evil One’s noose. The first sutta.

original: 2. Maññamānasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: maññamāna sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: 2. The Sutta on “Conceiving”

original: 64. Dutiye maññamānoti taṇhāmānadiṭṭhimaññanāhi maññamāno. Dutiyaṃ.
analyzed: dutiye maññamāno ti taṇhā māna diṭṭhi maññanāhi maññamānaḥ dutiyam
translated: “Conceiving”: conceiving by way of the conceivings of craving, conceit, and views. The second sutta.

original: 3. Abhinandamānasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: abhinandamāna sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: 3. The third, etc.

original: 65. Tatiye abhinandamānoti taṇhāmānadiṭṭhiabhinandanāhiyeva abhinandamāno. Tatiyaṃ.
analyzed: tatiye abhinandamānaḥ ti taṇhā māna diṭṭhi abhinandana hiyā iva abhinandamānaḥ tatiyam
translated: In the third, he delights in means he delights in only through delight in craving, conceit, and views. The third.

original: 4-5. Aniccasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The fourth, etc.

original: 66-68. Catutthe chandoti taṇhāchando. Pañcamachaṭṭhesupi eseva nayo. Catutthādīni.
analyzed: catutthe chando ti taṇhā chando pañcama chaṭṭhesu pi esa iva nayo catuttha ādīni
translated: In the fourth, desire means desire for craving. The same method applies in the fifth and sixth. The fourth, etc.

original: 7. Anattaniyasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: anattaniya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The seventh, etc.

original: 69. Sattame anattaniyanti na attano santakaṃ, attano parikkhārabhāvena suññatanti attho. Sattamaṃ.🔽8-10. Rajanīyasaṇṭhitasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: sattame na attano santakam attano parikkhāra bhāvena suññatanti attho sattamam
translated: In the seventh, not his own means not his own property. The meaning is: empty as his own belongings. The seventh.🔽The eighth, etc.

original: 70-72. Aṭṭhame rajanīyasaṇṭhitanti rajanīyena ākārena saṇṭhitaṃ, rāgassa paccayabhāvena ṭhitanti attho. Navamadasamāni rāhulasaṃyutte vuttanayeneva veditabbānīti. Aṭṭhamādīni.
analyzed: aṭṭhame rajanīya saṇṭhitanti rajanīyena ākārena saṇṭhitam rāgassa paccaya bhāvena ṭhitanti attho navama dasamāni rāhulasaṃyutte vutta nayena iva veditabbāni iti aṭṭhama ādīni
translated: In the eighth, he is attached by what is delightful means he is attached by the aspect of what is delightful. The meaning is: he is present as a condition for lust. The remaining suttas from the ninth to the fifteenth should be understood in the same way as stated in the Rāhulasamyutta. The eighth, etc.

original: Arahantavaggo sattamo.🔽8. Khajjanīyavaggo
analyzed: arahanta vaggaḥ sattamaḥ  khajjanīya vaggaḥ
translated: The seventh sub-chapter, “The Worthy One,” is finished.

original: 1-3. Assādasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: assāda sutta ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: The sub-chapter on “To Be Devoured”

original: 73-75. Khajjanīyavaggassa ādito tīsu suttesu catusaccameva kathitaṃ. Paṭhamādīni.
analyzed: khajjanīya vaggassa āditas tīsu suttesu catu saccam eva kathitam paṭhama ādīni
translated: The first three suttas in the “To Be Devoured” sub-chapter explain the four noble truths. The first, etc.

original: 4. Arahantasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: arahanta sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: 4. The sutta on the Perfected Ones

original: 76. Catutthe yāvatā, bhikkhave, sattāvāsāti, bhikkhave, yattakā sattāvāsā nāma atthi.
analyzed: catutthe yāvatā bhikkhave sattāvāsā ati bhikkhave yattakā sattāvāsā nāma atthi
translated: In the fourth sutta, “as far as the abodes of beings extend” means as far as the abodes of beings extend.

original: Yāvatā bhavagganti yattakaṃ bhavaggaṃ nāma atthi. Ete aggā ete seṭṭhāti ete aggabhūtā🔽ceva seṭṭhabhūtā ca. Yadidaṃ arahantoti ye ime arahanto nāma. Idampi suttaṃ purimanayeneva
analyzed: yāvatā bhavaggam ti yattakam bhavaggam nāma atthi ete aggāḥ ete seṭṭhā ati ete agga bhūtā  ca iva seṭṭha bhūtā ca yat idam arahanto ti ye ime arahanto nāma idam pi suttam purima nayena iva
translated: “As far as the summit of becoming extends” means as far as the summit of becoming extends. These are the highest, these are the best, means these are the highest and these are the best.

original: ussadanandiyañca palobhanīyañcāti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: ussada nandiyam ca palobhanīyam ca ati veditabbam
translated: That is to say, the Perfected Ones: those who are called Perfected Ones. This sutta too should be understood as a praise of the Dhamma in terms of the noble fruit and as a praise of the Sangha in terms of the noble person.🔽Then he said this:

original: Athāparaṃ etadavocāti tadatthaparidīpanāhi ceva visesatthaparidīpanāhi ca gāthāhi
analyzed: atha aparam etat avoca ati tad attha paridīpanāhi ca iva visesa ttha paridīpanāhi ca gāthāhi
translated: The verses that explain the meaning of that and the meaning of the distinction

original: etaṃ “sukhino vata arahanto”tiādivacanaṃ avoca. Tattha sukhinoti jhānasukhena maggasukhena
analyzed: etam sukhinaḥ vata arahantaḥ iti ādi vacanam avoca tattha sukhinaḥ ti jhāna sukhena magga sukhena
translated: he said this statement beginning, “Happy indeed are the Perfected Ones.” Herein, happy means happy with the happiness of jhana, the happiness of the path,

original: phalasukhena ca sukhitā. Taṇhā tesaṃ na vijjatīti tesaṃ apāyadukkhajanikā taṇhā na
analyzed: phala sukhena ca sukhitā taṇhā tesam na vijjati iti tesam apāya dukkha janikā taṇhā na
translated: and the happiness of fruition. Craving does not exist for them means that craving, which is the cause of the suffering of the states of loss,

original: vajjati. Evaṃ te imassapi taṇhāmūlakassa abhāvena sukhitāva. Asmimāno samucchinnoti
analyzed: vajjati evam te imassa api taṇhā mūlakassa abhāvena asmimānaḥ samucchinnoti
translated: does not exist for them. Thus they are happy because of the non-existence of this craving, which has craving for its root. The conceit “I am” is cut off means

original: navavidho asmimāno arahattamaggena samucchinno. Mohajālaṃ padālitanti ñāṇena avijjājālaṃ phālitaṃ.
analyzed: navavidhaḥ asmimānaḥ arahatta maggena samucchinnaḥ moha jālam padālitan ti ñāṇena avijjā jālam phālitan
translated: The nine kinds of conceit are cut off by the path of arahatship. The net of delusion is torn: the net of ignorance is torn by knowledge.

original: Anejanti ejāsaṅkhātāya taṇhāya pahānabhūtaṃ arahattaṃ. Anupalittāti taṇhādiṭṭhilepehi
analyzed: ejanti ejā saṅkhātāya taṇhāya pahāna bhūtam arahattam taṇhā diṭṭhi lepehi
translated: Without outflows : arahatship, which is the state of having abandoned craving called “outflow.” Unstained : unstained by the stains of craving and views.

original: alittā. Brahmabhūtāti seṭṭhabhūtā. Pariññāyāti tīhi pariññāhi parijānitvā. Sattasaddhammagocarāti
analyzed: a littā brahma bhūtā ati seṭṭha bhūtā pariññāya ati tīhi pariññāhi parijānitvā satta saddhamma gocarā ati
translated: Divine : become the best. Having fully understood : having fully understood by means of the three kinds of full understanding. The seven good dhammas are the province :

original: saddhā hirī ottappaṃ bāhusaccaṃ āraddhavīriyatā upaṭṭhitassatitā paññāti ime satta
analyzed: saddhā hirī ottappam bāhusaccam āraddha vīriya tā upaṭṭhita ssati tā paññā ati ime satta
translated: faith, conscience, shame, learning, the state of being energetic, the state of being established in mindfulness, and wisdom.

original: saddhammā gocaro etesanti sattasaddhammagocarā.🔽Sattaratanasampannāti sattahi bojjhaṅgaratanehi samannāgatā. Anuvicarantīti lokiyamahājanāpi
analyzed: saddhammā gocaraḥ satta saddhamma gocarā  satta ratana sampannā ati sattahi bojjhaṅga ratanehi samannāgatā anuvicaranti iti lokiya mahājanā api
translated: These are the seven good dhammas. The province of these is the seven good dhammas.🔽Endowed with the seven treasures : endowed with the seven treasures of the factors of enlightenment.

original: anuvicarantiyeva. Idha pana khīṇāsavānaṃ nirāsaṅkacāro nāma gahito. Tenevāha “pahīnabhayabheravā”ti.
analyzed: idha pana khīṇāsavānam nirāsaṅkacāraḥ nāma tena iva āha pahīna bhaya bheravā ati
translated: They wander : ordinary people in the world also wander. But here the conduct of those free from cankers is meant, which is free from fear and timidity. Therefore it is said: “free from fear and trembling.”

original: Tattha bhayaṃ bhayameva, bheravaṃ balavabhayaṃ. Dasahaṅgehi sampannāti asekkhehi
analyzed: tattha bhayam bhayam eva bheravam balava bhayam dasa haṅgehi asekkhehi
translated: Herein, fear is fear itself, and trembling is strong fear. Endowed with the ten factors : the ten factors of one beyond training.

original: dasahi aṅgehi samannāgatā. Mahānāgāti catūhi kāraṇehi mahānāgā. Samāhitāti upacārappanāhi🔽samāhitā. Taṇhā tesaṃ na vijjatīti “ūno loko atitto taṇhādāsoti kho, mahārāja, tena
analyzed: dasahi aṅgehi samannāgatā mahānāgā ati catūhi kāraṇehi mahānāgā samāhitā ati upacāra ppanāhi  samāhitā taṇhā tesam na vijjati iti ūnaḥ lokaḥ a tittaḥ taṇhā dāso ti kho mahā rāja tena
translated: endowed with ten factors. Great Nāgas: Nāgas for four reasons. Concentrated: concentrated by access and absorption. Craving does not exist for them: “The world is deficient, O Great King, it is burning, it is ablaze with craving.

original: bhagavatā”ti evaṃ vuttā dāsakārikā taṇhāpi tesaṃ natthi. Iminā khīṇāsavānaṃ bhujissabhāvaṃ dasseti.
analyzed: bhagavatā ati evam vuttā dāsa kārikā taṇhā api tesam na atthi iminā khīṇāsavānam bhujissa bhāvam dasseti
translated: Endowed with ten factors. Great Nāgas: for four reasons they are great nāgas. Concentrated: concentrated by access concentration and absorption concentration. Craving does not exist for them: the slavery of craving spoken of thus, “Great king, the world is deficient, wanting, in that there is no slave-woman to be found who is free from craving” , does not exist for them. By this he shows the lordship of those whose cankers are destroyed.

original: Asekhañāṇanti arahattaphalañāṇaṃ. Antimoyaṃ samussayoti pacchimo ayaṃ attabhāvo.
analyzed: asekha ñāṇam ti arahatta phala ñāṇam antimaḥ iyam samussayo ti pacchimaḥ ayam atta bhāvo
translated: Knowledge of one beyond training: knowledge of the fruit of arahantship. This is the last: this is the last individual existence.

original: Yo sāro brahmacariyassāti sāro nāma phalaṃ. Tasmiṃ aparapaccayāti tasmiṃ ariyaphale,
analyzed: yaḥ sāraḥ brahmacariyassa ati sāraḥ nāma phalam tasmim apara paccayā ati tasmim ariya phale
translated: The essence of the holy life: the essence is the fruit. In that they have no need of another: in that fruit of the noble path,

original: na aññaṃ pattiyāyanti, paccakkhatova paṭivijjhitvā ṭhitā. Vidhāsu na vikampantīti
analyzed: na aññam pattiyāyanti paccakkhatas va paṭivijjhitvā ṭhitāḥ vidhāsu na vikampanti iti
translated: they have no need of another, that is, they stand having penetrated it by their own direct knowledge. They do not tremble in the face of the various:

original: tīsu mānakoṭṭhāsesu na vikampanti. Dantabhūminti arahattaṃ. Vijitāvinoti rāgādayo vijetvā ṭhitā.
analyzed: tīsu māna koṭṭhāsesu na vikampanti danta bhūmim ti arahattam vijita avino ti rāga ādayaḥ vijetvā ṭhitā
translated: they do not tremble in the face of the three kinds of conceit. The state of being tamed: arahantship. Conquerors: they stand having conquered greed, etc.

original: Uddhantiādīsu uddhaṃ vuccati kesamatthako, apācīnaṃ pādatalaṃ, tiriyaṃ vemajjhaṃ.
analyzed: uddha nti ādīsu uddham vuccati kesamatthako apācīnam pāda talam tiriyam vemajjham
translated: In the case of the words “above” and the rest, “above” is said to be the hair of the head and so on, “below” is the soles of the feet, and “across” is the middle part of the body.

original: Uddhaṃ vā atītaṃ, apācīnaṃ anāgataṃ, tiriyaṃ paccuppannaṃ. Uddhaṃ vā vuccati devaloko,🔽apācīnaṃ apāyaloko, tiriyaṃ manussaloko. Nandī tesaṃ na vijjatīti etesu ṭhānesu saṅkhepato
analyzed: uddham vā atītam apācīnam anāgatam tiriyam paccuppannam uddham vā vuccati deva loko  apācīnam apāya loko tiriyam manussa lokaḥ nandī tesam na vijjati iti etesu ṭhānesu saṅkhepato
translated: Or else “above” is said to be the heavenly world, “below” is the world of the brutes, and “across” is the human world.

original: vā atītānāgatapaccuppannesu khandhesu tesaṃ taṇhā natthi. Idha vaṭṭamūlakataṇhāya
analyzed: vā atīta anāgata paccuppannesu khandhesu tesam taṇhā natthi idha vaṭṭa mūlaka taṇhāya
translated: “They have no delight in these” means that in brief, in these places, in the aggregates of the past, future, and present, they have no craving. Here the absence of craving rooted in the round is shown.

original: abhāvo dassito. Buddhāti catunnaṃ saccānaṃ buddhattā buddhā.🔽Idaṃ panettha sīhanādasamodhānaṃ – “vimuttisukhenamhā sukhitā, dukkhajanikā no taṇhā
analyzed: abhāvaḥ dassitaḥ buddha ati catunnam saccānam buddha ttā buddhā  idam pana ittha sīha nāda samodhānam vimutti sukhena amhā sukhitā dukkha janikā no taṇhā
translated: “Enlightened” means enlightened with regard to the four truths.

original: pahīnā, pañcakkhandhā pariññātā, dāsakārikataṇhā ceva vaṭṭamūlikataṇhā ca pahīnā,
analyzed: pahīnā pañca kkhandhāḥ pariññātāḥ dāsakārika taṇhā ca iva vaṭṭamūlika taṇhā ca pahīnā
translated: This is the application of the simile of the lion’s roar: “We are happy with the happiness of liberation; the craving that causes suffering is abandoned; the five aggregates are fully understood; the craving that is like a slave and the craving rooted in the round are abandoned;

original: anuttaramhā asadisā, catunnaṃ saccānaṃ buddhattā buddhā”ti bhavapiṭṭhe ṭhatvā abhītanādasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: catunnam saccānam buddha ttā buddha ati bhavapiṭṭhe ṭhatvā abhīta nāda saṅkhātam
translated: we are unsurpassed, incomparable, enlightened with regard to the four truths.” Standing on the back of becoming, they utter the lion’s roar called “fearlessness.”

original: sīhanādaṃ nadanti khīṇāsavāti. Catutthaṃ.
analyzed: sīhanādam nadanti catuttham
translated: they roar their lion’s roar as those whose taints are destroyed.” The fourth .

original: 5. Dutiyaarahantasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya arahanta sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The second on those who are Perfect in virtue.

original: 77. Pañcamaṃ vinā gāthāhi suddhikameva katvā kathiyamānaṃ bujjhanakānaṃ ajjhāsayena vuttaṃ. Pañcamaṃ.🔽6. Sīhasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: pañcamam vinā gāthāhi suddhikam eva katvā kathiyamānam bujjhanakānam ajjhāsayena vuttam pañcamam  sīha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The fifth is stated in the way it is without a verse, in order to arouse the minds of those who are to be developed. The fifth .🔽. The Lion.

original: 78. Chaṭṭhe sīhoti cattāro sīhā – tiṇasīho, kāḷasīho, paṇḍusīho, kesarasīhoti. Tesu🔽tiṇasīho kapotavaṇṇagāvisadiso tiṇabhakkho ca hoti. Kāḷasīho kāḷagāvisadiso tiṇabhakkhoyeva.
analyzed: chaṭṭhe sīho ti cattāro sīhā tiṇasīhaḥ kāḷasīhaḥ paṇḍusīhaḥ kesarasīhaḥ ti tesu  tiṇa sīhaḥ kapota vaṇṇagā visadisaḥ tiṇa bhakkhaḥ ca hoti kāḷasīhaḥ kāḷagā visadisaḥ tiṇa bhakkhaḥ yeva
translated: In the sixth , there are four kinds of lions: the grass lion, the black lion, the white lion, and the tawny lion.🔽Of these, the grass lion is the colour of a dove and eats grass. The black lion is the colour of a black cow and eats grass too.

original: Paṇḍusīho paṇḍupalāsavaṇṇagāvisadiso maṃsabhakkho. Kesarasīho lākhārasaparikammakateneva
analyzed: paṇḍu sīhaḥ paṇḍu palāsa vaṇṇagā visadisaḥ maṃsa bhakkhaḥ kesarasīhaḥ lākhā rasa parikamma katena iva
translated: The white lion is the colour of a withered leaf and eats meat. The tawny lion has a muzzle and a tail-tuft like those in the picture of a lion made with lac dye,

original: mukhena agganaṅguṭṭhena catūhi ca pādapariyantehi samannāgato, matthakatopissa paṭṭhāya
analyzed: mukhena agganaṅguṭṭhena catūhi ca pāda pariyantehi samannāgataḥ matthakataḥ pissa paṭṭhāya
translated: and it has four claws on each foot, and even from the top of its head

original: lākhātūlikāya katvā viya tisso rājiyo piṭṭhimajjhena gantvā antarasatthimhi dakkhiṇāvattā
analyzed: lākhā tūlikāya katvā viya tissaḥ rājiyaḥ piṭṭhi majjhena gantvā antarasatthimhi dakkhiṇāvattā
translated: lac dye has been applied as if with a brush, and three lines go along the backbone to the spine in the tail,

original: hutvā ṭhitā, khandhe panassa satasahassagghanikakambalaparikkhepo viya kesarabhāro
analyzed: hutvā ṭhitā khandhe panassa sata sahassa gghanika kambala parikkhepaḥ viya kesara bhāro
translated: and the hair of his head and beard, which was worth a hundred thousand, was like a fence of wool round him.

original: hoti, avasesaṭṭhānaṃ parisuddhaṃ sālipiṭṭhasaṅkhacuṇṇapicuvaṇṇaṃ hoti. Imesu catūsu
analyzed: hoti avasesa ṭṭhānam parisuddham sāli piṭṭha saṅkha cuṇṇa picu vaṇṇam hoti imesu catūsu
translated: But his mane is like a covering of a hundred-thousand- piece shawl over his shoulders. The rest of his body is pure like the colour of rice powder or lime powder.

original: sīhesu ayaṃ kesarasīho idha adhippeto.🔽Migarājāti migagaṇassa rājā. Āsayāti vasanaṭṭhānato suvaṇṇaguhato vā rajatamaṇiphalikamanosilāguhato🔽vā nikkhamatīti vuttaṃ hoti. Nikkhamamāno panesa catūhi kāraṇehi nikkhamati andhakārapīḷito🔽vā ālokatthāya, uccārapassāvapīḷito vā tesaṃ vissajjanatthāya, jighacchāpīḷito vā
analyzed: sīhesu ayam kesarasīhaḥ idha adhippeto  miga rājā ati miga gaṇassa rājā āsayā ati vasana ṭṭhānataḥ suvaṇṇa guhataḥ vā rajata maṇi phalika manosilā guhataḥ  vā nikkhamati iti vuttam hoti nikkhamamānaḥ pana esa catūhi kāraṇehi nikkhamati andhakāra pīḷito  vā āloka atthāya uccāra passāva pīḷitaḥ vā tesam vissajjana tthāya jighacchā pīḷitaḥ vā
translated: Of these four lions, it is the maned lion that is intended here.

original: gocaratthāya, sambhavapīḷito vā assaddhammapaṭisevanatthāya. Idha pana gocaratthāya🔽nikkhantoti adhippeto.
analyzed: gocara tthāya sambhava pīḍitaḥ vā assaddhamma paṭisevana tthāya idha pana gocara tthāya  nikkhanto ti adhippeto
translated: King of beasts: king of the herd of deer. From his lair: from his dwelling-place, which is either a golden cave or a crystal, gem or marble cave. What is meant is that he comes out. But he comes out for four reasons: either because he is oppressed by darkness and wants light, or because he is oppressed by urine and excrement and wants to get rid of them, or because he is oppressed by hunger and wants to find his food, or because he is oppressed by lust and wants to indulge in sexual intercourse. But here he is intended as coming out for the purpose of finding his food.

original: Vijambhatīti suvaṇṇatale vā rajatamaṇiphalikamanosilātalānaṃ vā aññatarasmiṃ dve
analyzed: vijambhati iti suvaṇṇa tale vā rajata maṇi phalika manosilā talānam vā aññatarasmim dve
translated: He yawns: on a golden surface or on a crystal, gem or marble surface.

original: pacchimapāde samaṃ patiṭṭhāpetvā purimapāde purato pasāretvā sarīrassa pacchābhāgaṃ
analyzed: pacchima pāde samam patiṭṭhāpetvā purima pāde puratas pasāretvā sarīrassa pacchābhāgam
translated: and then he stretches out his forepart and draws in his hindpart,🔽and he yawns, yawning like the sound of thunder, shaking the dust on his body.

original: ākaḍḍhitvā purimabhāgaṃ abhiharitvā piṭṭhiṃ nāmetvā gīvaṃ ukkhipitvā asanisaddaṃ🔽karonto viya nāsapuṭāni pothetvā sarīralaggaṃ rajaṃ vidhunanto vijambhati. Vijambhanabhūmiyañca🔽pana taruṇavacchako viya aparāparaṃ javati. Javato panassa sarīraṃ andhakāre paribbhamantaṃ
analyzed: ākaḍḍhitvā purima bhāgam abhiharitvā piṭṭhim nāmetvā gīvam ukkhipitvā asani saddam  karontaḥ viya nāsa puṭāni pothetvā sarīra laggam rajam vidhunantaḥ vijambhati vijambhana bhūmiyañca  pana taruṇa vacchakaḥ viya apara aparam javati javataḥ panassa sarīram andhakāre paribbhamantam
translated: And when he is yawning he moves to and fro like a young calf.

original: alātaṃ viya khāyati.🔽Anuviloketīti kasmā anuviloketi? Parānuddayatāya. Tasmiṃ kira sīhanādaṃ nadante papātāvāṭādīsu
analyzed: alātam viya khāyati  anuvilokā iti iti kasmai anuvilokā iti tasmin kira sīha nādam nadante papāta āvāṭa ādīsu
translated: And as he moves his body appears like a whirling firebrand to those who are in the dark.

original: visamaṭṭhānesu carantā hatthigokaṇṇamahiṃsādayo pāṇā papātepi āvāṭepi patanti, tesaṃ
analyzed: visama ṭṭhānesu carantā hatthi gokaṇṇa mahiṃsa ādayo pāṇā papāte pi āvāṭe pi patanti tesam
translated: Why does he look around? Out of compassion for others. For when he roars, it seems, elephants, oxen, buffaloes, and other creatures that wander in uneven places such as ravines and pits fall into the ravines and pits.🔽He looks around out of compassion for them.

original: anuddayāya anuviloketi. Kiṃ panassa luddakammassa paramaṃsakhādino anuddayā nāma
analyzed: anuddayāya anuvilokā iti kim panassa ludda kammassa para maṃsa khādinaḥ anuddayā nāma
translated: But why is he compassionate towards hunters and the like who are his enemies?

original: atthīti? Āma atthi. Tathā hesa “kiṃ me bahūhi ghātitehī”ti? Attano gocaratthāyapi🔽khuddake pāṇe na gaṇhāti, evaṃ anuddayaṃ karoti. Vuttampicetaṃ – “māhaṃ kho khuddake
analyzed: atthi iti atthi tathā ha isa kim me bahūhi ghātitehi iti attanaḥ gocara tthāya api  khuddake pāṇe na gaṇhāti evam anuddayam karoti vuttam pi ca itam mā aham kho khuddake
translated: “Is there?” “Yes, there is.” For he thinks, “What is the use of killing many?”

original: pāṇe visamagate saṅghātaṃ āpādesi”nti.
analyzed: pāṇe visama gate saṅghātam
translated: He does not even take small creatures for his own food. Thus he is “not violent.” And this is said of him: “I do not bring about the destruction of small creatures that have strayed into my path.”

original: Sīhanādaṃ nadatīti tikkhattuṃ tāva abhītanādaṃ nadati. Evañca panassa vijambhanabhūmiyaṃ🔽ṭhatvā nadantassa saddo samantā tiyojanapadesaṃ ekaninnādaṃ karoti, tamassa ninnādaṃ
analyzed: sīha nādam nadati iti tikkhattum tāva abhīta nādam nadati evam ca panassa vijambhana bhūmiyam  ṭhatvā nadantassa saddo samantā eka ninnādam karoti tamassa ninnādam
translated: “He roars his lion’s roar”: first he roars his fearless roar three times. And when he roars, standing on the ground where he has yawned,

original: sutvā tiyojanabbhantaragatā dvipadacatuppadagaṇā yathāṭhāne ṭhātuṃ na sakkonti. Gocarāya🔽pakkamatīti āhāratthāya gacchati. Kathaṃ? So hi vijambhanabhūmiyaṃ ṭhatvā dakkhiṇato
analyzed: sutvā ti yojana abbhantara gatāḥ dvipada catuppada gaṇāḥ yathāṭhāne ṭhātum na sakkonti gocarāya  pakkamati iti āhāra atthāya gacchati katham saḥ hi vijambhana bhūmiyam ṭhatvā dakkhiṇatas
translated: his roar makes a single sound throughout a region of three leagues all around. When the multitude of bipeds and quadrupeds within a region of three leagues hears that roar, they are unable to remain where they are.

original: vā vāmato vā uppatanto usabhamattaṃ ṭhānaṃ gaṇhāti, uddhaṃ uppatanto cattāripi aṭṭhapi
analyzed: vā vāmatas vā uppatantaḥ usabha mattam ṭhānam gaṇhāti uddham uppatantaḥ cattāri pi aṭṭha pi
translated: “He goes on his rounds for alms”: he goes for the purpose of eating. How? Standing on the ground where he has yawned, he takes a position the height of a bull when jumping, either to the right or to the left. When he jumps upward, he takes a position four or eight times the height of a bull.

original: usabhāni uppatati, samaṭṭhāne ujukaṃ pakkhandanto soḷasausabhamattampi vīsatiusabhamattampi
analyzed: usabhāni uppatati samaṭṭhāne ujukam pakkhandantaḥ soḷasa usabha mattam pi vīsati usabha mattam pi
translated: He springs up to the height of a palm-tree, and when he lands he does so in a place sixteen or twenty cubits distant.

original: ṭhānaṃ pakkhandati, thalā vā pabbatā vā pakkhandanto saṭṭhiusabhamattampi asītiusabhamattampi🔽ṭhānaṃ pakkhandati, antarāmagge rukkhaṃ vā pabbataṃ vā disvā taṃ pariharanto vāmato🔽vā dakkhiṇato vā, usabhamattampi apakkamati. Tatiyaṃ pana sīhanādaṃ naditvā teneva
analyzed: ṭhānam pakkhandati thalāḥ vā pabbatāḥ vā pakkhandantaḥ saṭṭhi usabha mattam pi asīti usabha mattam pi  ṭhānam pakkhandati antara āmagge rukkham vā pabbatam vā disvā tam pariharantaḥ vāmatas  vā dakkhiṇatas vā usabha mattam pi apakkamati tatiyam pana sīha nādam naditvā tena iva
translated: When he lands on the ground or on a rock, he does so in a place sixty or eighty cubits distant.🔽When he sees a tree or a rock on the way, he avoids it, going either to the left or to the right, and he goes back a distance of sixteen cubits.

original: saddhiṃ tiyojane ṭhāne paññāyati. Tiyojanaṃ gantvā nivattitvā ṭhito attanova nādassa
analyzed: saddhim ti yojane ṭhāne paññāyati ti yojanam gantvā nivattitvā ṭhitaḥ attanaḥ iva nādassa
translated: But when he roars his third roar, it is heard within a distance of three leagues. Having gone three leagues, he turns back and stands there. He himself hears the echo of his own roar.

original: anunādaṃ suṇāti. Evaṃ sīghena javena pakkamatīti.
analyzed: anunādam suṇāti evam sīghena javena pakkamati iti
translated: He goes with such speed.

original: Yebhuyyenāti pāyena. Bhayaṃ saṃvegaṃ santāsanti sabbaṃ cittutrāsasseva nāmaṃ. Sīhassa
analyzed: yebhuyyena ati pāyena bhayam saṃvegam santāsanti sabbam cittutrāsassa iva nāmam sīhassa
translated: Yebhuyyenāti pāyena: for the most part. Bhayaṃ saṃvegaṃ santāsanti: all these are names for fear of the mind.

original: hi saddaṃ sutvā bahū sattā bhāyanti, appakā na bhāyanti. Ke pana teti? Samasīho hatthājānīyo
analyzed: hi saddam sutvā bahū sattāḥ bhāyanti appakāḥ na bhāyanti ke pana te iti samasīhaḥ hatthājānīyaḥ
translated: For when they hear the lion’s roar, many beings are afraid, but few are not afraid.🔽But who are they? The lion’s equal is the elephant.

original: assājānīyo usabhājānīyo purisājānīyo khīṇāsavoti. Kasmā panete na bhāyantīti? Samasīho
analyzed: assājānīyaḥ usabhājānīyaḥ purisājānīyaḥ khīṇa asavaḥ ti kasmā pana ete na bhāyanti iti samasīhaḥ
translated: a horse thoroughbred, a bull thoroughbred, a human thoroughbred, and one whose cankers are destroyed. But why are they not afraid?

original: nāma “jātigottakulasūrabhāvehi samānosmī”ti na bhāyati, hatthājānīyādayo attano sakkāyadiṭṭhibalavatāya
analyzed: nāma jāti gotta kula sūra bhāvehi samānaḥ asmi iti na bhāyati attano sakkāya diṭṭhi balavatāya
translated: The lion, called the “equal,” is not afraid, thinking, “I am equal in species, family, and strength.” The horse thoroughbred, etc., are not afraid because of the strength of their false view of self.

original: na bhāyanti, khīṇāsavo sakkāyadiṭṭhipahīnattā na bhāyati.
analyzed: na bhāyanti khīṇa asavo sakkāya diṭṭhi pahīna ttā na bhāyati
translated: The one whose cankers are destroyed is not afraid because he has abandoned the false view of self.

original: Bilāsayāti bile sayantā bilavāsino ahinakulagodhādayo. Dakāsayāti udakavāsino macchakacchapādayo.🔽Vanāsayāti vanavāsino hatthiassagokaṇṇamigādayo. Pavisantīti “idāni āgantvā gaṇhissatī”ti
analyzed: bilāsayāti bile sayantāḥ bila vāsinaḥ ahi nakula godhā ādayaḥ dakāsayāti udaka vāsinaḥ maccha kacchapa ādayaḥ  vanāsayā ati vana vāsinaḥ hatthi assa gokaṇṇa miga ādayaḥ pavisanti iti idāni āgantvā gaṇhissati iti
translated: “Dwelling in holes” are those that live in holes, such as snakes, mongooses, and rats. “Dwelling in water” are those that live in water, such as fish, turtles, and so on.🔽“Dwelling in the forest” are those that live in the forest, such as elephants, horses, oxen, deer, and so on. “Entering” means that they enter the path, thinking, “Now he will come and catch me.”

original: maggaṃ olokentāva pavisanti. Daḷhehīti thirehi. Varattehīti cammarajjūhi. Mahiddhikotiādīsu
analyzed: maggam olokentā ava pavisanti daḷhehi iti thirehi varattehi iti camma rajjūhi mahiddhika uti ādīsu
translated: “Tie up” means with strong ropes. “Greatly powerful” and so on.

original: vijambhanabhūmiyaṃ ṭhatvā dakkhiṇapassādīhi usabhamattaṃ, ujukaṃ vīsatiusabhamattādilaṅghanavasena
analyzed: vijambhana bhūmiyam ṭhatvā dakkhiṇa passa ādīhi usabha mattam ujukam vīsati usabha matta ādi laṅghana vasena
translated: Standing on the ground of yawning, with his right side and so on, he is like a bull. Straight, with the manner of leaping, with the manner of a bull, and so on,

original: mahiddhikatā, sesamigānaṃ adhipatibhāvena mahesakkhatā, samantā tiyojane saddaṃ sutvā
analyzed: mahiddhika tā sesa migānam adhipati bhāvena mahesakkha tā samantā ti yojane saddam sutvā
translated: the Greatness of Power, the Greatness of Authority over the other animals, the Greatness of Fame, the Greatness of Glory, the Greatness of Splendour, the Greatness of Wealth, the Greatness
