analyzed: upagatam paccatthikam paccatthikaḥ me ayanti ñatvā appamattaḥ tāni tāni kammāni kāretvā  anattham pariharati attham pāpuṇāti evam sutavā ariya sāvakaḥ api na rūpam
translated: having found out that the other is his enemy, is careful, has the various kinds of work done,🔽avoids what is unprofitable and obtains what is profitable,

original: samanupassatī”tiādinā nayena pañcakkhandhe ahanti vā mamanti vā agahetvā, “paccatthikā
analyzed: samanupassati iti ādinā nayena pañca kkhandhe ahanti vā mamanti vā a gahetvā paccatthikā
translated: so too the learned noble disciple, without taking the five aggregates as “my self” or as “myself” in the way beginning, “He does not assume feeling to be his self” ,🔽having found out that “these are my enemies,”

original: me ete”ti ñatvā rūpasattakaarūpasattakādivasena vipassanāya yojetvāva tatonidānaṃ
analyzed: me ete iti ñatvā rūpa sattaka arūpa sattaka ādi vasena vipassanāya yojetvā ava tatonidānam
translated: combines insight with the aggregates by way of the seven sets of seven, beginning with the aggregate of material form, and avoids what is unprofitable and obtains what is profitable.

original: dukkhaṃ parivajjetvā aggaphalaṃ arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti. Sesamettha uttānameva. Tatiyaṃ.
analyzed: dukkham parivajjetvā agga phalam arahattam pāpuṇāti sesam ettha uttānam eva tatiyam
translated: and after avoiding suffering he reached the supreme fruit, Arahantship. The rest is clear. The Third Chapter.

original: 4. Anurādhasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: anurādha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Anurādha Sutta

original: 86. Catutthe araññakuṭikāyanti tasseva vihārassa paccante paṇṇasālāyaṃ. Taṃ tathāgatoti🔽tumhākaṃ satthā tathāgato taṃ sattaṃ tathāgataṃ. Aññatra imehīti tassa kira evaṃ
analyzed: catutthe arañña kuṭikāyanti tassa iva vihārassa paccante tam tathāgataḥ ti  tumhākam satthā tathāgato tam sattam tathāgatam aññatra imehi iti tassa kira evam
translated: In the fourth sutta, “a hut in the forest” means in a leaf hut behind the monastery. “The Tathāgata”:

original: ahosi “ime sāsanassa paṭipakkhā paṭivilomā, yathā ime bhaṇanti, na evaṃ satthā paññāpessati,🔽aññathā paññāpessatī”ti. Tasmā evamāha. Evaṃ vutte te aññatitthiyāti evaṃ therena
analyzed: ahosi ime sāsanassa paṭipakkhā paṭivilomā yathā ime bhaṇanti na evam satthā paññāpessati  aññathā paññāpessati iti tasmai evam āha evam vutte te añña titthiyā ti evam therena
translated: your Teacher, the Tathāgata. “That Tathāgata”: that Tathāgata, that being. “Except on these grounds”: it seems that he thought, “These are opponents of the Dispensation, hostile to it. The Teacher will not describe things in the way they do.

original: attano ca paresañca samayaṃ ajānitvā vutte ekadesena sāsanasamayaṃ jānantā therassa
analyzed: attano ca paresam ca samayam a jānitvā vutte ekadesena sāsana samayam jānantā therassa
translated: He will describe them otherwise.” That is why he said, “Except on these grounds.” When this was said, “those wanderers of other sects”: when the elder had said this, not knowing the occasion for himself or for others,🔽knowing only one aspect of the occasion for the Dispensation,

original: vāde dosaṃ dātukāmā te aññatitthiyā paribbājakā āyasmantaṃ anurādhaṃ etadavocuṃ.
analyzed: vāde dosam dātu kāmā te añña titthiyāḥ paribbājakāḥ āyasmantam anurādham etat avocuṃ
translated: desiring to find fault with the elder’s statement, those wanderers of other sects said this to the venerable Anurādha.

original: Taṃ kiṃ maññasi anurādhāti satthā tassa kathaṃ sutvā cintesi – “ayaṃ bhikkhu attano
analyzed: tam kim maññasi anurādhā ati satthā tassa katham sutvā cintesi ayam bhikkhu attanaḥ
translated: “What do you think of this, Anurādha?” The Teacher, having heard his statement, thought, “This bhikkhu

original: laddhiyaṃ dosaṃ na jānāti, kārako panesa yuttayogo, dhammadesanāya eva naṃ jānāpessāmī”ti
analyzed: dosam na jānāti kārako pana isa yutta yogaḥ dhamma desanāya eva nam jānāpessāmi iti
translated: He does not know the fault in himself, but he is a worker and a helper. I will make him know it by teaching him the Dhamma.”

original: tiparivaṭṭaṃ desanaṃ desetukāmo “taṃ kiṃ maññasi, anurādhā”tiādimāha. Athassa tāya
analyzed: ti parivaṭṭam desanam desetu kāmo tam kim maññasi anurādhā iti ādim āha atha assa tāya
translated: Desiring to teach the Dhamma in the three turnings, he said: “What do you think, Anurādha?” Then,

original: desanāya arahattappattassa anuyogavattaṃ āropento taṃ kiṃ maññasi, anurādha? Rūpaṃ
analyzed: desanāya arahatta ppattassa anuyogavattam āropento tam kim maññasi anurādha rūpaṃ
translated: after he had attained arahantship through that teaching, the Exalted One, in order to establish him in the duties of a disciple, said: “What do you think, Anurādha? Is material form …

original: tathāgatotiādimāha. Dukkhañceva paññapemi, dukkhassa ca nirodhanti vaṭṭadukkhañceva
analyzed: tathāgataḥ tiādim āha dukkhañca iva paññapemi dukkhassa ca nirodhanti vaṭṭa dukkhañca iva
translated: Is the Tathāgata?” He teaches the four noble truths: “I declare suffering and the cessation of suffering.”

original: vaṭṭadukkhassa ca nirodhaṃ nibbānaṃ paññapemi. Dukkhanti vā vacanena dukkhasaccaṃ🔽gahitaṃ. Tasmiṃ gahite samudayasaccaṃ gahitameva hoti, tassa mūlattā. Nirodhanti
analyzed: vaṭṭa dukkhassa ca nirodham nibbānam paññapemi dukkhan ti vā vacanena dukkha saccam  gahitam tasmin gahite samudaya saccam gahitam eva hoti tassa mūla ttā nirodhanti
translated: By the words “suffering” and “cessation,” he teaches the truth of suffering and the truth of cessation.

original: vacanena nirodhasaccaṃ gahitaṃ. Tasmiṃ gahite maggasaccaṃ gahitameva hoti tassa upāyattā.
analyzed: vacanena nirodha saccam gahitam tasmin gahite magga saccam gahitam eva hoti tassa upāyattā
translated: When the truth of suffering is grasped, the truth of origination is also grasped, because the latter is the root of the former. When cessation is grasped, the path is also grasped, because the path is the means to cessation.

original: Iti pubbe cāhaṃ, anurādha, etarahi ca catusaccameva paññapemīti dasseti. Evaṃ imasmiṃ
analyzed: iti pubbe ca aham anurādhe etarahi ca catu saccam eva paññapemi iti dasseti evam imasmin
translated: Thus he shows that in the past as well as now he teaches only the four truths.

original: sutte vaṭṭavivaṭṭameva kathitaṃ. Catutthaṃ.
analyzed: sutte vaṭṭa vivaṭṭam eva kathitam catuttham
translated: In the sutta itself, only the right and wrong ways of doing this are mentioned. The fourth.

original: 5. Vakkalisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vakkali sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Vakkali Sutta

original: 87. Pañcame kumbhakāranivesaneti kumbhakārasālāyaṃ. Thero kira vutthavasso pavāretvā
analyzed: pañcame kumbhakāra nivesana iti kumbhakāra sālā ayam theraḥ kira vuttha vassaḥ pavāretvā
translated: In the potter’s workshop: in the potter’s shed. The elder, it seems, had spent the Rains and was about to go to see the Blessed One after the Invitation ceremony.

original: bhagavantaṃ dassanāya āgacchati. Tassa nagaramajjhe mahāābādho uppajji, pādā na vahanti.
analyzed: bhagavantam dassanāya āgacchati tassa nagara majjhe mahā ābādhaḥ uppajji pādāḥ na vahanti
translated: On the way he fell seriously ill in the middle of the town. His feet would not carry him any further.

original: Atha naṃ mañcakasivikāya kumbhakārasālaṃ āhariṃsu. Sā ca sālā tesaṃ kammasālā, na
analyzed: atha nam mañcaka sivikāya kumbhakāra sālam āhariṃsu sā ca sālā tesam kamma sālā na
translated: So they brought him to the potter’s shed on a litter. And that shed was their workshop, not a dwelling-place.

original: nivesanasālā. Taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “kumbhakāranivesane viharatī”ti. Bāḷhagilānoti
analyzed: nivesana sālā tam sandhāya vuttam kumbhakāra nivesane viharati iti bāḷha gilānaḥ ti
translated: That is why it is said that he was “staying in the potter’s workshop.” He was “very ill”: he was seriously ill.

original: adhimattagilāno. Samadhosīti samantato adhosi, calanākārena apacitiṃ dassesi. Vattaṃ
analyzed: adhimatta gilānaḥ samadhosi iti samantataḥ adhosi calana ākārena apacitim dassesi vattam
translated: “He was lying down” : he was lying down with his whole body, showing his lack of interest by his inactivity.

original: kiretaṃ bāḷhagilānenapi buḍḍhataraṃ disvā uṭṭhānākārena apaciti dassetabbā. Tena
analyzed: kiretam bāḷha gilānena api buḍḍhataram disvā uṭṭhāna ākārena apaciti dassetabbā tena
translated: The practice is that even one who is very ill should show his lack of interest by getting up when he sees a more senior elder.

original: pana “mā cali mā calī”ti vattabbo. Santimāni āsanānīti buddhakālasmiñhi ekassapi
analyzed: pana mā cali mā cali iti vattabbo santi imāni āsanāni iti buddha kālasmin hi ekassa api
translated: But he should be told, “Don’t get up, venerable sir, don’t get up.” “There are these seats” : in the time of the Buddha, there were no chairs.

original: bhikkhuno vasanaṭṭhāne “sace satthā āgacchissati, idha nisīdissatī”ti āsanaṃ paññattameva🔽hoti antamaso phalakamattampi paṇṇasanthāramattampi. Khamanīyaṃ yāpanīyanti kacci
analyzed: bhikkhuno vasana ṭṭhāne sace satthā āgacchissati idha nisīdissati iti āsanam paññattam eva  hoti antamasaḥ phalaka mattam pi paṇṇa santhāra mattam pi khamanīyam yāpanīyanti kacci
translated: The monks’ dwelling place is already prepared with a seat, at least a piece of wood or a mat of leaves, thinking: “If the Teacher comes, he will sit here.”🔽“Is it bearable? Can you carry on?” he asks, meaning: “Can you bear the pain and carry on with your posture?”

original: dukkhaṃ khamituṃ iriyāpathaṃ vā yāpetuṃ sakkāti pucchati. Paṭikkamantīti nivattanti.🔽Abhikkamantīti adhigacchanti. Paṭikkamosānanti paṭikkamo etāsaṃ. Sīlato na upavadatīti
analyzed: dukkham khamitum iriyāpatham vā yāpetum sakkā iti pucchati paṭikkamanti iti nivattanti  abhikkamanti iti adhigacchanti paṭikkama usānanti paṭikkamaḥ etāsam sīlataḥ naḥ upavadati iti
translated: “They are turning back” means they are turning away.🔽“They are advancing” means they are approaching. “Their turning back” means their turning away.🔽“He does not reproach them in regard to virtue” means he does not reproach them in regard to virtue, i.e., he does not say: “Your virtue is poor.”

original: sīlaṃ ārabbha sīlabhāvena na upavadati. Cirapaṭikāhanti cirapaṭiko ahaṃ, cirato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: sīlam ārabbha sīla bhāvena naḥ upavadati cira paṭikā hanti cira paṭikaḥ aham ciratas paṭṭhāya
translated: “I have been turning back for a long time” means: “I have been turning away for a long time.” The meaning is: “From a long time ago I have been turning away from the world.”

original: ahanti attho. Pūtikāyenāti attano suvaṇṇavaṇṇampi kāyaṃ bhagavā dhuvapaggharaṇaṭṭhena
analyzed: aham ti suvaṇṇa vaṇṇam pi kāyam bhagavā dhuva paggharaṇa ṭṭhena
translated: “This putrid body” means: the Blessed One says this in the sense of the constant flow of urine and excrement from the body, even though it is the color of gold.

original: evamāha. Yo kho, vakkali, dhammanti idha bhagavā “dhammakāyo kho, mahārāja, tathāgato”ti
analyzed: evam āha yaḥ kho vakkali dhammanti idha bhagavā dhamma kāyaḥ kho mahā rāja tathāgataḥ ti
translated: “One who has the Dhamma” means: here the Blessed One shows the Dhamma-body, which is said in the passage: “The Tathagata is a Dhamma-body, great king.”

original: vuttaṃ dhammakāyataṃ dasseti. Navavidho hi lokuttaradhammo tathāgatassa kāyo nāma.
analyzed: vuttam dhammakāyatam dasseti navavidhaḥ hi lokuttara dhammo tathāgatassa kāyaḥ nāma
translated: For the Tathagata’s body is of nine kinds of supramundane Dhamma.

original: Idāni therassa tiparivaṭṭadhammadesanaṃ ārabhanto taṃ kiṃ maññasītiādimāha. Kāḷasilāti
analyzed: idāni therassa tiparivaṭṭa dhamma desanam ārabhanto tam kim maññasi iti ādim āha
translated: Now, beginning the teaching of the Dhamma in three sections, he said, “What do you think about this?” Kāḷasilā means

original: kāḷasilāvihāro. Vimokkhāyāti maggavimokkhatthāya. Suvimutto vimuccissatīti arahattaphalavimuttiyā🔽vimutto hutvā vimuccissati. Tā kira devatā “yena nīhārena iminā vipassanā āraddhā,
analyzed: kāḷasilā vihāraḥ vimokkhāya ati magga vimokkha atthāya su vimuttaḥ vimuccissati iti arahatta phala vimuttiyā  vimuttaḥ hutvā vimuccissati tāḥ kira devatāḥ yena nīhārena iminā vipassanā āraddhā
translated: Kāḷasilā Monastery. For the sake of deliverance means for the sake of the deliverance of the path. Well delivered, will be delivered means🔽having been delivered by the deliverance of the fruit of arahantship, he will be delivered. It seems that those deities, knowing that the penetration of insight had been begun by him,

original: anantarāyena arahattaṃ pāpuṇissatī”ti ñatvā evamāhaṃsu. Apāpakanti alāmakaṃ. Satthaṃ
analyzed: anantarāyena arahattam pāpuṇissati iti ñatvā evam āhaṃsu a pāpakam ti a lāmakam sattham
translated: and that he would attain arahantship without hindrance, said this. Free from evil means free from defilements.

original: āharesīti thero kira adhimāniko ahosi. So samādhivipassanāhi vikkhambhitānaṃ kilesānaṃ
analyzed: āharesi iti theraḥ kira adhimānikaḥ ahosi so samādhi vipassanāhi vikkhambhitānam kilesānam
translated: Took a knife means it seems that the elder was over-confident. He, not seeing the manifestation of the defilements that had been suppressed by concentration and insight,

original: samudācāraṃ apassanto “khīṇāsavomhī”ti saññī hutvā “kiṃ me iminā dukkhena jīvitena?
analyzed: samudācāram a passanto khīṇāsavaḥ asmi iti saññī hutvā kim me iminā dukkhena jīvitena
translated: thinking, “I am one whose cankers are destroyed,” said, “What is the use of this life of suffering to me?

original: Satthaṃ āharitvā marissāmī”ti tikhiṇena satthena kaṇṭhanāḷaṃ chindi. Athassa dukkhā
analyzed: sattham āharitvā marissāmi iti tikhiṇena satthena kaṇṭha nāḷam chindi athassa dukkhā
translated: I will take a knife and die.” With a sharp knife he cut his throat. Then painful

original: vedanā uppajji. So tasmiṃ khaṇe attano puthujjanabhāvaṃ ñatvā avissaṭṭhakammaṭṭhānattā
analyzed: vedanā uppajji saḥ tasmin khaṇe attanaḥ puthujjana bhāvam ñatvā a vissaṭṭha kammaṭṭhāna ttā
translated: feeling arose in him. He, knowing at that moment his own state of being an ordinary man, and because his meditation subject was not well developed,

original: sīghaṃ mūlakammaṭṭhānaṃ ādāya sammasanto arahattaṃ pāpuṇitvāva kālamakāsi. Paccavekkhaṇā
analyzed: sīgham mūlakammaṭṭhānam ādāya sammasantaḥ arahattam pāpuṇitvā ava kālam akāsi paccavekkhaṇā
translated: and he attained Arahantship while he was still carrying the meditation subject in his mind.

original: panassa ca kathaṃ ahosīti? Khīṇāsavassa ekūnavīsati paccavekkhaṇā na sabbāva avassaṃ
analyzed: panassa ca katham ahosi iti khīṇāsavassa ekūnavīsati paccavekkhaṇā na
translated: But how did he review? The twenty-one reviews of one whose cankers are destroyed are not all necessarily to be found in one who is an Arahant.

original: laddhabbā, tikhiṇenāpi pana asinā sīse chijjante ekaṃ dve ñāṇāni avassaṃ uppajjanti.
analyzed: laddhabbā tikhiṇena api pana asinā sīse chijjante ekam dve ñāṇāni avassam uppajjanti
translated: But when a sharp sword is cutting off one’s head, it is not possible for more than one or two consciousnesses to arise.

original: Vivattakkhandhanti parivattakkhandhaṃ. Semānanti sayamānaṃ. Thero kira uttānako nipanno
analyzed: vivatta kkhandham ti parivatta kkhandham semānam ti sayamānam theraḥ kiraḥ uttānakaḥ nipannaḥ
translated: “The body turned over”: the body turned over. “The self-mind”: the mind that is one’s own . The elder lay down on his back, it seems,🔽and brought the sword down. His body remained as it was,

original: satthaṃ āhari. Tassa sarīraṃ yathāṭhitameva ahosi. Sīsaṃ pana dakkhiṇapassena parivattitvā
analyzed: sattham āhari tassa sarīram yathā ṭhitam eva ahosi sīsam pana dakkhiṇa passena parivattitvā
translated: but his head turned over to the right

original: aṭṭhāsi. Ariyasāvakā hi yebhuyyena dakkhiṇapasseneva kālaṃ karonti. Tenassa sarīraṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhāsi ariya sāvakāḥ hi yebhuyyena dakkhiṇa passena iva kālam karonti tena assa sarīram
translated: and remained so. For the most part, noble disciples die turning to the right.🔽So his body remained as it was,

original: yathāṭhitaṃyeva ahosi. Sīsaṃ pana dakkhiṇapassena parivattitvā ṭhitaṃ. Taṃ sandhāya
analyzed: yathā ṭhitam yeva ahosi sīsam pana dakkhiṇa passena parivattitvā ṭhitam tam sandhāya
translated: but his head turned over to the right and remained so.🔽They say that it was because of this that the elder came to be called “the one whose body turned over.”

original: vivattakkhandho nāma jātotipi vadanti. Dhūmāyitattanti dhūmāyanabhāvaṃ. Timirāyitattanti
analyzed: vivatta khandhaḥ nāma vadanti dhūmāyitattanti dhūmāyana bhāvam timirāyitattanti
translated: “Smoked”: the state of being smoked. “Clouded”:

original: timirāyanabhāvaṃ. Dhūmavalāhakaṃ viya timiravalāhakaṃ viya cāti attho. Pañcamaṃ.
analyzed: timirāyana bhāvam dhūma valāhakam viya timira valāhakam viya ca ati pañcamam
translated: and the state of the eye’s film. The meaning is that it is like smoke and haze. The fifth.

original: 6. Assajisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: assaji sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . Commentary on the Assaji Sutta

original: 88. Chaṭṭhe kassapakārāmeti kassapaseṭṭhinā kārite ārāme. Kāyasaṅkhāreti assāsapassāse.🔽So hi te catutthajjhānena passambhitvā passambhitvā vihāsi. Evaṃ hotīti idāni taṃ🔽samādhiṃ appaṭilabhantassa evaṃ hoti. No cassāhaṃ parihāyāmīti kacci nu kho ahaṃ
analyzed: chaṭṭhe kassapaka ārāme iti kassapa seṭṭhinā kārite ārāme kāya saṅkhāre iti assāsa passāse  saḥ hi te catutthajjhānena passambhitvā passambhitvā vihāsi evam hoti iti idāni taṃ  samādhim a paṭilabhantassa evam hoti no cassa aham parihāyāmi iti kacci nu kho aham
translated: . In the Kassapaka arama: in the monastery built by the chief of the Kassapas. In the body’s formation: in breathing in and out.

original: sāsanato na parihāyāmi? Tassa kira ābādhadosena appitappitā samāpatti parihāyi, tasmā
analyzed: sāsanataḥ na parihāyāmi tassa kira ābādha dosena appita ppitā samāpatti parihāyi tasmā
translated: For he had lived in a state of complete tranquillity by means of the fourth jhana. Thus it occurs to him: now that he has not attained that concentration, thus it occurs to him. I shall not fall away: will I not fall away from the Dispensation? It seems that his attainment, which had been brought about by the removal of the fault of his illness, had fallen away. Therefore

original: evaṃ cintesi. Samādhisārakā samādhisāmaññāti samādhiṃyeva sārañca sāmaññañca maññanti.
analyzed: evam cintesi samādhi sārakā samādhi sāmaññā ati samādhiṃya iva sāram ca sāmaññañca maññanti
translated: he thought thus. The essence of concentration, the monkhood of concentration: they think that concentration alone is the essence and the monkhood.

original: Mayhaṃ pana sāsane na etaṃ sāraṃ, vipassanāmaggaphalāni sāraṃ. So tvaṃ samādhito
analyzed: mayham pana sāsane na etam sāram vipassanā magga phalāni sāram saḥ tvam samādhitaḥ
translated: But in my Dispensation this is not the essence. The essence is insight, the path, and fruition. He, falling away from concentration,🔽why did he think, “I shall fall away from the Dispensation”? Having thus consoled the elder, now

original: parihāyanto kasmā cintesi “sāsanato parihāyāmī”ti. Evaṃ theraṃ assāsetvā idānissa
analyzed: parihāyantaḥ kasmā cintesi sāsanataḥ parihāyāmi iti evam theram assāsetvā idānissa
translated: and when he was falling away, why did he think, “I am falling away from the Dispensation”? Having thus consoled the elder, now,

original: tiparivaṭṭaṃ dhammadesanaṃ ārabhanto taṃ kiṃ maññasītiādimāha. Athassa tiparivaṭṭadesanāvasāne🔽arahattaṃ pattassa satatavihāraṃ dassento so sukhaṃ ce vedanaṃ vedayatītiādimāha.
analyzed: ti parivaṭṭam dhamma desanam ārabhanto tam kim maññasi iti ādim āha athassa ti parivaṭṭa desanā avasāne  arahattam pattassa satata vihāram dassento saḥ sukham ce vedanam vedayati itiādim āha
translated: Then at the end of the teaching by the three-round method,

original: Tattha anabhinanditāti pajānātīti sukhavedanāya tāva abhinandanā hotu, dukkhavedanāya🔽kathaṃ hotīti? Dukkhaṃ patvā sukhaṃ pattheti, yadaggena sukhaṃ pattheti, tadaggena
analyzed: tattha an abhinanditā ati pajānāti iti sukha vedanāya tāva abhinandanā hotu dukkha vedanāya  katham hoti iti dukkham patvā sukham pattheti yad aggena sukham pattheti tad aggena
translated: showing his own constant abiding, he said, “If he feels a pleasant feeling, he understands: ‘I feel a pleasant feeling.’ He understands: ‘A pleasant feeling has arisen in me, and that has a basis, a source, a causal formation, a condition. It is impossible for a pleasant feeling to arise in one who has no basis, no source, no causal formation, no condition.’ He understands: ‘With a cause, with a condition, a pleasant feeling arises.’ He understands: ‘With the cessation of that same cause, that condition, the pleasant feeling ceases and subsides.’

original: dukkhaṃ patthetiyeva. Sukhavipariṇāmena hi dukkhaṃ āgatameva hotīti evaṃ dukkhe abhinandanā🔽veditabbā. Sesaṃ pubbe vuttanayamevāti. Chaṭṭhaṃ.🔽7. Khemakasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dukkham patthetiyā iva sukha vipariṇāmena hi dukkham āgatam eva hoti iti evam dukkhe abhinandanā  veditabbā sesam pubbe vutta nayam evā ti chaṭṭham  khemaka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: “If he feels a painful feeling, he understands: ‘I feel a painful feeling.’ He understands: ‘A painful feeling has arisen in me, and that has a basis, a source, a causal formation, a condition. It is impossible for a painful feeling to arise in one who has no basis, no source, no causal formation, no condition.’ He understands: ‘With a cause, with a condition, a painful feeling arises.’ He understands: ‘With the cessation of that same cause, that condition, the painful feeling ceases and subsides.’🔽“If he feels a neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling, he understands: ‘I feel a neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling.’ He understands: ‘A neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling has arisen in me, and that has a basis, a source, a causal formation, a condition. It is impossible for a neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling to arise in one who has no basis, no source, no causal formation, no condition.’ He understands: ‘With a cause, with a condition, a neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling arises.’ He understands: ‘With the cessation of that same cause, that condition, the neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling ceases and subsides.’

original: 89. Sattame attaniyanti attano parikkhārajātaṃ. Asmīti adhigatanti asmīti evaṃ pavattā🔽taṇhāmānā adhigatā. Sandhāvanikāyāti punappunaṃ gamanāgamanena. Upasaṅkamīti badarikārāmato
analyzed: sattame attaniyanti attano parikkhāra jātam asmi iti adhigatanti asmi iti evam pavattā 🔽taṇhā mānā adhigatā sandhāvanikāyā ati punappunam gamana āgamanena upasaṅkamīti badarikārāmataḥ
translated: “In this way, Khemaka, a bhikkhu abides contemplating feelings as feelings internally, or he abides contemplating feelings as feelings externally, or he abides contemplating feelings as feelings both internally and externally. Or else he abides contemplating in feelings their arising factors, or he abides contemplating in feelings their vanishing factors, or he abides contemplating in feelings both their arising and vanishing factors.

original: gāvutamattaṃ ghositārāmaṃ agamāsi. Dāsakatthero pana catukkhattuṃ gamanāgamanena
analyzed: gāvutamattam ghosita ārāmam agamāsi dāsaka ttheraḥ pana catu khattum gamana āgamanena
translated: and went to the Ghosita monastery, a distance of a gāvuta. But the Elder Dāsaka,🔽

original: taṃdivasaṃ dviyojanaṃ addhānaṃ āhiṇḍi. Kasmā pana taṃ therā pahiṇiṃsu? Vissutassa
analyzed: taṃ divasam dvi yojanam addhānam āhiṇḍi kasmā pana tam therā pahiṇiṃsu vissutassa
translated: and went to the Ghosita monastery, a distance of a gāvuta. But the Elder Dāsaka walked two leagues that day, going and coming four times.

original: dhammakathikassa santikā dhammaṃ suṇissāmāti. Sayaṃ kasmā na gatāti? Therassa vasanaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: dhamma kathikassa santikā dhammam suṇissāma ati sayam kasmā na gatā ati therassa vasanaṭṭhānaṃ
translated: But why did they send for him? Because they wanted to hear the Dhamma from a preacher of renown.

original: araññaṃ sambādhaṃ, tattha saṭṭhimattānaṃ therānaṃ ṭhātuṃ vā nisīdituṃ vā okāso natthīti🔽na gatā. “Idhāgantvā amhākaṃ dhammaṃ kathetū”tipi kasmā pana na pahiṇiṃsūti? Therassa
analyzed: araññam sambādham tattha saṭṭhimattānam therānam ṭhātum vā nisīditum vā okāsaḥ natthi iti  na gatāḥ idha āgantvā amhākam dhammam kathetu uti pi kasmā pana na pahiṇiṃsu iti therassa
translated: Why did they not go themselves? Because the elder’s dwelling was in the forest, in a difficult place, and there was no room there for sixty elders to stand or sit.🔽Why did they not send a message, “Come here and preach the Dhamma to us”? Because the elder was sick.

original: ābādhikattā. Atha kasmā punappunaṃ pahiṇiṃsūti? Sayameva ñatvā amhākaṃ kathetuṃ āgamissatīti.
analyzed: ābādhika ttā atha kasmai punappunam pahiṇiṃsu iti sayam eva ñatvā amhākam kathetum āgamissati iti
translated: But why did they send for him again and again? Because they thought, “He will come himself and preach the Dhamma to us.”

original: Theropi tesaṃ ajjhāsayaṃ ñatvāva agamāsīti.
analyzed: theraḥ api tesam ajjhāsayam ñatvā ava agamāsi iti
translated: And the elder, knowing their intention, went to them.

original: Na khvāhaṃ, āvuso, rūpanti yo hi rūpameva asmīti vadati, tena itare cattāro khandhā
analyzed: na khvā aham āvuso yaḥ hi rūpam eva asmi iti vadati tena itare cattāraḥ khandhāḥ
translated: “I do not say, friends, ‘The eye is not self’” . One who says that the eye is the self is referring only to the eye element.

original: paccakkhātā honti. Yo aññatra rūpā vadati, tena rūpaṃ paccakkhātaṃ hoti. Vedanādīsupi
analyzed: paccakkhātāḥ honti yaḥ aññatra rūpā vadati tena rūpam paccakkhātam hoti vedanā ādīsu pi
translated: and the form is denied. When one says anything other than ‘form,’ the form is denied. The same method applies to feeling, and so on.

original: eseva nayo. Therassa pana samūhato pañcasupi khandhesu asmīti adhigato, tasmā evamāha.
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ therassa pana samūhataḥ pañcasu pi khandhesu asmi iti adhigataḥ tasmai evam āha
translated: But the elder had the conceit ‘I am’ in the five aggregates, which had been crushed, so he said as he did.

original: Hotevāti hotiyeva. Anusahagatoti sukhumo. Ūseti chārikākhāre. Khāreti ūsakhāre. Sammadditvāti temetvā khādetvā.
analyzed: hotā iva ati hotiyā iva anusahagataḥ iti sukhumaḥ ūsā iti chārikā khāre khāreti ūsa khāre sammadditvā ati temetvā khādetvā
translated: ‘It would be’: it would be. ‘Subtle’: fine. ‘Ash’: the ash of the chaff. ‘Chaff’: the ash of the grain. ‘Having kneaded’: having mixed with water and kneaded.

original: Evameva khoti ettha idaṃ opammasaṃsandanaṃ – kiliṭṭhavatthaṃ viya hi puthujjanassa🔽cittācāro, tayo khārā viya tisso anupassanā, tīhi khārehi dhotavatthaṃ viya desanāya
analyzed: evam eva kho ti ettha idam opamma saṃsandanam kiliṭṭha vattham viya hi puthujjanassa  citta ācāro tayo khārāḥ viya tisso anupassanā tīhi khārehi dhota vattham viya desanāya
translated: ‘So too’: here is the correspondence of the simile: the layman’s mental process is like the dirty cloth,

original: madditvā ṭhito anāgāmino cittācāro, anusahagato ūsādigandho viya arahattamaggavajjhā
analyzed: madditvā ṭhitaḥ anāgāmino citta ācāro anusahagataḥ ūsa ādi gandho viya arahatta magga vajjhā
translated: the three contemplations are like the three ashes, the mental process of the non-returner, which is like the cloth washed with the three ashes and is left to dry, is like the mental process of the non-returner, which is steadied by the teaching,🔽the defilements to be eradicated by the path of arahatship are like the smell of the ash, etc., that remains,

original: kilesā, gandhakaraṇḍako viya arahattamaggañāṇaṃ gandhakaraṇḍakaṃ āgamma anusahagatānaṃ
analyzed: kilesāḥ gandha karaṇḍakaḥ viya arahatta magga ñāṇam gandha karaṇḍakam āgamma anu sahagatānam
translated: the knowledge of the path of arahatship is like the perfume casket, the defilements to be eradicated by the path of arahatship are like the smell of the ash, etc., that remains,

original: ūsagandhādīnaṃ samugghāto viya arahattamaggena sabbakilesakkhayo, gandhaparibhāvitavatthaṃ🔽nivāsetvā chaṇadivase antaravīthiyaṃ sugandhagandhino vicaraṇaṃ viya khīṇāsavassa
analyzed: ūsa gandha ādīnam samugghātaḥ viya arahatta maggena sabba kilesa kkhayaḥ gandha paribhāvita vattham  nivāsetvā chaṇa divase antara vīthiyam sugandha gandhinaḥ vicaraṇam viya khīṇāsavassa
translated: The destruction of all defilements by the path of arahatship is like the removal of the scent of the flower garland.

original: sīlagandhādīhi dasa disā upavāyantassa yathākāmacāro.🔽Ācikkhitunti kathetuṃ. Desetunti pakāsetuṃ. Paññāpetunti jānāpetuṃ. Paṭṭhapetunti
analyzed: sīla gandha ādīhi dasa disāḥ yathākāma cāro  ācikkhitunti kathetum desetunti pakāsetum paññāpetunti jānāpetum paṭṭhapetunti
translated: The conduct of one whose cankers are destroyed, who perfumes the ten directions with the scent of virtue, etc., and who acts as he wishes, is like the conduct of the perfume merchant who, after dressing himself in a cloth scented with perfume, walks about the streets for six days and then puts on the cloth again.🔽“To expound” means to expound. “To teach” means to reveal. “To make known” means to make known. “To establish” means to establish.

original: patiṭṭhāpetuṃ. Vivaritunti vivaṭaṃ kātuṃ. Vibhajitunti suvibhattaṃ kātuṃ. Uttānīkātunti🔽uttānakaṃ kātuṃ. Saṭṭhimattānaṃ therānanti te kira therena kathitakathitaṭṭhāne vipassanaṃ🔽paṭṭhapetvā uparūpari sammasantā desanāpariyosāne arahattaṃ pāpuṇiṃsu. Theropi aññena
analyzed: patiṭṭhāpetum vivaritum vivaṭam kātum vibhajitum ti su vibhattam kātum uttānīkātum  uttānakam kātum therānanti te kira therena kathita kathita ṭhāne vipassanam  paṭṭhapetvā uparu upari sammasantā desanā pariyosāne arahattam pāpuṇiṃsu theraḥ api aññena
translated: “To open up” means to open up. “To analyze” means to analyze. “To make plain” means to make plain.

original: nīhārena akathetvā vipassanāsahagatacitteneva kathesi. Tasmā sopi arahattaṃ pāpuṇi.
analyzed: nīhārena a kathetvā vipassanā sahagata cittena iva kathesi tasmā saḥ api arahattam pāpuṇi
translated: The sixty elders: it seems that they established insight in the places expounded by the elder and, by comprehending more and more, they reached arahatship at the conclusion of the teaching. The elder, too, expounded without any other motive than that of insight. Therefore he, too, reached arahatship.

original: Tena vuttaṃ – “saṭṭhimattānaṃ therānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ anupādāya āsavehi cittāni vimucciṃsu
analyzed: tena vuttam saṭṭhimattānam therānam bhikkhūnam an upādāya āsavehi cittāni vimucciṃsu
translated: Hence it was said: “The minds of sixty elders were freed from the taints by non-clinging,

original: āyasmato khemakassa cā”ti. Sattamaṃ.
analyzed: āyasmataḥ khemakassa ca ati sattamam
translated: and so was the venerable Khemaka’s.”

original: 8. Channasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: channa sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The seventh chapter

original: 90. Aṭṭhame āyasmā channoti tathāgatena saddhiṃ ekadivase jāto mahābhinikkhamanadivase🔽saddhiṃ nikkhamitvā puna aparabhāge satthu santike pabbajitvā “amhākaṃ buddho amhākaṃ🔽dhammo”ti evaṃ makkhī ceva paḷāsī ca hutvā sabrahmacārīnaṃ pharusavācāya saṅghaṭṭanaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhame tathāgatena saddhim eka divase jātaḥ mahā abhinikkhamana divase  saddhim nikkhamitvā puna aparabhāge satthu santike pabbajitvā amhākam buddhaḥ amhākam  dhammaḥ ti evam makkhī ca iva paḷāsī ca hutvā sabrahmacārīnam pharusa vācāya saṅghaṭṭanam
translated: In the eighth story, the venerable Channa was born on the same day as the Tathāgata.🔽He went forth with him on the Great Renunciation,🔽and later he went forth under the Master. He became conceited and arrogant, thinking, “Our Buddha, our Dhamma!” He was a monk who was harsh and abusive to his companions in the holy life.

original: karonto thero. Avāpuraṇaṃ ādāyāti kuñcikaṃ gahetvā. Vihārena vihāraṃ upasaṅkamitvāti
analyzed: karontaḥ theraḥ avāpuraṇam ādāya ati kuñcikam gahetvā vihārena vihāram upasaṅkamitvā ati
translated: Taking his key

original: ekaṃ vihāraṃ pavisitvā tato aññaṃ, tato aññanti evaṃ tena tena vihārena taṃ taṃ vihāraṃ
analyzed: ekam vihāram pavisitvā tatas aññam tatas aññanti evam tena tena vihārena tam tam vihāram
translated: he went from dwelling to dwelling, from cell to cell, saying, “Make way, venerable sirs! Make way, venerable sirs!🔽Don’t block my way!”

original: upasaṅkamitvā. Etadavoca ovadantu manti kasmā evaṃ mahantena ussāhena tattha tattha
analyzed: upasaṅkamitvā etat avocaḥ ovadantu manti kasmai evam mahantena ussāhena tattha tattha
translated: “Why are you going about with such great effort?”

original: gantvā etaṃ avocāti? Uppannasaṃvegatāya. Tassa hi parinibbute satthari dhammasaṅgāhakattherehi
analyzed: gantvā etam avoca ati uppanna saṃvega tāya tassa hi parinibbute satthari dhammasaṅgāhaka therehi
translated: and went and said this? —Because of his aroused sense of spiritual urgency. For when the Master had attained final Nibbāna, the venerable Ānanda was sent to Kosambī by the elders who were the compilers of the Dhamma and the Discipline.

original: pesito āyasmā ānando kosambiṃ gantvā brahmadaṇḍaṃ adāsi. So dinne brahmadaṇḍe sañjātapariḷāho
analyzed: pesitaḥ āyasmai ānando kosambim gantvā brahmadaṇḍam adāsi saḥ dinne brahmadaṇḍe sañjāta pariḷāhaḥ
translated: He gave the brahmadaṇḍa there. When the brahmadaṇḍa had been given, the venerable Channa was overcome by remorse.

original: visaññībhūto patitvā puna saññaṃ labhitvā vuṭṭhāya ekassa bhikkhuno santikaṃ gato,
analyzed: visaññībhūtaḥ patitvā puna saññam labhitvā vuṭṭhāya ekassa bhikkhuno santikam gataḥ
translated: He lost consciousness and fell down. When he had recovered consciousness, he got up and went to a bhikkhu.

original: so tena saddhiṃ kiñci na kathesi. Aññassa santikaṃ agamāsi, sopi na kathesīti evaṃ
analyzed: saḥ tena saddhim kiñci na kathesi aññassa santikam agamāsi saḥ api na kathesi iti evam
translated: He had no conversation with him. He went to another bhikkhu. He had no conversation with him either. In this way

original: sakalavihāraṃ vicaritvā nibbinno pattacīvaraṃ ādāya bārāṇasiṃ gantvā uppannasaṃvego
analyzed: sakala vihāram vicaritvā nibbinnaḥ patta cīvaram ādāya bārāṇasim gantvā uppanna saṃvegaḥ
translated: he went all over the monastery. Disgusted, he took his bowl and robe and went to Bārāṇasī. With his sense of spiritual urgency aroused,

original: tattha tattha gantvā evaṃ avoca.🔽Sabbe saṅkhārā aniccāti sabbe tebhūmakasaṅkhārā aniccā. Sabbe dhammā anattāti sabbe
analyzed: tattha tattha gantvā evam avoca  sabbe saṅkhārāḥ aniccā ati sabbe tebhūmaka saṅkhārāḥ aniccā sabbe dhammāḥ anattā ati sabbe
translated: he went here and there and said this.

original: catubhūmakadhammā anattā. Iti sabbepi te bhikkhū theraṃ ovadantā aniccalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: catu bhūmaka dhammāḥ anattāḥ iti sabbe pi te bhikkhū theram ovadantā anicca lakkhaṇam
translated: All formations are impermanent: all formations in the three planes of becoming are impermanent. All dhammas are not-self: all dhammas in the four planes of existence are not-self. Thus all the bhikkhus, in advising the elder,

original: anattalakkhaṇanti dveva lakkhaṇāni kathetvā dukkhalakkhaṇaṃ na kathayiṃsu. Kasmā?🔽Evaṃ kira nesaṃ ahosi – “ayaṃ bhikkhu vādī dukkhalakkhaṇe paññāpiyamāne rūpaṃ dukkhaṃ…pe…
analyzed: anatta lakkhaṇam ti dve iva lakkhaṇāni kathetvā dukkha lakkhaṇam na kathayiṃsu kasmā  evam kira na isam ahosi ayam bhikkhu vādī dukkha lakkhaṇe paññāpiyamāne rūpam
translated: They did not mention the characteristic of pain. Why not?🔽They thought, “This bhikkhu is a debater. If we explain the characteristic of pain to him, he will say, ‘You bhikkhus have come to pain.

original: viññāṇaṃ dukkhaṃ, maggo dukkho, phalaṃ dukkhanti ‘tumhe dukkhappattā bhikkhū nāmā’ti
analyzed: viññāṇam dukkham maggaḥ dukkhaḥ phalam dukkhanti tumhe dukkha ppattāḥ bhikkhū nāma ati
translated: Form is pain, feeling is pain, perception is pain, formations are pain, consciousness is pain. The path is pain, the fruition is pain.’

original: gahaṇaṃ gaṇheyya, yathā gahaṇaṃ gahetuṃ na sakkoti, evaṃ niddosamevassa katvā kathessāmā”ti
analyzed: gahaṇam gaṇheyya yathā gahaṇam gahetum na sakkoti evam niddosam evassa katvā kathessāma ati
translated: We shall explain the two characteristics to him in such a way that he will not be able to debate. We shall explain them to him in a way that will be free from danger to him.”

original: dveva lakkhaṇāni kathayiṃsu.
analyzed: dve iva lakkhaṇāni kathayiṃsu
translated: So they explained the two characteristics.

original: Paritassanā upādānaṃ uppajjatīti paritassanā ca upādānañca uppajjati. Paccudāvattati
analyzed: paritassanā upādānam uppajjati iti paritassanā ca upādānam ca uppajjati paccudāvattati
translated: “Apprehending, he is agitated” : both apprehension and agitation arise.

original: mānasaṃ, atha ko carahi me attāti yadi rūpādīsu ekopi anattā, atha ko nāma me attāti
analyzed: mānasam atha kaḥ carahi me attā ati yadi rūpa ādīsu ekaḥ api anattā atha kaḥ nāma me attā ati
translated: “Then what is my self?” : if one of the aggregates such as form is not the self, then what is one’s self?

original: evaṃ paṭinivattati “mayhaṃ mānasa”nti. Ayaṃ kira thero paccaye apariggahetvā vipassanaṃ
analyzed: evam paṭinivattati mayham mānasanti ayam kira thero paccaye a pariggahetvā vipassanam
translated: Thus his mind turns back, thinking, “My mind is my self.” This elder, it seems, was practicing insight without having discerned conditions.

original: paṭṭhapesi, sāssa dubbalavipassanā attagāhaṃ pariyādātuṃ asakkuṇantī saṅkhāresu suññato🔽upaṭṭhahantesu “ucchijjissāmi vinassissāmī”ti ucchedadiṭṭhiyā ceva paritassanāya
analyzed: paṭṭhapesi sā assa dubbala vipassanā atta gāham pariyādātum a sakkuṇantī saṅkhāresu suññataḥ  upaṭṭhahantesu ucchijjissāmi vinassissāmi iti uccheda diṭṭhiyā ca iva paritassanāya
translated: He began to develop it. But his insight was weak, and unable to overcome the conceit “I am,” he saw formations as void🔽and became frightened, thinking, “I shall be annihilated, I shall perish.” This was the condition for the false view of annihilation and for his fear.

original: ca paccayo ahosi. So ca attānaṃ pāpate papatantaṃ viya disvā, “paritassanā upādānaṃ
analyzed: ca paccayaḥ ahosi saḥ ca attānam pāpate papatantam viya disvā paritassanā upādānam
translated: Seeing himself as falling, he said: “My mind is troubled, my thoughts run wild,

original: uppajjati, paccudāvattati mānasaṃ, atha ko carahi me attā”ti āha. Na kho panevaṃ
analyzed: uppajjati paccudāvattati mānasam atha kaḥ carahi me attā iti āha na kho pana evam
translated: and now what is my self?” But it is not so for one who sees the Dhamma.

original: dhammaṃ passato hotīti catusaccadhammaṃ passantassa evaṃ na hoti. Tāvatikā vissaṭṭhīti🔽tattako vissāso. Sammukhā metanti thero tassa vacanaṃ sutvā, “kīdisā nu kho imassa🔽dhammadesanā sappāyā”ti? Cintento tepiṭakaṃ buddhavacanaṃ vicinitvā kaccānasuttaṃ
analyzed: dhammam passataḥ hoti iti catusacca dhammam passantassa evam na hoti tāvatikā vissaṭṭhī iti  tattakaḥ vissāsaḥ sammukhāḥ mā itanti thero tassa vacanam sutvā kīdisā nu kho imassa  dhamma desanā sappāyā ti cintento tepiṭakam buddha vacanam vicinitvā kaccāna suttam
translated: He has perfect confidence: he has perfect confidence in the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha.🔽Face to face with him: the elder thought, “What kind of teaching would be suitable for him?” He examined the entire Buddha-word, and he saw the Kaccana Sutta.

original: addasa “idaṃ āditova diṭṭhiviniveṭhanaṃ katvā majjhe buddhabalaṃ dīpetvā saṇhasukhumapaccayākāraṃ
analyzed: addasa idam āditas va diṭṭhi viniveṭhanam katvā majjhe buddha balam dīpetvā saṇha sukhuma paccaya ākāram
translated: He thought, “In this sutta the Buddha first turns away from the view of a self, in the middle he shows the power of the Buddha, and in the end he teaches the subtle and recondite conditionality.

original: pakāsayamānaṃ gataṃ, idamassa desessāmī”ti dassento “sammukhā meta”ntiādimāha. Aṭṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: pakāsayamānam gatam idam assa desessāmi iti dassentaḥ sammukhā mā etad iti ādim āha aṭṭhamaṃ
translated: and he is going to confess it, I will teach him this.” Showing this, he said, “Face to face with me” , and so on. The eighth .

original: 9-10. Rāhulasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: rāhula sutta ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Rāhulasutta, etc.

original: 91-92. Navamadasamāni rāhulasaṃyutte vuttatthāneva. Kevalaṃ hetāni ayaṃ theravaggoti katvā idhāgatānīti. Navamadasamāni.
analyzed: navama dasamāni rāhulasaṃyutte vutta tthānā iva kevalam ha etāni ayam thera vaggo ti katvā idha āgatāni iti navama dasamāni
translated: The nine suttas of the Rāhula Samyutta are commented on in the same way as the above. They are only brought in here as the “group of elders.” The nine suttas of the Rāhula Samyutta are commented on.

original: Theravaggo navamo.
analyzed: thera vaggaḥ navamaḥ
translated: The ninth chapter .

original: 10. Pupphavaggo🔽1. Nadīsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: puppha vaggaḥ  nadī sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Flower Group🔽The River Sutta

original: 93. Pupphavaggassa paṭhame pabbateyyāti pabbate pavattā. Ohārinīti sote patitapatitāni
analyzed: puppha vaggassa paṭhame pabbateyyā ti pabbate pavattā ohārinī iti sote patita patitāni
translated: In the first sutta of the Flower Group , “mountain-born” means occurring on a mountain. “Down-flowing” means flowing down after falling from the mountain.

original: tiṇapaṇṇakaṭṭhādīni heṭṭhāhārinī. Dūraṅgamāti nikkhantaṭṭhānato paṭṭhāya catupañcayojanasatagāminī.
analyzed: tiṇa paṇṇa kaṭṭha ādīni heṭṭhā hārinī dūra aṅgamā ati nikkhanta ṭṭhānataḥ paṭṭhāya catu pañca yojana sata gāminī
translated: “Far-reaching” means going a distance of four or five hundred leagues from the place where it issues forth.

original: Sīghasotāti caṇḍasotā. Kāsātiādīni sabbāni tiṇajātāni. Rukkhāti eraṇḍādayo dubbalarukkhā.
analyzed: sīghasotā ti caṇḍasotā kāsāti ādīni sabbāni tiṇa jātāni rukkhā ti eraṇḍa ādayaḥ dubbala rukkhā
translated: “Swift-flowing” means having a swift current. “Reeds” and so on are all kinds of grass. “Trees” are the weak trees such as castor-oil plants.

original: Te naṃ ajjholambeyyunti te tīre jātāpi onamitvā aggehi udakaṃ phusantehi adhiolambeyyuṃ,
analyzed: te nam ajjholambeyyunti te tīre jātāḥ api onamitvā aggehi udakam phusantehi adhiolambeyyuṃ
translated: “They would not be able to seize hold of it” : even though they grow on its banks, they would bend down and touch the water with their tops, but they would not be able to seize hold of it.

original: upari lambeyyunti attho. Palujjeyyunti samūlamattikāya saddhiṃ sīse pateyyuṃ. So
analyzed: upari lambeyyunti sa mūlamattikāya saddhim sīse pateyyum saḥ
translated: the meaning is, he would be unable to climb out. They would fall off: they would fall on his head together with the clay.

original: tehi ajjhotthaṭo vālukamattikodakehi mukhaṃ pavisantehi mahāvināsaṃ pāpuṇeyya.
analyzed: tehi ajjhotthaṭaḥ vāluka mattikā udakehi mukham pavisantehi mahā vināsam pāpuṇeyya
translated: He would come to a bad end, because of the sand, clay, and water that would enter his mouth.

original: Evameva khoti ettha sote patitapuriso viya vaṭṭasannissito bālaputhujjano daṭṭhabbo,
analyzed: evam eva kho ti ettha sote patita purisaḥ viya vaṭṭa sannissitaḥ bāla puthujjanaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: Just so, in the present context, the foolish worldling who is subject to the round should be regarded as the man who fell into the stream,

original: ubhatotīre kāsādayo viya dubbalapañcakkhandhā, “ime gahitāpi maṃ tāretuṃ na sakkhissantī”ti🔽tassa purisassa ajānitvā gahaṇaṃ viya ime khandhā “na mayhaṃ sahāyā”ti bālaputhujjanassa🔽ajānitvā catūhi gāhehi gahaṇaṃ, gahitagahitānaṃ palujjanattā purisassa byasanappatti
analyzed: ubhatas tīre kāsa ādayaḥ viya dubbala pañca kkhandhāḥ ime gahitā api mam tāretum na sakkhissanti iti  tassa purisassa a jānitvā gahaṇam viya ime khandhāḥ na mayham saha āyāti bāla puthujjanassa  a jānitvā catūhi gāhehi gahaṇam gahita gahitānam palujjana ttā purisassa byasana ppatti
translated: the five aggregates as the reeds, etc., on both banks, which are weak, and the thought, “They will not be able to save me even if I grasp them,”🔽as the man’s failure to recognize the reeds, etc., as his companions,🔽and the failure of the worldling to recognize the aggregates as his companions as his grasping them with the four kinds of clinging.

original: viya catūhi gāhehi gahitānaṃ khandhānaṃ vipariṇāme bālaputhujjanassa sokādibyasanappatti🔽veditabbā. Paṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: catūhi gāhehi gahitānam khandhānam vipariṇāme bāla puthujjanassa soka ādi byasana ppatti  veditabbā paṭhamam
translated: The man’s misfortune due to the falling off of the reeds, etc., as he grasps them,🔽should be understood as the worldling’s misfortune of sorrow, etc., due to the change of the aggregates as he grasps them with the four kinds of clinging.🔽The first sutta.

original: 2. Pupphasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: puppha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Exposition of the Flower Simile.

original: 94. Dutiye vivadatīti “aniccaṃ dukkhaṃ anattā asubha”nti yathāsabhāvena vadantena
analyzed: dutiye vivadati iti aniccam dukkham anattāḥ asubhanti yathā sabhāvena vadantena
translated: In the second, he disputes: he disputes with one who speaks in accordance with the true nature of things, saying, “Impermanent, painful, not-self, ugly.”

original: saddhiṃ “niccaṃ sukhaṃ attā subha”nti vadanto vivadati. Lokadhammoti khandhapañcakaṃ.
analyzed: saddhim niccam sukham attā subhanti vadantaḥ vivadati khandha pañcakam
translated: In the second, he disputes with one who speaks in accordance with the true nature of things, saying, “Impermanent, painful, not-self, foul,” by saying, “Permanent, pleasant, self, beautiful.” The worldling: the five aggregates.

original: Tañhi lujjanasabhāvattā lokadhammoti vuccati. Kinti karomīti kathaṃ karomi? Mayhañhi🔽paṭipattikathanameva bhāro, paṭipattipūraṇaṃ pana kulaputtānaṃ bhāroti dasseti. Imasmiṃ
analyzed: tat hi loka dhammaḥ ti vuccati kinti karomi iti katham karomi  paṭipatti kathanam eva bhāro paṭipatti pūraṇam pana kula puttānam bhāro ti dasseti imasmin
translated: For they are called “the worldling” because of their nature of being broken up. “What can I do?” means “How can I do it?”

original: sutte tayo lokā kathitā. “Nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, lokenā”ti ettha hi sattaloko kathito,🔽“atthi, bhikkhave, loke lokadhammo”ti ettha saṅkhāraloko, “tathāgato loke jāto loke
analyzed: sutte tayaḥ lokā kathitā na aham bhikkhave lokena ati ettha hi satta loko kathito  atthi bhikkhave loke loka dhammo ti ettha saṅkhāra lokaḥ tathāgataḥ loke jātaḥ loke
translated: For he shows that the burden is the teaching of the practice to him, but the fulfillment of the practice is the burden of the sons of good family. In this sutta, three worlds are spoken of. For in the passage, “Monks, I am not disputing with the world,” the world of beings is spoken of;

original: saṃvaḍḍho”ti ettha okāsaloko kathito. Dutiyaṃ.
analyzed: ettha okāsa loko kathito dutiyam
translated: in the passage, “Monks, there is a worldling in the world,” the world of formations is spoken of; and in the passage, “The Tathāgata is born in the world, he is brought up in the world,” the world of location is spoken of. The second sutta is finished.

original: 3. Pheṇapiṇḍūpamasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: pheṇa piṇḍūpama sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The commentary on the Simile of the Foam Sutta

original: 95. Tatiye gaṅgāya nadiyā tīreti ayujjhapuravāsino aparimāṇabhikkhuparivāraṃ cārikaṃ
analyzed: tatiye gaṅgāya nadiyā tīre ti ayujjha pura vāsinaḥ aparimāṇa bhikkhu parivāram cārikam
translated: In the third, on the bank of the river Ganges: the residents of Ayujjhapura, with an immeasurable number of monks as their retinue, went on a journey.

original: caramānaṃ tathāgataṃ attano nagaraṃ sampattaṃ disvā ekasmiṃ gaṅgāya nivattanaṭṭhāne
analyzed: caramānam tathāgatam attanaḥ nagaram sampattam disvā ekasmin gaṅgāya nivattana ṭhāne
translated: and when they saw the Tathāgata coming, they built a monastery for him at a place where the Ganges River made a bend,

original: mahāvanasaṇḍamaṇḍitappadese satthu vihāraṃ katvā adaṃsu. Bhagavā tattha viharati.
analyzed: mahā vana saṇḍa maṇḍita ppadese satthu vihāram katvā adaṃsu bhagavā tattha viharati
translated: in a region adorned with a great forest. The Blessed One stayed there.

original: Taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “gaṅgāya nadiyā tīre”ti. Tatra kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesīti
analyzed: tam sandhāya vuttam gaṅgāya nadiyāḥ tīre ti tatra kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi iti
translated: With reference to that place it is said, “on the bank of the Ganges River.” There the Blessed One addressed the bhikkhus:

original: tasmiṃ vihāre vasanto bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṃ gandhakuṭito nikkhamitvā gaṅgātīre paññattavarabuddhāsane
analyzed: tasmin vihāre vasantaḥ bhagavā sāyanha samayam gandhakuṭitaḥ nikkhamitvā gaṅgā tīre paññatta vara buddha āsane
translated: In that monastery, in the evening, the Blessed One emerged from the Fragrant Cell, sat down on the excellent Buddha seat prepared for him on the bank of the Ganges River,

original: nisinno gaṅgāya nadiyā āgacchantaṃ mahantaṃ pheṇapiṇḍaṃ disvā, “mama sāsane pañcakkhandhanissitaṃ
analyzed: nisinnaḥ gaṅgāya nadiyāḥ āgacchantam mahantam pheṇa piṇḍam disvā mama sāsane pañca kkhandha nissitam
translated: and seeing a great mass of foam coming down the river, he thought, “I will teach the Dhamma, which is based on the five aggregates,

original: ekaṃ dhammaṃ kathessāmī”ti cintetvā parivāretvā nisinne bhikkhū āmantesi.🔽Mahantaṃ pheṇapiṇḍanti uṭṭhānuṭṭhāne badarapakkappamāṇato paṭṭhāya anusotāgamanena
analyzed: ekam dhammam kathessāmi iti cintetvā parivāretvā nisinne bhikkhū āmantesi  mahantam pheṇa piṇḍanti uṭṭhā anuṭṭhāne badara pakkappamāṇataḥ paṭṭhāya anusotāgamanena
translated: in terms of a single Dhamma.” Then he addressed the bhikkhus who were sitting around him.🔽A great mass of foam: beginning with the size of a jujube fruit, rising up and rising up,

original: anupubbena pavaḍḍhitvā pabbatakūṭamattaṃ jātaṃ, yattha udakasappādayo anekapāṇayo
analyzed: anupubbena pavaḍḍhitvā pabbata kūṭa mattam jātam yattha udaka sappa ādayaḥ aneka pāṇayaḥ
translated: gradually increasing in size, it became as big as a mountain peak. In it many creatures such as water snakes

original: nivasanti, evarūpaṃ mahantaṃ pheṇapiṇḍaṃ. Āvaheyyāti āhareyya. So panāyaṃ pheṇapiṇḍo
analyzed: nivasanti evarūpam mahantam pheṇa piṇḍam āvaheyya ati āhareyya saḥ pana ayam pheṇa piṇḍaḥ
translated: and they live in it. ‘Fetch it’: he should bring it. But this foam-blob

original: uṭṭhitaṭṭhānepi bhijjati, thokaṃ gantvāpi, ekadviyojanādivasena dūraṃ gantvāpi, antarā
analyzed: uṭṭhita ṭṭhāne pi bhijjati thokam gantvā api eka dvi yojana ādi vasena dūram gantvā api antarā
translated: breaks up in the place where it arises, and after going a little way it breaks up in between,

original: pana abhijjantopi mahāsamuddaṃ patvā avassameva bhijjati. Nijjhāyeyyāti olokeyya.🔽Yoniso upaparikkheyyāti kāraṇena upaparikkheyya. Kiñhi siyā, bhikkhave, pheṇapiṇḍe
analyzed: pana a bhijjantaḥ api mahā samuddam patvā avassamā iva bhijjati nijjhāyeyya ati olokeyya  yonisaḥ upaparikkheyya ati kāraṇena upaparikkheyya kim hi siyā bhikkhave pheṇa piṇḍe
translated: and after going a long way it breaks up. ‘Consider’: he should look at it.🔽‘Examine’: he should examine it with a reason. ‘What is there, monks, in the foam-blob that could be called core?’

original: sāroti, bhikkhave, pheṇapiṇḍamhi sāro nāma kiṃ bhaveyya? Vilīyitvā viddhaṃseyyeva.
analyzed: sāro ti bhikkhave pheṇa piṇḍamhi sāraḥ nāma kim bhaveyya vilīyitvā viddhaṃseyya iva
translated: ‘What core, monks, could there be in the foam-blob? It would only break up and dissolve.’

original: Evameva khoti yathā pheṇapiṇḍo nissāro, evaṃ rūpampi niccasāradhuvasāraattasāravirahena
analyzed: evam eva kho ti yathā pheṇa piṇḍaḥ nissāraḥ evam rūpam pi nicca sāra dhuva sāra atta sāra virahena
translated: ‘Just so’: just as the foam-blob has no core, so too material form has no core through the absence of a core of permanence, pleasure, self, and beauty.

original: nissārameva. Yathā ca so “iminā pattaṃ vā thālakaṃ vā karissāmī”ti gahetuṃ na sakkā,
analyzed: nissāram eva yathā ca saḥ iminā pattam vā thālakam vā karissāmi iti gahetum na sakkā
translated: And just as it cannot be said, “With this I will make a bowl or a dish,”

original: gahitopi tamatthaṃ na sādheti, bhijjati eva, evaṃ rūpampi niccanti vā dhuvanti vā
analyzed: gahitaḥ api tam attham na sādheti bhijjati eva evam rūpam pi niccanti vā dhuvanti vā
translated: and even if it is taken it does not serve that purpose but only breaks up, so too material form is impermanent, unstable,

original: ahanti vā mamanti vā gahetuṃ na sakkā, gahitampi na tathā tiṭṭhati, aniccaṃ dukkhaṃ
analyzed: ahanti vā mamanti vā gahetum na sakkā gahitam pi na tathā tiṭṭhati aniccam dukkham
translated: It cannot be grasped as ‘I’ or ‘mine.’ Even if it is grasped, it does not remain so grasped. It is impermanent, painful,

original: anattā asubhaññeva hotīti evaṃ pheṇapiṇḍasadisameva hoti. Yathā vā pana pheṇapiṇḍo
analyzed: anattā asubhaññā iva hoti iti evam pheṇa piṇḍa sadisam eva hoti yathā vā pana pheṇa piṇḍaḥ
translated: not-self, and foul. Thus it is like a lump of froth.

original: chiddāvachiddo anekasandhighaṭito bahūnaṃ udakasappādīnaṃ pāṇānaṃ āvāso, evaṃ rūpampi🔽chiddāvachiddaṃ anekasandhighaṭitaṃ, kulavasenevettha asīti kimikulāni vasanti, tadeva🔽tesaṃ sūtigharampi vaccakuṭipi gilānasālāpi susānampi, na te aññattha gantvā gabbhavuṭṭhānādīni
analyzed: chidda avachiddaḥ aneka sandhi ghaṭitaḥ bahūnam udaka sappa ādīnam pāṇānam āvāsaḥ evam  chidda avachiddam aneka sandhi ghaṭitam kula vasena iva ittha asi iti kimi kulāni vasanti tat eva  tesam sūti gharam pi vacca kuṭi pi gilāna sālā api susānam pi na te aññattha gantvā gabbha vuṭṭhāna ādīni
translated: Or just as a lump of froth is perforated, full of holes, put together by many joints, and is the abode of many living things such as water-insects, so too is material form.

original: karonti, evampi pheṇapiṇḍasadisaṃ.
analyzed: karonti pheṇa piṇḍa sadisam
translated: It is perforated, full of holes, put together by many joints. In this case, eighty thousand species of worms live in it. That is its birthplace. It is also its privy, its hospital, and its charnel ground. They do not go elsewhere to be conceived, to be born, to defecate, to urinate, to spit, to blow the nose, to die, or to be buried. Thus it is like a lump of froth.

original: Yathā ca pheṇapiṇḍo ādito badarapakkamatto hutvā anupubbena pabbatakūṭamattopi hoti,
analyzed: yathā ca pheṇa piṇḍaḥ āditas badara pakka mattaḥ hutvā anupubbena pabbata kūṭa mattaḥ api hoti
translated: And just as a lump of froth starts off as small as a jujube fruit and gradually grows to the size of the peak of a mountain,

original: evaṃ rūpampi ādito kalalamattaṃ hutvā anupubbena byāmamattampi gomahiṃsahatthiādīnaṃ
analyzed: evam rūpam pi āditas kalala mattam hutvā anupubbena byāma mattam pi go mahiṃsa hatthi ādīnam
translated: so too does material form. It starts off as small as a jujube fruit in the first stage of the kalala, and gradually it grows to the size of a yoke. It is like an ox or a buffalo yoke.

original: vasena pabbatakūṭādimattaṃ hoti macchakacchapādīnaṃ vasena anekayojanasatapamāṇampi,🔽evampi pheṇapiṇḍasadisaṃ. Yathā ca pheṇapiṇḍo uṭṭhitamattopi bhijjati, thokaṃ gantvāpi,
analyzed: vasena pabbata kūṭa ādi mattam hoti maccha kacchapa ādīnam vasena aneka yojana sata pamāṇam pi  evam pi pheṇa piṇḍa sadisam yathā ca pheṇa piṇḍaḥ uṭṭhita mattaḥ api bhijjati thokam gantvā api
translated: It is the size of a mountain peak, etc., in the case of the abodes of the Cāpā and Tiracchānayoni, etc., and it is many a hundred leagues in size in the case of the abodes of the fish, turtles, and so on.🔽So too, material form is like the foam. And just as the foam, though big, breaks up as soon as it appears and does not last long,

original: dūraṃ gantvāpi, samuddaṃ patvā pana avassameva bhijjati, evamevaṃ rūpampi kalalabhāvepi🔽bhijjati abbudādibhāvepi, antarā pana abhijjamānampi vassasatāyukānaṃ vassasataṃ
analyzed: dūram gantvā api samuddam patvā pana avassam eva bhijjati evam evam rūpam pi kalala bhāve pi  bhijjati abbuda ādi bhāve pi antarā pana abhijjamānam pi vassa sata āyukānam vassa satam
translated: so too, material form breaks up in the embryonic stages of kalala, etc.,

original: patvā avassameva bhijjati, maraṇamukhe cuṇṇavicuṇṇaṃ hoti, evampi pheṇapiṇḍasadisaṃ.🔽Kiñhi siyā, bhikkhave, vedanāya sārotiādīsu vedanādīnaṃ pubbuḷādīhi evaṃ sadisatā🔽veditabbā. Yathā hi pubbuḷo asāro evaṃ vedanāpi. Yathā ca so abalo agayhūpago, na
analyzed: patvā avassam eva bhijjati maraṇa mukhe cuṇṇa vicuṇṇam hoti evam pi pheṇa piṇḍa sadisam  kim hi siyā bhikkhave vedanāya sārā ti ādīsu vedanā ādīnam pubbuḷā ādīhi evam sadisa tā  veditabbā yathā hi pubbuḷaḥ asāraḥ evam vedanā api yathā ca saḥ abalaḥ a gayhūpagaḥ na
translated: and in the course of the life of one with a life span of a hundred years it breaks up at the end of every hundred years, and at death it is quite broken up. So too, material form is like the foam.🔽What is there to say, bhikkhus, about feeling, etc.? The similarity between feeling, etc., and bubbles, etc., should be understood in this way in the passages: “Bhikkhus, feeling … perception … volitional formations … consciousness is inconstant, changeable, alterable by nature” , and so on.🔽For just as bubbles are insubstantial, so too is feeling. And just as a bubble, being weak and unsupported,

original: sakkā taṃ gahetvā phalakaṃ vā āsanaṃ vā kātuṃ, gahitopi bhijjateva, evaṃ vedanāpi
analyzed: sakkā tam gahetvā phalakam vā āsanam vā kātum gahitaḥ api bhijjatā iva evam vedanā api
translated: cannot be grasped even when reached, and breaks up as soon as it appears, so too, feeling cannot be grasped even when it is experienced, and it breaks up as soon as it appears.

original: abalā agayhūpagā, na sakkā niccāti vā dhuvāti vā gahetuṃ, gahitāpi na tathā tiṭṭhati,
analyzed: abalā agayhūpagā na sakkā vā dhuvāti vā gahetum gahitā api na tathā tiṭṭhati
translated: It is not strong enough to be grasped at as permanent or everlasting. Even if it is grasped at, it does not remain so.

original: evaṃ agayhūpagatāyapi vedanā pubbuḷasadisā. Yathā pana tasmiṃ tasmiṃ udakabindumhi🔽pubbuḷo uppajjati ceva bhijjati ca, na ciraṭṭhitiko hoti, evaṃ vedanāpi uppajjati
analyzed: evam vedanā pubbuḍa sadisā yathā pana tasmin tasmin udaka bindumhi  pubbuḷaḥ uppajjati ca iva bhijjati ca na cira ṭṭhitikaḥ hoti evam vedanā api uppajjati
translated: Thus feeling is like a bubble, in that it is not to be grasped at.

original: ceva bhijjati ca, na ciraṭṭhitikā hoti. Ekaccharakkhaṇe koṭisatasahassasaṅkhā uppajjitvā🔽nirujjhati. Yathā ca pubbuḷo udakatalaṃ, udakabinduṃ, udakajallaṃ, saṅkaḍḍhitvā puṭaṃ🔽katvā gahaṇavātañcāti cattāri kāraṇāni paṭicca uppajjati, evaṃ vedanāpi vatthuṃ ārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: ca iva bhijjati ca na cira ṭṭhitikā hoti ekaccha rakkhaṇe koṭi sata sahassa saṅkhā uppajjitvā  nirujjhati yathā ca pubbuḷaḥ udaka talam udaka bindum udaka jallam saṅkaḍḍhitvā puṭam  katvā gahaṇa vātam ca ati cattāri kāraṇāni paṭicca uppajjati evam vedanā api vatthum ārammaṇam
translated: Just as a bubble arises and breaks up in the water drop, and does not last long, so feeling arises and breaks up, and does not last long. In a single thought-moment it arises and ceases a hundred times, a thousand times, a hundred thousand times.

original: kilesajallaṃ phassasaṅghaṭṭanañcāti cattāri kāraṇāni paṭicca uppajjati. Evampi vedanā pubbuḷasadisā.
analyzed: kilesa jallam phassa saṅghaṭṭanam ca ati cattāri kāraṇāni paṭicca uppajjati evam pi vedanā pubbuḷa sadisā
translated: And just as a bubble arises in dependence on four conditions, namely, the water, the water drop, the wind, and the water spray, so feeling arises in dependence on four conditions, namely, the physical basis, the object, the defilements, and the impact of the object. Thus feeling is like a bubble.

original: Saññāpi asārakaṭṭhena marīcisadisā. Tathā agayhūpagaṭṭhena. Na hi sakkā taṃ gahetvā
analyzed: saññā api asāra kaṭṭhena marīci sadisā tathā agayhūpagaṭṭhena na hi sakkā tam gahetvā
translated: Perception is like a mirage in the sense of having no core. So too, in the sense of not being substantial. For one cannot

original: pivituṃ vā nhāyituṃ vā bhājanaṃ vā pūretuṃ. Apica yathā marīci vipphandati, sañjātūmivegā
analyzed: pivitum vā nhāyitum vā bhājanam vā pūretum apica yathā marīci vipphandati san jātūmi vegā
translated: take hold of it and drink or bathe in it or fill a vessel with it. Moreover, just as a mirage shimmers, appearing as if it were water rushing together,

original: viya khāyati, evaṃ nīlasaññādibhedā saññāpi nīlādianubhavanatthāya phandati vipphandati.
analyzed: viya khāyati evam nīla saññā ādi bhedā saññā api nīla ādi anubhavana tthāya phandati vipphandati
translated: so too perception shimmers, appearing as if it were the experiencing of blue, etc.

original: Yathā ca marīci mahājanaṃ vippalambheti “puṇṇavāpi viya puṇṇanadī viya dissatī”ti
analyzed: yathā ca marīci mahā janam vippalambheti puṇṇa vāpi viya puṇṇa nadī viya dissati iti
translated: And just as a mirage deceives people, making them think, “There is a pond full of water, a river full of water,”

original: vadāpeti, evaṃ saññāpi vippalambheti, “idaṃ nīlakaṃ subhaṃ sukhaṃ nicca”nti vadāpeti.
analyzed: vadāpa iti evam saññā api vippalambheti idam nīlakam subham sukham niccanti vadāpa iti
translated: so too perception deceives, making one think, “This blue, etc., is beautiful, desirable, permanent, pleasurable, and self.”

original: Pītakādīsupi eseva nayo. Evaṃ saññā vippalambhanenāpi marīcisadisā.
analyzed: pītaka ādīsu pi esā iva nayaḥ evam saññā vippalambhanena api marīci sadisā
translated: The same method applies to yellow, etc. So perception is like a mirage in the sense of deceiving.

original: Akukkukajātanti anto asañjātaghanadaṇḍakaṃ. Saṅkhārāpi asārakaṭṭhena kadalikkhandhasadisā,
analyzed: a kukkuka jātam ti antaḥ a sañjāta ghana daṇḍakam saṅkhārā api asāra kaṭṭhena kadali kkhandha sadisā
translated: Not having a core inside means not having a thick, solid stalk inside. Formations are like a plantain trunk in the sense of having no core.

original: tathā agayhūpagaṭṭhena. Yatheva hi kadalikkhandhato kiñci gahetvā na sakkā gopānasiādīnaṃ
analyzed: tathā agayhūpagaṭṭhena yathā iva hi kadali kkhandhato kiñci gahetvā na sakkā gopānasi ādīnam
translated: So too, in the sense of not being substantial. For just as one cannot take hold of anything from a plantain trunk and use it as a pillar, post,

original: atthāya upanetuṃ, upanītampi na tathā hoti, evaṃ saṅkhārāpi na sakkā niccādivasena
analyzed: atthāya upanetum upanītam pi na tathā hoti evam saṅkhārā api na sakkā nicca ādi vasena
translated: and when brought, it is not like that. So too, formations cannot be grasped as permanent, etc.,

original: gahetuṃ, gahitāpi na tathā honti. Yathā ca kadalikkhandho bahupattavaṭṭisamodhāno
analyzed: gahetum gahitā api na tathā honti yathā ca kadali kkhandhaḥ bahu patta vaṭṭi samodhānaḥ
translated: and when grasped, they are not like that. And just as a plantain tree is a collection of many leaves and sheaths,

original: hoti, evaṃ saṅkhārakkhandho bahudhammasamodhāno. Yathā ca kadalikkhandho nānālakkhaṇo.🔽Aññoyeva hi bāhirāya pattavaṭṭiyā vaṇṇo, añño tato abbhantaraabbhantarānaṃ, evameva
analyzed: hoti evam saṅkhāra kkhandhaḥ bahu dhamma samodhānaḥ yathā ca kadali kkhandhaḥ nānā lakkhaṇo  aññaḥ yeva hi bāhirāya pattavaṭṭiyāḥ vaṇṇo aññaḥ tatas evam eva
translated: so too the aggregate of formations is a collection of many states. And just as a plantain tree has many different characteristics,

original: saṅkhārakkhandhepi aññadeva phassassa lakkhaṇaṃ, aññā cetanādīnaṃ, samodhānetvā pana
analyzed: saṅkhāra kkhandhe pi aññat eva phassassa lakkhaṇam aññā cetanā ādīnam samodhānetvā pana
translated: for the colour of the outer leaf sheath is one thing, that of the inner ones another, and so too that of the core; so too, in the aggregate of formations the characteristic of contact is one thing, that of volition another, and so on. But when they are collected together,

original: saṅkhārakkhandhova vuccatīti evampi saṅkhārakkhandho kadalikkhandhasadiso.
analyzed: saṅkhāra khandho va vuccati iti evam pi saṅkhāra khandho kadali kkhandha sadiso
translated: they are called simply the aggregate of formations. So in this way too the aggregate of formations is like a plantain trunk.

original: Cakkhumā purisoti maṃsacakkhunā ceva paññācakkhunā cāti dvīhi cakkhūhi cakkhumā.
analyzed: cakkhumā puriso ti maṃsa cakkhunā ca iva paññā cakkhunā ca ati dvīhi cakkhūhi cakkhumā
translated: Possessed of eyes: possessed of two eyes, that is, of the fleshly eye and the eye of knowledge.

original: Maṃsacakkhumpi hissa parisuddhaṃ vaṭṭati apagatapaṭalapiḷakaṃ, paññācakkhumpi asārabhāvadassanasamatthaṃ.
analyzed: maṃsa cakkhum pi hissa parisuddham vaṭṭati apagata paṭala piḷakam paññā cakkhum pi asāra bhāva dassana samattham
translated: For his fleshly eye is clear and free from the film of ignorance, and his eye of knowledge is capable of seeing the non-existence of a core.

original: Viññāṇampi asārakaṭṭhena māyāsadisaṃ, tathā agayhūpagaṭṭhena. Yathā ca māyā ittarā
analyzed: viññāṇam pi asārakaṭṭhena māyā sadisam tathā agayhūpagaṭṭhena yathā ca māyā ittarā
translated: Consciousness is like a magical creation in being without core, and also in being not-to-be-so-probed.🔽And just as a magical creation is inferior,

original: lahupaccupaṭṭhānā, evaṃ viññāṇaṃ. Tañhi tatopi ittaratarañceva lahupaccupaṭṭhānatarañca.
analyzed: lahu paccupaṭṭhānā evam viññāṇam tat hi tatas pi ittarataram ca iva lahu paccupaṭṭhānataram ca
translated: so too is consciousness. For that is still more inferior and still more fleeting.

original: Teneva hi cittena puriso āgato viya gato viya ṭhito viya nisinno viya hoti. Aññadeva
analyzed: tena iva hi cittena purisaḥ āgataḥ viya gataḥ viya ṭhitaḥ viya nisinnaḥ viya hoti aññadeva
translated: And it is because of this kind of consciousness that a man seems to come, to go, to stand, to sit.🔽And the consciousness at the time of coming is one thing, that at the time of going, etc., is another.

original: ca āgamanakāle cittaṃ, aññaṃ gamanakālādīsu. Evampi viññāṇaṃ māyāsadisaṃ. Māyā ca
analyzed: ca āgamana kāle cittam aññam gamana kāla ādīsu evam pi viññāṇam māyā sadisam māyā ca
translated: So too is consciousness like a magical creation.

original: mahājanaṃ vañceti, yaṃkiñcideva “idaṃ suvaṇṇaṃ rajataṃ muttā”ti gāhāpeti, viññāṇampi🔽mahājanaṃ vañceti. Teneva hi cittena āgacchantaṃ viya gacchantaṃ viya ṭhitaṃ viya🔽nisinnaṃ viya katvā gāhāpeti. Aññadeva ca āgamane cittaṃ, aññaṃ gamanādīsu. Evampi
analyzed: mahājanam vañceti yaṃ kiñcid eva idam suvaṇṇam rajatam muttā ati gāhāpeti viññāṇam pi  mahājanam vañca iti tena iva hi cittena āgacchantam viya gacchantam viya ṭhitam viya  nisinnam viya katvā gāhāpeti aññat eva ca āgamane cittam aññam gamana ādīsu evam pi
translated: And a magical creation deceives the multitude, for whatever it is that it is made to be, that it makes people take for gold, silver, pearls, etc.,🔽so too consciousness deceives the multitude. For it is by this kind of consciousness that a man is made to come, to go, to stand, to sit, and he takes it to be so.

original: viññāṇaṃ māyāsadisaṃ.
analyzed: viññāṇam māyā sadisam
translated: And the consciousness at the time of coming is one thing, that at the time of going, etc., is another. So too is consciousness like a magical creation.

original: Bhūripaññenāti saṇhapaññena ceva vipulavitthatapaññena ca. Āyūti jīvitindriyaṃ. Usmāti
analyzed: bhūri paññena ati saṇha paññena ca iva vipula vitthata paññena ca jīvitindriyam
translated: “To one of great understanding”: to one of gentle understanding and of wide and extensive understanding. “Life” is the life faculty. “Heat” is the heat element.

original: kammajatejodhātu. Parabhattanti nānāvidhānaṃ kimigaṇādīnaṃ bhattaṃ hutvā. Etādisāyaṃ
analyzed: kamma ja tejaḥ dhātu nānāvidhānam kimi gaṇa ādīnam bhattam hutvā etādisāyam
translated: the fire element born of kamma. “Food for others”: it is food for various kinds of deer, etc.

original: santānoti etādisī ayaṃ paveṇī matakassa yāva susānā ghaṭṭīyatīti. Māyāyaṃ bālalāpinīti🔽yvāyaṃ viññāṇakkhandho nāma, ayaṃ bālamahājanalapāpanikamāyā nāma. Vadhakoti dvīhi
analyzed: etādisī ayam paveṇī matakassa yāva susānā ghaṭṭīyati iti māyā ayam bāla lāpinī iti  yvā ayam viññāṇa kkhandhaḥ nāma ayam nāma dvīhi
translated: the fire element born of kamma. “Food for others”: it is the food of various kinds of deer, etc. “This is how it goes on”: this is how this succession goes on until it reaches the charnel ground. “This is a trickster, a deceiver of fools”:

original: kāraṇehi ayaṃ khandhasaṅkhāto vadhako aññamaññaghātanenapi, khandhesu sati vadho
analyzed: kāraṇehi ayam khandha saṅkhātaḥ vadhakaḥ aññamañña ghātanena api khandhesu sati vadhaḥ
translated: this is the aggregate of consciousness. It is a trickster, a deceiver of fools, a magician who conjures up a phantom woman. “A murderer”: this is the murderer called the “aggregate,” for two reasons: because of mutual destruction, and because murder is evident when the aggregates are present.

original: paññāyatītipi. Ekā hi pathavīdhātu bhijjamānā sesadhātuyo gahetvāva bhijjati, tathā
analyzed: ekā hi pathavī dhātu bhijjamānā sesa dhātuyaḥ gahetvā ava bhijjati tathā
translated: For when one of the four primary elements is destroyed, it destroys the other primary elements together with it.

original: āpodhātuādayo. Rūpakkhandho ca bhijjamāno arūpakkhandhe gahetvāva bhijjati, tathā
analyzed: āpodhātu ādayaḥ rūpa kkhandho ca bhijjamānaḥ arūpa kkhandhe gahetvā ava bhijjati tathā
translated: And so too with the water element, etc. And when the materiality aggregate is destroyed, it destroys the immaterial aggregates together with it.

original: arūpakkhandhesu vedanādayo saññādike. Cattāropi cete vatthurūpanti evaṃ aññamaññavadhanenettha
analyzed: arūpa khandhesu vedanā ādayaḥ saññā ādike cattāro api ca ite vatthu rūpanti evam aññamañña vadhanena ittha
translated: And so too with the other immaterial aggregates, feeling, etc. Thus the murderer should be understood here in terms of mutual destruction.

original: vadhakatā veditabbā. Khandhesu pana sati vadhabandhanacchedādīni sambhavanti, evaṃ
analyzed: vadhaka tā veditabbā khandhesu pana sati vadha bandhana cheda ādīni sambhavanti evam
translated: But when the aggregates are present, murder, bondage, cutting, etc., are possible. Thus the murderer should be understood here in terms of the presence of murder, etc., when the aggregates are present.

original: etesu sati vadhabhāvatopi vadhakatā veditabbā. Sabbasaṃyoganti sabbaṃ dasavidhampi
analyzed: etesu sati vadha bhāvataḥ api vadhaka tā veditabbā sabba saṃyogam ti sabbam dasavidham pi
translated: and in these it should be understood that the killers are killers by reason of the killing. “All bondages”: all the ten kinds.

original: saṃyojanaṃ. Accutaṃ padanti nibbānaṃ. Tatiyaṃ.
analyzed: saṃyojanam accutam padanti nibbānam tatiyam
translated: and so they should be understood as killers by reason of their being killers of the living. All fetters: all the ten kinds of fetters. The deathless state: Nibbāna. The third.

original: 4-6. Gomayapiṇḍasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: gomaya piṇḍa sutta ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Gomayapiṇḍa Sutta, etc., is ended.

original: 96-98. Catutthe sassatisamanti sinerumahāpathavīcandimasūriyādīhi sassatīhi samaṃ.
analyzed: catutthe sassati samanti sineru mahā pathavī candima sūriya ādīhi sassatīhi samam
translated: In the fourth sutta, “equal to the eternal” means equal to the eternal things such as Sineru, the great earth, the moon, and the sun.

original: Parittaṃ gomayapiṇḍanti appamattakaṃ madhukapupphappamāṇaṃ gomayakhaṇḍaṃ. Kuto panānenetaṃ🔽laddhanti. Paribhaṇḍakaraṇatthāya ābhatato gahitanti eke. Atthassa pana viññāpanatthaṃ
analyzed: parittam gomaya piṇḍanti appamattakam madhuka puppha ppamāṇam gomaya khaṇḍam kutas pana anena itam  laddhanti paribhaṇḍa karaṇa atthāya ābhatataḥ gahitanti eke atthassa pana viññāpana attham
translated: A little dung-ball: a small lump of dung the size of a honey-ball. But how did he get it?🔽Some say: “He took it from the place where it was brought for the purpose of making manure.” But it should be understood that he made it appear in his hand by resolving through supernormal power in order to illustrate the meaning.

original: iddhiyā abhisaṅkharitvā hatthāruḷhaṃ katanti veditabbanti. Attabhāvapaṭilābhoti paṭiladdhaattabhāvo.
analyzed: iddhiyā abhisaṅkharitvā hattha āruḷham katanti veditabbanti atta bhāva paṭilābhaḥ ti paṭiladdha atta bhāvaḥ
translated: The acquisition of a selfhood: the selfhood that has been acquired.

original: Na yidaṃ brahmacariyavāso paññāyethāti ayaṃ maggabrahmacariyavāso nāma na paññāyeyya.
analyzed: na yidam brahmacariya vāso paññāyetha ati ayam magga brahmacariya vāsaḥ nāma na paññāyeyya
translated: The life of purity would not be evident: the life of purity called the path would not be evident.

original: Maggo hi tebhūmakasaṅkhāre vivaṭṭento uppajjati. Yadi ca ettako attabhāvo nicco bhaveyya,
analyzed: maggaḥ hi tebhūmaka saṅkhāre vivaṭṭentaḥ uppajjati yadi ca ettakaḥ atta bhāvaḥ niccaḥ bhaveyya
translated: For the path arises as the unravelling of the formations of the three planes. If this selfhood were permanent,

original: maggo uppajjitvāpi saṅkhāravaṭṭaṃ vivaṭṭetuṃ na sakkuṇeyyāti brahmacariyavāso na paññāyetha.🔽Idāni sace koci saṅkhāro nicco bhaveyya, mayā mahāsudassanarājakāle anubhūtā sampatti
analyzed: maggaḥ uppajjitvā api saṅkhāra vaṭṭam vivaṭṭetum na sakkuṇeyya ati brahmacariya vāsaḥ na paññāyetha  idāni sace koci saṅkhāraḥ niccaḥ bhaveyya mayā mahāsudassana rāja kāle anubhūtā sampatti
translated: and the path, even though it arose, would be unable to break the round of existence, and then the life of purity would not be known.

original: niccā bhaveyya, sāpi ca aniccāti taṃ dassetuṃ bhūtapubbāhaṃ bhikkhu rājā ahosintiādimāha.
analyzed: niccā bhaveyya sā api ca aniccā iti tam dassetum bhūta pubbā aham bhikkhu rājā ahosin tiādim āha
translated: Now, if any formation were permanent, then the prosperity I experienced in the time of the Great Sudassana would be permanent, and that too would be impermanent. To show this he said: “Bhikkhus, formerly, in the past, I was a king named Mahāsudassana.”

original: Tattha kusāvatīrājadhānippamukhānīti kusāvatīrājadhānī tesaṃ nagarānaṃ pamukhā, sabbaseṭṭhāti
analyzed: tattha kusāvatī rājadhāni ppamukhāni iti kusāvatī rājadhānī tesam nagarānam pamukhā sabba seṭṭhā ti
translated: Herein, Kusāvatī was the chief of their cities,

original: attho. Sāramayānīti rattacandanasāramayāni. Upadhānaṃ pana sabbesaṃ suttamayameva.🔽Goṇakatthatānīti caturaṅgulādhikalomena kāḷakojavena atthatāni, yaṃ mahāpiṭṭhiyakojavoti
analyzed: sāra mayāni iti ratta candana sāra mayāni upadhānam pana sabbesam sutta mayam eva  goṇakatthatāni iti catur aṅgula adhika lomena kāḷakojavena atthatāni yam mahāpiṭṭhiyakojavā ti
translated: the meaning is, it was the best of all. Made of heartwood: made of red sandalwood. The mattress was made of thread in all cases.🔽They were covered with a black antelope skin with the neck to the east, with the hair outside,

original: vadanti. Paṭakatthatānīti ubhatolomena uṇṇāmayena setakambalena atthatāni. Paṭalikatthatānīti
analyzed: vadanti paṭakatthatāni iti ubhatolomena uṇṇa āmayena seta kambalena atthatāni paṭalikatthatāni iti
translated: which is called a “great blanket.” They were covered with a white blanket with the nap outside, on both sides. They were covered with a fine piece of cloth,

original: ghanapupphena uṇṇāmayaattharaṇena atthatāni. Kadalimigapavarapaccattharaṇānīti kadalimigacammamayena🔽uttamapaccattharaṇena atthatāni. Taṃ kira paccattharaṇaṃ setavatthassa upari kadalimigacammaṃ🔽attharitvā sibbetvā karonti. Sauttaracchadānīti saha uttaracchadena, upari baddhena
analyzed: ghana pupphena uṇṇā maya attharaṇena atthatāni kadali miga pavara paccattharaṇāni iti kadali miga camma mayena  uttama paccattharaṇena tam kira paccattharaṇam seta vatthassa upari kadali miga cammam  attharitvā sibbetvā karonti sa uttaracchadāni iti saha uttaracchadena upari baddhena
translated: with a pillow of thick flowers. With the best deer-hide rugs: with the best rugs made of deer-hide from the Kadali deer. That rug, it seems, is made by spreading a deer-hide from the Kadali deer over a white cloth,

original: rattavitānena saddhinti attho. Ubhatolohitakūpadhānīti sīsūpadhānañca pādūpadhānañcāti🔽pallaṅkānaṃ ubhatolohitakūpadhānāni. Vejayantarathappamukhānīti ettha vejayanto nāma
analyzed: ratta vitānena saddhinti attho ubhatas lohitaka upadhāni iti sīsu upadhānam ca pādu upadhānam ca ati  pallaṅkānam ubhatolohitakūpadhānāni vejayanta ratha ppamukhāni iti ettha vejayantaḥ nāma
translated: and then sewing it on. With an upper covering: with an upper covering, with a red cloth fastened above, is the meaning. With red cushions at both ends: with red cushions at the head and at the foot,

original: tassa rañño ratho, yassa cakkānaṃ indanīlamaṇimayā nābhi, sattaratanamayā arā, pavāḷamayā
analyzed: tassa raññaḥ rathaḥ yassa inda nīla maṇi mayāḥ nābhi satta ratana mayāḥ arā pavāḷa mayāḥ
translated: is the meaning. With the Vejayanta Palace foremost: here the Vejayanta is the king’s chariot, the hub of whose wheels is made of sapphire, the spokes of the seven precious substances, the rim of coral,

original: nemi, rajatamayo akkho, indanīlamaṇimayaṃ upakkharaṃ, rajatamayaṃ kubbaraṃ. So tesaṃ
analyzed: nemi rajata mayaḥ akkhaḥ inda nīla maṇi mayam upakkharam rajata mayam kubbaram saḥ tesam
translated: the axle-pin of silver, the fender of sapphire, and the shaft of silver. That chariot is

original: rathānaṃ pamukho aggo. Dukūlasandānānīti dukūlasantharāni. Kaṃsūpadhāraṇānīti rajatamayadohabhājanāni.
analyzed: rathānam pamukhaḥ aggaḥ dukūla sandānāni iti dukūla santharāni kaṃsu upadhāraṇāni iti rajata maya doha bhājanāni
translated: The best of all chariots. With cushions of dukūla: with cushions of dukūla cloth. With silver poles: with silver flagstaffs.

original: Vatthakoṭisahassānīti yathārucitaṃ paribhuñjissatīti nhatvā ṭhitakāle upanītavatthāneva
analyzed: vattha koṭi sahassāni iti yathārucitam paribhuñjissati iti nhatvā ṭhita kāle upanīta vatthānā eva
translated: With a thousand koṭis of cloths: this is said with reference to the cloths that were brought to him when he was standing there after bathing, thinking, “I will use whatever I like.”

original: sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Bhattābhihāroti abhiharitabbabhattaṃ.
analyzed: sandhāya itam vuttam bhattābhihāraḥ iti abhiharitabba bhattam
translated: With food brought by the gods: with food that the gods brought.

original: Yamahaṃ tena samayena ajjhāvasāmīti yattha vasāmi, taṃ ekaññeva nagaraṃ hoti, avasesesu
analyzed: yam aham tena samayena ajjhāvasāmi iti yattha vasāmi tam ekaññā iva nagaram hoti avasesesu
translated: The city I lived in then: the city where I lived was just one city; in the rest

original: puttadhītādayo ceva dāsamanussā ca vasiṃsu. Pāsādakūṭāgārādīsupi eseva nayo. Pallaṅkādīsu
analyzed: putta dhīta ādayaḥ ca iva dāsa manussā ca vasiṃsu pāsāda kūṭāgāra ādīsu pi esa iva nayo pallaṅka ādīsu
