translated: my sons, daughters, and so on, and the human slaves lived. The same applies to the palaces, towers, and so on.

original: ekaṃyeva sayaṃ paribhuñjati, sesā puttādīnaṃ paribhogā honti. Itthīsu ekāva paccupaṭṭhāti,
analyzed: ekam yā iva sayam paribhuñjati sesā putta ādīnam paribhogāḥ honti itthīsu ekā ava paccupaṭṭhāti
translated: In the couches, etc., he himself used just one; the rest were used by his sons and so on. Among the women, just one attended on him;

original: sesā parivāramattā honti. Velāmikāti khattiyassa vā brāhmaṇiyā, brāhmaṇassa vā khattiyāniyā
analyzed: sesā parivāra mattā honti khattiyassa vā brāhmaṇiyā brāhmaṇassa vā khattiyāniyā
translated: the rest were just his retinue. Among the Velāma women, the Velāma women were the wives of the khattiyas and brahmins,

original: kucchismiṃ jātā. Paridahāmīti ekaṃyeva dussayugaṃ nivāsemi, sesāni parivāretvā vicarantānaṃ
analyzed: kucchismim jātā paridahāmi iti ekam yā iva dussa yugam nivāsemi sesāni parivāretvā vicarantānam
translated: I am wearing a single pair of garments, the rest are being worn by those who are wandering about after having surrounded me.

original: asītisahassādhikānaṃ soḷasannaṃ purisasatasahassānaṃ hontīti dasseti. Bhuñjāmīti🔽paramappamāṇena nāḷikodanamattaṃ bhuñjāmi, sesaṃ parivāretvā vicarantānaṃ cattālīsasahassādhikānaṃ
analyzed: asīti sahassa adhikānam purisa sata sahassānam honti iti dasseti bhuñjāmi iti  parama ppamāṇena nāḷika udana mattam bhuñjāmi sesam parivāretvā vicarantānam cattālīsa sahassa adhikānam
translated: I am showing that they belong to 160,000 men. I am eating a measure of rice, the rest is being eaten by those who are wandering about after having surrounded me.

original: aṭṭhannaṃ purisasatasahassānaṃ hotīti dasseti. Ekathālipāko hi dasannaṃ janānaṃ pahoti.
analyzed: aṭṭhannam purisa sata sahassānam hoti iti dasseti ekathā āli pākaḥ hi dasannam janānam pahoti
translated: I am showing that it belongs to 84,000 men. For a single cooking of rice suffices for ten persons.

original: Iti imaṃ mahāsudassanakāle sampattiṃ dassetvā idāni tassā aniccataṃ dassento iti
analyzed: iti imam mahāsudassana kāle sampattim dassetvā idāni tassāḥ anicca tam dassentaḥ iti
translated: Having thus shown the prosperity of the time of Mahāsudassana, the Master now said iti kho bhikkhu, etc., in order to show its impermanence.

original: kho bhikkhūtiādimāha. Tattha vipariṇatāti pakatijahanena nibbutapadīpo viya apaṇṇattikabhāvaṃ
analyzed: kho bhikkhu iti ādim āha tattha vipariṇatā ti pakati jahanena nibbuta padīpaḥ viya apaṇṇattika bhāvam
translated: There, vipariṇatā means that it has reached a state of non-existence like a lamp that has gone out by the exhaustion of the oil.

original: gatā. Evaṃ aniccā kho bhikkhu saṅkhārāti evaṃ hutvāabhāvaṭṭhena aniccā. Ettāvatā
analyzed: gatāḥ evam aniccāḥ kho bhikkhu saṅkhārāḥ ti evam hutvā abhāva ṭṭhena aniccāḥ ettāvatā
translated: Thus, bhikkhu, are formations impermanent. In this way, they are impermanent in the sense of non-existence after having been.

original: bhagavā yathā nāma puriso satahatthubbedhe campakarukkhe nisseṇiṃ bandhitvā abhiruhitvā
analyzed: bhagavā yathā nāma purisaḥ sata hatthu bedhe campaka rukkhe nisseṇim bandhitvā abhiruhitvā
translated: The Blessed One descended from the plane of the Great Sudassana’s prosperity, which was a hundred thousand leagues high, as if descending from a tree a hundred cubits high, after climbing up it by means of a creeper,

original: campakapupphaṃ ādāya nisseṇiṃ muñcanto otareyya, evamevaṃ nisseṇiṃ bandhanto viya
analyzed: campaka puppham ādāya nisseṇim muñcantaḥ otareyya evam evam nisseṇim bandhantaḥ viya
translated: and after taking a champak flower, he let go of the creeper and descended.

original: anekavassakoṭisatasahassubbedhaṃ mahāsudassanasampattiṃ āruyha sampattimatthake ṭhitaṃ🔽aniccalakkhaṇaṃ ādāya nisseṇiṃ muñcanto viya otiṇṇo. Evaṃ addhuvāti evaṃ udakapubbuḷādayo🔽viya dhuvabhāvarahitā. Evaṃ anassāsikāti evaṃ supinake pītapānīyaṃ viya anulittacandanaṃ
analyzed: aneka vassa koṭi sata sahassa ubbedham mahāsudassana sampattim āruyha sampatti matthake ṭhitam  anicca lakkhaṇam ādāya nisseṇim muñcantaḥ viya otiṇṇaḥ evam evam udaka pubbuḷā ādayo  viya dhuva bhāva rahitā evam evam supinake pīta pānīyam viya anulitta candanam
translated: So too, after climbing up the plane of the Great Sudassana’s prosperity, which was a hundred thousand leagues high, and after taking the sign of impermanence, he let go of the plane of prosperity and descended.🔽Thus it is impermanent: thus it is devoid of permanence like water bubbles, etc.,🔽Thus it is not satisfying: thus it is devoid of satisfaction like water drunk in a dream, like sandalwood ointment applied in a dream,

original: viya ca assāsavirahitā. Iti imasmiṃ sutte aniccalakkhaṇaṃ kathitaṃ. Pañcame sabbaṃ
analyzed: ca assāsa virahitā iti imasmim sutte anicca lakkhaṇam kathitam pañcame sabbam
translated: Thus it is not a self: thus it is devoid of a self like a palmyra tree that has been chopped down at the top, like a water-snake. Thus in this sutta the characteristic of impermanence is taught. In the fifth sutta the method of explanation is the same as before.

original: vuttanayameva. Chaṭṭhaṃ tathā bujjhanakassa ajjhāsayena vuttaṃ. Catutthādīni.
analyzed: vutta nayam eva chaṭṭham tathā bujjhanakassa ajjhāsayena vuttam catuttha ādīni
translated: The sixth sutta was spoken with the intention of awakening. The fourth sutta, etc.,

original: 7. Gaddulabaddhasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: gaddulabaddha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The explanation of the Gaddulabaddha Sutta is finished.

original: 99. Sattame yaṃ mahāsamuddoti yasmiṃ samaye pañcame sūriye uṭṭhite mahāsamuddo ussussati.🔽Dukkhassa antakiriyanti cattāri saccāni appaṭivijjhitvā avijjāya nivutānaṃyeva sataṃ
analyzed: sattame yam mahā samuddaḥ iti yasmin samaye pañcame sūriye uṭṭhite mahā samuddaḥ ussussati  cattāri saccāni a paṭivijjhitvā avijjāya
translated: 99. Seventh: “The great ocean”: at the time when the great ocean dries up when the fifth sun has risen.🔽“The end of suffering”: I do not declare the end, the limit, of the suffering of the round for those who are still covered by ignorance without having penetrated the four truths.

original: vaṭṭadukkhassa antakiriyaṃ paricchedaṃ na vadāmi. Sā gaddulabaddhoti gaddulena baddhasunakho.
analyzed: vaṭṭa dukkhassa anta kiriyam paricchedam na vadāmi sā gaddula baddhā iti gaddulena baddha su nakhaḥ
translated: “Tied by a rope”: a dog tied by a rope of gaddul.

original: Khīleti pathaviyaṃ ākoṭite mahākhīle. Thambheti nikhaṇitvā ṭhapite thambhe. Evameva
analyzed: khīla iti pathaviyam ākoṭite mahā khīle thambha iti nikhaṇitvā ṭhapite thambhe evam eva
translated: “A stake”: a great stake driven into the ground.

original: khoti ettha sunakho viya vaṭṭanissito bālo, gaddulo viya diṭṭhi, thambho viya sakkāyo,🔽gaddularajjuyā thambhe upanibaddhasunakhassa thambhānuparivattanaṃ viya diṭṭhitaṇhāya
analyzed: kho ti ettha su nakhaḥ viya vaṭṭa nissitaḥ bālaḥ gaddulaḥ viya diṭṭhi thambhaḥ viya sakkāyaḥ  gaddula rajjuyā thambhe upanibaddha su nakhassa thambha anuparivattanam viya diṭṭhi taṇhāya
translated: “Just so”: here the fool who is bound to the round is like the dog; the view is like the gaddul; the personality is like the stake;

original: sakkāye baddhassa puthujjanassa sakkāyānuparivattanaṃ veditabbaṃ. Sattamaṃ.
analyzed: sakkāye baddhassa puthujjanassa sakkāya anuparivattanam veditabbam sattamam
translated: the round of the personality of the worldling who is bound to the personality by craving for views should be understood to be like the turning of the stake by the dog tied to the stake by the rope of gaddul.🔽The seventh sutta of the Gaddhulovada

original: 8. Dutiyagaddulabaddhasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya gaddulabaddha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The commentary on the second sutta of the Gaddhulovada

original: 100. Aṭṭhame tasmāti yasmā diṭṭhigaddulanissitāya taṇhārajjuyā sakkāyathambhe upanibaddho
analyzed: aṭṭhame tasmā iti yasmai diṭṭhi gaddula nissitāya taṇhā rajjuyā sakkāya thambhe upanibaddhaḥ
translated: 100.In the eighth case, “because” means that the fool, the worldling, is bound to the stake of personality view by the rope of craving that depends on the pit of false view,

original: vaṭṭanissito bālaputhujjano sabbiriyāpathesu khandhapañcakaṃ nissāyeva pavattati,
analyzed: vaṭṭa nissitaḥ bāla puthujjanaḥ sa biriyāpathesu khandha pañcakam nissāya iva pavattati
translated: and he goes about depending on the five aggregates in all his activities.

original: yasmā vā dīgharattamidaṃ cittaṃ saṃkiliṭṭhaṃ rāgena dosena mohena, tasmā. Cittasaṃkilesāti🔽sunhātāpi hi sattā cittasaṃkileseneva saṃkilissanti, malaggahitasarīrāpi cittassa
analyzed: yasmai vā dīgharattam idam cittam saṃkiliṭṭham rāgena dosena mohena tasmai citta saṃkilesā ati  sunhātā api hi sattā citta saṃkilesena iva saṃkilissanti malagga hita sarīrā api cittassa
translated: Or else, “because” means that for a long time this mind has been defiled by lust, hatred, and delusion.

original: vodānattā visujjhanti. Tenāhu porāṇā –
analyzed: vodānattāḥ visujjhanti tena āhu porāṇāḥ
translated: For even though beings are well bathed, they are defiled by the defilement of the mind; and even though their bodies are smeared with dirt, they are purified by the purification of the mind. Therefore the ancients said:

original: “Rūpamhi saṃkiliṭṭhamhi, saṃkilissanti māṇavā;
analyzed: rūpamhi saṃkiliṭṭhamhi saṃkilissanti māṇavāḥ
translated: “When form is defiled, the young man is defiled;

original: Rūpe suddhe visujjhanti, anakkhātaṃ mahesinā.
analyzed: rūpe suddhe visujjhanti an akkhātam mahesinā
translated: When form is pure, they are purified, though the Great Sage did not proclaim it.

original: “Cittamhi saṃkiliṭṭhamhi, saṃkilissanti māṇavā;
analyzed: cittamhi saṃkiliṭṭhamhi saṃkilissanti māṇavā
translated: “When the mind is defiled, the young man is defiled;

original: Citte suddhe visujjhanti, iti vuttaṃ mahesinā”ti.
analyzed: citte suddhe visujjhanti iti vuttam mahesinā ati
translated: When the mind is pure, they are purified, though the Great Sage did not proclaim it.”

original: Caraṇaṃ nāma cittanti vicaraṇacittaṃ. Saṅkhā nāma brāhmaṇapāsaṇḍikā honti, te paṭakoṭṭhakaṃ
analyzed: caraṇam nāma cittanti vicaraṇa cittam saṅkhāḥ nāma brāhmaṇa pāsaṇḍikāḥ honti te paṭakoṭṭhakam
translated: “Conduct” is the investigating mind. The “Saṅkhyas” are the brahmin heretics who pound rice in a mortar.

original: katvā tattha nānappakārā sugatiduggativasena sampattivipattiyo lekhāpetvā, “imaṃ
analyzed: katvā tattha nānappakārā sugati duggati vasena sampatti vipattiyaḥ lekhāpetvā imaṃ
translated: and having had drawn there the various kinds of good and bad fortunes of the heavens and the hells, he said: “This

original: kammaṃ katvā idaṃ paṭilabhati, idaṃ katvā ida”nti dassentā taṃ cittaṃ gahetvā vicaranti.🔽Citteneva cittitanti cittakārena cintetvā katattā cittena cintitaṃ nāma. Cittaññeva🔽cittataranti tassa cittassa upāyapariyesanacittaṃ tatopi cittataraṃ. Tiracchānagatā🔽pāṇā citteneva cittitāti kammacitteneva cittitā. Taṃ pana kammacittaṃ ime vaṭṭakatittirādayo🔽“evaṃ cittā bhavissāmā”ti āyūhantā nāma natthi. Kammaṃ pana yoniṃ upaneti, yonimūlako
analyzed: kammam katvā idam paṭilabhati idam katvā idam ti dassentā tam cittam gahetvā vicaranti  cittena iva cittitanti cittakārena cintetvā cittena cintitam nāma cittaññā iva  cittataranti tassa cittassa upāya pariyesana cittam tatas api cittataram tiracchāna gatā  pāṇā cittena iva cittitā ati kamma cittena iva cittitā tam pana kamma cittam ime vaṭṭaka tittira ādayo  evam cittāḥ bhavissāma ati āyūhantāḥ nāma natthi kammam pana yonim upaneti yoni mūlakaḥ
translated: Having done so, they show the mind how to proceed by having the various kinds of good and bad fortune, which are the results of good and bad actions, written down, saying, “By doing this action one obtains that result, by doing that one obtains this.”

original: tesaṃ cittabhāvo. Yoniupagatā hi sattā taṃtaṃyonikehi sadisacittāva honti. Iti yonisiddho🔽cittabhāvo, kammasiddhā yonīti veditabbā.
analyzed: tesam citta bhāvaḥ yoni upagatāḥ hi sattā taṃ taṃyonikehi sadisa cittāḥ ava honti iti yoni siddhaḥ 🔽citta bhāvaḥ kamma siddhā yoni iti veditabbā
translated: “By mind alone is the mind created”: it is called “created by mind” because it is created by the mind that conceives. “The mind is more mind-created”: the mind that seeks the means is more mind-created than the first mind. “Animals are mind-created by mind alone”: they are mind-created by the kamma-mind. But those kamma-minds do not exist in the partridges, etc., thinking, “We will be like this.” The kamma leads to the womb, and the state of mind of those partridges, etc., is rooted in the womb. For beings who have entered a womb have minds similar to those of the beings in that womb. Thus the state of mind is established by the womb, and the womb is established by the kamma.

original: Apica cittaṃ nāmetaṃ sahajātaṃ sahajātadhammacittatāya bhūmicittatāya vatthucittatāya🔽dvāracittatāya ārammaṇacittatāya kammanānattamūlakānaṃ liṅganānattasaññānānattavohāranānattādīnaṃ
analyzed: apica cittam nāma etam sahajātam sahajāta dhamma citta tāya bhūmi citta tāya vatthu citta tāya  dvāra citta tāya ārammaṇa citta tāya kamma nānatta mūlakānam liṅga nānatta saññā nānatta vohāra nānatta ādīnam
translated: Furthermore, this mind is more mental than the animal mind, because it produces the various kinds of minds such as the mind of the same moment, the mind of the same state, the mind of the same basis,

original: anekavidhānaṃ cittānaṃ nipphādanatāyapi tiracchānagatacittato cittatarameva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: aneka vidhānam tiracchāna gata cittataḥ cittataram eva veditabbam
translated: the mind of the same door, and the mind of the same object, and also because it produces the various kinds of minds such as the various kinds of signs, the various kinds of perceptions, the various kinds of expressions, and so on, which are rooted in the variety of kamma.

original: Rajakoti vatthesu raṅgena rūpasamuṭṭhāpanako. So pana acheko amanāpaṃ rūpaṃ karoti,
analyzed: rajako ti vatthesu raṅgena rūpa samuṭṭhāpanako so pana achekaḥ amanāpam rūpam karoti
translated: A dyer is one who produces colour in cloth by dyeing. But the unskilled one produces an unlovely colour,

original: cheko manāpaṃ dassanīyaṃ, evameva puthujjano akusalacittena vā ñāṇavippayuttakusalena🔽vā cakkhusampadādivirahitaṃ virūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti, ñāṇasampayuttakusalena cakkhusampadādisampannaṃ
analyzed: chekaḥ manāpam dassanīyam evam eva puthujjanaḥ akusala cittena vā ñāṇa vippayutta kusalena  vā cakkhu sampad ādi virahitam virūpam samuṭṭhāpeti ñāṇa sampayutta kusalena cakkhu sampad ādi sampannam
translated: while the skilled one produces a lovely, beautiful colour. So too, the worldling produces an ugly colour with an unwholesome mind or with wholesome-uncertain mind,

original: abhirūpaṃ. Aṭṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: abhirūpam aṭṭhamam
translated: while one with a mind accompanied by knowledge produces a beautiful colour with a wholesome-with-knowledge mind. The eighth case is finished.

original: 9. Vāsijaṭasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vāsijaṭa sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The explanation of the ninth case🔽In the ninth case, “Bhikkhus, just as from a hen . . .

original: 101. Navame seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, kukkuṭiyā aṇḍānīti imā kaṇhapakkhasukkapakkhavasena
analyzed: navame seyyathā api bhikkhave kukkuṭiyāḥ aṇḍāni iti imā kaṇha pakkha sukka pakkha vasena
translated: . . . and the white-winged ones” are the black-winged and white-winged chickens.

original: dve upamā vuttā. Tāsu kaṇhapakkhaupamā atthassa asādhikā, itarā sādhikāti. Sukkapakkhaupamāya
analyzed: dve upamāḥ vuttā tāsu kaṇhapakkha opamā atthassa asādhikā itarā sādhikā ati sukkapakkha opamāya
translated: Two similes are given. Of these, the simile of the dark side is not a help to the meaning, but the other is.

original: evaṃ attho veditabbo – seyyathāti opammatthe nipāto, apīti sambhāvanatthe. Ubhayenāpi🔽seyyathā nāma, bhikkhaveti dasseti. Kukkuṭiyā aṇḍāni aṭṭha vā dasa vā dasa vā dvādasa
analyzed: evam atthaḥ veditabbaḥ seyyathā iti opamma atthe nipātaḥ api iti sambhāvanā tthe ubhayena api  seyyathā nāma bhikkhave iti dasseti kukkuṭiyāḥ aṇḍāni aṭṭha vā dasa vā dasa vā dvādasa
translated: The meaning of the simile of the bright side should be understood as follows. The word seyyathā is a particle in the sense of example; apīti is in the sense of possibility.

original: vāti ettha pana kiñcāpi kukkuṭiyā vuttappakārato ūnādhikānipi aṇḍāni honti, vacanasiliṭṭhatāya🔽pana evaṃ vuttaṃ. Evañhi loke siliṭṭhavacanaṃ hoti. Tānassūti tāni assu, tāni bhaveyyunti🔽attho. Kukkuṭiyā sammā adhisayitānīti tāya ca janettiyā kukkuṭiyā pakkhe pasāretvā
analyzed: vā ti ettha pana kiñcā api kukkuṭiyāḥ vutta ppakārataḥ ūna adhikāni api aṇḍāni honti vacana siliṭṭha tāya  pana evam vuttam evam hi loke siliṭṭha vacanam hoti tān assu iti tāni assu tāni bhaveyyun ti  attho kukkuṭiyā sammā adhisayitāni iti tāya ca janettiyā kukkuṭiyā pakkhe pasāretvā
translated: With both he shows that it is like this, bhikkhus. Kukkuṭiyā aṇḍāni aṭṭha vā dasa vā dvādasa vāti here, although the hen’s eggs may be less or more than those stated, still it is said thus for the sake of the form of the statement.

original: tesaṃ upari sayantiyā sammā adhisayitāni. Sammā pariseditānīti kālena kālaṃ utuṃ
analyzed: tesam upari sayantiyā sammā adhisayitāni sammā pariseditāni iti kālena kālam
translated: For this is the form of statement in the world. Tānassūti tāni assu, tāni bhaveyyunti is the meaning. Kukkuṭiyā sammā adhisayitānīti by that hen, the mother, the eggs were properly sat upon. Sammā pariseditānīti from time to time, the heat of the sun and moon

original: gaṇhāpentiyā suṭṭhu samantato seditāni usmīkatāni. Sammā paribhāvitānīti kālena kālaṃ
analyzed: gaṇhāpentiyā suṭṭhu samantataḥ seditāni usmīkatāni sammā paribhāvitāni iti kālena kālam
translated: When she warms them properly, she warms them all over, she warms them thoroughly.

original: suṭṭhu samantato bhāvitāni, kukkuṭagandhaṃ gāhāpitānīti attho. Kiñcāpi tassā kukkuṭiyāti
analyzed: suṭṭhu samantataḥ bhāvitāni kukkuṭa gandham gāhāpitāni iti attho kiñcā api tassā kukkuṭiyā ti
translated: When she turns them properly, she turns them all over, she turns them thoroughly. The meaning is that she makes them take on the smell of a hen.🔽Even though she does not wish:

original: tassā kukkuṭiyā iminā tividhakiriyākaraṇena appamādaṃ katvā kiñcāpi na evaṃ icchā
analyzed: tassā kukkuṭiyā iminā tividha kiriyā karaṇena appamādam katvā kiñcā api na evam icchā
translated: Even though that hen does not wish thus,🔽“Let these chicks break out of the eggshell safely and easily,”

original: upajjeyya. Atha kho bhabbāva teti atha kho te kukkuṭapotakā vuttanayena sotthinā🔽abhinibbhijjituṃ bhabbāva. Te hi yasmā tāya kukkuṭiyā evaṃ tīhākārehi tāni aṇḍāni
analyzed: upajjeyya atha kho bhabbā va te iti atha kho te kukkuṭa potakāḥ vutta nayena sotthinā  abhinibbhijjitum bhabbāva te hi yasmā tāya kukkuṭiyai evam tīhākārehi tāni aṇḍāni
translated: nevertheless they are able to do so.

original: paripāliyamānāni na pūtīni honti, yo nesaṃ allasineho, sopi pariyādānaṃ gacchati,
analyzed: paripāliyamānāni na pūtīni honti yaḥ allasinehaḥ saḥ api pariyādānam gacchati
translated: For since the eggs are protected by the hen in these three ways, they do not go bad, the moisture in them does not dry up,

original: kapālaṃ tanukaṃ hoti, pādanakhasikhā ca mukhatuṇḍakañca kharaṃ hoti, sayampi pariṇāmaṃ
analyzed: kapālam tanukam hoti pāda nakha sikhā ca mukha tuṇḍakañca kharam hoti sayam pi pariṇāmam
translated: the shell becomes thin, the points of the claws and the tip of the beak become sharp, and they themselves reach maturity.🔽When the shell is thin, light is visible inside it.

original: gacchanti, kapālassa tanuttā bahi āloko anto paññāyati, tasmā “ciraṃ vata mayaṃ saṅkuṭitahatthapādā
analyzed: gacchanti kapālassa tanuttāḥ bahi ālokaḥ anto paññāyati tasmā ciram vata mayam saṅkuṭita hattha pādā
translated: “How long have we been sitting with our limbs drawn in?”

original: sambādhe sayimhā, ayañca bahi āloko dissati, ettha dāni no sukhavihāro bhavissatī”ti🔽nikkhamitukāmā hutvā kapālaṃ pādena paharanti, gīvaṃ pasārenti, tato taṃ kapālaṃ
analyzed: sambādhe ayam ca bahi āloko dissati ettha dāni no sukha vihāraḥ bhavissati iti  nikkhamitu kāmāḥ hutvā kapālam pādena paharanti gīvam pasārenti tatas tam kapālam
translated: “We are cramped inside the egg. But there is light outside. It will be pleasant for us to live there.”🔽And when they are eager to come out, they peck at the shell with their claws and beaks and break out.

original: dvedhā bhijjati. Atha te pakkhe vidhunantā taṃkhaṇānurūpaṃ viravantā nikkhamantiyeva,
analyzed: dvedhā bhijjati atha te pakkhe vidhunantā taṃkhaṇa anurūpam viravantā nikkhamantiyā iva
translated: Then they shake their wings and cry out in accordance with their kind and come out.

original: nikkhamitvā ca gāmakkhettaṃ upasobhayamānā vicaranti.
analyzed: nikkhamitvā ca gāma khettam upasobhayamānāḥ vicaranti
translated: And when they have come out, they wander about beautifying the village and fields.

original: Evameva khoti idaṃ opammasampaṭipādanaṃ. Taṃ evaṃ atthena saṃsanditvā veditabbaṃ🔽– tassā kukkuṭiyā aṇḍesu tividhakiriyākaraṇaṃ viya hi imassa bhikkhuno bhāvānuyogaṃ🔽anuyuttakālo, kukkuṭiyā tividhakiriyāsampādanena aṇḍānaṃ apūtibhāvo viya bhāvanānuyogamanuyuttassa
analyzed: evam eva kho ti idam opamma sampaṭipādanam tam evam atthena saṃsanditvā veditabbam  tassā kukkuṭiyāḥ aṇḍesu tividha kiriyā karaṇam viya hi imassa bhikkhuno bhāva anuyogam  anuyutta kālaḥ kukkuṭiyā tividha kiriyā sampādanena aṇḍānam a pūti bhāvaḥ viya bhāvanā anuyogam anuyuttassa
translated: So too, the simile is applied thus.🔽The time when the bhikkhu devotes himself to development by means of the kinds of insight mentioned in the way stated is like the time when the hen devoted herself to the three activities with regard to the eggs.

original: bhikkhuno tividhānupassanāsampādanena vipassanāñāṇassa aparihāni, tassā tividhakiriyākaraṇena
analyzed: bhikkhuno tividha anupassanā sampādanena vipassanā ñāṇassa tividha kiriyā karaṇena
translated: The non-failure of the bhikkhu’s insight knowledge through his accomplishment of the three contemplations while devoted to development is like the non-spoiling of the eggs through the hen’s accomplishment of the three activities.🔽The bhikkhu’s emergence from the egg of the underlying tendency to lust, etc., by means of the three kinds of emergence is like the chicks’ emergence from the egg by means of the three kinds of pecking.

original: allasinehapariyādānaṃ viya tassa bhikkhuno tividhānupassanāsampādanena bhavattayānugatanikantisinehapariyādānaṃ,
analyzed: alla sineha pariyādānam viya tassa bhikkhuno tividha anupassanā sampādanena bhava tayā anugata nikanti sineha pariyādānam
translated: The exhaustion of the moisture of affection for the three kinds of becoming by the bhikkhu’s perfecting of the three contemplations is like the exhaustion of the moisture of affection for the eggs.

original: aṇḍakapālānaṃ tanubhāvo viya tassa bhikkhuno avijjaṇḍakosassa tanubhāvo, kukkuṭapotakānaṃ🔽pādanakhasikhamukhatuṇḍakānaṃ thaddhakharabhāvo viya bhikkhuno vipassanāñāṇassa tikkhakharavippasanna
analyzed: aṇḍa kapālānam tanu bhāvaḥ viya tassa bhikkhuno avijjaṇḍa kosassa tanu bhāvaḥ kukkuṭa potakānam  pāda nakha sikha mukha tuṇḍakānam thaddha khara bhāvaḥ viya bhikkhuno vipassanā ñāṇassa tikkha khara vippasanna
translated: The attenuation of the bhikkhu’s egg-shell of ignorance is like the attenuation of the eggs.🔽The keenness and lucidity of the bhikkhu’s insight knowledge is like the sharpness and keenness of the chicks’ claws, beak, and wings.🔽The time for the bhikkhu’s insight knowledge to reach maturity is like the time for the chicks to hatch.🔽The time for the bhikkhu’s insight knowledge to reach maturity is like the time for the chicks to hatch.

original: sūrabhāvo, kukkuṭapotakānaṃ pariṇāmakālo viya bhikkhuno vipassanāñāṇassa pariṇāmakālo🔽vaḍḍhitakālo gabbhaggahaṇakālo, kukkuṭapotakānaṃ pādanakhasikhāya vā mukhatuṇḍakena🔽vā aṇḍakosaṃ padāletvā pakkhe papphoṭetvā sotthinā abhinibbhidākālo viya tassa bhikkhuno
analyzed: sūra bhāvaḥ kukkuṭa potakānam pariṇāma kālaḥ viya bhikkhuno vipassanā ñāṇassa pariṇāma kālaḥ  vaḍḍhita kālaḥ gabbha ggahaṇa kālaḥ kukkuṭa potakānam pāda nakha sikhāya vā mukhatuṇḍakena  vā aṇḍa kosam padāletvā pakkhe papphoṭetvā sotthinā abhinibbhidā kālaḥ viya tassa bhikkhuno
translated: The time for the bhikkhu’s insight knowledge to reach maturity is like the time for the chicks to hatch.🔽The time for the bhikkhu’s insight knowledge to reach maturity is like the time for the chicks to hatch.🔽The time for the bhikkhu’s insight knowledge to reach maturity is like the time for the chicks to hatch.🔽The time for the bhikkhu’s insight knowledge to reach maturity is like the time for the chicks to hatch.🔽The time for the bhikkhu’s insight knowledge to reach maturity is like the time for the chicks to hatch.🔽The time for the bhikkhu’s insight knowledge to reach maturity is like the time for the chicks to hatch.🔽The time for the bhikkhu’s insight knowledge to reach maturity is like the time for the chicks to hatch.🔽The time for the bhikkhu’s insight knowledge to reach maturity is like the time for the chicks to hatch.🔽The time for the bhikkhu’s insight knowledge to reach maturity is like the time for the chicks to hatch.🔽The time for the bhikkhu’s insight knowledge to reach maturity is like the time for the chicks to hatch.🔽The time for the bhikkhu’s insight knowledge to reach maturity is like the time for the chicks to hatch.🔽The time for the bhikkhu’s insight knowledge to reach maturity is like the time for the chicks to hatch.🔽The time for the bhikkhu’s insight knowledge to reach maturity is like the time for the chicks to hatch.🔽The time for the bhikkhu’s insight knowledge to reach maturity is like the time for the chicks to hatch.

original: vipassanāñāṇagabbhaṃ gaṇhāpetvā vicarantassa tajjātikaṃ utusappāyaṃ vā bhojanasappāyaṃ
analyzed: vipassanā ñāṇa gabbham gaṇhāpetvā vicarantassa tad jātikam utu sappāyam vā bhojana sappāyam
translated: The time for the bhikkhu’s insight knowledge to reach maturity is

original: vā puggalasappāyaṃ vā dhammassavanasappāyaṃ vā labhitvā ekāsane nisinnasseva vipassanaṃ
analyzed: vā puggala sappāyam vā dhammassavana sappāyam vā labhitvā eka āsane nisinnassa iva vipassanam
translated: Or else, having obtained a suitable person or a suitable place for hearing the Dhamma, he develops insight while sitting in a single session and,

original: vaḍḍhentassa anupubbādhigatena arahattamaggena avijjaṇḍakosaṃ padāletvā abhiññāpakkhe🔽papphoṭetvā sotthinā arahattapattakālo veditabbo. Yathā pana kukkuṭapotakānaṃ pariṇatabhāvaṃ
analyzed: vaḍḍhentassa anupubba adhigatena arahatta maggena a vijjaṇḍa kosam padāletvā abhiññā pakkhe  papphoṭetvā sotthinā arahatta patta kālaḥ veditabbaḥ yathā pana kukkuṭa potakānam pariṇata bhāvam
translated: by the path of arahantship, which is attained in due course, he bursts open the shell of ignorance and,🔽having rubbed out the defilements on the side of purification, he reaches the time of attaining arahantship in safety.

original: ñatvā mātāpi aṇḍakosaṃ bhindati, evaṃ tathārūpassa bhikkhuno ñāṇaparipākaṃ ñatvā satthāpi –
analyzed: ñatvā mātā api aṇḍa kosam bhindati evam tathārūpassa bhikkhuno ñāṇa paripākam ñatvā satthā api
translated: But just as the mother hen, knowing that the chicks are fully developed, breaks open the shell with her claws and beak, so too the Teacher, knowing that the disciple’s knowledge is fully developed,

original: “Ucchinda sinehamattano, kumudaṃ sāradikaṃva pāṇinā;
analyzed: ucchinda kumudam pāṇinā
translated: “Tear out the root of craving, as one pulls out a reed from a reed-bed;

original: Santimaggameva brūhaya, nibbānaṃ sugatena desita”nti. –🔽Ādinā nayena obhāsaṃ pharitvā gāthāya avijjaṇḍakosaṃ paharati. So gāthāpariyosāne
analyzed: santi maggam eva nibbānam sugatena desitanti  ādinā nayena obhāsam pharitvā gāthāya avijjaṇḍakosam paharati saḥ gāthā pariyosāne
translated: Make the path of peace your own, Nibbāna taught by the One of Perfect Peace.”🔽Having first spread light by this stanza, he strikes the shell of ignorance with the verse. At the end of the verse,

original: avijjaṇḍakosaṃ bhinditvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti. Tato paṭṭhāya yathā te kukkuṭapotakā
analyzed: avijjaṇḍa kosam bhinditvā arahattam pāpuṇāti tatas paṭṭhāya yathā te kukkuṭa potakā
translated: the disciple breaks open the shell of ignorance and attains arahantship. From then on, just as those chicks,

original: gāmakkhettaṃ upasobhayamānā tattha vicaranti, evaṃ ayampi mahākhīṇāsavo nibbānārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: gāma khettam upasobhayamānā tattha vicaranti evam ayam pi mahā khīṇāsavaḥ nibbāna ārammaṇam
translated: and beautify the village and fields as they wander there, so too this Great Ascetic, having attained Nibbāna, which is the supreme beauty,🔽

original: phalasamāpattiṃ appetvā saṅghārāmaṃ upasobhayamāno vicarati.🔽Palagaṇḍassāti vaḍḍhakissa. So hi olambakasaṅkhātaṃ palaṃ dhāretvā dārūnaṃ gaṇḍaṃ
analyzed: phala samāpattim saṅgha ārāmam upasobhayamānaḥ vicarati  palagaṇḍassa ati vaḍḍhakissa saḥ hi olambaka saṅkhātam palam dhāretvā gaṇḍam
translated: and they wander about beautifying the village and the fields, so too this great arahat, after arousing the fruition attainment of Nibbāna as his object, wanders about beautifying the monastery.🔽‘The carpenter’ is the builder. He is called a carpenter because he carries a chip, that is, a piece of wood, and removes the knots, that is, the faults, of the timber.

original: haratīti palagaṇḍoti vuccati. Vāsijaṭeti vāsidaṇḍakassa gahaṇaṭṭhāne. Ettakaṃ vata
analyzed: harati iti palagaṇḍo ti vuccati vāsijaṭā iti vāsidaṇḍakassa gahaṇa ṭṭhāne ettakam vata
translated: ‘The handle of the axe’ is the place where the handle of the axe is held. The meaning is that he thinks: ‘Today, so much of my cankers have been destroyed.

original: me ajja āsavānaṃ khīṇanti pabbajitassa hi pabbajjāsaṅkhepena uddesena paripucchāya
analyzed: me ajja āsavānam khīṇanti pabbajitassa hi pabbajjā saṅkhepena uddesena paripucchāya
translated: For the cankers of one who has gone forth are destroyed all the time by the going forth itself, by the recitation of the summary of the Dhamma, by the questioning of the pupil,

original: yoniso manasikārena vattapaṭipattiyā ca niccakālaṃ āsavā khīyanti. Evaṃ khīyamānānaṃ
analyzed: yonisaḥ manasikārena vatta paṭipattiyā ca niccakālam āsavāḥ khīyanti evam khīyamānānam
translated: by the proper attention, and by the practice of the right way. But while they are being destroyed in this way,

original: pana tesaṃ “ettakaṃ ajja khīṇaṃ, ettakaṃ hiyyo”ti evamassa ñāṇaṃ na hotīti attho.🔽Imāya upamāya vipassanāyānisaṃso dīpito. Hemantikenāti hemantasamayena. Paṭippassambhantīti
analyzed: pana tesam ettakam ajja khīṇam ettakam hiyyo ti evam assa ñāṇam na hoti iti attho  imāya upamāya vipassanāya anisaṃsaḥ dīpitaḥ hemantikena ati hemanta samayena paṭippassambhanti iti
translated: he does not know: “Today so much has been destroyed, yesterday so much.”🔽This simile illustrates the benefits of insight.

original: thirabhāvena parihāyanti.
analyzed: thira bhāvena parihāyanti
translated: ‘The cold weather’ is the cold season. ‘Are allayed’ means that they are diminished by the firmness .

original: Evameva khoti ettha mahāsamuddo viya sāsanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ, nāvā viya yogāvacaro, nāvāya
analyzed: evam eva kho ti ettha mahā samuddaḥ viya sāsanam daṭṭhabbam nāvā viya yogāvacaraḥ nāvāya
translated: So too, the Dispensation should be regarded as the ocean, the bhikkhu as the ship,

original: mahāsamudde pariyādānaṃ viya imassa bhikkhuno ūnapañcavassakāle ācariyupajjhāyānaṃ
analyzed: mahā samudde pariyādānam viya imassa bhikkhuno ūna pañca vassa kāle ācariya upajjhāyānam
translated: the bhikkhu’s wandering about in the presence of teachers and preceptors as the ship’s going to sea,

original: santike vicaraṇaṃ, nāvāya mahāsamuddodakena khajjamānānaṃ bandhanānaṃ tanubhāvo viya🔽bhikkhuno pabbajjāsaṅkhepena uddesaparipucchādīhi ceva saṃyojanānaṃ tanubhāvo, nāvāya
analyzed: santike vicaraṇam nāvāya mahā samudda udakena khajjamānānam bandhanānam tanu bhāvaḥ viya  bhikkhuno pabbajjā saṅkhepena uddesa paripuccha ādīhi ca iva saṃyojanānam tanu bhāvaḥ nāvāya
translated: the thinning of the fetters as the thinning of the ship’s timbers by the ocean water,

original: thale ukkhittakālo viya bhikkhuno nissayamuccakassa kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā araññe vasanakālo,
analyzed: thale ukkhitta kālaḥ viya bhikkhuno nissayamuccakassa kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā araññe vasana kālo
translated: the bhikkhu’s going to the forest to do the meditation subject as the ship’s going ashore,

original: divā vātātapena saṃsussanaṃ viya vipassanāñāṇena taṇhāsnehasaṃsussanaṃ, rattiṃ himodakena
analyzed: divā vāta ātapena saṃsussanam viya vipassanā ñāṇena taṇhā sneha saṃsussanam rattim hima udakena
translated: the drying of the moisture of craving by the knowledge of insight as the drying of the timbers by the wind and sun,

original: temanaṃ viya kammaṭṭhānaṃ nissāya uppannena pītipāmojjena cittatemanaṃ, rattindivaṃ
analyzed: temanam viya kammaṭṭhānam nissāya uppannena pīti pāmojjena citta temanam rattindivam
translated: the refreshing of the mind by the happiness and gladness that arise with the meditation subject as the ship’s refreshing by the cool water at night,

original: vātātapena ceva himodakena ca parisukkhaparitintānaṃ bandhanānaṃ dubbalabhāvo viya
analyzed: vāta ātapena ca iva hima udakena ca parisukkha paritintānam bandhanānam dubbala bhāvaḥ viya
translated: the weakening of the fetters as the weakening of the timbers by the cool water at night and the drying by the wind and sun by day,

original: ekadivasaṃ utusappāyādīni laddhā vipassanāñāṇapītipāmojjehi saṃyojanānaṃ bhiyyosomattāya
analyzed: eka divasam utusappāya ādīni laddhā vipassanā ñāṇa pīti pāmojjehi saṃyojanānam bhiyyosoma ttāya
translated: Having received the requisite conditions one day, he made the fetters still weaker by means of insight knowledge, happiness, and gladness.🔽The arising of the path knowledge of arahatship is like the bursting of the monsoon clouds.

original: dubbalabhāvo, pāvussakamegho viya arahattamaggañāṇaṃ, meghavuṭṭhiudakena nāvāya bandhe
analyzed: dubbala bhāvaḥ pāvussaka meghaḥ viya arahatta magga ñāṇam megha vuṭṭhi udakena nāvāya bandhe
translated: The state of the fetters after the arising of the path knowledge of arahatship is like the state of the ship after the rain water has been pumped out.

original: pūtibhāvo viya āraddhavipassakassa rūpasattakādivasena vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhentassa okkhāyamāne🔽pakkhāyamāne kammaṭṭhāne ekadivasaṃ utusappāyādīni laddhā ekapallaṅkena nisinnassa🔽arahattaphalādhigamo, pūtibandhanāvāya kañci kālaṃ ṭhānaṃ viya khīṇasaṃyojanassa
analyzed: pūti bhāvaḥ āraddha vipassakassa rūpa sattaka ādi vasena vipassanam vaḍḍhentassa okkhāyamāne  pakkhāyamāne kammaṭṭhāne eka divasam utusappāya ādīni laddhā eka pallaṅkena nisinnassa  arahatta phala adhigamaḥ pūtibandha nāvāya kañci kālam ṭhānam viya khīṇa saṃyojanassa
translated: When the meditator develops insight by way of the material septad, etc., his meditation subject becomes clearer and clearer.🔽Having received the requisite conditions one day, he attains arahatship while sitting in the same posture.🔽The state of the arahat whose fetters are exhausted is like the state of the ship after the rotten planks have been removed.

original: arahato mahājanaṃ anuggaṇhantassa yāvatāyukaṃ ṭhānaṃ, pūtibandhanāvāya anupubbena🔽bhijjitvā apaṇṇattikabhāvūpagamo viya khīṇāsavassa upādiṇṇakkhandhabhedena anupādisesāya
analyzed: arahataḥ mahājanam anuggaṇhantassa yāvatāyukam ṭhānam pūtibandha nāvāya anupubbena  bhijjitvā apaṇṇattika bhāva upagamaḥ viya khīṇāsavassa upādiṇṇa kkhandha bhedena an upādisesāya
translated: The arahat’s state of remaining in the world for a certain period of time, helping the multitude of people, is like the state of the ship after the rotten planks have been removed.🔽The arahat’s state of attaining the state of non-returning by way of the attainment of the element of Nibbana without residue left is like the state of the ship after it has gradually broken up and disappeared.

original: nibbānadhātuyā parinibbutassa apaṇṇattikabhāvūpagamoti imāya upamāya saṃyojanānaṃ
analyzed: nibbāna dhātuyā parinibbutassa apaṇṇattika bhāva upagamaḥ ti imāya upamāya saṃyojanānam
translated: By this simile the Blessed One shows the state of the fetters.

original: dubbalatā dīpitā. Navamaṃ.
analyzed: dubbala tā dīpitā navamam
translated: and the weakness of the defilements is shown. The ninth chapter is finished.

original: 10. Aniccasaññāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: anicca saññā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the tenth chapter

original: 102. Dasame aniccasaññāti aniccaṃ aniccanti bhāventassa uppannasaññā. Pariyādiyatīti
analyzed: dasame anicca saññā ati aniccam aniccanti bhāventassa uppanna saññā pariyādiyati iti
translated: In the tenth chapter: the perception of impermanence is the perception arisen in one who is developing the meditation subject in this way: “Impermanent, impermanent.”🔽It overthrows: it throws away.🔽All conceit “I am”: the ninefold conceit “I am,”

original: khepayati. Sabbaṃ asmimānanti navavidhaṃ asmimānaṃ. Mūlasantānakānīti santānetvā
analyzed: khepayati sabbam asmimānam ti navavidham asmimānam mūla santānakāni iti santānetvā
translated: which is firmly rooted and well embedded:🔽the defilements are like the roots and the well embedded roots,

original: ṭhitamūlāni. Mahānaṅgalaṃ viya hi aniccasaññā, khuddānukhuddakāni mūlasantānakāni🔽viya kilesā, yathā kassako kasanto naṅgalena tāni padāleti, evaṃ yogī aniccasaññaṃ
analyzed: ṭhita mūlāni mahānaṅgalam viya hi anicca saññā khuddānukhuddakāni mūla santānakāni  viya kilesāḥ yathā kassakaḥ kasantaḥ naṅgalena tāni padāleti evam yogī anicca saññam
translated: and the perception of impermanence is like a great plough,

original: bhāvento aniccasaññāñāṇena kilese padāletīti idamettha opammasaṃsandanaṃ.
analyzed: bhāventaḥ anicca saññā ñāṇena kilese padāleti iti idam ettha opamma saṃsandanam
translated: and the meditator is like a ploughman. Just as the ploughman ploughs up the roots with the plough, so too the meditator ploughs up the defilements with the perception of impermanence. This is the way the simile should be understood here.

original: Odhunātīti heṭṭhā dhunāti. Niddhunātīti papphoṭeti. Nicchoṭetīti papphoṭetvā chaḍḍeti.
analyzed: odhunāti iti heṭṭhā dhunāti niddhunāti iti papphoṭeti nicchoṭeti iti papphoṭetvā chaḍḍeti
translated: It shakes: it shakes them below. It thoroughly shakes: it shakes them and then turns them over. It thoroughly turns over: it turns them over and then throws them out.

original: Idhāpi pabbajāni viya kilesā, lāyanaṃ nicchoṭanaṃ viya aniccasaññāñāṇanti iminā atthena
analyzed: idha api pabbajāni viya kilesāḥ lāyanam nicchoṭanam viya anicca saññā ñāṇam ti iminā atthena
translated: Here too the defilements are like the weeds, and the perception of impermanence is like the shaking and the turning over.

original: upamā saṃsandetabbā.
analyzed: upamā saṃsandetabbā
translated: This is the way the simile should be understood here.

original: Vaṇṭacchinnāyāti tiṇhena khurappena vaṇṭacchinnāya. Tadanvayāni bhavantīti taṃ ambapiṇḍiṃ
analyzed: vaṇṭacchinnāya ati tiṇhena khurappena vaṇṭacchinnāya tad anvayāni bhavanti iti tam amba piṇḍim
translated: Cut off at the stalk: cut off with a sharp sickle. They are of the same continuity: that piece of mango.

original: anugacchanti, tassā patamānāya ambāni bhūmiyaṃ patanti. Idhāpi ambapiṇḍi viya kilesā,
analyzed: anugacchanti tassā patamānāya ambāni bhūmiyam patanti idha api kilesāḥ
translated: “Cut off at the root”: cut off with a sharp knife. “They follow on”: they follow on that bunch of mangoes. “As it falls”: as it falls, the mangoes fall to the ground. Here too the defilements are like the bunch of mangoes,

original: tiṇhakhurappo viya aniccasaññā, yathā khurappena chinnāya ambapiṇḍiyā sabbāni ambāni
analyzed: tiṇha khurappaḥ viya anicca saññā yathā khurappena chinnāya amba piṇḍiyā sabbāni ambāni
translated: the perception of impermanence is like the sharp knife, just as when the bunch of mangoes is cut off with the knife all the mangoes

original: bhūmiyaṃ patanti, evaṃ aniccasaññāñāṇena kilesānaṃ mūlabhūtāya avijjāya chinnāya
analyzed: bhūmiyam patanti evam anicca saññā ñāṇena kilesānam mūla bhūtāya avijjāya chinnāya
translated: fall to the ground, so too when the ignorance that is the root of the defilements is cut off by the knowledge consisting in the perception of impermanence,

original: sabbakilesā samugghātaṃ gacchantīti, idaṃ opammasaṃsandanaṃ.
analyzed: sabba kilesā samugghātam gacchanti iti idam opamma saṃsandanam
translated: all the defilements are uprooted. This is the application of the simile.

original: Kūṭaṅgamāti kūṭaṃ gacchanti. Kūṭaninnāti kūṭaṃ pavisanabhāvena kūṭe ninnā. Kūṭasamosaraṇāti
analyzed: kūṭaṅgamā ati kūṭam gacchanti kūṭa ninnā ati kūṭam pavisana bhāvena kūṭe ninnā kūṭa samosaraṇā ati
translated: “They go to the peak”: they go to the peak. “They enter the peak”: they enter the peak in the sense of going into the peak. “They reach the peak”:

original: kūṭe samosaritvā ṭhitā. Idhāpi kūṭaṃ viya aniccasaññā, gopānasiyo viya catubhūmakakusaladhammā,
analyzed: kūṭe samosaritvā ṭhitāḥ idha api kūṭam viya anicca saññā gopānasiyaḥ viya catu bhūmaka kusala dhammā
translated: they reach the peak and stay there. Here too the perception of impermanence is like the peak, and the profitable states consisting of the four paths are like the rafters,

original: yathā sabbagopānasīnaṃ kūṭaṃ aggaṃ, evaṃ kusaladhammānaṃ aniccasaññā aggā. Nanu ca
analyzed: yathā sabba gopānasīnam kūṭam aggam evam kusala dhammānam anicca saññāḥ aggāḥ nanu ca
translated: just as the peak is the highest of all the rafters, so too the perception of impermanence is the highest of the profitable states. But is not

original: aniccasaññā lokiyā, sā lokiyakusalānaṃ tāva aggaṃ hotu, lokuttarānaṃ kathaṃ agganti?
analyzed: anicca saññā lokiyā sā lokiya kusalānam tāva aggam hotu lokuttarānam katham aggam ti
translated: The perception of impermanence is mundane. It is the foremost of the mundane profitable, but how is it the foremost of the supramundane?

original: Tesampi paṭilābhakaraṇatthena agganti veditabbā. Iminā upāyena sabbāsu upamāsu opammasaṃsandanaṃ
analyzed: tesam pi paṭilābha karaṇa atthena agganti veditabbā iminā upāyena sabbāsu upamāsu opamma saṃsandanam
translated: It should be understood that it is the foremost in the sense of being the cause of their acquisition. This is how the application of the similes should be understood in all the similes.

original: veditabbaṃ. Purimāhi panettha tīhi aniccasaññāya kiccaṃ, pacchimāhi balanti. Dasamaṃ.
analyzed: veditabbam purimāhi pana ittha tīhi anicca saññāya kiccam pacchimāhi balanti dasamam
translated: But the function of the perception of impermanence is by means of the first three, and the function of the other three is by means of the last three.

original: Pupphavaggo dasamo.
analyzed: puppha vaggaḥ dasamaḥ
translated: The tenth chapter is called the Chapter on Flowers.

original: Majjhimapaṇṇāsako samatto.🔽11. Antavaggo
analyzed: majjhima paṇṇāsakaḥ samatto  anta vaggaḥ
translated: The middle fifties are completed.🔽The Chapter on the End

original: 1. Antasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: anta sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Sutta on the End

original: 103. Antavaggassa paṭhame antāti koṭṭhāsā. Idaṃ suttaṃ catusaccavasena pañcakkhandhe yojetvā antoti vacanena bujjhanakānaṃ ajjhāsayavasena vuttaṃ. Paṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: anta vaggassa paṭhame antā ti koṭṭhāsāḥ idam suttam catu sacca vasena pañca kkhandhe yojetvā antaḥ ti vacanena bujjhanakānam ajjhāsaya vasena vuttam paṭhamam
translated: In the first of the chapters called “The End” , “end” is a part. This sutta is given in terms of the four truths and the five aggregates, and it is said with the intention of those who are awakened in terms of the word “end.”

original: 2-3. Dukkhasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: dukkha sutta ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: The Explanation of the Suttas

original: 104-105. Dutiyampi pañcakkhandhe catusaccavasena yojetvā dukkhanti bujjhanakānaṃ
analyzed: dutiyam pi pañca kkhandhe catu sacca vasena yojetvā dukkhanti
translated: The second is given in terms of the four truths and the five aggregates, and it is said with the intention of those who are awakened in terms of the word “suffering.”

original: ajjhāsayena kathitaṃ. Tatiyampi tatheva sakkāyoti bujjhanakānaṃ ajjhāsayena kathitaṃ. Dutiyatatiyāni.🔽4. Pariññeyyasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ajjhāsayena kathitam tatiyam pi tathā iva ajjhāsayena kathitam dutiya tatiyāni  pariññeyya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: and he said it with the intention of awakening them. And a third time he said the same thing, with the intention of awakening them. The second and third.🔽The explanation of the “Discourse on What Should Be Fully Understood” is finished.

original: 106. Catutthe pariññeyyeti parijānitabbe samatikkamitabbe. Pariññanti samatikkamaṃ.
analyzed: catutthe pariññeyyā iti parijānitabbe samatikkamitabbe pariññanti samatikkamam
translated: In the fourth, “what should be fully understood” : what should be fully known, what should be surmounted. “Fully understood” : surmounting.

original: Pariññātāvinti tāya pariññāya parijānitvā samatikkamitvā ṭhitaṃ. Rāgakkhayotiādīhi
analyzed: pariññātāvin ti tāya pariññāya parijānitvā samatikkamitvā ṭhitam rāga kkhaya uti ādīhi
translated: “One who has fully understood” : one who, by means of that full understanding, has fully known and surmounted and abides . By the words “the destruction of lust” and so on

original: nibbānaṃ dassitaṃ. Catutthaṃ.
analyzed: nibbānam dassitam catuttham
translated: Nibbana is shown. The fourth.

original: 5-10. Samaṇasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the “Monks” and so on is finished.🔽In the fifth and the rest, the four truths are stated. In the “Nine-month Discourse” and the “Discourse on the Destruction of Defilements,”

original: 107-112. Pañcamādīsu catūsu cattāri saccāni kathitāni. Navamadasamesu kilesappahānanti. Pañcamādīni.
analyzed: pañcama ādīsu catūsu cattāri saccāni kathitāni navama dasamesu kilesa pahānan ti pañcama ādīni
translated: the fifth and the rest.

original: Antavaggo ekādasamo.
analyzed: anta vaggaḥ ekādasamaḥ
translated: The eleventh sub-chapter on the end is finished.

original: 12. Dhammakathikavaggo
analyzed: dhammakathika vaggo
translated: The chapter on the preacher of the Dhamma

original: 1-2. Avijjāsuttādivaṇṇanā🔽113-114. Dhammakathikavaggassa paṭhame ettāvatā ca avijjāgato hotīti yāvatā imāya
analyzed: dhammakathika vaggassa paṭhame ettāvatā ca avijjā gataḥ hoti iti yāvatā imāya
translated: The explanation of the “Ignorance” and so on is finished.

original: catūsu saccesu aññāṇabhūtāya avijjāya samannāgato, ettāvatā avijjāgato hotīti attho.
analyzed: catūsu saccesu aññāṇa bhūtāya avijjāya samannāgataḥ ettāvatā avijjā āgataḥ hoti iti attho
translated: In the first of the chapter on the preacher of the Dhamma, “and so far he is ignorant” : as far as he is endowed with ignorance, which is the state of not knowing the four truths, so far he is ignorant. This is the meaning.

original: Dutiyepi eseva nayo. Paṭhamadutiyāni.
analyzed: dutiye pi esa iva paṭhama dutiyāni
translated: The same method applies to the second question. The first and second questions.

original: 3. Dhammakathikasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dhammakathika sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the Discourse on the Preacher of Dhamma.

original: 115. Tatiye paṭhamena dhammakathiko, dutiyena sekhabhūmi, tatiyena asekhabhūmīti evaṃ dhammakathikaṃ pucchitena visesetvā dve bhūmiyo kathitā. Tatiyaṃ.
analyzed: tatiye paṭhamena dhamma kathikaḥ dutiyena sekha bhūmi tatiyena asekha bhūmi iti evam dhamma kathikam pucchitena visesetvā dve bhūmiyaḥ kathitā tatiyam
translated: In the third question, the first questioner is a preacher of Dhamma, the second a person in the state of training, and the third a person in the state of no-more-training. Thus, having distinguished the preacher of Dhamma, two states are mentioned. The third question.

original: 4. Dutiyadhammakathikasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya dhammakathika sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the Second Discourse on the Preacher of Dhamma.

original: 116. Catutthe tissannampi pucchānaṃ tīṇi vissajjanāni kathitāni. Catutthaṃ.
analyzed: catutthe tissannam pi pucchānam tīṇi vissajjanāni kathitāni catuttham
translated: In the fourth question, the answers to the three questions are given. The fourth question.

original: 5-9. Bandhanasuttādivaṇṇanā🔽117-121. Pañcame atīradassīti tīraṃ vuccati vaṭṭaṃ, taṃ na passati. Apāradassīti🔽pāraṃ vuccati nibbānaṃ, taṃ na passati. Baddhoti kilesabandhanena baddho hutvā jīyati
analyzed: bandhana sutta ādi vaṇṇanā  pañcame a tīra dassī iti tīram vuccati vaṭṭam tam na passati a pāra dassī iti  pāram vuccati nibbānam tam na passati baddhaḥ ti kilesa bandhanena baddhaḥ hutvā jīyati
translated: The exposition of the Discourse on the Bond, etc.

original: ca mīyati ca asmā lokā paraṃ lokaṃ gacchatīti. Imasmiṃ sutte vaṭṭadukkhaṃ kathitanti.
analyzed: ca mīyati ca asmā lokā param lokam gacchati iti imasmin sutte vaṭṭadukkham kathitanti
translated: In the fifth question, one who does not see the near shore does not see the round of rebirths, which is called the near shore. One who does not see the far shore does not see Nibbāna, which is called the far shore. One who is bound lives and dies bound by the bonds of defilements and goes from this world to the other world. In this discourse the suffering of the round of rebirths is mentioned.

original: Chaṭṭhādīni uttānatthāneva. Pañcamādīni.
analyzed: chaṭṭha ādīni uttāna tthāna iva pañcama ādīni
translated: The sixth and following questions are self-evident. The fifth question.

original: 10. Sīlavantasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sīlavanta sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the Discourse on the Virtuous.

original: 122. Dasame aniccatotiādīsu hutvā abhāvākārena aniccato, paṭipīḷanākārena dukkhato,🔽ābādhaṭṭhena rogato, antodosaṭṭhena gaṇḍato, tesaṃ tesaṃ gaṇḍānaṃ paccayabhāvena🔽vā khaṇanaṭṭhena vā sallato dukkhaṭṭhena aghato, visabhāgamahābhūtasamuṭṭhānaābādhapaccayaṭṭhena
analyzed: dasame aniccato ti ādīsu hutvā abhāva ākārena aniccato paṭipīḷana ākārena dukkhato  ābādha aṭṭhena rogataḥ antodosa aṭṭhena gaṇḍataḥ tesam tesam gaṇḍānam paccaya bhāvena  vā khaṇana ṭṭhena vā sallataḥ dukkha ṭṭhena aghataḥ visa bhāga mahābhūta samuṭṭhāna ābādha paccaya ṭṭhena
translated: As to the tenth tetrad, in the case of the phrases “impermanent,” etc., the aspect of non-existence as “having ceased” is the “impermanent” aspect, the aspect of oppression is the “painful” aspect,🔽the aspect of disease is the “disease” aspect, the aspect of internal corruption is the “sickness” aspect,🔽the aspect of being a condition for the various kinds of abscesses is the “abscess” aspect, the aspect of being a thorn is the “thorn” aspect, the aspect of being a source of pain is the “harming” aspect,

original: ābādhato, asakaṭṭhena parato, palujjanaṭṭhena palokato, sattasuññataṭṭhena suññato,
analyzed: ābādhataḥ asaka ṭṭhena paratas palujjana ṭṭhena palokataḥ satta suññata ṭṭhena suññataḥ
translated: the aspect of being a condition for the disease of being subject to the various kinds of misfortune is the “disease” aspect, the aspect of being other is the “alien” aspect, the aspect of decaying is the “decaying” aspect, the aspect of voidness of self is the “void” aspect,

original: attābhāvena anattato. Evamettha “aniccato palokato”ti dvīhi padehi aniccamanasikāro,
analyzed: attā bhāvena anattataḥ evam ettha aniccato palokato ti dvīhi padehi anicca manasikāro
translated: the aspect of non-self is the “non-self” aspect. So here the two phrases “impermanent” and “decaying” should be understood to express the bringing of the idea of impermanence to mind,

original: “suññato anattato”ti dvīhi anattamanasikāro, sesehi dukkhamanasikāro vuttoti veditabbo.
analyzed: suññataḥ anattataḥ ti dvīhi anatta manasikāraḥ sesehi dukkha manasikāraḥ vuttaḥ ti veditabbaḥ
translated: the two phrases “void” and “non-self” the bringing of the idea of non-self to mind, and the rest the bringing of the idea of pain to mind.

original: Sesamettha uttānameva. Dasamaṃ.
analyzed: sesam ettha uttānam eva dasamam
translated: The rest here is self-evident. This is the tenth tetrad.

original: 11. Sutavantasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sutavanta sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the verse, “The one who has learned much” , is finished.

original: 123. Tathā ekādasame. Dasamasmiñhi “sīlavatā”ti catupārisuddhisīlaṃ vuttaṃ, idha sutavatāti kammaṭṭhānasutaṃ idameva nānākaraṇaṃ. Ekādasamaṃ.
analyzed: tathā ekādasame dasamasmin hi sīlavatā ati catu pārisuddhi sīlam vuttam idha sutavatā ati kammaṭṭhāna sutam idam eva nānākaraṇam ekādasamam
translated: So too with the eleventh. In the tenth the virtue of the fourfold purity is called “virtue” , but here the virtue of learning the meditation subject is called “virtue” . This is the only difference. The eleventh.

original: 12-13. Kappasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the “Eon” chapter.🔽The twelfth to the twentieth are similar to the “Advice to Rāhula” .

original: 124-125. Dvādasamaterasamāni rāhulovādasadisānevāti. Dvādasamaterasamāni.
analyzed: dvādasa mateḥ asamāni dvādasa mateḥ asamāni
translated: The twelfth to the twentieth.

original: Dhammakathikavaggo dvādasamo.
analyzed: dhammakathika vaggaḥ dvādasamaḥ
translated: The twelfth sub-chapter on preachers of Dhamma is finished.

original: 13. Avijjāvaggo
analyzed: avijjā vaggaḥ
translated: The Ignorance Chapter

original: 1-10. Samudayadhammasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the “Arising of Ill” chapter.

original: 126-135. Avijjāvaggo uttānatthova. Imasmiñhi vagge sabbasuttesu catusaccameva kathitaṃ.
analyzed: avijjā vaggaḥ uttāna atthaḥ uva imasmin hi vagge sabba suttesu catu saccam eva kathitam
translated: The Ignorance chapter is self-explanatory. For in all the texts in this chapter the four truths are taught.

original: Avijjāvaggo terasamo.
analyzed: avijjā vaggo terasamaḥ
translated: The thirteenth sub-chapter on ignorance is finished.

original: 14. Kukkuḷavaggo🔽1-13. Kukkuḷasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: kukkuḷa vaggaḥ
translated: The Embers Chapter🔽The commentary on the “Embers” chapter.

original: 136-149. Kukkuḷavaggassa paṭhame kukkuḷanti santattaṃ ādittaṃ chārikarāsiṃ viya mahāpariḷāhaṃ.
analyzed: kukkuḷa vaggassa paṭhame santattam ādittam chārika rāsim viya mahā pariḷāham
translated: In the first text in the Embers chapter, “embers” is a great conflagration like a mass of burning coals.

original: Imasmiṃ sutte dukkhalakkhaṇaṃ kathitaṃ, sesesu aniccalakkhaṇādīni. Sabbāni cetāni
analyzed: imasmin sutte dukkha lakkhaṇam kathitam sesesu anicca lakkhaṇa ādīni sabbāni cetāni
translated: In this text the characteristic of pain is taught, and in the others the characteristics of impermanence, etc.,

original: pāṭiyekkaṃ puggalajjhāsayena kathitānīti.
analyzed: pāṭiyekkam puggala jhāsayena kathitāni iti
translated: but all these texts are taught separately according to the inclinations of individuals.

original: Kukkuḷavaggo cuddasamo.
analyzed: kukkuḷa vaggaḥ cud dasamaḥ
translated: The fourteenth sub-chapter on embers is finished.

original: 15. Diṭṭhivaggo
analyzed: diṭṭhi vaggo
translated: 15. The Chapter about Views

original: 1-9. Ajjhattasuttādivaṇṇanā🔽150-158. Diṭṭhivaggassa paṭhame kiṃ upādāyāti kiṃ paṭicca. Dutiye kiṃ abhinivissāti
analyzed: diṭṭhi vaggassa paṭhame kim upādāya ati kim paṭicca dutiye kim abhinivissa ati
translated: The Exposition of the Sutta on the Internal, etc.

original: kiṃ abhinivisitvā, paccayaṃ katvāti attho. Tatiyādīsu diṭṭhītiādīni puggalajjhāsayena
analyzed: kim abhinivisitvā paccayam katvā ti attho tatiya ādīsu diṭṭhi iti ādīni puggala jjhāsayena
translated: In the first of the sutta in this chapter, “What is it that they cling to? ” means “What is it that they cling to as”? In the second, “What do they misapprehend? ” means “What do they misapprehend as”? In the third, etc., the terms “view” and so on are stated🔽with reference to the inclinations of the individuals concerned.

original: vuttāni. Paṭhamādīni.
analyzed: vuttāni paṭhama ādīni
translated: The first, etc.,

original: 10. Ānandasuttavaṇṇanā🔽159. Dasame upasaṅkamīti aññe bhikkhū pañcakkhandhakammaṭṭhānaṃ kathāpetvā yuñjitvā🔽ghaṭetvā arahattaṃ patvā satthu santike aññaṃ byākaronte disvā “ahampi pañcakkhandhakammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: ānanda sutta vaṇṇanā  dasame upasaṅkamīti aññe bhikkhū pañcakkhandha kammaṭṭhānam kathāpetvā yuñjitvā  ghaṭetvā arahattam patvā satthu santike aññam byākaronte disvā aham pi pañcakkhandha kammaṭṭhānam
translated: The Exposition of the Sutta on Ānanda

original: kathāpetvā yuñjanto ghaṭento, arahattaṃ patvā aññaṃ byākarissāmī”ti cintetvā upasaṅkami.🔽Satthā pana attano dharamānakāle therassa uparimaggattayavajjhānaṃ kilesānaṃ pahānaṃ
analyzed: kathāpetvā yuñjantaḥ ghaṭentaḥ arahattam patvā aññam byākarissāmi iti cintetvā upasaṅkami  satthā pana attanaḥ dharamāna kāle therassa upari magga ttaya vajjhānam kilesānam pahānam
translated: In the tenth sutta, “he approached” means that he approached the Teacher after seeing other bhikkhus who had attained arahatship by having the meditation subject of the five aggregates explained to them, by endeavoring and striving, and by making the breakthrough, and after thinking, “I too will have the meditation subject of the five aggregates explained to me, and by endeavoring and striving, I will attain arahatship and make the breakthrough. ”

original: apassantopi “imassa cittaṃ gaṇhissāmī”ti kathesi. Tassāpi ekaṃ dve vāre manasi katvāva
analyzed: a passantaḥ api imassa cittam gaṇhissāmi iti kathesi tassa api ekam dve vāre manasi katvā ava
translated: But the Teacher, even though he did not see the destruction of the defilements that would make the elder attain the three higher paths, spoke thus, thinking, “I will take hold of his mind.” The elder too, after giving his mind attention only once or twice,

original: buddhupaṭṭhānavelā jātāti gantabbaṃ hoti. Itissa cittaṃ sampahaṃsamāno vimuttiparipācanīyadhammova
analyzed: buddha upaṭṭhāna velā jātā ati gantabbam hoti iti ssa cittam sampahaṃsamānaḥ vimutti paripācanīya dhammaḥ uva
translated: and the time for attending on the Enlightened One has come.

original: so kammaṭṭhānānuyogo jātoti. Dasamaṃ.
analyzed: so kammaṭṭhāna anuyogaḥ jāto ti dasamam
translated: Thus, as he is encouraging his mind, the practice of the meditation subject has arisen as a factor that ripens in deliverance.🔽(10)

original: Diṭṭhivaggo pannarasamo.🔽Uparipaṇṇāsako samatto.🔽Khandhasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: diṭṭhi vaggaḥ pannarasamaḥ  upari paṇṇāsakaḥ samatto  khandha saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The fifteenth chapter called ‘The Chapter on Views’ is ended.🔽The second part is finished.🔽The exposition of the Khandha Samyutta is completed.

original: 2. Rādhasaṃyuttaṃ
analyzed: rādha saṃyuttam
translated: The Connected Discourses with Rādha

original: 1. Paṭhamavaggo🔽1. Mārasuttavaṇṇanā🔽160. Rādhasaṃyuttassa paṭhame māro vā assāti maraṇaṃ vā bhaveyya. Māretā vāti māretabbo
analyzed: paṭhama vaggo         rādha saṃyuttassa paṭhame māraḥ vai assa ati maraṇam vā bhaveyya māretā vā ati māretabbo
translated: The First Chapter🔽The Discourse on Māra

original: vā. Yo vā pana mīyatīti yo vā pana marati. Nibbidatthanti nibbidāñāṇatthaṃ. Nibbānatthāti
analyzed: vā yaḥ vā pana mīyati iti yaḥ vā pana marati nibbida attham nibbida āñāṇa ttham nibbāna tthā ati
translated: In the first discourse in the Rādha Saṃyutta, ‘Māra or death’ means death. ‘To be killed’ means to be killed by death. ‘Or anyone who dies’ means anyone who dies. ‘For the sake of disenchantment’ means for the sake of the knowledge of disenchantment. ‘For the sake of Nibbāna’ means

original: phalavimutti nāmesā anupādānibbānatthāti attho. Accayāsīti atikkantosi. Nibbānogadhanti
analyzed: phala vimutti nāma esā an upādā nibbāna tthā ati atthaḥ accayāsi iti atikkantaḥ asi nibbāna ogadhanti
translated: the meaning is for the sake of the Nibbāna that is without attachment. ‘You have gone beyond’ means you have gone beyond. ‘The Nibbāna element’ means

original: nibbāne patiṭṭhitaṃ. Idaṃ maggabrahmacariyaṃ nāma nibbānabbhantare vussati, na nibbānaṃ
analyzed: nibbāne patiṭṭhitam idam maggabrahmacariyam nāma nibbāna abbhantare vussati na nibbānam
translated: established in Nibbāna. This holy life has Nibbāna as its culmination; it does not have Nibbāna as its essence.

original: atikkamitvāti attho. Nibbānapariyosānanti nibbānaṃ assa pariyosānaṃ, nipphatti niṭṭhāti attho. Paṭhamaṃ.
analyzed: atikkamitvā ti attho nibbāna pariyosānanti nibbānam assa pariyosānam nipphatti niṭṭhā ti attho paṭhamam
translated: Nibbana-termination: nibbana is its termination, its outcome, its end, is what is meant. The first.

original: 2-10. Sattasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: . Commentary on the Seven Suttas Beginning with the “Being”

original: 161-169. Dutiye satto sattoti laggapucchā. Tatra satto tatra visattoti tatra laggo🔽tatra vilaggo. Paṃsvāgārakehīti paṃsugharakehi. Keḷāyantīti kīḷanti. Dhanāyantīti🔽dhanaṃ viya maññanti. Mamāyantīti “mama idaṃ, mama ida”nti mamattaṃ karonti, aññassa
analyzed: dutiye satto satto ti lagga pucchā tatra satto tatra visatto ti tatra laggo  tatra vilaggo paṃsu āgārakehi iti paṃsu gharakehi keḷāyanti iti kīḍanti dhanāyanti iti  dhanam viya maññanti mamāyanti iti mama idam mama idam ti mamattam karonti aññassa
translated: . In the second sutta, “being” is a question about attachment. Therein, “being” is attachment,

original: phusitumpi na denti. Vikīḷaniyaṃ karontīti “niṭṭhitā kīḷā”ti te bhindamānā kīḷāvigamaṃ
analyzed: phusitum pi na denti vikīḷaniyam karonti iti niṭṭhitā kīḷā ati te bhindamānā kīḷā vigamam
translated: “unbeing” is non-attachment. “With dust-heap-dwellers” : with those who live in dust heaps. “They play” : they play about. “They reckon” : they reckon as wealth. “They reckon as ‘mine'” : they make “mine” by saying “This is mine, that is mine.” They do not give a chance to another. “They make it a plaything” : they make a plaything of it, and when the play is finished they break it up and make an end of the play.

original: karonti. Tatiye bhavanettīti bhavarajju. Catutthaṃ uttānameva. Pañcamādīsu catūsu
analyzed: karonti tatiye bhava nettī iti bhava rajju catuttham uttānam eva pañcama ādīsu catūsu
translated: In the third sutta, “the eye-string of becoming” is the rope of becoming. The fourth sutta is self-evident. In the four suttas beginning with the fifth,

original: cattāri saccāni kathitāni, dvīsu kilesappahānanti. Dutiyādīni.🔽Paṭhamo vaggo.🔽2. Dutiyavaggo🔽1-12. Mārasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: cattāri saccāni kathitāni dvīsu kilesa ppahānan ti dutiya ādīni 🔽paṭhamaḥ vaggo 🔽dutiya vaggo 🔽
translated: the four truths are stated, and in the two suttas the abandoning of defilements. The second, etc., suttas.

original: 170-181. Dutiyavaggassa paṭhame māro, māroti maraṇaṃ pucchati. Yasmā pana rūpādivinimuttaṃ🔽maraṇaṃ nāma natthi, tenassa bhagavā rūpaṃ kho, rādha, mārotiādimāha. Dutiye māradhammoti
analyzed: dutiya vaggassa paṭhame māraḥ māro ti maraṇam pucchati yasmā pana rūpa ādi vinimuttam  maraṇam nāma na atthi tena assa bhagavā rūpam kho rādha māraḥ iti ādim āha dutiye māra dhammaḥ ti
translated: In the first of the second group, Mara asks about death, “Mara” being a name for death. But since there is no death apart from form, etc.,

original: maraṇadhammo. Etenupāyena sabbattha attho veditabboti.
analyzed: maraṇa dhammaḥ etena upāyena sabbattha atthaḥ veditabbaḥ iti
translated: the Blessed One says, “Rādha, ‘Mara’ is a term for form” , etc. In the second sutta, “the state of being Mara’s” is the state of being subject to death. The meaning should be understood in each instance according to the context.

original: Dutiyo vaggo.
analyzed: dutiyaḥ vaggo
translated: The second vagga is finished.

original: 3-4. Āyācanavaggādi
analyzed: āyācana vagga ādi
translated: The chapter of requests, etc.

original: 1-11. Mārādisuttaekādasakavaṇṇanā
translated: The eleven suttas of the Māra Samyutta

original: 182-205. Tato paraṃ uttānatthameva. Ayañhi rādhatthero paṭibhāniyatthero nāma. Tathāgatassa🔽imaṃ theraṃ disvā sukhumaṃ kāraṇaṃ upaṭṭhāti. Tenassa bhagavā nānānayehi dhammaṃ
analyzed: tato param uttāna attham eva ayam hi rādha tthero paṭibhāniya theraḥ nāma tathāgatassa  imam theram disvā sukhumam kāraṇam upaṭṭhāti tena assa bhagavā nānā nayehi dhammaṃ
translated: are straightforward in meaning. For this Elder Rādha was known as the Elder of Ready Speech. The Tathāgata

original: deseti. Evaṃ imasmiṃ rādhasaṃyutte ādito dve vaggā pucchāvasena desitā, tatiyo āyācanena,
analyzed: deseti evam imasmin rādha saṃyutte āditas dve vaggā pucchā vasena desitā tatiyaḥ āyācanena
translated: saw that this elder was a subtle reasoner, so he taught him the Dhamma with various reasons. Thus in this Rādha Samyutta the first two vaggas are taught in the form of questions, the third in the form of a request,

original: catuttho upanisinnakakathāvasena. Sakalampi panetaṃ rādhasaṃyuttaṃ therassa vimuttiparipācanīyadhammavaseneva🔽gahitanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: catutthaḥ upanisinnaka kathā vasena sakalam pi pana etam rādha saṃyuttam therassa vimutti paripācanīya dhamma vasena iva 🔽gahitan ti veditabbam
translated: and the fourth in the form of a conversation. But the whole Rādha Samyutta should be understood as taught in order to ripen the elder’s liberation.

original: Rādhasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: rādha saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the Connected Discourses with Rādha is ended.

original: 3. Diṭṭhisaṃyuttaṃ🔽1. Sotāpattivaggo
analyzed: diṭṭhi saṃyuttam  sotāpatti vaggaḥ
translated: The Connected Discourses with Views🔽The Stream-Enterer Group

original: 1. Vātasuttavaṇṇanā🔽206. Diṭṭhisaṃyutte na vātā vāyantītiādīsu evaṃ kira tesaṃ diṭṭhi – “yepi ete rukkhasākhādīni🔽bhañjantā vātā vāyanti, na ete vātā, vātaleso nāmeso, vāto pana esikatthambho viya
analyzed: vāta sutta vaṇṇanā  diṭṭhi saṃyutte na vātāḥ vāyanti itiādīsu evam kira tesam diṭṭhi ye pi ete rukkha sākhā ādīni  bhañjantā vātāḥ vāyanti na ete vātāḥ vātalesaḥ nāma isaḥ vāto pana esikatthambhaḥ viya
translated: The Wind Discourse

original: pabbatakūṭaṃ viya ca ṭhito. Tathā yāpi etā tiṇakaṭṭhādīni vahantiyo nadiyo sandanti,
analyzed: pabbata kūṭam viya ca tathā yā api etā tiṇa kaṭṭha ādīni vahantiyaḥ nadiyaḥ sandanti
translated: In the Connected Discourses with Views, the passage beginning, “The winds do not blow” is to be interpreted as follows. The view of these people is that “the winds that blow breaking up tree branches and so on are not winds; they are wind-dust, as it were. But the wind itself is like a pillar or like the face of a rock.

original: na ettha udakaṃ sandaki, udakaleso nāmesa, udakaṃ pana esikatthambho viya pabbatakūṭaṃ
analyzed: na ettha udakam sandaki udakalesaḥ nāma isa udakam pana esikatthambhaḥ viya pabbata kūṭam
translated: Similarly, the rivers that flow along carrying grass, sticks, and so on, are not flowing; the water is not flowing. The water is like a pillar or like the face of a rock.

original: viya ca ṭhitaṃ. Yāpimā gabbhiniyo vijāyantīti ca vuccanti, kiñcāpi tā milātudarā🔽honti, gabbho pana na nikkhamati, gabbhaleso nāmeso, gabbho pana esikatthambho viya
analyzed: ca ṭhitam gabbhiniyaḥ vijāyanti iti ca vuccanti kiñca api tāḥ milātudarā  honti gabbhaḥ pana na nikkhamati gabbhalesaḥ nāma iso gabbho pana esikatthambhaḥ viya
translated: And the women who are said to be giving birth are not giving birth; their bellies are swollen,🔽but the embryo does not come out. The embryo is like a pillar or like the face of a rock.

original: pabbatakūṭaṃ viya ca ṭhito. Yepi ete candimasūriyā udenti vā apenti vā, neva te udenti
analyzed: pabbata kūṭam viya ca ṭhitaḥ ye pi ete candima sūriyāḥ udenti vā apenti vā na iva te udenti
translated: And the moon and sun that rise and set are not rising and setting;

original: na apenti, candimasūriyaleso nāmesa, candimasūriyā pana esikatthambho viya pabbatakūṭaṃ viya ca ṭhitā”ti.
analyzed: na apenti candima sūriya lesaḥ nāma īsa candima sūriyā pana esika thambhaḥ viya pabbata kūṭam viya ca ṭhitā ati
translated: They do not reach them. The moon and sun are like a measuring rod or the peak of a gable. They stand still.”

original: 2-4. Etaṃmamasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Sutta Beginning “This Is Mine”

original: 207-209. Diṭṭhantiādīsu diṭṭhaṃ rūpāyatanaṃ. Sutaṃ saddāyatanaṃ. Mutaṃ gandhāyatanaṃ🔽rasāyatanaṃ phoṭṭhabbāyatanaṃ. Tañhi patvā gahetabbato mutanti ca vuttaṃ. Avasesāni
analyzed: diṭṭha nti ādīsu diṭṭham rūpa āyatanam sutam sadda āyatanam mutam gandha āyatanam  rasa āyatanam phoṭṭhabba āyatanam tat hi patvā gahetabbato mutan ti ca vuttam avasesāni
translated: Seen: the visible-data base. Heard: the sound base. Sensed: the odour, flavour, and tangible-data bases.🔽For these are called sensed because they are sensed by being contacted.🔽The remaining seven bases are cognized.

original: sattāyatanāni viññātaṃ nāma. Pattanti pariyesitvā vā apariyesitvā vā pattaṃ. Pariyesitanti🔽pattaṃ vā apattaṃ vā pariyesitaṃ. Anuvicaritaṃ manasāti cittena anusañcaritaṃ. Lokasmiñhi
analyzed: satta āyatanāni viññātam nāma pattanti pariyesitvā vā a pariyesitvā vā pattam pariyesitanti  pattam vā a pattam vā pariyesitam anuvicaritam manasā ati cittena anusañcaritam lokasmin hi
translated: The obtained: that which is obtained by searching for it or without searching for it.🔽The searched for: that which is searched for whether it is obtained or not obtained.🔽The investigated with wisdom: that which is investigated with wisdom.

original: pariyesitvā pattampi atthi, pariyesitvā nopattampi, apariyesitvā pattampi, apariyesitvā
analyzed: pariyesitvā pattampi atthi pariyesitvā no pattampi a pariyesitvā pattampi a pariyesitvā
translated: In the world there are four kinds of things: those obtained by searching for them, those not obtained by searching for them, those obtained without searching for them, and those not obtained without searching for them.

original: nopattampi. Tattha pariyesitvā pattaṃ pattaṃ nāma, pariyesitvā nopattaṃ pariyesitaṃ
analyzed: nopattam pi tattha pariyesitvā pattam pattam nāma pariyesitvā nopattam pariyesitam
translated: Herein, that which is obtained by searching for it is called obtained; that which is not obtained by searching for it is searched for.

original: nāma. Apariyesitvā pattañca apariyesitvā nopattañca manasānuvicaritaṃ nāma. Atha🔽vā pariyesitvā pattampi apariyesitvā pattampi pattaṭṭhena pattaṃ nāma, pariyesitvā🔽nopattameva pariyesitaṃ nāma, apariyesitvā nopattaṃ manasānuvicaritaṃ nāma. Sabbaṃ
analyzed: nāma a pariyesitvā pattañca a pariyesitvā no pattañca manasā anuvicaritam nāma atha  vā pariyesitvā pattam pi a pariyesitvā pattam pi patta ṭṭhena pattam nāma pariyesitvā  no pattam eva pariyesitam nāma a pariyesitvā no pattam manasā anuvicaritam nāma sabbam
translated: “Not sought for and not sought for as a bowl” means not sought for as a bowl and not sought for as not a bowl.

original: vā etaṃ manasā anuvicaritameva.
analyzed: vai etam manasā anuvicaritam eva
translated: Or alternatively, “sought for and sought for as a bowl” means what is sought for as a bowl and what is sought for as not a bowl in the sense of a bowl. “Sought for and not sought for as a bowl” means what is sought for as a bowl and what is not sought for as a bowl. “Not sought for and not sought for as a bowl” means what is not sought for as a bowl and what is not sought for as not a bowl. Or all of it is simply what is not sought for.

original: 5. Natthidinnasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: natthidinna sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . Explanation of the Sutta on What is Not Given

original: 210. Natthi dinnantiādīsu natthi dinnanti dinnassa phalābhāvaṃ sandhāya vadanti.
analyzed: natthi dinna nti ādīsu natthi dinna nti dinnassa phala abhāvam sandhāya vadanti
translated: As regards “There is no giving” and so on, they say this with reference to the non-existence of the fruit of giving.

original: Yiṭṭhaṃ vuccati mahāyāgo. Hutanti paheṇakasakkāro adhippeto. Tampi ubhayaṃ phalābhāvameva
analyzed: vuccati mahāyāgaḥ hutanti paheṇaka sakkāro adhippeto tat pi ubhayam phala abhāvam eva
translated: “Offered” is a great sacrifice. “Sacrifice” is a respectful offering. They deny both of these with reference to the non-existence of fruit.

original: sandhāya paṭikkhipanti. Sukatadukkaṭānanti sukatadukkatānaṃ, kusalākusalānanti attho.
analyzed: sandhāya paṭikkhipanti su kata dukkaṭānam ti su kata dukkatānam kusala akusalānam
translated: “Good and bad deeds” : the meaning is, wholesome and unwholesome deeds.

original: Phalaṃ vipākoti yaṃ phalanti vā vipākoti vā vuccati, taṃ natthīti vadanti. Natthi
analyzed: phalam vipāko ti yam phalanti vā vipāko ti vā vuccati tam natthi iti vadanti natthi
translated: “The fruit, the result” : they say that what is called “fruit” or “result” does not exist.

original: ayaṃ lokoti paraloke ṭhitassa ayaṃ loko natthi. Natthi paro lokoti idha loke ṭhitassapi
analyzed: ayam loko ti para loke ṭhitassa ayam loko natthi natthi paraḥ loko ti idha loke ṭhitassa api
translated: “There is no world beyond”: there is no world beyond for one who is in the world beyond.

original: paro loko natthi, sabbe tattha tattheva ucchijjantīti dassenti. Natthi mātā natthi🔽pitāti tesu sammāpaṭipattimicchāpaṭipattīnaṃ phalābhāvavasena vadanti. Natthi sattā
analyzed: paraḥ lokaḥ natthi sabbe tattha tattha iva ucchijjanti iti dassenti natthi mātā natthi  pitā iti tesu sammā paṭipattim icchā paṭipattīnam phala abhāva vasena vadanti na atthi sattā
translated: “There is no other world”: there is no other world for one who is in this world. They show that all beings are annihilated right there.🔽“There is no mother”: “There is no father”: they say this because there is no result of right and wrong conduct.🔽“There are no spontaneously reborn beings”: they say that there are no beings who die here and are reborn there.

original: opapātikāti cavitvā uppajjanakasattā nāma natthīti vadanti. Natthi loke samaṇabrāhmaṇāti
analyzed: opapātikā ati cavitvā uppajjanaka sattā nāma natthi iti vadanti natthi loke samaṇa brāhmaṇā ti
translated: “There are no ascetics and brahmins in the world who are perfectly developed and perfectly awakened”:

original: loke sammāpaṭipannā samaṇabrāhmaṇā nāma natthīti vadanti.🔽Cātumahābhūtikoti catumahābhūtamayo. Pathavī pathavīkāyanti ajjhattikā pathavīdhātu🔽bāhiraṃ pathavīdhātuṃ. Anupetīti anuyāti. Anupagacchatīti tasseva vevacanaṃ, anugacchatītipi
analyzed: loke sammāpaṭipannā samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ nāma na atthi iti vadanti  cātumahābhūtikā iti catu mahābhūta mayā pathavī ajjhattikā pathavī dhātu  bāhiram pathavī dhātum anupeti iti anuyāti anupagacchati iti tassa iva vevacanam anugacchati iti pi
translated: they say that there are no ascetics and brahmins in the world who are perfectly developed and perfectly awakened.🔽“The four great elements are not included in the self”: the four great elements are not included in the self. “The earth element is not the bodily form element”: the internal earth element

original: attho. Ubhayenāpi upeti upagacchatīti dassenti. Āpādīsupi eseva nayo. Indriyānīti
analyzed: atthaḥ ubhayena api upeti upagacchati iti dassenti āpa ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ indriyāni iti
translated: is not the external earth element. “It does not approach”: it does not go. “It does not go forth”: this is a synonym for that. The meaning is: it does not go. With both they show that it approaches and goes forth. The same method applies to the other three great elements. “The faculties”:

original: manacchaṭṭhāni indriyāni. Saṅkamantīti ākāsaṃ pakkhandanti. Āsandipañcamāti nipannamañcena
analyzed: indriyāni saṅkamanti iti ākāsam pakkhandanti āsandi pañcamā ati nipanna mañcena
translated: The six faculties ending with the mind. They go on: they go into the open air. With a couch and a chair as the fifth: with a bedstead as the fifth.

original: pañcamā, mañco ceva, cattāro mañcapāde gahetvā ṭhitā cattāro purisā cāti attho. Yāva🔽āḷāhanāti yāva susānā. Padānīti “ayaṃ evaṃ sīlavā ahosi, evaṃ dussīlo”tiādinā nayena
analyzed: pañcamā mañco ca iva cattāraḥ mañca pāde gahetvā ṭhitā cattāro purisā ca ati yāva  padāni iti ayam evam sīlavā evam dussīlaḥ iti ādinā nayena
translated: The meaning is: with a bedstead and four men standing holding the four legs of the bedstead.🔽As far as the charnel-ground fence: as far as the cemetery. The words:

original: pavattāni guṇāguṇapadāni. Sarīrameva vā ettha padānīti adhippetaṃ. Kāpotakānīti kapotakavaṇṇāni,
analyzed: pavattāni guṇa aguṇa padāni sarīram eva vā ettha padāni iti adhippetam kāpotakāni iti kapotaka vaṇṇāni
translated: The meaning is: “He was virtuous like this, he was unvirtuous like that,” and so on. Or the words here intended may be the bones.🔽Ashen-gray: the colour of a dove, is the meaning.

original: pārāvatapakkhavaṇṇānīti attho. Bhassantāti bhasmantā. Ayameva vā pāḷi. Āhutiyoti🔽yaṃ paheṇakasakkārādibhedaṃ dinnadānaṃ, sabbaṃ taṃ chārikāvasānameva hoti, na tato🔽paraṃ phaladāyakaṃ hutvā gacchatīti attho. Dattupaññattanti dattūhi bālamanussehi
analyzed: pārāvata pakkha vaṇṇāni iti atthaḥ bhassantā ati bhasmantā ayam eva vā pāḷi āhutiyā ti  yam paheṇaka sakkāra ādi bhedam dinna dānam sabbam tam chārikā avasānam eva hoti na tatas  param phala dāyakam hutvā gacchati iti atthaḥ dattu paññattanti dattūhi bāla manussehi
translated: Ashes: this is the reading.🔽The meaning is: all the giving that is made, classed as honouring with a pendent and so on, ends in ashes, it does not go on to give fruit beyond that.

original: paññattaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – bālehi abuddhīhi paññattamidaṃ dānaṃ, na paṇḍitehi.
analyzed: paññattam idam vuttam hoti bālehi abuddhīhi paññattam idam dānam na paṇḍitehi
translated: Made by fools: made by foolish ordinary people.

original: Bālā denti, paṇḍitā gaṇhantīti dassenti.
analyzed: bālāḥ denti paṇḍitāḥ gaṇhanti iti dassenti
translated: They show that fools give and the wise receive.

original: 6. Karotosuttavaṇṇanā🔽211. Karototi sahatthā karontassa. Kārayatoti āṇattiyā kārentassa. Chindatoti paresaṃ
analyzed: karoto sutta vaṇṇanā  karototi sahatthā karontassa kārayatoti āṇattiyā kārentassa chindatoti paresam
translated: The explanation of the verse on the doer🔽“The doer”: one who does by his own hand. “The causer”: one who causes another to do by command. “The cutter”: one who cuts off the hands, etc., of others. “The causer of cutting”: one who causes another to cut off. “The tormentor”: one who torments with a stick, etc.

original: hatthādīni chindantassa. Chedāpayatoti parehi chedāpentassa. Pacatoti daṇḍena pīḷentassa.🔽Pacāpayatoti parehi daṇḍādinā pīḷāpentassa. Socato socāpayatoti parassa bhaṇḍaharaṇādīhi🔽sokaṃ sayaṃ karontassāpi parehi kārentassāpi. Kilamato kilamāpayatoti āhārupacchedabandhanāgārapavesanādīhi🔽sayaṃ kilamentassapi parehi kilamāpentassapi. Phandato phandāpayatoti paraṃ phandantaṃ
analyzed: hattha ādīni chindantassa chedāpayato ti parehi chedāpentassa pacato ti daṇḍena pīḷentassa  pacāpayatoti parehi daṇḍa ādinā pīḷāpentassa socato socāpayatoti parassa bhaṇḍa haraṇa ādīhi  sokam sayam karontassa api parehi kārentassa api kilamato kilamāpayato ti āhāra upaccheda bandhana āgāra pavesana ādīhi  sayam kilamentassa api parehi kilamāpentassa api phandataḥ phandāpayataḥ iti param phandantam
