translated: “The causer of tormenting”: one who causes another to torment with a stick, etc. “The sorroWer”: one who sorrows himself or causes another to sorrow by the taking away of another’s goods, etc. “The vexer”: one who vexes himself or causes another to vex by the cutting off of food, by binding, by throwing into prison, etc.

original: phandanakāle sayampi phandato parempi phandāpayato. Pāṇamatipātayatoti pāṇaṃ hanantassapi🔽hanāpentassapi. Evaṃ sabbattha karaṇakārāpanavaseneva attho veditabbo.
analyzed: phandana kāle sayam pi phandataḥ parempi phandāpayataḥ pāṇam atipātayataḥ iti pāṇam hanantassa api 🔽evam sabbattha karaṇa kārāpana vasena iva atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: “The abuser”: one who abuses himself or causes another to abuse by the cutting off of food, by binding, by throwing into prison, etc. “The reviler”: one who reviles himself or causes another to revile by the cutting off of food, by binding, by throwing into prison, etc. “The scorner”: one who scorns himself or causes another to scorn by the cutting off of food, by binding, by throwing into prison, etc. “The mocker”: one who mocks himself or causes another to mock by the cutting off of food, by binding, by throwing into prison, etc. “The striker”: one who strikes himself or causes another to strike by the cutting off of food, by binding, by throwing into prison, etc. “The thrower”: one who throws himself or causes another to throw by the cutting off of food, by binding, by throwing into prison, etc. “The killer”: one who kills himself or causes another to kill by the cutting off of food, by binding, by throwing into prison, etc. “The causer of killing”: one who kills himself or causes another to kill by the cutting off of food, by binding, by throwing into prison, etc. “The taker”: one who takes himself or causes another to take by the cutting off of food, by binding, by throwing into prison, etc. “The causer of taking”: one who takes himself or causes another to take by the cutting off of food, by binding, by throwing into prison, etc. “The user”: one who uses himself or causes another to use by the cutting off of food, by binding, by throwing into prison, etc

original: Sandhinti gharasandhiṃ. Nillopanti mahāvilopaṃ. Ekāgārikanti ekameva gharaṃ parivāretvā🔽vilumpanaṃ. Paripanthe tiṭṭhatoti āgatāgatānaṃ acchindanatthaṃ magge tiṭṭhato. Karoto🔽na karīyati pāpanti yaṃkiñci pāpaṃ karomīti saññāya karotopi pāpaṃ na karīyati, natthi🔽pāpaṃ. Sattā pana karomāti evaṃsaññino hontīti dīpenti. Khurapariyantenāti khuraneminā,
analyzed: sandhim ti ghara sandhim ekāgārikam iti ekam eva gharam parivāretvā  vilumpanam paripanthe tiṭṭhato ti āgata āgatānam a chindana attham magge tiṭṭhato karoto  na karīyati pāpanti yaṃ kiñci pāpam karomi iti saññāya karotaḥ api pāpam na karīyati natthi  pāpam sattā pana karoma ati evaṃsaññinaḥ honti iti dīpenti khura pariyantena ati khura neminā
translated: “A house-joint” means a house-joint. “A great theft” means a great robbery. “A single house” means a robbery in which a single house is surrounded.🔽“Standing in the road” means standing in the road in order to rob those who come along. “Doing”🔽“no evil is done” means that even though one acts with the perception that one is doing some evil, no evil is done,🔽there is no evil. But beings are made to perceive thus: “They are doing.” “On the edge of a razor” means on the edge of a razor.

original: khuradhārasadisapariyantena vā. Ekamaṃsakhalanti ekamaṃsarāsiṃ. Puñjanti tasseva🔽vevacanaṃ. Tatonidānanti ekamaṃsakhalakaraṇanidānaṃ.🔽Dakkhiṇanti dakkhiṇatīre manussā kakkhaḷā dāruṇā, te sandhāya hanantotiādi vuttaṃ.🔽Uttaranti uttaratīre saddhā honti pasannā buddhamāmakā dhammamāmakā saṅghamāmakā,
analyzed: khura dhāra sadisa pariyantena vā eka maṃsa khalanti eka maṃsa rāsim puñjanti tassa iva 🔽vevacanam eka maṃsa khala karaṇa nidānam 🔽dakkhiṇanti dakkhiṇa tīre manussā kakkhaḷā dāruṇā te sandhāya hananto tiādi vuttaṃ 🔽uttaranti uttara tīre saddhāḥ honti pasannāḥ buddha māmakāḥ dhamma māmakā saṅgha māmakā
translated: Sandhi means a house-joint. Nillopa means a great theft. Ekagārika means surrounding a single house and robbing it. Paripantha tiṭṭhati means standing on the road in order to rob those who come along. Karoto na karīyati pāpanti even though one acts with the thought “I am doing some evil,” no evil is done; there is no evil. But beings think thus: “We are doing.” Khurapariyantenā ti khuraneminā, with a razor’s edge. Khuradhārasadisapariyantena vā, with an edge like a razor’s edge. Ekamaṃsakhalanti ekamaṃsarāsiṃ, a heap of flesh. Puñjanti is a synonym for that. Tatonidānanti ekamaṃsakhalakaraṇanidānaṃ, because of the reason for making a heap of flesh. Dakkhiṇanti on the southern bank people are harsh and cruel. Referring to them, it is said: “killing, etc.” Uttaranti on the northern bank people are faithful and confident, they are devoted to the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Saṅgha,

original: te sandhāya dadantotiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha yajantoti mahāyāgaṃ karonto. Damenāti indriyadamena
analyzed: te sandhāya dadantaḥ itiādi vuttam tattha yajantaḥ iti mahā yāgam karontaḥ damena ati indriya damena
translated: “He gives, thinking of them” and so on is said. Herein, he gives, thinking of them: he makes a great sacrifice. By giving: by giving the gift of the faculties.

original: uposathakammena. Saṃyamenāti sīlasaṃyamena. Saccavajjenāti saccavacanena. Āgamoti
analyzed: uposatha kammena saṃyamena ati sīla saṃyamena saccavajjena ati saccavacanena āgamaḥ ti
translated: By self-control: by the self-control of virtue. By truth: by the truth-act. By arrival:

original: āgamanaṃ, pavattīti attho. Sabbathāpi pāpapuññānaṃ kiriyameva paṭikkhipanti.
analyzed: āgamanam pavatti iti attho sabbathā api pāpa puññānam kiriyam eva paṭikkhipanti
translated: by arrival, by coming, is the meaning. They all reject the performance of evil and of merit.

original: 7. Hetusuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: hetu sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: Commentary on the Discourse on the Root

original: 212. Natthi hetu natthi paccayoti ettha paccayoti hetuvevacanameva. Ubhayenāpi vijjamānameva
analyzed: natthi hetu natthi paccayo ti ettha paccayo ti hetu vevacanam eva ubhayena api vijjamānam eva
translated: As to “there is no cause, there is no condition”: here “condition” is a synonym for “cause.” By both they reject the existing cause and condition

original: kāyaduccaritādīnaṃ saṃkilesapaccayaṃ, kāyasucaritādīnañca visuddhipaccayaṃ paṭikkhipanti.
analyzed: kāya duccarita ādīnam saṃkilesa paccayam kāya su carita ādīnam ca visuddhi paccayam paṭikkhipanti
translated: for the defilement of bodily misconduct, etc., and for the purification of bodily good conduct, etc.

original: Natthi balanti yamhi attano bale patiṭṭhitā ime sattā devattampi mārattampi brahmattampi
analyzed: natthi balanti yamhi attanaḥ bale patiṭṭhitāḥ ime sattā devattam pi mārattam pi brahmattam pi
translated: There is no power: they reject the power on which beings are established, by which they attain to the state of a god, the state of a Mara, the state of a Brahma,

original: sāvakabodhimpi paccekabodhimpi sabbaññutampi pāpuṇanti, taṃ balaṃ paṭikkhipanti.
analyzed: sāvaka bodhim pi pacceka bodhim pi sabbaññu tam pi pāpuṇanti tam balam paṭikkhipanti
translated: the enlightenment of a disciple, the enlightenment of a paccekabuddha, and omniscience.

original: Natthi vīriyantiādīni sabbāni aññamaññavevacanāneva. “Idaṃ no vīriyena, idaṃ purisathāmena,
analyzed: natthi vīriya nti ādīni sabbāni idam naḥ vīriyena idam purisa thāmena
translated: “There is no energy” and so on are all synonyms for each other. “This is ours by energy, this is ours by manliness,

original: idaṃ purisaparakkamena patta”nti, evaṃ pavattavacanapaṭikkhepakaraṇavasena panetāni visuṃ ādiyanti.
analyzed: idam purisa parakkamena evam pavatta vacana paṭikkhepa karaṇa vasena pana itāni visum ādiyanti
translated: this is ours by manly endeavour,” thus they speak and they take up the practice of opposing what is said.

original: Sabbe sattāti oṭṭhagoṇagadrabhādayo anavasese pariggaṇhanti. Sabbe pāṇāti ekindriyo
analyzed: sabbe sattā ati oṭṭha goṇa gadrabha ādayaḥ anavasese pariggaṇhanti sabbe pāṇā ati eka indriyaḥ
translated: “All beings” they take to mean all without exception, including oxen, goats, donkeys, and so on. “All breathing things” they say

original: pāṇo, dvindriyo pāṇotiādivasena vadanti. Sabbe bhūtāti aṇḍakosavatthikosesu bhūte
analyzed: pāṇaḥ dvindriyaḥ pāṇa iti ādi vasena vadanti sabbe bhūtā ati aṇḍa kosa vatthi kosesu bhūte
translated: referring to a breathing thing with one sense, a breathing thing with two senses, and so on. “All creatures” they say🔽referring to creatures in the egg and in the womb.

original: sandhāya vadanti. Sabbe jīvāti sāliyavagodhumādayo sandhāya vadanti. Tesu hi te viruhanabhāvena
analyzed: sandhāya vadanti sabbe sāli yava godhuma ādayaḥ sandhāya vadanti tesu hi te viruhana bhāvena
translated: “All persons” they say referring to rice, barley, wheat, and so on, for these are regarded as “persons” in the sense of growing.

original: jīvasaññino. Avasā abalā avīriyāti tesaṃ attano vaso vā balaṃ vā vīriyaṃ vā natthi.
analyzed: jīva saññinaḥ a vasāḥ abalāḥ a vīriyā ti tesam attanaḥ vasaḥ vā balam vā vīriyam vā natthi
translated: “They are helpless, without energy” means that they have no power, strength, or energy of their own.

original: Niyatisaṅgatibhāvapariṇatāti ettha niyatīti niyatatā. Saṅgatīti channaṃ abhijātīnaṃ
analyzed: niyati saṅgati bhāva pariṇatā ati ettha niyatī iti niyata tā saṅgatī iti channam abhijātīnam
translated: “They are subject to the rule of kamma” means that they are subject to the condition of kamma.

original: tattha tattha gamanaṃ. Bhāvoti sabhāvoyeva. Evaṃ niyatiyā ca saṅgatiyā ca bhāvena
analyzed: tattha tattha gamanam evam niyatiyā ca saṅgatiyā ca bhāvena
translated: and going here and there. The state is the mere being.

original: ca pariṇatā nānappakārataṃ pattā. Yena hi yathā bhavitabbaṃ, so tatheva bhavati.🔽Yena na bhavitabbaṃ, so na bhavatīti dassenti. Chasvevābhijātīsūti chasu eva abhijātīsu
analyzed: ca pariṇatāḥ nānā pakāra tat pattāḥ yena hi yathā bhavitabbam saḥ tathā iva bhavati  yena na bhavitabbam saḥ na bhavati iti dassenti chasu eva abhijātīsu iti chasu eva abhijātīsu
translated: Going here and there. State: mere being. Thus they show that they have come to various states by means of destiny, meeting, and state. For it is just as it should be that one who should be thus is thus,🔽and that one who should not be thus is not thus.🔽In the six kinds of reappearance: they show that there is no other plane of pleasure and pain than the six kinds of reappearance.

original: ṭhatvā sukhañca dukkhañca paṭisaṃvedenti, aññā sukhadukkhabhūmi natthīti dassenti.
analyzed: ṭhatvā sukham ca dukkham ca paṭisaṃvedenti aññā sukha dukkha bhūmi natthi iti dassenti
translated: For they experience pleasure and pain only in the six kinds of reappearance.

original: 8-10. Mahādiṭṭhisuttādivaṇṇanā🔽213-215. Akaṭāti akatā. Akaṭavidhāti akatavidhānā, “evaṃ karohī”ti kenaci kāritāpi🔽na hontīti attho. Animmitāti iddhiyāpi na nimmitā. Animmātāti animmāpitā. “Animmitabbā”tipi
analyzed: evam karohi iti kenaci kāritā api  na honti iti atthaḥ a nimmitā ati iddhiyā api na nimmitā a nimmātā ati a nimmāpitā a nimmitabbā atipi
translated: The Description of the Great Discourse on the False View, etc.

original: pāṭho, na nimmitabbāti attho. Vañjhāti vañjhapasuvañjhatālādayo viya aphalā kassaci
analyzed: pāṭhaḥ na nimmitabbā ati atthaḥ vañjhā ati vañjha pasu vañjha tāla ādayaḥ viya aphalā kassaci
translated: Unmade: not made. Unplanned: not planned by anyone with the words, “Do it thus.” The meaning is that they are not made. Uncreated: not created even by supernormal power. Uncaused: not caused. The reading is also “animmitā” . The meaning is, not created. Barren: fruitless for anyone, like a barren woman, a barren cow, a barren field, and so on.

original: ajanakā. Pabbatakūṭaṃ viya ṭhitāti kūṭaṭṭhā. Esikaṭṭhāyino viya hutvā ṭhitāti esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā,
analyzed: ajanakā pabbata kūṭam viya ṭhitā ati kūṭa ṭṭhā esika ṭṭhāyinaḥ viya hutvā ṭhitā ati esika ṭṭhāyi ṭhitā
translated: They are not born. They stand firm like the peak of a mountain: they are peak-standers. They stand firm like a pillar: they are pillar-standers.

original: yathā sunikhāto esikatthambho niccalo tiṭṭhati, evaṃ ṭhitāti attho. Na iñjantīti🔽esikatthambho viya ṭhitattā na calanti. Na vipariṇamantīti pakatiṃ na vijahanti.
analyzed: yathā su nikhātaḥ esikatthambhaḥ niccalaḥ tiṭṭhati evam ṭhitā ati atthaḥ na iñjanti iti  viya ṭhita ttāḥ na calanti na vipariṇamanti iti pakatim na vijahanti
translated: The meaning is that they stand without moving like a pillar firmly embedded in a firm place. They do not waver:🔽they do not move because they stand like a pillar. They do not change: they do not abandon their normal state.

original: Na aññamaññaṃ byābādhentīti aññamaññaṃ na upahananti. Nālanti na samatthā. Pathavīkāyotiādīsu🔽pathavīyeva pathavīkāyo, pathavīsamūho vā. Sattannaṃtveva kāyānanti yathā muggarāsiādīsu
analyzed: na aññam aññam byābādhenti iti aññam aññam na upahananti na alanti na samatthā  pathavīyā iva pathavī kāyaḥ pathavī samūhaḥ vā yathā mugga rāsi ādīsu
translated: They do not harass one another: they do not oppress one another. They do not endure: they are not able to.🔽In the passage beginning with “the earth body” ,🔽the earth body is the earth itself or a collection of earth.🔽In the seven bodies: just as when a weapon is struck in a heap of clubs, etc.,

original: pahaṭaṃ satthaṃ muggarāsiādīnaṃ antareneva pavisati, evaṃ sattannaṃ kāyānaṃ antarena🔽chiddena vivarena satthaṃ pavisati. Tattha “ahaṃ imaṃ jīvitā voropemī”ti kevalaṃ
analyzed: pahaṭam sattham mugga rāsi ādīnam antarena iva pavisati evam sattannam kāyānam antarena  chiddena vivarena sattham pavisati tattha aham imam jīvitā voropemi iti kevalam
translated: it penetrates only among the clubs, etc., so too, the weapon penetrates among the seven bodies

original: saññāmattameva hotīti dassenti.
analyzed: saññā mattam eva hoti iti dassenti
translated: through a hole that opens up. Here they show that there is only the mere idea “I am depriving this being of life.”

original: Yonipamukhasatasahassānīti pamukhayonīnaṃ uttamayonīnaṃ cuddasasatasahassāni aññāni
analyzed: yoni pamukha sata sahassāni iti pamukha yonīnam uttama yonīnam cuddasa sata sahassāni aññāni
translated: “A hundred thousand kinds of wombs and doors” : a hundred thousand principal wombs, principal kinds of wombs, fourteen hundred thousand other kinds of wombs,

original: ca saṭṭhisatāni aññāni ca chasatāni pañca ca kammuno satānīti pañcakammasatāni cāti
analyzed: ca saṭṭhi satāni aññāni ca cha satāni pañca ca kammuno satāni iti pañca kamma satāni ca ati
translated: and another six hundred thousand and another six hundred and five hundred kinds of actions, that is, five hundred kinds of actions and five hundred kinds of actions.

original: kevalaṃ takkamattakena niratthakadiṭṭhiṃ dīpenti. Pañca ca kammāni tīṇi ca kammānītiādīsupi🔽eseva nayo. Keci panāhu “pañca kammānīti pañcindriyavasena gaṇhanti, tīṇīti kāyakammādivasenā”ti.
analyzed: kevalam takka mattakena niratthaka diṭṭhim dīpenti pañca ca kammāni tīṇi ca kammāni iti ādīsu pi  keci pana āhu pañca kammāni iti pañca indriya vasena gaṇhanti tīṇi iti kāya kamma ādi vasena ati
translated: They merely point out a useless view by mere counting. The same method applies to the other statements such as “five kinds of actions and three kinds of actions.”🔽But some say: “They take ‘five kinds of actions’ to mean the five faculties and ‘three kinds of actions’ to mean bodily action, etc.”

original: Kamme ca aḍḍhakamme cāti ettha panassa kāyakammavacīkammāni kammanti laddhi, manokammaṃ
analyzed: kamme ca aḍḍhakamme ca ati ettha panassa kāya kamma vacī kammāni kammanti laddhi manaḥ kammaṃ
translated: “Actions and half-actions”: here his theory is that bodily action and verbal action are actions, and mental action is a half-action.

original: upaḍḍhakammanti. Dvaṭṭhipaṭipadāti dvāsaṭṭhipaṭipadāti vadanti. Dvaṭṭhantarakappāti
analyzed: upaḍḍha kammanti dvaṭṭhi paṭipadā ati dvāsaṭṭhi paṭipadā ati vadanti dvaṭṭha antara kappā ti
translated: “The sixty-two ways”: they say that there are sixty-two ways.

original: ekasmiṃ kappe catusaṭṭhi antarakappā nāma honti, ayaṃ pana aññe dve ajānanto evamāha.
analyzed: ekasmin kappe catusaṭṭhi antarakappāḥ nāma honti ayam pana aññe dve a jānantaḥ evam āha
translated: “The sixty-two minor eons”: in one eon there are sixty-four minor eons, but he, not knowing the other two, says this.🔽“The six classes”: the black class, the blue class, the red class, the yellow class, the white class,

original: Chaḷābhijātiyoti kaṇhābhijāti nīlābhijāti lohitābhijāti haliddābhijāti sukkābhijāti
analyzed: kaṇha abhijāti nīla abhijāti lohita abhijāti halidda abhijāti sukka abhijāti
translated: and the variegated class.

original: paramasukkābhijātīti imā cha abhijātiyo vadanti. Tattha orabbhikā sūkarikā sākuṇikā🔽māgavikā luddā macchaghātakā corā coraghātakā bandhanāgārikā, ye vā panaññepi keci🔽kurūrakammantā, ayaṃ kaṇhābhijātīti vadanti. Bhikkhū nīlābhijātīti vadanti. Te kira🔽catūsu paccayesu kaṇṭake pakkhipitvā khādanti, “bhikkhū ca kaṇṭakavuttikā”ti ayaṃ
analyzed: paramasukkā abhijātī iti imāḥ cha abhijātiyaḥ vadanti tattha orabbhikā sūkarikā sākuṇikā  māgavikāḥ luddāḥ maccha ghātakā corā cora ghātakā bandhanāgārikāḥ ye vā pana aññe pi keci  kurūra kammantāḥ ayam kaṇha abhijātī iti vadanti bhikkhū nīla abhijātī iti vadanti te kira  catūsu paccayesu kaṇṭake pakkhipitvā khādanti bhikkhū ca kaṇṭaka vuttikā ati ayaṃ
translated: “The most excellent white-born”: these are the six kinds of birth. Herein, the following are called “black-born”: butchers, swineherds, fowlers,🔽hunters, fishermen, thieves, executioners, prison wardens, and others of that sort who live by a black livelihood. The bhikkhus are called “blue-born.” They are said to

original: hissa pāḷi eva. Atha vā kaṇṭakavuttikā eva nāma eke pabbajitāti vadanti. Lohitābhijāti
analyzed: hissa pāḷi eva atha vā kaṇṭakavuttikā eva nāma eke pabbajitā ati vadanti lohitābhijāti
translated: eat by inserting food into the crevices of their teeth. The text reads: “The bhikkhus live on what they pick up.” Or it may be that some of the bhikkhus are called “blue-born” because they live on what they pick up. The Niganthas are called “red-born.”

original: nāma nigaṇṭhā ekasāṭakāti vadanti. Ime kira purimehi dvīhi paṇḍaratarā. Gihī odātavasanā🔽acelakasāvakā haliddābhijātīti vadanti. Evaṃ attano paccayadāyake nigaṇṭhehipi jeṭṭhakatare
analyzed: nāma nigaṇṭhāḥ ekasāṭakāti vadanti ime kira purimehi dvīhi paṇḍaratarā gihī odātavasanā  acelaka sāvakāḥ halidda abhijātī iti vadanti evam attanaḥ paccaya dāyake nigaṇṭhehi pi jeṭṭhakatare
translated: They wear a single garment. They are said to be whiter than the first two. The white-clad householders are called “yellow-born.”

original: karonti. Ājīvakā ājīviniyo ayaṃ sukkābhijātīti vadanti. Te kira purimehi catūhi paṇḍaratarā.
analyzed: karonti ājīvakāḥ ājīviniyaḥ ayam sukka abhijātī iti vadanti te kira purimehi catūhi paṇḍaratarā
translated: The naked ascetics are called “tawny-born.” Thus they make the Niganthas, who provide them with requisites, the most excellent of the four. The Ajivikas and Ajiviki-nis are called “white-born.” They are said to be whiter than the first four.

original: Nando vaccho, kiso saṃkicco, makkhali gosālo paramasukkābhijātīti vadanti. Te kira
analyzed: nandaḥ vacchaḥ kisaḥ saṃkiccaḥ makkhali gosālo paramasukka abhijātī iti vadanti te kira
translated: Nanda was a calf, Kisa Saṅkicca a cowherd, and Makkhali Gosāla a supreme white-clothed one. They are said to be

original: sabbehi paṇḍaratarā.
analyzed: sabbehi paṇḍaratarā
translated: whiter than all the others.

original: Aṭṭha purisabhūmiyoti mandabhūmi khiḍḍābhūmi vīmaṃsakabhūmi ujugatabhūmi sekhabhūmi🔽samaṇabhūmi jānanabhūmi pannabhūmīti imā aṭṭha purisabhūmiyoti vadanti. Tattha jātadivasato
analyzed: manda bhūmi khiḍḍā bhūmi vīmaṃsaka bhūmi uju gata bhūmi sekha bhūmi  samaṇa bhūmi jānana bhūmi panna bhūmi iti imāḥ aṭṭha purisa bhūmiyaḥ ti vadanti tattha jāta divasato
translated: Eight human stages: the stage of the dull, the stage of play, the stage of investigation, the stage of right progress, the stage of the trainee,

original: paṭṭhāya satta divase sambādhaṭṭhānato nikkhantattā sattā mandā honti momūhā, ayaṃ
analyzed: paṭṭhāya satta divase sambādha ṭṭhānataḥ sattāḥ mandāḥ honti momūhāḥ ayaṃ
translated: the stage of the ascetic, the stage of the knower, the stage of the enlightened one. These are said to be the eight human stages. Herein, for seven days from the day of birth, beings are dull and confused because they have come out from a confined space, this is

original: mandabhūmīti vadanti. Ye pana duggatito āgatā honti, te abhiṇhaṃ rodanti ceva viravanti🔽ca, sugatito āgatā taṃ anussaritvā anussaritvā hasanti, ayaṃ khiḍḍābhūmi nāma. Mātāpitūnaṃ
analyzed: manda bhūmiḥ iti vadanti ye pana duggatitaḥ āgatāḥ honti te abhiṇham rodanti ca iva viravanti  ca sugatitaḥ āgatā tam anussaritvā anussaritvā hasanti ayam khiḍḍābhūmi nāma mātā pitūnam
translated: said to be the stage of the dull. But those who have come from a bad destination cry and wail frequently,

original: hatthaṃ vā pādaṃ vā mañcaṃ vā pīṭhaṃ vā gahetvā bhūmiyaṃ padanikkhipanaṃ vīmaṃsakabhūmi
analyzed: hattham vā pādam vā mañcam vā pīṭham vā gahetvā bhūmiyam pada nikkhipanam vīmaṃsaka bhūmi
translated: and those who have come from a good destination laugh and laugh, remembering and remembering that. This is called the stage of play. Taking hold of mother and father’s hand or foot or bed or chair and placing the foot on the ground, this is the stage of investigation.

original: nāma. Padasā gantuṃ samatthakālo ujugatabhūmi nāma. Sippāni sikkhanakālo sekhabhūmi
analyzed: nāma padasā gantum samattha kālaḥ uju gata bhūmi nāma sippāni sikkhana kālaḥ sekha bhūmi
translated: The time when he is able to go on foot is called the level of uprightness.🔽The time when he trains in the crafts is called the level of training.

original: nāma. Gharā nikkhamma pabbajanakālo samaṇabhūmi nāma. Ācariyaṃ sevitvā jānanakālo
analyzed: nāma gharā nikkhamma pabbajana kālo samaṇa bhūmi nāma ācariyam sevitvā jānana kālo
translated: The time when he goes forth from home into homelessness is called the level of asceticism. The time when he learns by attending on a teacher is called the level of learning.

original: jānanabhūmi nāma. “Bhikkhu ca pannako jino na kiñci āhā”ti evaṃ alābhiṃ samaṇaṃ pannabhūmīti vadanti.
analyzed: jānanabhūmi nāma bhikkhu ca pannakaḥ jinaḥ na kiñci āha ati evam alābhim samaṇam pannabhūmī iti vadanti
translated: “The monk, the perfected one, the victor, does not eat anything” — thus they call the ascetic who does not eat anything the level of non-eating.🔽Ninety-nine hundred: ninety-nine hundred ways of living as an Ājīvaka.

original: Ekūnapaññāsa ājīvakasateti ekūnapaññāsa ājīvavuttisatāni. Paribbājakasateti paribbājakapabbajjāsatāni.🔽Nāgavāsasateti nāgamaṇḍalasatāni. Vīse indriyasateti vīsa indriyasatāni. Tiṃse nirayasateti
analyzed: ekūnapaññāsaḥ ājīvaka satā iti ekūnapaññāsaḥ ājīva vutti satāni paribbājaka satā iti paribbājaka pabbajjā satāni  nāga vāsa satā iti nāga maṇḍala satāni vīse indriya satā iti vīse indriya satāni tiṃse niraya satā iti
translated: Ninety hundred wanderers: ninety hundred kinds of wandering-on-alms-food.🔽Ninety hundred snake-houses: ninety hundred snake-circles.🔽Twenty hundred faculties: twenty hundred faculties.🔽Three hundred hells: three hundred hells.

original: tiṃsa nirayasatāni. Rajodhātuyoti rajaokiraṇaṭṭhānāni. Hatthapiṭṭhipādapiṭṭhādīni
analyzed: tiṃsa niraya satāni hattha piṭṭhi pāda piṭṭha ādīni
translated: The dust-element: he speaks referring to the back of the hand, the back of the foot, etc., which are places for the scattering of dust.

original: sandhāya vadati. Satta saññīgabbhāti oṭṭhagoṇagadrabhaajapasumigamahiṃse sandhāya
analyzed: sandhāya vadati satta sandhāya
translated: Seven-sensed wombs: he speaks referring to the ox, the buffalo, the ass, the sheep, the deer, the elephant, and the bull.

original: vadati. Satta asaññīgabbhāti sāliyavagodhumamuggakaṅguvarakakudrūsake sandhāya vadati.🔽Nigaṇṭhigabbhāti gaṇṭhimhi jātagabbhā, ucchuveḷunaḷādayo sandhāya vadati. Satta devāti
analyzed: vadati satta sāli yava godhuma mugga kaṅgu varaka kudrūsake sandhāya vadati  nigaṇṭhi gabbhā ati gaṇṭhimhi jāta gabbhāḥ ucchu veḷu naḷa ādayaḥ sandhāya vadati satta deva iti
translated: “Seven kinds of Nigrantha wombs”: he says this referring to the wombs of knots, such as sugar cane, bamboo, and reeds. “Seven kinds of gods”:

original: bahū devā, so pana sattāti vadati. Manussāpi anantā, so sattāti vadati. Satta pesācāti
analyzed: bahū devā so pana sattā ati vadati manussā api anantā so sattā ati vadati satta pesācā ati
translated: there are many gods, but he says “seven.” “Seven kinds of humans”: humans are infinite, but he says “seven.” “Seven kinds of demons”:🔽he says this referring to the great demons. “Seven great lakes”: he says this referring to the lakes Kaṇṇamuṇḍa, Rathakāra, Anotatta, Sīhappapāta, Chaddanta, Mucalinda, and Kuṇāladaha.

original: pisācā mahantamahantā, sattāti vadati. Sarāti mahāsarā. Kaṇṇamuṇḍa-rathakāra-anotatta-sīhappapāta-chaddanta-mucalinda-kuṇāladahe gahetvā vadati.🔽Pavuṭāti gaṇṭhikā. Papātāti mahāpapātā. Papātasatānīti khuddakapapātasatāni. Supināti
analyzed: pisācā mahanta mahantā sattā ati vadati sarā ati mahāsarā kaṇṇa muṇḍa rathakāra anotatta sīhappapāta chaddanta mucalinda kuṇāla dahe gahetvā vadati  pavuṭā ati gaṇṭhikā papātā ati mahā papātā papāta satāni iti khuddaka papāta satāni supinā ati
translated: “Seven kinds of whirlpools”: he says this referring to whirlpools. “Seven great abysses”: he says this referring to great abysses. “Seven hundred abysses”: he says this referring to seven hundred small abysses. “Seven great dreams”:

original: mahāsupinā. Supinasatānīti khuddakasupinasatāni. Mahākappinoti mahākappānaṃ. Ettha🔽ekamhā mahāsarā vassasate vassasate kusaggena ekaṃ udakabinduṃ nīharitvā sattakkhattuṃ
analyzed: mahā supinā supina satāni iti khuddaka supina satāni mahā kappinaḥ ti mahā kappānam ettha 🔽ekamhā mahā sarā vassa sate vassa sate kusaggena ekam udaka bindum nīharitvā satta kkhattum
translated: he says this referring to great dreams. “Seven hundred dreams”: he says this referring to seven hundred small dreams. “Seven great eons”: here🔽he says this referring to the great eons. “Seven hundred eons”: he says this referring to seven hundred small eons. “Seven thousand eons”: he says this referring to seven thousand small eons. “Seven hundred thousand eons”: he says this referring to seven hundred thousand small eons. “Seven million eons”: he says this referring to seven million small eons. “Seven hundred million eons”: he says this referring to seven hundred million small eons. “Seven billion eons”: he says this referring to seven billion small eons. “Seven hundred billion eons”: he says this referring to seven hundred billion small eons. “Seven hundred septillion eons”: he says this referring to seven hundred septillion small eons. “Seven octillion eons”: he says this referring to seven octillion small eons. “Seven hundred octillion eons”: he says this referring to seven hundred octillion small eons. “Seven nonillion eons”: he says this referring to seven nonillion small eons. “Seven hundred nonillion eons”: he says this referring to seven hundred nonillion small eons. “Seven hundred decillion eons”: he says this referring to seven hundred dec

original: tamhi sare nirudake kate eko mahākappoti vadati. Evarūpānaṃ mahākappānaṃ caturāsītisatasahassāni🔽khepetvā bāle ca paṇḍite ca dukkhassantaṃ karontīti ayamassa laddhi. Paṇḍitopi kira
analyzed: tamhi sare nirudake kate ekaḥ mahā kappaḥ iti vadati evarūpānam mahā kappānam catur asīti sata sahassāni  khepetvā bāle ca paṇḍite ca dukkhassantam karonti iti ayam assa laddhi paṇḍitaḥ api kira
translated: When that aeon was finished, he said that there was a great aeon. Having thus passed 84,000 great aeons,🔽he brought an end to the suffering of fools and the wise. This is his doctrine. The wise one, it seems,🔽

original: antarāvisujjhituṃ na sakkoti, bālopi tato uddhaṃ na gacchati.🔽Sīlena vāti acelakasīlena vā aññena vā yena kenaci. Vatenāti tādiseneva vatena. Tapenāti🔽tapokammena. Aparipakkaṃ paripāceti nāma yo “ahaṃ paṇḍito”ti antarā visujjhati. Paripakkaṃ
analyzed: na sakkoti bālaḥ api tatas uddham na gacchati  sīlena vā ati acelaka sīlena vā aññena vā yena kenacid vatena ati tādisena iva vatena tapena ati  tapo kammena a paripakkam paripāca iti nāma yaḥ aham paṇḍitaḥ iti antarā visujjhati paripakkam
translated: When that aeon is exhausted, he says that a great aeon is exhausted. Having exhausted 8,400,000 great aeons in this way, he makes an end of suffering for both the fool and the wise. The fool, it seems, is unable to attain purification in the interval, and the wise man does not go beyond the time stated.

original: phussa phussa byantīkaroti nāma yo “ahaṃ bālo”ti vuttaparimāṇakālaṃ atikkamitvā yāti.🔽Hevaṃ natthīti evaṃ natthi. Tañhi ubhayampi na sakkā kātunti dīpeti. Doṇamiteti doṇena
analyzed: phussa phussa byantīkaroti nāma yaḥ aham bālaḥ ti vutta parimāṇa kālam atikkamitvā yāti  ha ivam natthi iti evam natthi tat hi ubhayam pi na sakkā kātunti dīpe ti doṇa mitā iti doṇena
translated: By virtue: by the virtue of the naked ascetics or by any other kind of virtue. By austerity: by the austerity of the naked ascetics or by any other kind of austerity. He ripens what is unripened: he who, thinking “I am wise,” attains purification in the interval. He makes an end of suffering by the mere ending of the aggregates: he who, thinking “I am a fool,” goes beyond the stated time.

original: mitaṃ viya. Sukhadukkheti sukhadukkhaṃ. Pariyantakateti vuttaparimāṇena kālena katapariyanto.
analyzed: mitam viya sukha dukkha iti sukha dukkham pariyanta kata iti vutta parimāṇena kālena kata pariyantaḥ
translated: There is no such possibility: he shows that both are impossible. Measured by the doṇa: as if measured by the doṇa. Pleasure and pain: pleasure and pain. With the ending of life: with the ending of the stated time.

original: Natthi hāyanavaḍḍhaneti natthi hāyanavaḍḍhanāni, na saṃsāro paṇḍitassa hāyati, na
analyzed: na atthi hāyana vaḍḍhane iti na atthi hāyana vaḍḍhanāni na saṃsāraḥ paṇḍitassa hāyati na
translated: “There is no diminution or increase”: there is no diminution or increase. The wise one’s samsara does not diminish,

original: bālassa vaḍḍhatīti attho. Ukkaṃsāvakaṃseti ukkaṃsāvakaṃsā. Hāyanavaḍḍhanānamevetaṃ🔽vevacanaṃ. Idāni tamatthaṃ upamāya sādhento seyyathāpi nāmātiādimāha. Tattha suttaguḷeti
analyzed: bālassa vaḍḍhati iti attho ukkaṃsa avakaṃsā iti ukkaṃsa avakaṃsā hāyana vaḍḍhanānam eva etam  vevacanam idāni tam attham upamāya sādhentaḥ seyyathā api nāma ati ādim āha tattha sutta guḷa iti
translated: the fool’s does not increase. This is the meaning. “The scales and the balance”: the scales and the balance. This is a synonym for diminution and increase.

original: veṭhetvā katasuttaguḷe. Nibbeṭhiyamānameva paletīti pabbate vā rukkhagge vā ṭhatvā
analyzed: veṭhetvā kata sutta guḷe nibbeṭhiyamānam eva paleti iti pabbate vā rukkha gge vā ṭhatvā
translated: Now, in order to establish this meaning by means of a simile, he said, “Just as, bhikkhus, a ball of string,” etc. Herein, “a ball of string” is a ball of string made by twisting together threads. “As it is unwinding, it goes only to its end”: thrown on a mountain or on a tree-top,

original: khittaṃ suttappamāṇena nibbeṭhiyamānameva gacchati, sutte khīṇe tattheva tiṭṭhati,
analyzed: khittam sutta ppamāṇena nibbeṭhiyamānam eva gacchati sutte khīṇe tattha eva tiṭṭhati
translated: it goes only to its end by unwinding with a thread’s measure; when the thread is finished, it stays there,

original: na gacchati evameva bālā ca paṇḍitā ca kālavasena nibbeṭhiyamānā sukhadukkhaṃ palenti,
analyzed: na gacchati evam eva bālā ca paṇḍitā ca kāla vasena nibbeṭhiyamānā sukha dukkham
translated: it does not go. So too, the fool and the wise one, as they are unwinding with the passage of time, go only to the end of pleasure and pain,

original: yathāvuttena kālena atikkamantīti dasseti.🔽11-18. Antavāsuttādivaṇṇanā🔽216-223. Antavā lokoti ekato vaḍḍhitanimittaṃ lokoti gāhena vā takkena vā uppannadiṭṭhi.
analyzed: yathā vuttena kālena atikkamanti iti dasseti 🔽        🔽antavā lokoti ekatas vaḍḍhita nimittam lokoti gāhena vā takkena vā uppanna diṭṭhi
translated: he shows that they go by the measure of time stated.

original: Anantavāti sabbato vaḍḍhitaṃ appamāṇanimittaṃ lokoti gāhena vā takkena vā uppannadiṭṭhi.
analyzed: anantavā ti sabbatas vaḍḍhitam appamāṇa nimittam lokoti gāhena vā takkena vā uppanna diṭṭhi
translated: “Infinite” is the view that arises through a wide or narrow range that the immeasurable visible form is the world.

original: Taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīranti jīvañca sarīrañca ekamevāti uppannadiṭṭhi. Sesaṃ sabbattha
analyzed: tam jīvam tam sarīram ti jīvam ca sarīram ca ekam eva ati uppanna diṭṭhi sesam sabbattha
translated: “That living being is this living body” is the view that arises that the living being and the living body are one and the same. The rest is clear in all instances.

original: uttānamevāti. Imāni tāva sotāpattimaggavasena aṭṭhārasa veyyākaraṇāni ekaṃ gamanaṃ.🔽2. Dutiyagamanādivaggavaṇṇanā
analyzed: uttānam eva ati imāni tāva sa utāpatti magga vasena aṭṭhārasa veyyākaraṇāni ekam gamanam  dutiya gamana ādi vagga vaṇṇanā
translated: These are the eighteen answers to the questioner’s question, which make up one “going” in the case of the stream-enterer’s path.

original: 224-301. Dutiyaṃ gamanaṃ dukkhavasena vuttaṃ. Tatrāpi aṭṭhāraseva veyyākaraṇāni, tato parāni “rūpī attā hotī”tiādīni aṭṭha veyyākaraṇāni, tehi saddhiṃ taṃ dutiyapeyyāloti vutto.
analyzed: dutiyam gamanam dukkha vasena vuttam tatra api aṭṭhārasā iva veyyākaraṇāni tatas parāni rūpī attā hoti itiādīni aṭṭha veyyākaraṇāni tehi saddhim tam dutiyapeyyālo ti vutto
translated: The second “going” and so on are stated in terms of the second jhāna. Here too there are eighteen answers to the questioner’s question. The next eight answers beginning with “The self is material after death” are called the second sub-chapter.

original: Tattha rūpīti ārammaṇameva “attā”ti gahitadiṭṭhi. Arūpīti jhānaṃ “attā”ti gahitadiṭṭhi.
analyzed: tattha rūpī iti ārammaṇam eva attā ati gahita diṭṭhi arūpī iti jhānam attā ati gahita diṭṭhi
translated: Herein, “material” is the view that arises grasping the object as the self. “Immaterial” is the view that arises grasping the jhāna as the self.

original: Rūpī ca arūpī cāti ārammaṇañca jhānañca “attā”ti gahitadiṭṭhi. Neva rūpī nārūpīti
analyzed: rūpī ca arūpī ca ati ārammaṇañca jhānañca attā ati gahita diṭṭhi na iva rūpī na arūpī iti
translated: “Both material and immaterial” is the view that arises grasping both the object and the jhāna as the self. “Neither material nor immaterial” is the view that arises grasping the object and the jhāna as the self.

original: takkamattena gahitadiṭṭhi. Ekantasukhīti lābhītakkījātissarānaṃ uppannadiṭṭhi. Jhānalābhinopi🔽hi atīte ekantasukhaṃ attabhāvaṃ manasikaroto evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati. Takkinopi “yathā🔽etarahi ahaṃ ekantasukhī, evaṃ samparāyepi bhavissāmī”ti uppajjati. Jātissarassapi🔽sattaṭṭhabhave sukhitabhāvaṃ passantassa evaṃ uppajjati, ekantadukkhītiādīsupi eseva nayo.🔽Tatiyapeyyālo aniccadukkhavasena tehiyeva chabbīsatiyā suttehi vutto, catutthapeyyālo tiparivaṭṭavasenāti.
analyzed: takka mattena gahita diṭṭhi ekanta sukhī iti uppanna diṭṭhi jhāna lābhinaḥ pi  hi atīte ekanta sukham atta bhāvam manasikarotaḥ evam diṭṭhi uppajjati takkinaḥ api yathā  etarahi aham ekanta sukhī evam samparāye pi bhavissāmi iti uppajjati jātissarassa api  satta ṭṭha bhave sukhita bhāvam passantassa evam uppajjati ekanta dukkhī iti ādīsu pi esa eva nayo  tatiya peyyālaḥ anicca dukkha vasena tehi yeva chabbīsatiyā suttehi vutto catuttha peyyālaḥ ti parivaṭṭa vasena ati
translated: and the view that arises in the case of the one who has taken it by mere report is the view that “He is happy.”🔽For the view arises in the case of one who has attained jhāna when he brings to mind his own former state of being in which he was happy.🔽And in the case of the one who has taken it by report it arises thus, “Just as I am now happy, so I shall be in the future too.”🔽And in the case of the one who has taken it by hearsay it arises thus, “He is happy in the seven stations of consciousness and in the eight abode of beings.”🔽The third chapter is stated with the twenty-six suttas by way of impermanence and suffering. The fourth chapter is by way of the three turnings.

original: Diṭṭhisaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽4. Okkantasaṃyuttaṃ🔽1-10. Cakkhusuttādivaṇṇanā🔽302-311. Okkantasaṃyutte adhimuccatīti saddhādhimokkhaṃ paṭilabhati. Okkanto sammattaniyāmanti
analyzed: diṭṭhi saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā 🔽okkanta saṃyuttam 🔽        🔽okkanta saṃyutte adhimuccati iti saddhā adhimokkham paṭilabhati okkantaḥ sammatta niyāmanti

original: paviṭṭho ariyamaggaṃ. Abhabbo ca tāva kālaṃ kātunti iminā uppanne magge phalassa
analyzed: paviṭṭhaḥ ariya maggam abhabbo ca tāva kālam kātun ti iminā uppanne magge phalassa
translated: and has entered the noble path. And he is incapable of dying🔽before he has realized the fruit. This shows that there is no obstacle to the fruit🔽when the path has arisen. For when the path has arisen, there is no obstacle

original: anantarāyataṃ dīpeti. Uppannasmiñhi magge phalassa antarāyakaraṇaṃ nāma natthi. Tenevāha
analyzed: anantarāyatam dīpeti uppannasmin hi magge phalassa antarāya karaṇam nāma natthi tena iva āha
translated: to the fruit. Hence it is said:

original: – “ayañca puggalo sotāpattiphalasacchikiriyāya paṭipanno assa, kappassa ca uḍḍayhanavelā
analyzed: ayam ca puggalo sotāpatti phala sacchikiriyāya paṭipannaḥ assa kappassa ca uḍḍayhana velā
translated: “If this person were to die while practising for the realization of the fruit of stream-entry,🔽even before the aeon came to its end,

original: assa, neva tāva kappo uḍḍayheyya, yāvāyaṃ puggalo na sotāpattiphalaṃ sacchikaroti,🔽ayaṃ vuccati puggalo ṭhitakappī”ti. Mattaso nijjhānaṃ khamantīti pamāṇato olokanaṃ
analyzed: assa nā iva tāva kappaḥ uḍḍayheyya yāvā ayam puggalaḥ na sotāpatti phalam sacchikaroti  ayam vuccati puggalo ṭhita kappī iti mattasaḥ nijjhānam khamanti iti pamāṇataḥ olokanam
translated: the aeon would not come to its end before he had realized the fruit of stream-entry.🔽This is called a person who will live out the aeon. ”

original: khamanti. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: khamanti sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: “They can endure the scrutiny of the measuring rod”: they can endure the scrutiny of the measuring rod of the Suttas, etc. The rest is clear throughout.

original: Okkantasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: okkanta saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of the section on “entering” is ended.

original: 5. Uppādasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the section on “arising”

original: 312-321. Uppādasaṃyutte sabbaṃ pākaṭameva.
analyzed: uppāda saṃyutte sabbam pākaṭam eva
translated: In the section on “arising” all is clear.

original: Uppādasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: uppāda saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of the section on “arising” is ended.

original: 6. Kilesasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the section on “defilement”

original: 322-331. Kilesasaṃyutte cittasseso upakkilesoti kataracittassa? Catubhūmakacittassa.
analyzed: kilesa saṃyutte cittassa iso upakkileso ti katara cittassa catu bhūmaka cittassa
translated: In the section on “defilement” the text asks, “Whose defilement is this?” and then answers, “It is the defilement of the mind.” Of what kind of mind? Of the mind of the four planes.

original: Tebhūmakacittassa tāva hotu, lokuttarassa kathaṃ upakkileso hotīti? Uppattinivāraṇato.
analyzed: tebhūmaka cittassa tāva hotu lokuttarassa katham upakkilesaḥ hoti iti uppatti nivāraṇato
translated: First of all, let it be that of the three-plane consciousness. But how is it a defilement of the supramundane? —By preventing its arising.

original: So hi tassa uppajjituṃ appadānena upakkilesoti veditabbo. Nekkhammaninnanti navalokuttaradhammaninnaṃ.🔽Cittanti samathavipassanācittaṃ. Abhiññā sacchikaraṇīyesu dhammesūti paccavekkhaṇañāṇena
analyzed: saḥ hi tassa uppajjitum appadānena upakkilesaḥ ti veditabbo nekkhamma ninnam ti nava lokuttara dhamma ninnam  cittam ti samatha vipassanā cittam abhiññā sacchikaraṇīyesu dhammesu iti paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇena
translated: For that should be understood as a defilement since it does not give it occasion to arise. “Intent on renunciation”: intent on the nine supramundane states.🔽“Mind”: the consciousness of serenity and insight.🔽“Ideas to be directly known”: the six ideas to be directly known, namely, the six kinds of direct knowledge.

original: abhijānitvā sacchikātabbesu chaḷabhiññādhammesu, ekaṃ dhammaṃ vā gaṇhantena nekkhammanti
analyzed: abhijānitvā sacchikātabbesu chaḷabhiññā dhammesu ekam dhammam vā gaṇhantena nekkhammanti
translated: “One idea”: the renunciation to be directly known by the one who apprehends the renunciation.

original: gahetabbaṃ. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: gahetabbam sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: The rest is all clear.

original: Kilesasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: kilesa saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the chapter on defilements is ended.

original: 7. Sāriputtasaṃyuttaṃ
analyzed: sāriputtasaṃyuttam
translated: The Connected Discourses with Sāriputta

original: 1-9. Vivekajasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: viveka ja sutta ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the First Fifty Suttas of the Viveka-Vagga

original: 332-340. Sāriputtasaṃyuttassa paṭhame na evaṃ hotīti ahaṅkāramamaṅkārānaṃ pahīnattā evaṃ na hoti. Dutiyādīsupi eseva nayo. Paṭhamādīni.
analyzed: sāriputta saṃyuttassa paṭhame na evam hoti iti ahaṅkāra mamaṅkārānam pahīna ttā evam na hoti dutiya ādīsu pi esa iva nayo paṭhama ādīni
translated: In the first sutta of the Sāriputta Samyutta in the first section, “he does not think thus” because he has abandoned the conceit “I am” and the conceit “I am this.” The same method of explanation applies in the second and the rest.

original: 10. Sucimukhīsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sucimukhī sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Sucimukhi Sutta

original: 341. Dasame sucimukhīti evaṃnāmikā. Upasaṅkamīti theraṃ abhirūpaṃ dassanīyaṃ suvaṇṇavaṇṇaṃ
analyzed: dasame sucimukhī iti evaṃnāmikā upasaṅkamīti theram abhirūpam dassanīyam suvaṇṇa vaṇṇam
translated: In the tenth, the one called Sucimukhī. She approached the Elder: she saw the Elder who was handsome, good-looking, golden-skinned,

original: samantapāsādikaṃ disvā “iminā saddhiṃ parihāsaṃ karissāmī”ti upasaṅkami. Atha therena
analyzed: samantapāsādikam disvā iminā saddhim parihāsam karissāmi iti upasaṅkami atha therena
translated: and inspiring on all sides, and she thought “I will have some fun with him,” and so she approached him. Then,

original: tasmiṃ vacane paṭikkhitte “idānissa vādaṃ āropessāmī”ti maññamānā tena hi, samaṇa,
analyzed: tasmin vacane paṭikkhitte idānissa vādam āropessāmi iti maññamānā tena hi samaṇa
translated: when the Elder refused her request, thinking “Now I will refute his doctrine,” she said, “Well then, ascetic,

original: ubbhamukho bhuñjasīti āha. Disāmukhoti catuddisāmukho, catasso disā olokentoti attho.
analyzed: ubbhamukhaḥ bhuñjasi iti āha disāmukho ti catuddisāmukho catassaḥ disāḥ olokento ti attho
translated: you eat facing upwards.” Facing the four quarters means facing the four directions; the meaning is, looking at the four directions.

original: Vidisāmukhoti catasso vidisā olokento.
analyzed: vidisāmukhaḥ ti catassaḥ vidisāḥ olokento
translated: Facing the intermediate points means looking at the four intermediate points.

original: Vatthuvijjātiracchānavijjāyāti vatthuvijjāsaṅkhātāya tiracchānavijjāya. Vatthuvijjā
analyzed: vatthuvijjā tiracchānavijjāya ati vatthuvijjā saṅkhātāya tiracchānavijjāya vatthuvijjā
translated: The art of reading physical marks and the art of divination means the art of reading physical marks and the art of divination called “the art of reading physical marks.”

original: nāma lābuvatthu-kumbhaṇḍavatthu-mūlakavatthu-ādīnaṃ vatthūnaṃ phalasampattikāraṇakālajānanupāyo.
analyzed: nāma lābu vatthu kumbhaṇḍa vatthu mūlaka vatthu ādīnam vatthūnam phala sampatti kāraṇa kāla jānan upāyaḥ
translated: The art of reading physical marks is a method of knowing the time when the fruit of such things as a gourd, a pumpkin, a radish, etc., will be ripe.

original: Micchājīvena jīvikaṃ kappentīti teneva vatthuvijjātiracchānavijjāsaṅkhātena micchājīvena
analyzed: micchājīvena jīvikam kappenti iti tena iva vatthu vid jāti racchāna vijjā saṅkhātena micchājīvena
translated: They make a living by wrong livelihood: by that very wrong livelihood called “the art of reading physical marks” and “the art of divination,”

original: jīvikaṃ kappenti, tesaṃ vatthūnaṃ sampādanena pasannehi manussehi dinne paccaye paribhuñjantā
analyzed: jīvikam kappenti tesam vatthūnam sampādanena pasannehi manussehi dinne paccaye paribhuñjantā
translated: They live by means of the requisites given by the faithful who are satisfied with the success of their undertakings.

original: jīvantīti attho. Adhomukhāti vatthuṃ oloketvā bhuñjamānavasena adhomukhā bhuñjanti🔽nāma. Evaṃ sabbattha yojanā kātabbā. Api cettha nakkhattavijjāti “ajja imaṃ nakkhattaṃ
analyzed: jīvanti iti atthaḥ adhomukhā ati vatthum oloketvā bhuñjamāna vasena adhomukhāḥ bhuñjanti  nāma evam sabbattha yojanā kātabbā api ca ittha nakkhatta vijjā ti ajja imam nakkhattam
translated: The meaning is that they live by using the requisites obtained from the faithful who are satisfied with the success of their undertakings. Looking down at the ground: they eat looking down at the ground as they eat.

original: iminā nakkhattena gantabbaṃ, iminā idañcidañca kātabba”nti evaṃ jānanavijjā. Dūteyyanti🔽dūtakammaṃ, tesaṃ tesaṃ sāsanaṃ gahetvā tattha tattha gamanaṃ. Pahiṇagamananti ekagāmasmiṃyeva🔽ekakulassa sāsanena aññakulaṃ upasaṅkamanaṃ. Aṅgavijjāti itthilakkhaṇapurisalakkhaṇavasena
analyzed: iminā nakkhattena gantabbam iminā idam ca idam ca kātabbanti evam jānana vijjā dūteyyanti  dūta kammam tesam tesam sāsanam gahetvā tattha tattha gamanam pahiṇa gamanam ti eka gāmasmiṃ yeva  eka kulassa sāsanena añña kulam upasaṅkamanam aṅga vijjā ti itthi lakkhaṇa purisa lakkhaṇa vasena
translated: The same method of explanation applies in each instance. Herein, the science of astrology is the knowledge of the stars, such as the knowledge of which star is to rise, of which star it is today, of which direction it has reached, of what it will do, of what it is doing, of what it has done.🔽The science of augury is the knowledge of omens, such as the knowledge of what is to be expected by the occurrence of an earth tremor, a rainbow, a meteor, a thunder- bolt, an earthquake, and so on. The science of politics is the knowledge of the thirty-two arts of politics, such as the knowledge of how to behave in regard to the fourfold army, how to behave in regard to the six expedients of kings, and so on.

original: aṅgasampattiṃ ñatvā “tāya aṅgasampattiyā idaṃ nāma labbhatī”ti evaṃ jānanavijjā.
analyzed: aṅga sampattim ñatvā tāya aṅga sampattiyāḥ idam nāma labbhati iti evam jānana vijjā
translated: The science of animal cries is the knowledge of what is to be expected by the cries of peacocks, parrots, mynahs, and so on. The science of the marks of animals is the knowledge of what is to be expected by the marks on the bodies of cows, horses, etc., such as the knowledge of which cow with which mark on her body will be milked thus.

original: Vidisāmukhāti aṅgavijjā hi taṃ taṃ sarīrakoṭṭhāsaṃ ārabbha pavattattā vidisāya pavattā
analyzed: vidisāmukhā ati aṅga vijjā hi tam tam sarīra koṭṭhāsam ārabbha pavatta ttā vidisāya pavattā
translated: The four directions: the science of physiognomy is called “the four directions” because it occurs in regard to this or that part of the body.🔽Therefore, those who make a living by that science and eat are called “those who eat facing the four directions.”

original: nāma, tasmā tāya vijjāya jīvikaṃ kappetvā bhuñjantā vidisāmukhā bhuñjanti nāma. Evamārocesīti
analyzed: nāma tasmai tāya vijjāya jīvikam kappetvā bhuñjantāḥ vidisā mukhāḥ bhuñjanti nāma evam ārocesi iti
translated: Thus he announced:

original: “dhammikaṃ samaṇā”tiādīni vadamānā sāsanassa niyyānikaṃ guṇaṃ kathesi. Tañca paribbājikāya
analyzed: dhammikam samaṇa ati ādīni vadamānā sāsanassa niyyānikam guṇam kathesi tat ca paribbājikāya
translated: while saying “Monks are righteous,” she spoke of the quality of the Dispensation’s being a way out . And having heard

original: kathaṃ sutvā pañcamattāni kulasatāni sāsane otariṃsūti.
analyzed: katham sutvā pañcamattāni kula satāni sāsane otariṃsu iti
translated: her talk, five hundred families entered the Dispensation.

original: Sāriputtasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sāriputtasaṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Connected Discourses with Sāriputta is finished.

original: 8. Nāgasaṃyuttaṃ
analyzed: nāga saṃyuttam
translated: The Connected Discourses with Nāgas

original: 1. Suddhikasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: suddhika sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the Suddhāvāsa Sutta

original: 342. Nāgasaṃyutte aṇḍajāti aṇḍe jātā. Jalābujāti vatthikose jātā. Saṃsedajāti saṃsede
analyzed: nāga saṃyutte aṇḍa jāti aṇḍe jātā jalābu jāti vatthi kose jātā saṃseda jāti saṃsede
translated: In the Connected Discourses with Nāgas, “born from an egg” means born from an egg. “Born from the womb” means born from a membrane. “Born from moisture” means born from

original: jātā. Opapātikāti upapatitvā viya jātā. Idañca pana suttaṃ aṭṭhuppattiyā vuttaṃ.
analyzed: jātā opapātikā ti upapatitvā viya jātā idam ca pana suttam aṭṭhuppattiyā vuttam
translated: moisture. “Appearing by transformation” means born as if by reappearance. And this sutta was spoken with reference to the origin of the eight.

original: Bhikkhūnañhi “kati nu kho nāgayoniyo”ti kathā udapādi. Atha bhagavā puggalānaṃ nāgayonīhi
analyzed: bhikkhūnam hi kati nu kho nāga yoniyaḥ ti kathā udapādi atha bhagavā puggalānam nāga yonīhi
translated: For a discussion arose among the monks: “How many kinds of nāga wombs are there?” Then the Blessed One said:

original: uddharaṇatthaṃ nāgayoniyo āvikaronto imaṃ suttamāha.
analyzed: uddharaṇa attham nāga yoniyaḥ āvikarontaḥ imam suttam āha
translated: He spoke this Thread in order to reveal the wombs of the Nāga order for the purpose of their deliverance.

original: 2-50. Paṇītatarasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: paṇītatara sutta ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Paṇītatarasutta, etc.

original: 343-391. Dutiyādīsu vossaṭṭhakāyāti ahituṇḍikaparibuddhaṃ agaṇetvā vissaṭṭhakāyā.
analyzed: dutiya ādīsu vossaṭṭhakāyā ti ahituṇḍika paribuddham a gaṇetvā vissaṭṭhakāyā
translated: In the second and the rest of the verses, “with bodies well developed” : except the one who was awakened by the snake-charmer, the rest had well-developed bodies.

original: Dvayakārinoti duvidhakārino, kusalākusalakārinoti attho. Sacajja mayanti sace ajja
analyzed: dvaya kārino ti duvidha kārino kusala akusala kārino ti attho sacajja mayanti sace ajja
translated: “With a twofold action” : with a twofold performance, the meaning is, with a good and a bad performance. “If today” : if today.

original: mayaṃ. Sahabyataṃ upapajjatīti sahabhāvaṃ āpajjati. Tatrassa akusalaṃ upapattiyā
analyzed: mayam sahabyatam upapajjati iti sahabhāvam āpajjati tatra assa akusalam upapattiyā
translated: “He would be reborn in their company” : he would be reborn in their company. There the unwholesome would be the condition for rebirth,

original: paccayo hoti, kusalaṃ upapannānaṃ sampattiyā. Annanti khādanīyabhojanīyaṃ. Pānanti
analyzed: paccayaḥ hoti kusalam upapannānam sampattiyāḥ annam ti khādanīya bhojanīyam pānam ti
translated: and the wholesome would be the condition for the excellence of the rebirth. “Food” : edible and drinkable. “Drink” :

original: yaṃkiñci pānakaṃ. Vatthanti nivāsanapārupanaṃ. Yānanti chattupāhanaṃ ādiṃ katvā yaṃkiñci
analyzed: yaṃ kiñci pānakam vatthanti nivāsana pārupanam yānanti chattupāhanam ādim katvā yaṃ kiñci
translated: any kind of beverage. “Clothes” : under and upper garments. “Conveyances” : any kind of conveyance such as an umbrella, a pair of shoes, etc.

original: gamanapaccayaṃ. Mālanti yaṃkiñci sumanamālādipupphaṃ. Gandhanti yaṃkiñci candanādigandhaṃ.
analyzed: gamana paccayam mālanti yaṃ kiñci sumana mālā ādi puppham gandhanti yaṃ kiñci candana ādi gandham
translated: “Flowers” : any kind of flower such as the jasmine, the garland-flower, etc. “Perfume” : any kind of perfume such as sandalwood, etc.

original: Vilepananti yaṃkiñci chavirāgakaraṇaṃ. Seyyāvasathapadīpeyyanti mañcapīṭhādiseyyaṃ
analyzed: vilepanam ti yaṃkiñci chavi rāga karaṇam mañca pīṭha ādi seyyam
translated: “Ointment” : any kind of ointment that removes the skin’s impurities. “Beds, seats, and dwellings” : beds and chairs, etc.

original: ekabhūmikādiāvasathaṃ vaṭṭitelādipadīpūpakaraṇañca detīti attho. Tesañhi dīghāyukatāya
analyzed: eka bhūmikā ādi āvasatham vaṭṭita ilā ādi padīpū pakaraṇam ca deti iti tesam hi dīgha āyuka tāya
translated: The meaning is that he gives them a dwelling-place in one plane, etc., and he gives them the means of lighting it, etc. For they make the wish, thinking, “May we be long-lived,”

original: ca vaṇṇavantatāya ca sukhabahulatāya ca patthanaṃ katvā imaṃ dasavidhaṃ dānavatthuṃ
analyzed: ca vaṇṇavanta tāya ca sukha bahula tāya ca patthanam katvā imam dasavidham dāna vatthum
translated: and “May we be beautiful,” and “May we have much happiness,” and after giving this tenfold gift

original: datvā taṃ sampattiṃ anubhavituṃ tattha nibbattanti. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: da tvā tam sampattim anubhavitum tattha nibbattanti sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: they are reborn there to enjoy that good fortune. The rest is self-explanatory in all instances.

original: Nāgasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: nāga saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the Nāga Saṃyutta is ended.

original: 9. Supaṇṇasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā
translated: Description of the Supaṇṇa Saṃyutta

original: 392-437. Supaṇṇasaṃyutte pattānaṃ vaṇṇavantatāya garuḷā supaṇṇāti vuttā. Idhāpi paṭhamasuttaṃ🔽purimanayeneva aṭṭhuppattiyaṃ vuttaṃ. Harantīti uddharanti. Uddharamānā ca pana te
analyzed: supaṇṇa saṃyutte pattānam vaṇṇavanta tāya garuḷā supaṇṇā iti vuttā idha api paṭhama suttam  purima nayena iva aṭṭhuppattiyam vuttam haranti iti uddharanti uddharamānā ca pana te
translated: In the Supaṇṇa Saṃyutta the birds are called supaṇṇas because of the beauty of their feathers. Here too the first sutta🔽is given in the way already described in the Nidāna. They carry them off: they take them out. And while they are taking them out,

original: attanā hīne vā same vā uddharituṃ sakkonti, na attanā paṇītatare. Sattavidhā hi anuddharaṇīyanāgā
analyzed: attanā hīne vā same vā uddharitum sakkonti na attanā paṇītatare sattavidhāḥ hi an uddharaṇīya nāgā
translated: they can take out those that are inferior or equal to themselves, but not those that are superior to themselves. For there are seven kinds of nāgas called “not to be carried off”

original: nāma paṇītatarā kambalassatarā dhataraṭṭhā sattasīdantaravāsino pathaviṭṭhakā pabbataṭṭhakā
analyzed: nāma paṇītatarā kambalassatarā dhataraṭṭhā sattasīdantaravāsino patha viṭṭhakā pabbata ṭṭhakā
translated: that are superior to them: the kambalas, the assataras, the dhataraṭṭhas, the satta, the sīdanti, the avāsins, and the paṭhaviṭṭhas and the pabbataṭṭhas.

original: vimānaṭṭhakāti. Tatra aṇḍajādīnaṃ jalābujādayo paṇītatarā, te tehi anuddharaṇīyā.🔽Kambalassatarā pana nāgasenāpatino, te yattha katthaci disvā yo koci supaṇṇo uddharituṃ
analyzed: tatra aṇḍa ja ādīnam jalābu ja ādayaḥ paṇītatarā te tehi an uddharaṇīyā  kambalassatarā pana nāga senāpatino te yattha katthacid disvā yaḥ koci su paṇṇaḥ uddharituṃ
translated: “In the case of the egg-born, etc., the water-born are more refined, and they cannot be lifted by the former.🔽But the Nāgasenāpatis are more refined than the blanket-born, and no Supaṇṇa whatever can lift them wherever they are seen.

original: na sakkoti. Dhataraṭṭhā pana nāgarājāno, tepi koci uddharituṃ na sakkoti. Ye pana
analyzed: na sakkoti dhataraṭṭhāḥ pana nāga rājāno te pi koci uddharitum na sakkoti ye pana
translated: But the Dhataraṭṭha Nāgarājas cannot be lifted by anyone.

original: sattasīdantare mahāsamudde vasanti, te yasmā katthaci vikampanaṃ kātuṃ na sakkā,
analyzed: mahā samudde vasanti te yasmai katthaci vikampanam kātum na sakkā
translated: But those that live in the great ocean between the seven Sītā mountains cannot be lifted by anyone, since they cannot be shaken anywhere,

original: tasmā koci uddharituṃ na sakkoti. Pathaviṭṭhakādīnaṃ nilīyanokāso atthi, tasmā tepi🔽uddharituṃ na sakkoti. Ye pana mahāsamudde ūmipiṭṭhe vasanti, te yo koci samo vā
analyzed: tasmā koci uddharitum na sakkoti patha viṭṭhaka ādīnam nilīyana ukāso atthi tasmā te pi  uddharitum na sakkoti ye pana mahā samudde ūmi piṭṭhe vasanti te yaḥ koci samaḥ vā
translated: and those that live on the earth, etc., cannot be lifted by anyone, since they have a place to lie down in.

original: paṇītataro vā supaṇṇo uddharituṃ sakkoti. Sesaṃ nāgasaṃyutte vuttanayamevāti.
analyzed: paṇītataraḥ vā su paṇṇaḥ uddharitum sakkoti sesam nāgasaṃyutte vutta nayam eva ati
translated: But those that live on the ocean’s surface can be lifted by any Supaṇṇa equal to them or more refined than they. The rest is in the way already stated in the Nāga chapter.

original: Supaṇṇasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: supaṇṇa saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of the Supaṇṇa chapter is ended.

original: 10. Gandhabbakāyasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Exposition of the Gandhabbakāya Chapter

original: 438-549. Gandhabbakāyasaṃyutte mūlagandhe adhivatthāti yassa rukkhassa mūle gandho🔽atthi, taṃ nissāya nibbattā. So hi sakalopi rukkho tesaṃ upakappati. Sesapadesupi🔽eseva nayo. Gandhagandheti mūlādigandhānaṃ gandhe. Yassa hi rukkhassa sabbesampi🔽mūlādīnaṃ gandho atthi, so idha gandho nāma. Tassa gandhassa gandhe, tasmiṃ adhivatthā.🔽Idha mūlādīni sabbāni tesaṃyeva upakappanti. So dātā hoti mūlagandhānanti so kāḷānusārikādīnaṃ
analyzed: gandhabba kāya saṃyutte mūla gandhe yassa rukkhassa mūle gandho  atthi tam nissāya nibbattā so hi sakalaḥ api rukkhaḥ tesam upakappati sesa padesu pi  esa iva nayaḥ gandha gandha iti mūla ādi gandhānam gandhe yassa hi rukkhassa sabbesam pi  mūla ādīnam gandhaḥ atthi saḥ idha gandho nāma tassa gandhassa gandhe tasmin adhivatthā  idha mūla ādīni sabbāni tesam yeva upakappanti saḥ dātā hoti so kāḷānusārika ādīnam
translated: In the case of the root-odour, etc., in the “Brahma-world-deities” chapter, “in what is based on” is the root of a tree in whose odour🔽they arise, since the whole tree is useful to them. The same method applies in the other cases. “The odour of odour”: the odour of the odour of the root, etc. For the tree in which there is the odour of all the roots, etc., is called here “odour.” The odour of that odour is “in what is based on.”

original: mūlagandhānaṃ dātā hoti. Evaṃ sabbapadesu attho veditabbo. Evañhi sarikkhadānampi🔽datvā patthanaṃ ṭhapenti, asarikkhadānampi. Taṃ dassetuṃ so annaṃ detītiādi dasavidhaṃ
analyzed: mūla gandhānam dātā hoti evam sabba padesu atthaḥ veditabbaḥ evam hi sa rikkha dānam pi  da tvā patthanam ṭhapenti tam dassetum saḥ annam deti itiādi dasavidham
translated: Here all the roots, etc., are useful to them. “He is a giver of root-odours”: he is a giver of the root-odours of the black-wood tree, etc. The meaning should be understood in all the passages in this way. For it is after giving such like gifts

original: dānavatthu vuttaṃ. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: dāna vatthu vuttam sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: that they make their aspiration. And they make their aspiration after giving unlike gifts too. In order to show that, the tenfold gift of requisites is mentioned beginning with “He gives food” . The rest is self-explanatory in all passages.

original: Gandhabbakāyasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: gandhabbakāyasaṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the “Brahma-world-deities” chapter is finished.

original: 11. Valāhakasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: valāhakasaṃyutta vaṇṇanā
translated: 11. The Connected Discourses on the Cloud

original: 550-606. Valāhakasaṃyutte valāhakakāyikāti valāhakanāmake devakāye uppannā ākāsacārikadevā.🔽Sītavalāhakāti sītakaraṇavalāhakā. Sesapadesupi eseva nayo. Cetopaṇidhimanvāyāti
analyzed: valāhaka saṃyutte valāhakakāyikā ati valāhaka nāmake devakāye uppannā ākāsacārikadevā  sīta valāhakā ati sīta karaṇa valāhakā sesa padesu pi eṣā iva cetaḥ upaṇidhim anvāyāti
translated: In the Connected Discourses on the Cloud, “cloud-dwelling deities” are deities born in the deity-world called “cloud.”

original: cittaṭṭhapanaṃ āgamma. Sītaṃ hotīti yaṃ vassāne vā hemante vā sītaṃ hoti, taṃ utusamuṭṭhānameva.🔽Yaṃ pana sītepi atisītaṃ, gimhe ca uppannaṃ sītaṃ, taṃ devatānubhāvena nibbattaṃ🔽sītaṃ nāma. Uṇhaṃ hotīti yaṃ gimhāne uṇhaṃ, taṃ utusamuṭṭhānikaṃ pākatikameva. Yaṃ
analyzed: citta ṭṭhapanam āgamma sītam hoti iti yam vassāne vā hemante vā sītam hoti tam utu samuṭṭhānam eva  yam pana sīte pi ati sītam gimhe ca uppannam sītam tam devatā anubhāvena nibbattam  sītam nāma uṇham hoti iti yam gimhāne uṇham tam utu samuṭṭhānikam pākatikam eva yam
translated: “Cool clouds” are clouds that cool. The same method applies in the other cases. “In accordance with the wish of their minds” means “in accordance with the stabilization of their minds.” “It becomes cool” : what is cool in the rainy season or in winter is only naturally cool.🔽But what is very cool even in the cool season, and what is cool in the hot season, is called “cool” because it is produced by the influence of deities.

original: pana uṇhepi atiuṇhaṃ, sītakāle ca uppannaṃ uṇhaṃ, taṃ devatānubhāvena nibbattaṃ uṇhaṃ
analyzed: pana uṇhe api ati uṇham sīta kāle ca uppannam uṇham tam devatā anubhāvena nibbattam uṇham
translated: “It becomes hot” : what is hot in the hot season is only naturally hot. But what is very hot even in the hot season, and what is hot in the cool season, is called “hot” because it is produced by the influence of deities.

original: nāma. Abbhaṃ hotīti abbhamaṇḍapo hoti. Idhāpi yaṃ vassāne ca sisire ca abbhaṃ uppajjati,
analyzed: nāma abbham hoti iti abbha maṇḍapaḥ hoti idha api yam vassāne ca sisire ca abbham uppajjati
translated: “It rains” : a rain-cloud appears. Here, too, what rains in the rainy season and in winter is only naturally cool.

original: taṃ utusamuṭṭhānikaṃ pākatikameva. Yaṃ pana abbheyeva atiabbhaṃ, sattasattāhampi
analyzed: tam utu samuṭṭhānikam pākatikam eva yam pana ati abbham satta satta aham pi
translated: That is natural. But that which is excessive is excessive. It obscures the sun and moon and makes all dark for seven days and seven nights.

original: candasūriye chādetvā ekandhakāraṃ karoti, yañca cittavesākhamāsesu abbhaṃ, taṃ devatānubhāvena🔽uppannaṃ abbhaṃ nāma. Vāto hotīti yo tasmiṃ tasmiṃ utumhi uttaradakkhiṇādipakativāto
analyzed: canda sūriye chādetvā eka andhakāram karoti yat ca citta vesākha māsesu abbham tam devatā anubhāvena  uppannam abbham nāma vātaḥ hoti iti yaḥ tasmin tasmin utumhi uttara dakkhiṇa ādi pakati vāto
translated: And that which occurs in the months Citta, Vesākha, and Āsāḷhi is called “produced by the influence of deities.”

original: hoti, ayaṃ utusamuṭṭhānova. Yopi pana rukkhakkhandhādipadālano ativāto nāma atthi,
analyzed: hoti ayam utu samuṭṭhānaḥ eva yaḥ api pana rukkha kkhandha ādi padālanaḥ ativātaḥ nāma atthi
translated: “There is a wind”: the wind that blows in such and such a season from the north, south, and so on is natural. But there is also a wind called “wind of destruction,” which destroys the trunk of a tree and so on.

original: ayañceva, yo ca aññopi akālavāto, ayaṃ devatānubhāvanibbatto nāma. Devo vassatīti
analyzed: ayam ca iva yaḥ ca aññaḥ api akāla vāto ayam devatā anubhāva nibbatto nāma devaḥ vassati iti
translated: And that which is untimely is called “produced by the influence of deities.”

original: yaṃ vassike cattāro māse vassaṃ, taṃ utusamuṭṭhānameva. Yaṃ pana vasseyeva ativassaṃ,
analyzed: yam vassike cattāraḥ māse vassam tam utu samuṭṭhānam eva yam pana vasseya iva ativassam
translated: “There is rain”: the rain that falls in the four months of the rainy season is natural. But that which falls in the non-rainy season is excessive.

original: yañca cittavesākhamāsesu vassaṃ, taṃ devatānubhāvanibbattaṃ nāma.
analyzed: yat ca citta vesākha māsesu vassam tam devatānubhāvanibbattam nāma
translated: And that which occurs in the months Citta, Vesākha, and Āsāḷhi is called “produced by the influence of deities.”

original: Tatridaṃ vatthu – eko kira vassavalāhakadevaputto talakūṭakavāsi khīṇāsavattherassa
analyzed: tatra idam vatthu ekaḥ kira vassavalāhaka deva putto talakūṭaka vāsi khīṇāsava therassa
translated: Here is a story. A certain deity who caused rain, it is said, was a resident of Talakūṭa. He was a stream-enterer.

original: santikaṃ gantvā vanditvā aṭṭhāsi. Thero “kosi tva”nti pucchi. “Ahaṃ, bhante, vassavalāhakadevaputto”ti.
analyzed: santikam gantvā vanditvā aṭṭhāsi thero ko asi tvanti pucchi aham bhante vassa valāhaka deva putto ti
translated: He went to the Elder, saluted him, and stood in attendance. The Elder asked him, “Who are you? ” “Venerable sir, I am the god Vassavalāhaka.”

original: “Tumhākaṃ kira cittena devo vassatī”ti? “Āma, bhante”ti. “Passitukāmā maya”nti. “Temissatha,
analyzed: tumhākam kira cittena devaḥ vassati iti āma bhante iti passitu kāmāḥ mayanti temissatha
translated: “Is it true that rain falls when you think of it?” “Yes, venerable sir.” “We should like to see it.” “Very well, venerable sir,

original: bhante”ti. “Meghasīsaṃ vā gajjitaṃ vā na paññāyati, kathaṃ temissāmā”ti? “Bhante,🔽amhākaṃcittena devo vassati, tumhe paṇṇasālaṃ pavisathā”ti. “Sādhu devaputtā”ti so
analyzed: bhante iti megha sīsam vā gajjitam vā na paññāyati katham temissāma ati bhante  amhākaṃcid tena devaḥ vassati tumhe paṇṇa sālam pavisatha ati sādhu deva putta ati saḥ
translated: I will do so.” “We do not see a cloud or hear a rumble of thunder; how will you do it?” “Venerable sir,🔽rain falls when we think of it; you enter the leaf hut.” “Very well, god.” He washed his feet and entered the leaf hut.

original: pāde dhovitvā paṇṇasālaṃ pāvisi. Devaputto tasmiṃ pavisanteyeva ekaṃ gītaṃ gāyitvā
analyzed: pāde dhovitvā paṇṇa sālam pāvisi devaputto tasmin ekam gītam gāyitvā
translated: The moment he entered, the god raised his hand and sang a song,

original: hatthaṃ ukkhipi. Samantā tiyojanaṭṭhānaṃ ekameghaṃ ahosi. Thero addhatinto paṇṇasālaṃ
analyzed: hattham ukkhipi samantā ti yojana ṭṭhānam eka megham ahosi theraḥ addhatintaḥ paṇṇasālam
translated: and a cloud covered the whole area for three leagues. The Elder entered the leaf hut.

original: paviṭṭhoti. Apica devo nāmesa aṭṭhahi kāraṇehi vassati nāgānubhāvena supaṇṇānubhāvena
analyzed: paviṭṭhaḥ ti apica devaḥ nāma esa aṭṭhahi kāraṇehi vassati nāga anubhāvena supaṇṇa anubhāvena
translated: Moreover, rain falls for eight reasons: by the power of nāgas, by the power of supaṇṇas,

original: devatānubhāvena saccakiriyāya utusamuṭṭhānena mārāvaṭṭanena iddhibalena vināsameghenāti.
analyzed: devatā anubhāvena sacca kiriyāya utu samuṭṭhānena māra avaṭṭanena iddhi balena vināsa meghena ati
translated: by the power of a deity, by a declaration of truth, by the arising of a season, by Mara’s prompting, by the power of supernormal power, by a shower of rain.

original: Valāhakasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: valāhakasaṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the Linked Pericope on the Cloud is ended.

original: 12. Vacchagottasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā🔽607-661. Vacchagottasaṃyutte aññāṇāti aññāṇena. Evaṃ sabbapadesu karaṇavaseneva attho🔽veditabbo. Sabbāni cetāni aññamaññavevacanānevāti. Imasmiñca pana saṃyutte ekādasa
analyzed: vacchagottasaṃyutte aññāṇā ti aññāṇena evam sabba padesu karaṇa vasena iva attho  veditabbaḥ sabbāni ca itāni imasmin ca pana saṃyutte ekādasa
translated: The Linked Pericope on Vacchagotta

original: suttāni pañcapaññāsa veyyākaraṇānīti veditabbāni.
analyzed: suttāni pañcapaññāsa veyyākaraṇāni iti veditabbāni
translated: In the Linked Pericope on Vacchagotta, “ignorance” is ignorance. The meaning should be understood in this way in all the passages. And all these are synonyms. And in this Linked Pericope there are eleven suttas with fifty-five explanations.

original: Vacchagottasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: vacchagotta saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the Linked Pericope on Vacchagotta is ended.

original: 13. Jhānasaṃyuttaṃ
analyzed: jhāna saṃyuttam
translated: The Linked Pericope on Jhana

original: 1. Samādhimūlakasamāpattisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: samādhi mūlaka samāpatti sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Sutta on Concentration Rooted in Absorption

original: 662. Jhānasaṃyuttassa paṭhame samādhikusaloti paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ pañcaṅgikaṃ dutiyaṃ
analyzed: jhāna saṃyuttassa paṭhame samādhi kusalo ti paṭhamam jhānam pañcaṅgikam dutiyam
translated: In the first sutta in the Linked Pericope on Jhana, “skilled in concentration” is skilled in defining the jhana factors thus: the first jhana has five factors, the second jhana has three factors,

original: tivaṅgikanti evaṃ aṅgavavatthānakusalo. Na samādhismiṃ samāpattikusaloti cittaṃ hāsetvā
analyzed: tivaṅgikam ti evam aṅga vavatthāna kusalaḥ na samādhismim samāpatti kusalaḥ iti cittam hāsetvā
translated: and so on. “Unskilled in attaining concentration” is unskilled in making the mind enter into concentration by means of the jhana factors.

original: kallaṃ katvā jhānaṃ samāpajjituṃ na sakkoti. Iminā nayena sesapadānipi veditabbāni.
analyzed: kallam katvā jhānam samāpajjitum na sakkoti iminā nayena sesa padāni api veditabbāni
translated: he is not skilled in entering upon jhāna by making the sign compact. The rest should be understood in this way.

original: 2-55. Samādhimūlakaṭhitisuttādivaṇṇanā🔽663-716. Dutiyādīsu na samādhismiṃ ṭhitikusaloti jhānaṃ ṭhapetuṃ akusalo, sattaṭṭhaaccharāmattaṃ🔽jhānaṃ ṭhapetuṃ na sakkoti. Na samādhismiṃ vuṭṭhānakusaloti jhānato vuṭṭhātuṃ akusalo,🔽yathāparicchedena vuṭṭhātuṃ na sakkoti. Na samādhismiṃ kallitakusaloti cittaṃ hāsetvā🔽kallaṃ kātuṃ akusalo. Na samādhismiṃ ārammaṇakusaloti kasiṇārammaṇesu akusalo. Na
analyzed: dutiya ādīsu na samādhismim ṭhiti kusalaḥ ti jhānam ṭhapetum akusalaḥ  jhānam ṭhapetum na sakkoti na samādhismim vuṭṭhāna kusalo ti jhānataḥ vuṭṭhātum akusalaḥ  yathā paricchedena vuṭṭhātum na sakkoti na samādhismim kallita kusalo ti cittam hāsetvā  kallam kātum akusalaḥ na samādhismim ārammaṇa kusalo ti kasiṇa ārammaṇesu akusalaḥ na
translated: The explanation of the Suttas beginning with the One on Steadying the Mind

original: samādhismiṃ gocarakusaloti kammaṭṭhānagocare ceva bhikkhācāragocare ca akusalo. Na🔽samādhismiṃ abhinīhārakusaloti kammaṭṭhānaṃ abhinīharituṃ akusalo. Na samādhismiṃ
analyzed: samādhismim gocara kusalo ti kammaṭṭhāna gocare ca iva bhikkhācāra gocare ca akusalaḥ na 🔽samādhismim abhinīhāra kusalaḥ ti kammaṭṭhānam abhinīharitum akusalaḥ na samādhismim
translated: In the second and the rest, he is not skilled in steadying the mind in jhāna: he is not skilled in steadying the mind in jhāna by making it stay on the sign. He is not skilled in emerging from jhāna: he is not skilled in emerging from jhāna by adverting to the shortcomings of the jhāna. He is not skilled in making the mind rise out of jhāna: he is not skilled in making the mind rise out of jhāna by giving attention to the object of change-of-lineage. He is not skilled in resolving upon the duration of jhāna: he is not skilled in resolving upon the duration of jhāna by giving attention to the object of absorption. He is not skilled in shortening or prolonging the duration of jhāna: he is not skilled in shortening or prolonging the duration of jhāna by giving attention to the object of absorption. He is not skilled in the field of jhāna: he is not skilled in the field of jhāna by giving attention to the object of absorption. He is not skilled in the sign of jhāna: he is not skilled in the sign of jhāna by giving attention to the object of absorption.

original: sakkaccakārīti jhānaṃ appetuṃ sakkaccakārī na hoti. Na samādhismiṃ sātaccakārīti
analyzed: sakkaccakārī iti jhānam appetum sakkaccakārī na hoti na samādhismim sātaccakārī iti
translated: He is not one who makes an effort to bring about absorption: he is not one who makes an effort to bring about jhana. He is not one who perseveres in maintaining absorption:🔽he is not one who perseveres in maintaining jhana. He is not one who arouses zeal for absorption:

original: jhānappanāya satatakārī na hoti, kadācideva karoti. Na samādhismiṃ sappāyakārīti🔽samādhissa sappāye upakārakadhamme pūretuṃ na sakkoti. Tato paraṃ samāpattiādīhi
analyzed: jhāna ppanāya satata kārī na hoti kadācid eva karoti na samādhismim sappāya kārī iti  samādhissa sappāye upakāraka dhamme pūretum na sakkoti tato param samāpatti ādīhi
translated: he is not one who arouses zeal for the maintenance of jhana. He is not one who exercises carefulness in absorption:

original: padehi yojetvā catukkā vuttā. Tesaṃ attho vuttanayeneva veditabbo. Sakalaṃ panettha
analyzed: padehi yojetvā catukkā vuttā tesam atthaḥ vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ sakalam pana ittha
translated: he is not one who exercises carefulness in the fulfilment of the helpful things for jhana. The remaining four terms beginning with “readiness for absorption” should be construed in the same way as the preceding terms. The rest is as already stated.

original: jhānasaṃyuttaṃ lokiyajjhānavaseneva kathitanti.
analyzed: jhāna saṃyuttam lokiya jhāna vasena iva kathitan ti
translated: But all this is said in terms of mundane jhana.

original: Jhānasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽Iti sāratthappakāsiniyā saṃyuttanikāya-aṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: jhāna saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  iti sārattha ppakāsiniyā saṃyutta nikāya aṭṭhakathāya
translated: The exposition of the Jhāna Samyutta is completed.

original: Khandhavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: khandha vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Khandha Vagga is finished.

original: Saṃyuttanikāya-aṭṭhakathāya dutiyo bhāgo.
analyzed: saṃyutta nikāya aṭṭhakathāya dutiyaḥ bhāgaḥ
translated: The second part of the Nidāna Samyutta is finished.
